ORDINANCE NO. 19-1749
AN ORDINANCE AMENDING
APPENDIX A, THE ZONING ORDINANCE
OF THE CODE OF ORDINANCES OF THE
VILLAGE OF NORTHFIELD, ILLINOIS
A duly noticed public hearing was held by the Plan and Zoning Commission of the Village of Northfield on September 3, 2019 on the application for
a text amendment to Article IV, Section 4-5 of the Village of Northfield Zoning Ordinance.
The Plan and Zoning Commission of the Village of Northfield has now filed its report of findings and recommendation to the President and Board of
Trustees with respect to the application. The report and recommendation has been considered by this President and Board of Trustees.
NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT ORDAINED by the President and Board of Trustees of the Village of Northfield, Cook County, Illinois, as follows:
SECTION 1: Small wireless facilities in a right of way shall be a permitted use within all zoning districts in the Village of Northfield.
SECTION 2: Small wireless facilities outside of a right of way shall be a permitted use in the O/R and M-1 zoning districts in the Village of
Northfield.
SECTION 3: Small wireless facilities outside of a right of way shall be a special use in the R-1, R-2, R-3, R-4, R-5, R-6, NC, B-1, B-2 and VC
zoning districts in the Village of Northfield.
SECTION 4: Section 4-5 “Permitted and Special Use Table” and Sections 5-2 “R-1 Use Regulations”, Section 6-2 “R-2 Use Regulations”, Section
7-2 “R-3 Use Regulations”, Section 8-2 “R-4 Use Regulations”, Section 9-2 “R-5 Use Regulations”, Section 10-2 “R-6 Use Regulations”, Section 12-2 “B-1
Use Regulations”, Section 12.1-2 “B-2 Use Regulations”, Section13-2 “VC Use Regulations”, Section 11-2 “NC Use Regulations”, Section 14-2 “O/R Use
Regulations”, and Section 15-2 “M-1 Use Regulations” of Appendix A shall be amended in accordance with Sections 1, 2 and 3 above.
SECTION 5: That all ordinances or parts of ordinances in conflict herewith are hereby repealed.
SECTION 6: This Ordinance shall be in full force and effect from and upon its passage, approval and publication in the manner provided by law.

ORDINANCE NO. 19-1750
AN ORDINANCE AMENDING
APPENDIX A, THE ZONING ORDINANCE
OF THE CODE OF ORDINANCES OF THE
VILLAGE OF NORTHFIELD, ILLINOIS
A duly noticed public hearing was held by the Plan and Zoning Commission of the Village of Northfield on September 3, 2019 on the application for
a text amendment to Article IV, Sections 4-5, 11-2, 12-2, 12.1-2, 13-2, 14-2 and 15-2 of the Village of Northfield Zoning Ordinance.
The Plan and Zoning Commission of the Village of Northfield has now filed its report of finding and recommendations to the President and Board of
Trustees with respect to the application. The report and recommendation has been considered by this President and Board of Trustees.
NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT ORDAINED by the President and Board of Trustees of the Village of Northfield, Cook County, Illinois, as follows:
SECTION 1: A medical/dental office with 5,000 square feet or more of floor area shall be a special use in the NC, B-1, B-2, O/R or M-1 zoning
districts.
SECTION 2: A medical/dental office with less than 5,000 square feet of floor area shall be a permitted use in the NC, B-1, B-2, or O/R and M-1
zoning districts.
SECTION 3: A medical/dental office of less than 5,000 square feet in the VC zoning district located above the first floor shall be a permitted use.
Any other medical/dental office on the first floor shall be a special use.
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=886 3/377

Section 12.1-2 “B-2 Use Regulations”, Section 13-2 “VC Use Regulations”, Section 14-2 “O/R Use Regulations”, and Section 15-2 “M-1 Use Regulations”
of Appendix A shall be amended in accordance with Sections 1, 2 and 3 above.
SECTION 5: That all ordinances or parts of ordinances in conflict herewith are hereby repealed.
SECTION 6: This Ordinance shall be in full force and effect from and upon its passage, approval and publication in the manner provided by law.

A duly noticed public hearing was held by the Plan and Zoning Commission of the Village of Northfield on September 3, 2019 on the application for a text
amendment to Article XIX, Section 19-3 of the Village of Northfield Zoning Ordinance.
The Plan and Zoning Commission of the Village of Northfield has now filed its report of findings and recommendation to the President and Board of Trustees with
respect to the application. The report and recommendation has been considered by the President and Board of Trustees.
NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT ORDAINED by the President and Board of Trustees of the Village of Northfield, Cook County, Illinois, acting in the exercise of their
home rule powers, as follows:

Northfield, Illinois, shall be amended as follows:
A. Section 19-3(B)(3)(a) shall be amended by deleting the last sentence of the paragraph.
B. Section 19-3(B)(3) shall be amended by deleting the last paragraph.
C. A new Section 19-3(B)(4) shall be added and shall be and read as follows:
(4) Relief from the restrictions set forth in this Subsection (B) of Section 19-3 may be granted only by the Village Board. Such relief
may be granted only for specific special events and for a specific time frame. Any person seeking such relief shall file a petition with the Village Clerk not
less than 45 days prior to the event for which the relief is sought. The person seeking relief shall provide notice of the application by mail to the owner or
occupant of all properties located within two hundred fifty feet (250’), excluding rights of way, of the subject property. This notice shall be given not less
than fifteen (15) days nor more than thirty (30) days prior to the meeting at which the Village Board will consider the application. An affidavit certifying that
the above notices have been sent must be tendered to the Department of Community Development not less than fifteen (15) days prior to the meeting.
The fee for such a petition shall be as set forth in Section 19-3 of Appendix D. The Village Board may apply such conditions as it may deem appropriate
to any relief granted pursuant to this paragraph.
C. Article I, “Fees” of Appendix D “Fees and Bonds” shall be amended by adding the following new fee in numerical order as follows:
Sec. 19-3 Application for relief, special
event permit
$50.00
SECTION 2: That all ordinances or parts of ordinances in conflict herewith are hereby repealed.
SECTION 3: This Ordinance shall be in full force and effect from and upon its passage and approval in the manner provided by law.

PREFACE
This Village Code of the Village of Northfield, as supplemented, contains ordinances up to and including ordinance 19-1740, passed March 19, 2019.
Ordinances of the Village adopted after said ordinance supersede the provisions of this Village Code to the extent that they are in conflict or inconsistent
therewith. Consult the Village office in order to ascertain whether any particular provision of the Code has been amended, superseded or repealed.
Sterling Codifiers
Coeur d'Alene, Idaho
Title Chapter 1
GENERAL PROVISIONS
Chapter 1
GENERAL PROVISIONS
ARTICLE I. INFORMATIONAL MATTERS
Sec. 1-1: HOME RULE AUTHORITY; HOW CODE DESIGNATED AND CITED.
The ordinances embraced in this and the following chapters and sections shall constitute and be designated the NORTHFIELD VILLAGE CODE 1986.
This code and each of its individual provisions and requirements are hereby ratified, adopted, and readopted pursuant to the home rule authority of the
village of Northfield. If any previously adopted provisions or requirements would have been declared an inappropriate exercise of nonrule home power,
each such individual provision or requirement is now readopted in the exercise of the village's home rule powers. (Ord. 10-1470, 12-6-2010)
Sec. 1-2: PURPOSE.
In the interpretation and application of any provisions of this code, they shall be held to be the minimum requirements adopted for promotion of the public
health, safety, comfort, convenience and general welfare. Where any provision of this code imposes greater restriction upon the subject matter than the
general provision imposed by this code, the provision imposing the greater restriction or regulation shall be deemed to be controlling. (1986 Code)
Sec. 1-3: DEFINITIONS AND RULES OF CONSTRUCTION.
In the interpretation and construction of this code, the following definitions and rules of construction shall be observed, unless they are inconsistent with
the manifest intent of the board of trustees or the context clearly required otherwise:
COMPUTATION OF TIME. The time within which any act provided by law is to be done shall be computed by excluding the first day and including the last,
unless the last day is Sunday or a legal holiday, and then it shall also be excluded. If the day succeeding such Sunday or holiday is also a holiday or a
Sunday, then such succeeding day shall also be excluded.
CORPORATE AUTHORITIES. The president and board of trustees of the village of Northfield, Illinois.
COUNTY. The words "county" or "the county" mean Cook County in the state of Illinois.
COURT. The circuit court of Cook County, Illinois, including all its divisions, districts and branches.
GOOD CHARACTER AND REPUTATION. That the applicant lack good character and reputation in the community in which he resides, may be
determined by previous arrest record, association with persons known to lack good moral character, open and notorious adultery or other acts of moral
turpitude or other conduct contrary to good morals.
IN THE VILLAGE. The words "in the village" or "within the village" mean and include all territory over which the village now has or shall hereafter acquire
jurisdiction for the exercise of its police powers or other regulatory powers.
JOINT AUTHORITY. Words purporting to give a joint authority to three (3) or more public officers or other persons shall be construed as giving such
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=886 6/377
authority to a majority of such officers or persons.
LIMITS. The corporate limits of the village of Northfield.
MASCULINE GENDER. Any word signifying the masculine gender shall also be deemed to include the feminine and neuter genders.
MONTH. A calendar month.
NAME OF ANY OFFICER. Where any title of any officer appears in this code, the title shall be interpreted as though the words "of the village of Northfield"
were added to such name.
NUMBER. Words importing the singular number may extend and be applied to several persons or things and words importing the plural number may
include the singular.
OATH. Shall be deemed to include an affirmation, and the word "sworn" shall be construed to include the word "affirmed".
OCCUPANT OR TENANT. Applied to a building or land, mean any person who holds a written or oral lease of or actually occupies the whole or a part of
such building or land, either alone or with others.
OFFICER. An officer of the village of Northfield. Only elected officials, the village manager, department heads or other persons specified in this code or in
the Illinois municipal code as officers shall be considered officers of the village of Northfield.
OWNER. The word "owner", applied to a building or land, shall include any part owner, joint owner, tenant in common, tenant in partnership or joint tenant
of the whole or a part of such building or land, either alone or with others.
PERSON. Any individual, partnership, corporation, joint stock association, club, society, association or any city, village or state, or any subdivision thereof;
and includes any trustee, receiver, assignee, or personal representative thereof.
PERSONAL PROPERTY. Personal property includes every species of property except "real property" as defined by this section.
PRECEDING, FOLLOWING. The words "preceding" and "following" mean immediately before and next after, respectively.
PRESIDENT. The president of the village of Northfield.
PROPERTY. Shall include real and personal property.
REAL PROPERTY. Shall include lands, tenements and hereditaments and shall embrace all chattels real.
RULES AND REGULATIONS. Shall include all properly published standards set forth by an officer of the village of Northfield pursuant to a valid delegation
of authority from the corporate authorities.
SEAL. The seal of the village of Northfield.
SHALL. Wherever the word "shall" appears in this code, it shall be considered mandatory and not directive.
SIDEWALK. That portion of a street between the curb lines or the lateral lines of a roadway and the adjacent property lines, intended for the use of
pedestrians.
STATE. The words "state" or "the state" mean the state of Illinois.
STREET. The entire width between property lines of every way or place of whatever nature when any part thereof is open to the use of the public, as a
matter of right for purposes of vehicular traffic.
TENSE. Words in the present tense include the future.
VILLAGE. The words "village" or "the village" mean the village of Northfield in Cook County, state of Illinois, except as otherwise provided. When the word
"village" is capitalized, as here, it means the municipal corporation. When it is uncapitalized, it means the territory enclosed with the village limits.
WRITTEN, IN WRITING. The words "written" and "in writing" may include printing and any other mode of representing words and letters, but when the
written signature of any person is required by law to any official or public writing or bond required by law, it shall be in the proper handwriting of such
person, or in case he is unable to write, by his proper mark.
YEAR. A calendar year unless otherwise expressed.
ZONING ORDINANCE. The zoning ordinance of the village of Northfield, including all amendments, alterations, additions and revisions thereto, which
ordinance is on file in the office of the village clerk. The zoning ordinance is contained in appendix A of this code. (1986 Code)
Sec. 1-4: CATCHLINES OF SECTIONS.
The boldfaced catchlines of the several sections of this code are intended as mere catchwords to indicate the contents of the section and shall not be
deemed to taken to be the titles of such sections, nor as any part of the section, nor unless expressly so provided shall they be so deemed when any of
such sections, including the catchlines, are amended or reenacted. (1986 Code)
Sec. 1-5: SEVERABILITY OF PARTS OF CODE.
Should any section, paragraph, sentence, clause, phrase or word of this code be declared invalid or unconstitutional by a court of competent jurisdiction,
such invalidity or unconstitutionality shall not affect any of the remaining words, phrases, clauses, sentences, paragraphs or sections of this code, since
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=886 7/377
the same would have been enacted by the board of trustees without the incorporation in this code of any such invalid or unconstitutional word, phrase,
clause, sentence, paragraph or section. (1986 Code)
Sec. 1-6: EFFECT OF REPEAL OF REPEALING ORDINANCES.
When any ordinance repealing a former ordinance, clause or provision, or any chapter, article or section of this code shall itself be repealed, such repeal
shall not be construed to revive such former ordinance, clause or provision or any chapter, article, or section of this code, unless it shall be therein so
expressly provided. The repeal of an ordinance shall not affect any punishment or penalty incurred before the repeal took effect, nor any suit, prosecution
or proceeding pending at the time of the repeal, for any offense committed or cause of action arising under the ordinance repealed. (1986 Code)
Sec. 1-7: SEAL ESTABLISHED.
The seal heretofore provided and used by and for the village, the impression of which is a scroll bearing the inscription, "Village of Northfield, Cook County,
Illinois" shall be, and is hereby established and declared to have been and now to be the seal of the village. (1986 Code)
Sec. 1-8: CUSTODY OF SEAL.
The village seal, as established in the preceding section, shall remain in the custody of the village clerk, to be used by the village clerk and the president of
the village whenever required by law. (1986 Code)
Sec. 1-9: FISCAL YEAR DETERMINED.
The fiscal year of the village is hereby fixed and determined to commence on the first day of May in each year. (1986 Code)
Sec. 1-10: OFFICIAL TIME.
Central Standard Time shall be the official time within the village for the transaction of all village business; provided that from two o'clock (2:00) A.M. on the
last Sunday in April in each year, official time for the village shall be advanced one hour. At two o'clock (2:00) A.M. on the last Sunday in October in each
year, official time shall, by the retarding of one hour, be returned to Central Standard Time. All legal or official proceedings of the village board of trustees
and all official business of the village shall be regulated as to time in accordance with the provisions of this section. When by ordinance, resolution or
action of any municipal officer or body, an act must be performed at or within a prescribed time, it shall be performed according to the official time as herein
prescribed. When the words "daylight saving" or "daylight saving time" are used in any official document or contract, it shall be understood to have
reference to the time herein fixed for the period from the last Sunday in April to the last Sunday in October. (1986 Code)
Sec. 1-11: VILLAGE DATUM AND BENCH MARK ESTABLISHED.
The datum for the establishment of grades in the village is hereby established as that of the United States coast and geodetic survey, which is based on
mean sea level.
The standard elevation of the top of the circular bronze disc located at the base of the in the Village of Northfield shall be and is hereby
established at feet above datum, which elevation shall be the Northfield Standard Bench Mark from which all Village grades and benches shall
be established.
Note: The City of Chicago and some other municipalities use the "Chicago City Datum" which was based on the low water line of Lake Michigan for the
year A.D. 1847. The precise level of this datum was determined in A.D. 1903 by the United States Coast and Geodetic Survey to be 579.938 feet above
mean sea level. By Chicago City Datum the Northfield Standard Bench Mark would therefore have an elevation of feet.
(1986 Code)
Sec. 1-12: ALL OFFICIAL MEETINGS OPEN TO PUBLIC; EXCEPTIONS.
(1) Exceptions. As provided by the Illinois Compiled Statutes, all meetings of all legislative, executive, administrative or advisory bodies shall be open and
public, subject only to the following exceptions1:
(a) In a matter of collective negotiating between the village and its employees. (1986 Code)
(b) Where the acquisition of real property is being considered, or where the consideration for the sale or lease of village property is to be discussed.
(Ord. 01-1064, 5-21-2001)
(c) Where a pending court proceeding against or on behalf of the Village is being considered. This shall include meeting to discuss threatened litigation,
establish reserves and to settle claims under the Local Government Tort Immunity Act.
(d) Where there are constitutional provisions for closed meetings.
(e) Where Federal regulations provide for closed meetings.
(f) Where the appointment, employment, or dismissal of an employee or officer of the Village is to be considered or where testimony on a complaint
lodged against an employee or officer is to be heard, but no final action may be taken in closed session.
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=886 8/377
(g) Where an advisory committee appointed to provide the Village with professional consultation on matters germane to its operation meets to consider
matters of professional ethics or standards of performance.
(h) Where the Village Board is considering the filling of a vacancy to the Village Board. (1986 Code)
If these exceptional matters are on the agenda along with other matters, the consideration of the other matters must be open and public. Further, the
body may go into closed or executive session only upon a vote of a majority of its members present at an open meeting for which proper notice was
given. Minutes must be taken at all executive sessions. Audio and/or video recordings are required to be kept of closed session meetings. The tapes
of closed session meetings shall be destroyed eighteen (18) months after the final adjournment of the meeting if, upon review by the Village Attorney,
it is determined that the conditions as set forth by the Open Meetings Act and Village policy have been met. (1986 Code; amd. Ord. 06-1304, 12-5-
2006)
(2) Discrimination Complaints. This section shall not prevent the Village from enacting ordinances which provide for closed meetings for conciliating
complaints or discrimination under 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-11.1-1 of the Illinois Municipal Code.
(3) Notice Of Meetings. The Village shall give public notice of the schedule of regular meetings at the beginning of each calendar or fiscal year and shall
state the regular dates, times, and places of such meetings.
Public notice of any special meeting, or of any reconvened meeting, shall be given at least twenty four (24) hours before such meetings. However, this
requirement of public notice of reconvened meetings does not apply to any case where the meeting is to be reconvened within twenty four (24) hours
nor to any case where announcement of the time and place of the reconvened meeting was made at the original meeting and there is no change in the
agenda.
(4) Method Of Notice. Public notice shall be given by posting a copy of the notice in the lobby of the Village Hall.
The Village shall supply copies of the notice of its regular meetings, and notice of any special, rescheduled or reconvened meeting, to any reasonably
proximate news medium that has filed an annual request for such notice. Any such news medium shall also be given the same notice of all special,
rescheduled or reconvened meetings in the same manner as members of the meeting body, provided that the medium has given the Village an
address within the Village at which such notice may be given.
(5) Notice Of Schedule Changes. If a change is made in regular meeting dates, at least ten (10) days' notice of such change shall be given by publication
in a newspaper of general circulation in the Village. Notice of such change shall also be posted in the lobby of the Village Hall. Notice of such change
shall also be supplied to those news media which have filed an annual request for notice as provided in subsection (4) of this section. (1986 Code)
Sec. 1-13: GENERAL PENALTY; CONTINUING VIOLATIONS.
Whenever in this Code or in any ordinance of the Village or any rule or regulation promulgated pursuant thereto, any act is prohibited or when any act or
failure to act is declared to be unlawful, where no specific penalty is provided therefor, the violation of any such provision of this Code or any ordinance
shall be punishable by a fine as set forth in appendix D, article III of this Code. (Ord. 97-915, 10-27-1997)
A violation of any provision of this Code, or of any ordinance shall constitute a separate offense for each day such violation continues. It is also hereby
declared to be an offense for any person to command, encourage, request, aid, abet, or agree with another to commit a violation of this Code when such is
made with the specific intent that said violation be committed. (1986 Code; amd. Ord. 95-866, 11-27-1995)
ARTICLE II. ETHICAL PROVISIONS
Sec. 1-14: DEFINITIONS.
The following definitions shall apply to this article:
BUSINESS ENTITY. Any organization or enterprise (operated for profit), including, but not limited to, a sole proprietorship, partnership, corporation, firm,
business, trust, joint venture, syndicate or association.
CONSIDERATION FROM THE VILLAGE. Any request from the village, whether involving official discretion or a purely ministerial function, for any license,
permit, legislation, cooperation, financing or litigation aid. This does not include vehicle or animal licenses.
CONTRACT OR DOING BUSINESS WITH THE VILLAGE. Any agreement between the village and any person, firm, corporation or other business entity
for the purchase of materials, goods, services or real estate. Contract shall also mean a deposit of monies, loans, or other financial services provided to
the village by banks and thrift institutions. Contract shall include employment by the village.
DIRECT BUSINESS COMPETITION. Direct business competition occurs when one or more business entities provide a similar product or service and as a
matter of practice compete for the same market or customers.
EMPLOYEE. Any person employed by the village of Northfield whether part time or full time.
ENTITY. Shall include the definition of a person and business entity, and shall include not-for-profit corporations.
FINANCIAL INTEREST. Any economic interest or relationship, whether by ownership, trust, purchase, sale, lease, contract, option, investment,
employment, gift, fee or otherwise; whether present, promised or reasonably expected; whether direct or indirect; whether or not legally enforceable;
whether in the person or in a parent or subsidiary corporation, or in another subsidiary of the same parent corporation. A financial interest shall include, but
is expressly not limited to, any economic interest, as set forth above, of a spouse or minor child, as well as any economic interest held by an agent on
behalf of an official, appointee or employee, his spouse or minor child, by a business entity managed or controlled by, or by a trust in which an official,
appointee or employee has a substantial interest. A business entity is controlled by an official, appointee or employee when that person's spouse or minor
child, singly or in the aggregate, possess a majority ownership interest in the entity. An official, appointee or employee has a substantial interest in a trust
when that person, the spouse or minor child, singly or in the aggregate, have a present or future interest worth more than one thousand dollars
($1,000.00). "Financial Interest" shall not include ownership through purchase at fair market value of less than one percent (1%) of the share of a parent,
subsidiary or other affiliated corporation whose shares are registered and traded on a nationally recognized securities market. "Financial Interest" shall
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=886 9/377
also not include authorized compensation or salary paid to an official, appointee or employee for services rendered to the village of Northfield, or any
economic benefit generally available to the residents of the village of Northfield.
GIFT. Shall be defined as in the text and regulations of the state officials and employees ethics act, 5 Illinois Compiled Statutes 430/1-1 et seq.
IMMEDIATE FAMILY. An individual's spouse, dependent children, or others claimed by the individual as dependents for income tax purposes. All reference
to a "person" or "person filing the statement" shall include spouse and minor children.
NOTIFICATIONS. Whenever notification of interested village residents is required by this code in contemplation of a zoning or other land use or structure
change, it shall be the responsibility of the person seeking the consideration to provide written notice to the residents. Unless otherwise stated in this code,
interested village residents shall mean all owners of record of real estate within two hundred fifty feet (250') of the boundaries of the property for which the
change is sought. Unless otherwise stated, this notice shall be given not less than fifteen (15) days nor more than thirty (30) days prior to the required
hearing or public meeting. All notices pursuant to this section shall be delivered by registered or certified mail, return receipt requested.
OFFICIAL. Any person appointed or elected to any board, commission or other office of the village and any person appointed to any office listed in
chapters 2 and 3 of this code.
OWNERSHIP INTEREST. A person has an ownership interest if the person is the sole proprietor, partner, stockholder, other equity interest owner, joint
venturer, beneficial owner or any other legally recognized interest normally indicating ownership.
PAST YEAR. The preceding calendar year plus any time elapsed during the current year prior to the filing of the disclosure statement.
PERSON. Any individual, entity, corporation, proprietorship, partnership, firm, association, trade union, trust, estate or group, as well as any parent or
subsidiary of any of the foregoing entities, whether or not operated for profit.
PUBLIC BODY. Any agency, board, body, commission, committee, department or office of the village. (Ord. 94-814, 8-22-1994; amd. Ord. 99-957, 1-25-
1999; Ord. 05-1244, 6-21-2005)
Sec. 1-15: DISCLOSURE STATEMENT2.
A. Time For Filing. Officials shall file the disclosure statement immediately upon taking office and it shall apply to the three hundred sixty five (365) days
immediately preceding the taking of office. Reference to "doing business with the village" shall apply to the same period as references to the person's
interest in business. Persons already holding office at the time of adoption of this article II shall file the disclosure statement within thirty (30) days of
such adoption. If the information furnished in the disclosure statement changes during the official's tenure or term of employment, the official shall so
notify the village clerk in writing within thirty (30) days of the change.
B. Persons Required To File. The following persons shall be required to file a disclosure statement:
(1) Zoning board of appeals members.
(2) Plan and zoning commission.
(3) Architectural commission members.
(4) Employees as defined in 5 Illinois Compiled Statutes 420/4A-101 et seq. (disclosure of economic interest).
(5) Village attorney.
(6) Village engineer.
(7) Village prosecutor.
(8) All persons holding an elective office.
C. Contents Of Disclosure Statement. The disclosure statement shall report the following:
(1) Real Property. Any financial interest in real property located inside or in an unincorporated area within one and one-half (11/2) miles of the
corporate limits of the village of Northfield. The statement shall include the common address and permanent index number ("PIN") of each parcel of
real estate owned and shall indicate the nature of the interest held in the real estate.
The property in which the person resides shall be exempt from the provisions of this section. (Ord. 94-814, 8-22-1994)
(2) Interest In Business Entity Doing Business With Or Seeking Consideration From The Village. Any financial or ownership interest of one
percent (1%) or more in any business entity which has done business with or sought consideration from the village during the past year. The
disclosure shall include the extent and nature of the ownership interest and the type of business conducted with or consideration sought from the
village.
(3) Position Of Influence In Business Entity Doing Business With Or Seeking Consideration From The Village. Any position of influence such as
officer, director, partner, attorney for, or consultant of any business entity doing business with or seeking consideration from the village of Northfield.
The disclosure shall include your position and the type of business conducted with or consideration sought from the village.
(4) Employment By Business Entity Doing Business With Or Seeking Consideration From The Village. Any employment by any entity doing
business with or seeking consideration from the village. The statement shall include the name of the employing entity and the type of business
conducted with or consideration sought from the village.
(5) Personal Business Done With Or Consideration Sought From The Village. Any business which you have done with or any consideration which
you have sought from the village. This statement shall include the type of business with or consideration sought from the village. (Ord. 94-814, 8-22-
1994; amd. Ord. 05-1244, 6-21-2005)
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=886 10/377
D. Requests For Release. All disclosure statements filed under this article shall be available for examination and copying by the public at all reasonable
times. Each person examining a statement must first fill out a form identifying the examiner by name and address with the date of examination.
The village clerk shall promptly notify each person required to file a statement under this article of each instance of an examination of his statement by
sending him a duplicate original of the identification form filled out by the person examining his statement. (Ord. 94-814, 8-22-1994)
Sec. 1-16: PROHIBITIONS.
A. Use Of Position To Obtain Employment For Others. No official shall, directly or indirectly obtain or seek to obtain preferential treatment for any
person seeking employment or other consideration from the village for any purpose other than the betterment, advantage or best interests of the
village. Nothing shall preclude the corporate authorities from exercising the full authority vested in them in the hiring of the village manager or other
official which it has a duty to hire.
B. Discrimination On Account Of Race, Religion, National Origin Or Sex. No official shall appoint or remove from, or in any way favor or discriminate
against any other person with respect to any appointive office because of his or her race, religion, national origin or sex. However, this provision does
not impair the appointing authority's discretion in determining the requirements for a position or in specifying a job assignment for a person already
employed. Neither shall this provision affect any right or obligation of the village to function as an affirmative action employer.
C. Rewards For Political Activity. No official shall promise an appointment to any remunerated municipal position as a reward for any political activity or
cause or require any village employee to contribute to or perform services for any political party as a condition of continued employment or under threat
of detriment to employment.
D. Use Of Village Equipment. No official or employee shall request or permit the use of the village owned vehicles, equipment, materials or property for
convenience, profit or political purposes, except when such services are available to the public generally or are provided as village policy for the use of
such public official.
E. Representation Of Persons In Matters Involving The Village Of Northfield. No person serving in the following capacities within the village shall,
while serving or within two (2) years after his or her office or employment has ceased, act as agent, consultant or attorney for any party requesting any
consideration from the village or making any claim against the village:
(1) Village president.
(2) Village trustee.
(3) Village manager or assistant village manager.
(4) Department head.
(5) Member of plan and zoning commission (prohibition shall apply only to appearances before that commission).
(6) Member of zoning board of appeals (prohibition shall apply only to appearances before the zoning board of appeals).
(7) Village attorney.
(8) Village engineer.
(9) Village prosecutor.
F. Pecuniary Gain From The Village. No elected village official, the village manager, the assistant village manager, finance director, village attorney,
superintendent of public works, police chief or fire rescue chief shall do any business of any kind or nature with the village except for the performance
of those duties specified for the particular office holder by statute, ordinance or other regulation or order. This shall not prevent an entity in which one of
those officials has an ownership interest from doing business with the village so long as the conflicting ownership interest is one percent (1%) or less or
the affected official complies with the conflict of interest requirements of section 1-17 of this article. (Ord. 94-814, 8-22-1994; amd. Ord. 99-985, 6-21-
1999; Ord. 99-993, 9-27-1999)
Sec. 1-17: POLICY REGARDING CONFLICT OF INTEREST.
A. Persons Who Are To Avoid Conflict Of Interest. All officials, employees or professional consultants for the village shall attempt to avoid conflicts of
interest with the village. However, if any person develops a conflict of interest due to business commitments or other matters of personal advantage
that were not designed to exploit the official's or employee's position with the village, the person shall comply with subsection C of this section.
B. Standard For Determining Conflict Of Interest. For purposes of this section, a conflict of interest is created when a nonvillage interest would cause
an impairment of the official's ability to exercise independent judgment on behalf of the village. The standard for determining impairment of independent
judgment is objective rather than subjective and shall be whether a person of ordinary and reasonable judgment would be affected.
Any of the foregoing notwithstanding, a person shall be deemed to have a conflict of interest in the following circumstances:
(1) The person has or is about to acquire more than a one percent (1%) ownership interest in or is about to become an officer, director, management
official, employee, attorney or other professional consultant in any entity seeking consideration from or attempting to establish a business relationship
with the village.
(2) The person is representing another person or entity as an advocate or consultant in a circumstance in which the other entity or person has an
interest which is adverse to the interests of the village, or when that other entity or person is actively seeking consideration from the village.
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=886 11/377
C. Resolving Conflicts Of Interest.
(1) If a member of the corporate authorities develops a conflict of interest, that member shall be permitted to issue written statements with respect to or
participate in public meeting discussions of the issue involved in the conflict, however the member shall also abide by the following:
(a) Make full written or other public disclosure of the conflict.
(b) Refrain from voting on the issue involved in the conflict.
(c) Refrain from private discussions with other members of the corporate authorities, village staff members or village consultants with respect to the
issue involved in the conflict.
(2) If the village manager, assistant village manager or finance director develops a conflict of interest with respect to a village matter or if any other
employee or consultant develops such a conflict of interest and may reasonably be expected to advise or participate in the discussion of the issue
that is the subject of the conflict, that person shall:
(a) Make full written or other public disclosure of the conflict; and
(b) Abide by any prohibitions or restrictions issued by either the corporate authorities or the village manager, with respect to participation in the
resolution of the issue that is the subject of the conflict.
(3) If the conflict involves numerous issues or is so pervasive that it would render the person unable to properly carry out his or her obligations to the
village, the person should resign the office or position. (Ord. 94-814, 8-22-1994)
Sec. 1-17.1: COMPETING WITH AN ENTITY SEEKING CONSIDERATION FROM THE VILLAGE.
An official shall comply with subsection 1-17C(1) of this article when the official: 1) has actual knowledge that an entity is seeking consideration from or
attempting to establish a business relationship with the village; and 2) has actual knowledge that the same entity is in direct business competition with
another entity in which the same official has or is about to acquire more than a one percent (1%) interest in or is about to become an officer, director,
management official, employee, attorney or other professional consultant. (Ord. 94-814, 8-22-1994)
Sec. 1-17.2: STATE OFFICIALS AND EMPLOYEES ETHICS ACT.
A. The regulations of section 5-153 and article 104 of the state officials and employees ethics act, 5 Illinois Compiled Statutes 430/1-1 et seq., (hereinafter
referred to as the "act" in this section) are hereby adopted by reference and made applicable to the officers and employees of the village to the extent
required by 5 Illinois Compiled Statutes 430/70-5.
B. The solicitation or acceptance of gifts prohibited to be solicited or accepted under the act, by any officer or any employee of the village, is hereby
prohibited.
C. The offering or making of gifts prohibited to be offered or made to an officer or employee of the village under the act, is hereby prohibited.
D. The participation in political activities prohibited under the act, by any officer or employee of the village, is hereby prohibited. (Ord. 04-1208, 5-18-2004)
E. For purposes of this section, the terms "officer" and "employee" shall be defined in sections 1-3 of this chapter and 1-14, "Definitions", of this article.
(Ord. 05-1244, 6-21-2005)
F. To the extent allowed by law, the penalties for violations of this section shall be the same as those set forth in section 1-24, "Penalty", of this article.
(Ord. 04-1208, 5-18-2004; amd. Ord. 05-1244, 6-21-2005)
G. This section does not repeal or otherwise amend or modify any existing ordinances or policies which regulate the conduct of village officers and
employees. To the extent that any such existing ordinances or policies are less restrictive than this section, however, the provisions of this section shall
prevail in accordance with the provisions of 5 Illinois Compiled Statutes 430/70-5(a).
H. Any amendment to the act that becomes effective after the effective date of this section shall be incorporated into this section by reference and shall be
applicable to the solicitation, acceptance, offering and making of gifts and to prohibited political activities. However, any amendment that makes its
provisions optional for adoption by municipalities shall not be incorporated into this section by reference without formal action by the corporate
authorities of the village.
I. If the Illinois supreme court declares the act unconstitutional in its entirety, then this section shall be repealed as of the date that the Illinois supreme
court's decision becomes final and not subject to any further appeals or rehearings. This section shall be deemed repealed without further action by the
corporate authorities of the village if the act is found unconstitutional by the Illinois supreme court.
J. If the Illinois supreme court declares part of the act unconstitutional but upholds the constitutionality of the remainder of the act, or does not address the
remainder of the act, then the remainder of the act as adopted by this section shall remain in full force and effect; however, that part of this section
relating to the part of the act found unconstitutional shall be deemed repealed without further action by the corporate authorities of the village. (Ord. 04-
1208, 5-18-2004)
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=886 12/377
Sec. 1-18: PURCHASE OF PROPERTY.
Nothing in this article shall be construed as precluding an official or employee from buying property which may someday be the subject of zoning or similar
action as long as such official or employee does not acquire such property on the basis of information which is unavailable to other members of the public
and does not vote or attempt to influence the vote of others with respect to such property. (Ord. 94-814, 8-22-1994)
Sec. 1-19: FILING OF COMPLAINT.
The village clerk is authorized to receive and maintain a log of all complaints made against individuals subject to this article. Each complaint shall be
submitted to the village attorney. Upon a review of the evidence, the village attorney shall make a recommendation to the corporate authorities as to
whether or not prosecution is warranted. The corporate authorities shall then, by majority vote including the president, authorize or not authorize
prosecution for violation of a local ordinance. If it is a member of the corporate authorities who is accused, that member shall not participate in the vote. If
the vote is to not authorize prosecution, then neither the village attorney nor the village prosecutor may commence prosecution.
For purposes of this section, "prosecution" shall mean the filing of an action in the circuit court of Cook County, by either the village attorney or village
prosecutor alleging violations of this article. In the event no prosecution is commenced, the village attorney's log and complaint files shall not be open for
public inspection, unless requested by the individual who was the subject of the complaint. However, the person making the complaint shall be notified in
writing of the decision of the corporate authorities. To the extent that it is practicable to do so, an elected village official should use his or her best efforts to
notify, in writing, other elected village officials prior to filing a complaint or charges against any village official or employee. If the complaint is against the
village attorney or if it is otherwise inappropriate for the village attorney, the corporate authorities shall retain independent counsel to evaluate and if
necessary prosecute the complaint. (Ord. 94-814, 8-22-1994)
Sec. 1-20: APPLICABILITY OF STATE LAW.
Nothing in this article shall be deemed to or in any way restrict the application of any state statute or any common law provision with respect to conflict of
interest, malfeasance, misfeasance, nonfeasance in office which would otherwise be applicable to any person subject to the provisions of this article. The
provisions of this article shall be deemed additional requirements and shall in no way be construed to be in derogation of present statutory penalties and
other local remedies for acts prohibited in this article. (Ord. 94-814, 8-22-1994)
Sec. 1-21: DEFENSE OF GOOD FAITH.
It shall be an absolute defense to any action brought against any official, employee or agent that, prior to acting, the person received in writing and in good
faith from the Village Attorney, or person appointed by the Corporate Authorities to act in his stead, an opinion that the action is not a violation of this
article. (Ord. 94-814, 8-22-1994)
Sec. 1-22: OTHER RULES AND REGULATIONS.
In addition to the provisions of this article, the Village Manager is authorized to promulgate rules and regulations for employees relating to outside
employment and business interests, conflict of interests, or other ethical matters as he may deem necessary. In the event of a conflict between such rules
and regulations promulgated by the Village Manager and the requirements of this article, the more stringent rules, regulations or requirements shall apply
to Village employees. (Ord. 94-814, 8-22-1994)
Sec. 1-23: SEVERABILITY.
The various provisions of this article are to be considered as severable, and if any part or portion of this article shall be held invalid by any court of
competent jurisdiction, such decision shall not affect the validity of the remaining provisions of this article. (Ord. 94-814, 8-22-1994)
Sec. 1-24: PENALTY.
Any person guilty of violating the provisions of this article shall be fined in accordance with appendix D, article III of this Code. (Ord. 97-915, 10-27-1997)
ARTICLE III. MAILING LISTS
Sec. 1-25: REQUESTS FOR LISTS; COSTS.
The following shall apply to organizations or businesses or individuals desiring to obtain a mailing list of residents and/or businesses (names and
addresses) generated through water/sewer billings:
(1) Nonprofit organizations, businesses and individuals can obtain the Village's mailing list or labels for a charge as set forth in appendix D, article I of
this Code.
(2) For profit organizations, businesses and individuals can obtain the Village's mailing list or labels for a charge as set forth in appendix D, article I of
this Code.
All requests must first be made in writing to the Village Manager and must certify (by form provided) that the list is for a single event and that the individual,
organization or business will not lend or sell the list to any other group or agency. Any organization, business or individual reusing or selling the mailing list
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=886 13/377
in violation of the certification set out shall pay an administrative fee as set forth in appendix D of this Code and shall be permanently barred from
purchasing the mailing list thereafter, unless appealed to the Village President. (Ord. 01-1080, 9-24-2001; amd. Ord. 05-1235, 4-19-2005)
ARTICLE IV. REIMBURSEMENT FOR PRIVATE FACILITIES
Sec. 1-26: STATEMENT OF POLICY.
It has been and is the policy of the Village of Northfield to approve the creation and maintenance of private roadways and service facilities ("private
facilities") in appropriate circumstances. This policy has recognized that the owners of private facilities are solely responsible for the installation, operation
and maintenance costs of the private facilities and their accompanying safety and other appurtenant devices ("appurtenant devices") such as traffic signals
and signs which control traffic on the private roadways. (Ord. 05-1260, 10-18-2005, eff. 1-1-2006)
Sec. 1-27: CHARGES BY GOVERNMENTAL AGENCIES.
In each instance in which the village is billed by a governmental agency, including, but not limited to, the state of Illinois and the county of Cook or the
metropolitan water reclamation district for the installation, operation and/or maintenance of appurtenant devices serving a private facility, the village may
pay such bill. The village shall, in turn, promptly bill the full amount of such payment to the record owner or owners of the private facility for reimbursement.
(Ord. 05-1260, 10-18-2005, eff. 1-1-2006)
Sec. 1-28: OWNER(S) OF PRIVATE FACILITIES RESPONSIBLE FOR PAYMENT OF CHARGES.
The owner or owners of a private facility shall reimburse the village for the payment of any bill from a governmental agency for the installation, operation
and maintenance costs of appurtenant devices serving their private facilities. For purposes of this article, "owner" shall mean the record or beneficial
owner and in the case where the property is served by a homeowners' association that is responsible for the private facilities, it shall mean that
association. If more than one owner is served by the private facilities, the village shall have the sole authority to reasonably allocate the cost between or
among these owners. (Ord. 05-1260, 10-18-2005, eff. 1-1-2006)
ARTICLE V. PAYMENT OF VILLAGE OBLIGATIONS
Sec. 1-29: PAYMENT OF ALL VILLAGE OBLIGATIONS PRIOR TO ANY VILLAGE ACTION.
The village shall not enter into any contract, neither shall the village take any action on any request for a license, permit, annexation, rezoning or
development, if the person/business seeking the contract or action owes any fees, fines, forfeitures or taxes to the village of Northfield or is in violation of
any laws or regulations of the village of Northfield, or that the village is authorized to enforce. This provision shall not be construed so as to prevent the
issuance of a permit or license when the issuance of the permit or license would have the effect of bringing the applicant or the applicant's property into
compliance with the laws or regulations that are applicable. (Ord. 09-1420, 7-21-2009)
ARTICLE VI. PROPERTY TAX CAP POLICY
Sec. 1-30: PROPERTY TAX CAP.
Even if the village of Northfield is a home rule unit, the village board shall abide by the property tax limitation as set forth in property tax extension limitation
law5, commonly referred to as the property tax cap, except upon the affirmative vote of five (5) trustees and then only if one of the following has occurred:
(1) The Northfield electorate, at an advisory referendum, has approved an increase in a percentage that exceeds the statutory limitations; or
(2) The village board has declared by resolution either: a) a fiscal emergency, or b) a budgetary mandate from the Illinois legislature; or c) a budgetary
mandate from a court of competent jurisdiction. (Ord. 10-1452, 5-18-2010)
