Title Chapter 2
ADMINISTRATIVE ORGANIZATION
Chapter 2
ADMINISTRATIVE ORGANIZATION
ARTICLE I. OFFICERS GENERALLY
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=886 14/377
Sec. 2-1: ELECTIONS FOR MUNICIPAL OFFICERS.
Elections for municipal officers shall be held as provided by statute and shall be at the time provided by statute. (1986 Code)
Sec. 2-2: APPOINTMENT, SUSPENSION AND REMOVAL OF CERTAIN OFFICERS.
Unless otherwise provided, all appointive officers shall be appointed by the president, by and with the advice and consent of the board of trustees, at the
first regular meeting of the board held after the regular election of members of the board of trustees, or as soon thereafter as may be practicable, and shall
hold their office for such time as required by statute or as the board by ordinance or resolution provides. Any officers so appointed may be removed from
office by the president acting in accordance with the laws in such case made and provided. All vacancies so made may be filled in the manner in this
section provided. These appointive officers shall include the village treasurer, village clerk and such others as may be designated by statute or this code.
(1986 Code; amd. Ord. 92-721, 5-26-1992)
Sec. 2-3: RESIDENCY REQUIREMENT.
All elected officials, the village clerk, the village treasurer and members of village boards and commissions shall reside within the corporate limits of the
village of Northfield for at least one year prior to the date of election or appointment. However, any contract employee of the village who holds the position
of village clerk or village treasurer, and is not otherwise required to live in the village, shall be exempt from this requirement. (1986 Code; amd. Ord. 05-
1228, 1-18-2005)
Sec. 2-4: OATH OF OFFICE.
All elected or appointed officers of this village shall, before entering upon the duties of their respective offices, take and subscribe to the following oath or
affirmation, "I do solemnly swear (or affirm, as the case may be) that I will support the Constitution of the State of Illinois, and that I will faithfully discharge
all the duties of according to the best of my ability", which oath or affirmation, so subscribed shall be filed in the office of the village clerk.
In addition, the corporate authorities may require any such elected or appointed officer to execute such statements, affidavits, or certificates to evidence
compliance with and observation of the provisions of "an act to prevent fraudulent and corrupt practices in the making and accepting of contracts by public
officers", 50 Illinois Compiled Statutes 105/1-4, as in the sole judgment of the corporate authorities may from time to time be deemed advisable. In
addition, the corporate authorities, in its discretion, may require village employees to execute statements, affidavits or certificates for the purpose of
disclosing conflicts of interests, if any, which would be inconsistent with the policy enunciated in said act. (1986 Code)
Sec. 2-5: BOND - REQUIRED.
Any bond required to be filed of an officer, employee or agent of the village shall be paid out of the village treasury unless otherwise specified by resolution
of the corporate authorities. The amount of the respective bonds shall be determined from time to time by the corporate authorities as set forth in appendix
D of this code. If any such officer shall not take the oath or affirmation as required, and shall not present such bond to the village clerk within ten (10) days
after notification by the village clerk of his election or appointment or in such other time as is expressly authorized by the corporate authorities, his duties
shall be declared vacant. Such bond, however, if not already approved as to form and sureties by the corporate authorities, shall be received by the clerk
subject to the approval of the corporate authorities, and in case the corporate authorities shall at the next regular meeting require a different form of bond
or other sureties, the village clerk shall immediately notify the officer filing such bond of the required changes, and in case a new bond is not filed
complying with such requirements within ten (10) days after such notification, or such other time as is expressly authorized by the corporate authorities,
the office of the principal in the bond shall be declared vacant. The bond of each officer or employee of the village as required shall be executed in favor of
the village and must be secured by a surety company licensed to do business in the state of Illinois. Nothing in this section shall prevent the corporate
authorities from including in its insurance coverage a bond or similar security for any or all officers, employees or agents who are required to supply bonds.
(1986 Code)
Sec. 2-6: DELIVERY OF BOOKS TO SUCCESSOR.
Any officer of the village whose term of office has expired shall, within five (5) days after notification and request by the village president, deliver to his
successor in office all books, property, and effects of every description that may be in his possession and that belong to the village of Northfield. (1986
Code)
Sec. 2-6.1: ISSUANCE OF IDENTIFICATION BADGES TO ELECTED AND APPOINTED VILLAGE OFFICIALS AND
REGULATIONS ON THEIR USE.
A. It is the policy of the village of Northfield to issue identification badges to elected and appointed officials of the village to facilitate their interaction with
the public in the community when in performance of their public duties.
B. Village staff is hereby directed to acquire and maintain the necessary equipment for the production of identification badges for each elected and
appointed village official. These badges shall contain a photo of the official, the village's logo, the official's name, the title of the office, and an expiration
date, which shall be the same as the date of the expiration of the official's term. Such badges shall be uniform in appearance.
C. Such an identification badge shall be issued to each official as soon as is practicable after he or she is sworn into office.
D. All badges and other indications of village office issued prior to the effective date hereof shall be returned to the village at the time the new identification
badges required herein are issued to village officials currently holding office.
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=886 15/377
E. It is the policy of the village that identification badges be used only during the course of an official's performance of his or her official duties, and then
only as needed to identify the official to the public as a duly empowered village official. When displaying such a badge for identification purposes, the
official shall inform the individual to whom he or she is presenting identification of the official's title of office.
F. Badges issued under this section shall not be used to convey or imply that the village official holding the badge is authorized to act as a police officer, to
effect an arrest, or to detain, search or question an individual. Badges issued under this section shall not be displayed as part of an attempt to influence
or gain favor or to avoid being ticketed, charged, or detained by a law enforcement officer of any jurisdiction.
G. Any report of misuse of a village identification badge issued under this section shall be reviewed by the village board of trustees and may result in
censure, other sanction, or removal from office where circumstances warrant and acting in accordance with the law in such case made and provided.
H. Identification badges of elected and appointed village officials must be returned to the village upon expiration of the term of office or other termination of
office with the village. (Ord. 05-1253, 8-16-2005)
Sec. 2-7: ACCESS TO BOOKS BY GOVERNING BODY.
The president or any member of the board of trustees and the village manager shall, at any time so desired, have free access for the examination of all
books, papers, vouchers, warrants, entries or accounts of each and every such office, and upon a resolution adopted by the corporate authorities, or an
order promulgated by the village manager, demand a written report on any matter which may be designated in such resolution or such order of the village
manager, and within the time so set forth. (1986 Code)
Sec. 2-8: SALARIES.
All officers and employees of the village shall receive such salaries as may be from time to time provided by ordinance or otherwise fixed by the corporate
authorities. (1986 Code)
ARTICLE II. BOARD OF TRUSTEES
Sec. 2-9: COMPOSITION.
The board of trustees shall consist of six (6) trustees. (1986 Code)
Sec. 2-10: ELECTION AND TERM OF OFFICE.
The trustees are to be elected to office for a term of four (4) years and until their successors are elected and shall have qualified. (1986 Code)
Sec. 2-11: VACANCY.
Whenever a vacancy in the office of a trustee occurs during his or her term, that vacancy shall be filled pursuant to the Illinois municipal code. (1986 Code)
Sec. 2-12: DUTIES.
Except as otherwise provided by law, the board of trustees shall exercise the same powers and perform the same duties as the city council in cities,
according to the Illinois municipal code. The board shall be the legislative department of the village government, and shall perform such duties and have
such powers as may be delegated by statute to it. It shall pass ordinances, resolutions, and motions in the same manner as a city council. (1986 Code)
Sec. 2-13: QUORUM.
No business shall be conducted by the corporate authorities unless a quorum is present. A quorum shall consist of a majority of the corporate authorities
then elected and holding office. (1986 Code)
Sec. 2-14: APPROVAL AND VETO.
All resolutions and motions: 1) which create any liability against the village, or 2) which provide for the expenditure or appropriation of its money, or 3) to
sell any village property and all ordinances passed by the board of trustees, shall be deposited with the village clerk. If the president approves of them, he
shall sign them. Those of which he disapproves, he shall return to the board of trustees, with his written objections at the next regular meeting of the board
of trustees, occurring not less than five (5) days after their passage. The president may disapprove of any one or more sums appropriated in any
ordinance, resolution or motion making an appropriation, and if so, the remainder shall be effective. If the president fails to return any ordinance or any
specified resolution or motion with his written objections, within the designated time, it shall become effective despite the absence of his signature.
Every resolution and motion herein specified and every ordinance or part of any which is returned to the board of trustees by the president shall be
reconsidered by the board of trustees. If, after such reconsideration, two-thirds (2/3) of all the trustees then holding office shall agree to pass an ordinance,
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=886 16/377
resolution or motion, notwithstanding the president's refusal to approve it, then it shall be effective. The vote on the question of passage over the
president's veto shall be by yeas and nays, and shall be recorded.
No vote of the board of trustees shall be reconsidered or rescinded at a special meeting, unless there are present at the special meeting as many trustees
as were present when the vote was taken. (1986 Code)
Sec. 2-15: REGULAR MEETINGS.
The regular meeting of the board of trustees shall be held on the third Tuesday of each month or as otherwise set forth in the annual schedule to be
posted prior to January 1 of each year. The meetings shall commence at such time as may be set by the village board pursuant to law and no notice of
such regular meeting shall be required. In the event the regular meeting date falls on a legal holiday, or for any other reason cannot be held, the meeting
shall be held on such other day as the president or the board may appoint. (Ord. 06-1305, 12-5-2006)
The meeting place of the said board, and of all commissions and committees appointed by the board, shall be at the Northfield village hall, unless
otherwise ordered by the board. (Ord. 99-1001, 10-28-1999)
Sec. 2-16: SPECIAL MEETINGS, NOTICE TO BOARD MEMBERS.
Special meetings may be called by the president or any three (3) trustees upon at least forty eight (48) hours' notice to all members and the president,
except that if all the trustees and the president are present at a special meeting, no notice of the meeting shall be necessary and such notice shall be
deemed waived. (Ord. 07-1327, 4-17-2007)
Sec. 2-17: COMMITTEE OF THE WHOLE.
The committee of the whole of the board of trustees shall be a standing committee, along with any such other committees the board shall from time to time
create. The village president may appoint trustees to serve as liaisons to staff to advise and direct on the specialized activities of the village in areas such
as finance, legal, and public works and safety. All such specialized activities shall be reported out to the committee of the whole. (Ord. 06-1300, 10-17-
2006)
Sec. 2-18: COMMITTEES; APPROVAL OF CLAIMS.
No claim against the village shall be allowed by the board of trustees until it has been referred to the committee of the whole for examination and approval.
(Ord. 06-1300, 10-17-2006)
Sec. 2-18.1: DETERMINING THE AGENDA FOR ALL MEETINGS OF THE CORPORATE AUTHORITIES.
An agenda shall be deemed set when it has either been distributed to the corporate authorities or has been posted for public review. Once an agenda for a
special meeting has been set, no items may be added to that agenda for that particular special meeting. The village president shall have the authority to
determine the agenda for all meetings of the corporate authorities subject only to the following conditions:
(1) The president may delegate the responsibility for development of the agenda to the village manager.
(2) An item shall be placed on the agenda if that item has received an affirmative vote for such placement from a standing or other duly appointed
committee of the village board.
(3) An item shall be added to an agenda if the following circumstances apply:
(a) If any two (2) trustees submit such a request in writing to the village president at least five (5) days in advance of any meeting for which the
request is made; or
(b) If any two (2) trustees jointly make such a request at an open session of a consolidated committee meeting of the board; or
(c) If a motion to add such an additional item at a regular board meeting is adopted by a majority of those present and voting.
(4) If in the ordinary course of business a village trustee or chairperson of a village commission or board has requested that a matter be placed on the
village board agenda, the village president or the village manager, as the case may be, shall notify the corporate authorities of the request.
(5) Once an agenda is set, items may be added or removed only by declaration of such addition or removal by the village president at an open session
meeting of the corporate authorities. Additionally, an item may be added to the agenda of a regular board meeting as set forth in subsection (3) of
this section. This shall apply to items which have been removed by declaration of the village president. (Ord. 94-813, 8-22-1994)
Sec. 2-19: RULES OF ORDER.
Rule 1. Call To Order. The president shall take the chair at the hour at which the meeting shall have been called, and call the meeting to order.
Rule 2. Order Of Business. The board of trustees shall then take up business in the following order:
(1) Roll call
(2) Minutes of the preceding meeting
(3) Petitions and communications
(4) Reports of officers
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=886 17/377
(5) Reports of committees
(6) Reading and consideration of proposed ordinances and resolutions
(7) Other business
Rule 3. Order And Decorum. The president shall preserve order and decorum; may speak to points of order in preference to any other member and shall
decide questions of order, subject to an appeal to the trustees by any two (2) members, on which appeal no member shall speak more than twice, unless
by leave of the board of trustees.
Rule 4. Right To Speak. Every member, previous to speaking, shall address the presiding officer, but shall not proceed with his remarks until named and
recognized by the chair.
Rule 5. Transgression Of Rules. If any member transgresses the rules of the board of trustees, the president or any member may call him to order, and
when called to order, the member shall take his seat unless permitted to explain.
Rule 6. Duty To Vote; Motions In Writing. Every member, when a question is taken, shall vote unless excused by the board of trustees, unless he be
directly interested in the question, in which case no such member shall vote. All motions shall be in writing if the president, clerk, or any member so
demands.
Rule 7. Disposition Of Reports Or Motions. After a report is made or a motion stated by the president, it shall be in possession of the board of trustees
but it may be amended or laid on the table, or withdrawn at any time before the question is put.
Rule 8. Order Of Motions. When a question is under consideration, no motion shall be received but to adjourn; lay on the table; the previous question;
postpone to a certain day; to commit; to amend; to substitute, or postpone indefinitely, which several motions shall be considered only on a majority vote of
the members present.
Rule 9. Preclusion Of Amendments. A motion for the "previous question", to lay on the table, or to commit until it is decided, shall preclude all
amendments or substitutes and debate of the main question; and a motion to postpone a question indefinitely, or to adjourn it to a certain day, until it is
decided, shall preclude all amendments and substitutes to the main question.
Rule 10. Blanks To Be Filled. When a blank is to be filled, and different sums or times proposed, the question shall first be put upon the largest sum or
the longest time.
Rule 11. Report Of Committees. All special committees to whom any matter may be referred, shall report thereon in a timely fashion giving the
recommendation of the majority of the committee. Those not in favor may present a minority report.
Rule 12. Questions Containing Several Propositions. When a question before the board of trustees contains several distinct propositions, any member
may call for a division of the question, so as to take a vote on each proposition separately.
Rule 13. Petitions. All petitions addressed to the board of trustees shall be in writing and filed by the clerk, unless withdrawn by leave of the board of
trustees, except as otherwise provided by statute.
Rule 14. Reconsideration. A member who votes with the prevailing side or any trustee who was absent at the time the vote was taken may move a
reconsideration, but no such motion shall be in order after the expiration of the next meeting of the board of trustees following the meeting when such vote
was taken.
Rule 15. Nonmembers Addressing Board. It shall not be allowable for any person not a member of the board of trustees, except the village officers, to
address such board without the consent of the presiding officer.
Rule 16. Robert's Rules Of Order. Whenever a question of parliamentary law not fully covered by the preceding rules shall arise, the same shall be
decided in accordance with the rules of parliamentary law as laid down in "Robert's Rules Of Order".
Rule 17. Suspension Or Amendment Of Rules. Any or all of the preceding rules or amendments thereto may be suspended or amended or additional
rules adopted by consent of the majority of the board of trustees then present. (1986 Code)
Rule 18. Voting Procedure; Telephone Meeting; Quorum1. Any matter requiring a roll call vote at a regular meeting of the board of trustees may be
voted on by an absent trustee via a conference telephone call or other electronic means between the absent trustee and the rest of the board present at
the regular meeting under the conditions set forth in section 2-15 of this article. The absent trustee's vote shall be made and recorded as if he or she were
physically present at the regular meeting. Only those trustees physically present at the meeting may be counted in determining the existence of a quorum.
(Ord. 06-1273, 1-17-2006)
Sec. 2-20: PROCEDURE FOR PASSAGE OF ORDINANCES, RESOLUTIONS AND MOTIONS.
The following shall be the procedure for passage of all ordinances, resolutions, and motions by the board of trustees and may not be waived or modified
except by an ordinance for that purpose and only as provided by law:
(1) Ordinances. A proposed ordinance, when first introduced at a board meeting, shall be read to the board or a written copy shall be submitted to
each member. Any alterations in the proposed ordinance suggested by the board member and generally agreed upon shall then be incorporated in
the draft, after which the president shall call for a vote on the proposed ordinance.
(2) Resolutions. Any resolutions or amendments thereto shall be reduced to writing before presentation, upon the request of any member of the
board, and after being read, shall be handed to the village clerk. If the resolution consists of several distinct propositions, each shall be voted upon
separately at the request of any member.
(3) Motions. Any motions or amendments thereto shall be reduced to writing upon the request of any member of the board. Each motion shall be
limited to one proposition.
(4) Passage. The passage of all ordinances, and any resolutions or motions shall require the concurrence of a majority of the corporate authorities
then holding office, unless a greater number is required by law. The president may vote on all questions coming before the board, and shall vote on
any ordinance, motion or resolution:
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=886 18/377
(a) Where the vote of the trustees has resulted in a tie; or
(b) Where no more than three (3) of the trustees elected or appointed have voted in favor of an ordinance, resolution or motion, even though there is
no tie vote; or
(c) Where a vote greater than a majority of the corporate authorities is required by law to adopt an ordinance, resolution or motion. (1986 Code)
Sec. 2-20.1: PARTICIPATION IN MEETINGS VIA TELEPHONE CONFERENCE CALL OR OTHER ELECTRONIC MEANS.
For the purposes of this section and as per amendments to the open meetings act effective January 1, 2007, the term "meeting" is redefined as "any
gathering whether in person, by video, audio conference, telephone call, electronic means (such as, without limitation, electronic mail, electronic chat and
other instant messaging or other means of interactive communication) of a majority of a quorum of the public body held for the purpose of discussing
public business (including closed session meetings)".
Any meeting of the board of trustees may be attended by a maximum of two (2) absent trustees via telephone conference call or other electronic means
provided there is a quorum of the public body physically present and subject to the following conditions:
(1) The absent trustee(s) cannot be present at the meeting or public hearing because of one of the following three (3) reasons:
(a) Personal illness or disability,
(b) Employment/business related reasons or business of the public body, or
(c) A family or other emergency;
(2) A maximum of two (2) elected officials may attend a meeting or public hearing by telephone conference call or other electronic means provided a
quorum of the board is physically present and following approval of the remote attendance by the board members. The elected official(s) who first
makes the appropriate request shall be given first consideration;
(3) The trustee(s) must provide notice of participation by telephone conference call or other electronic means to the village clerk at least forty eight (48)
hours in advance, when possible, so that the public notice of the meeting or public hearing contains as its first item, "Consideration of and possible
actions on any request(s) for electronic participation in the meeting" and includes the following information:
(a) The name(s) of the trustee(s) attending in that manner,
(b) The reasons for not being present at the meeting or public hearing to vote in person, and
(c) The type of medium through which the trustee(s) will attend.
If appropriate, a listing of locations, if any, where the public may attend the meeting or public hearing through use of the technology being used will
be included as part of the agenda;
(4) Where it is not practicable for the absent trustee(s) to provide forty eight (48) hours' notice of participation by telephone conference call or other
electronic means, the president, or presiding officer, prior to the convening of the meeting or public hearing, shall announce the information noted in
subsection (3) of this section;
(5) If the president or other presiding officer attends the meeting or public hearing by telephone conference call or other electronic means, he or she
may participate in the meeting discussions and vote in such circumstances as may require the vote of the president, but a presiding officer pro tem
shall be appointed to chair the meeting. Such presiding officer pro tem shall retain the ability to vote as an elected official on any issue before the
board in that meeting;
(6) The voice of the absent elected official(s) participating by telephone conference call or other electronic means, after being identified by the rest of
the board as belonging to the absent trustee(s), shall be simultaneously broadcast to the public present at the meeting or public hearing so that their
voice(s) can be heard. The absent trustee(s) must also be able to hear any public comment regarding the issue(s) elicited at the meeting or public
hearing before the vote is taken;
(7) An absent trustee participating in a vote on any agenda item by telephone or other electronic means shall attend to and participate in the entire
discussion of that agenda item before being permitted to vote. If there is an interruption of telephonic or other service for any reason during the
discussion of that item, the meeting shall proceed and the absent trustee(s) may not vote on the item during which the interruption occurred;
(8) The board, in its discretion, and by majority vote, may authorize its staff, consultants or other individuals to participate in the proceedings of the
meeting by telephone conference call or other electronic means, to the extent permissible under Illinois law;
(9) The village clerk shall record as part of the minutes of the meeting, the name of the trustee(s) attending electronically, the reason for the trustee(s)
not being present at the meeting to vote in person, and the type of medium (telephone conference or other electronic means) through which the
trustee(s) attended the meeting;
(10) It shall be the sole responsibility of the absent trustee(s) to provide, prior to the meeting, the telephone number where they can be contacted, if
attending via telephone conference. Absent trustee(s) must ensure that all televisions, radios, other telephones or loud distracting noises within
hearing range of the absent trustee during the course of the meeting are turned off or eliminated. (Ord. 07-1350, 12-3-2007)
ARTICLE III. VILLAGE PRESIDENT
Sec. 2-21: ELECTION AND TERM OF OFFICE.
The village president shall be elected for a term of four (4) years. (1986 Code)
Sec. 2-22: DUTIES; POWERS.
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=886 19/377
The president shall be the chief executive officer and chief presiding officer of the village board and:
(1) Shall be the president of the board of trustees as provided by statute.
(2) Shall vote according to the requirements of subsection 2-20(4) of this chapter.
(3) Shall be, ex officio, a member of all boards and commissions of the village of Northfield.
(4) Shall be the liquor control commissioner of the village of Northfield.
In addition, the president shall perform all such duties and have such powers as may be required or granted by statute or by provision of this code or other
ordinances, including the power to solemnize marriages as set forth in 750 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/209. (Ord. 95-832, 2-27-1995)
Sec. 2-23: BOND, OATH OF OFFICE.
Before entering upon the duties of his office, the president shall give a bond as provided in section 2-5 of this chapter. (1986 Code)
Sec. 2-24: ABSENCE, TEMPORARY DISABILITY OR VACANCY.
(1) If the president is absent from an individual meeting but is capable of performing his duties, a member of the board shall be selected as a presiding
officer by the board members present.
(2) Upon notice of a temporary absence from the village or temporary disability of the president, the chairman of the finance committee shall act as
president pro tem, and during the absence or disability of the president, shall perform the duties pertaining to the office. If the temporary absence or
disability lasts longer than thirty (30) days, the board of trustees shall then elect one of its members to act as president pro tem at the first board
meeting occurring at least thirty (30) days after said notice. The elected president pro tem shall serve until the president resumes his duties or until
the office is declared vacant.
(3) Whenever a vacancy in the office of president occurs during his term, the vacancy shall be filled for the remainder of the term at the next election of
trustees, unless the vacancy is filled by a special election as provided by law. During the period from the time that the vacancy occurs until a
president is elected and has qualified, the vacancy may be filled by the election of an acting president by the board of trustees.
(4) Nothing in this section shall deprive a temporary presiding officer or president pro tem from voting in his capacity as a trustee, but he shall not be
entitled to another vote in his capacity as temporary presiding officer or president pro tem. Where a president's vote is required by subsection 2-20(4)
(a) or (4)(b) of this chapter, the issue voted upon shall be tabled until one of the following has occurred:
(a) The permanent president is present.
(b) A new president has been elected.
(c) An acting president has been elected pursuant to subsection 2-24(3) of this section; or
(d) There is a unanimous vote of the trustees present to permit the presiding officer or president pro tem to vote as the president. (1986 Code)
ARTICLE IV. VILLAGE MANAGER
Sec. 2-25: APPOINTMENT AND REMOVAL: QUALIFICATIONS; VACANCY.
The village manager shall be appointed by the president and board of trustees for an indefinite term. He shall be chosen on the basis of his executive and
administrative qualifications, with special reference to his actual experience in or his knowledge of accepted practice respecting the duties of his office
hereinafter set forth. It is the policy of the village of Northfield that the village manager shall establish residency in the village within one year of
appointment. The corporate authorities, at their sole discretion, may waive this requirement on such conditions as they deem appropriate. Once waived,
the village manager may not subsequently be required to establish residency within the village of Northfield.
Neither the village president nor any village trustee shall be appointed as village manager during the term for which he shall have been elected, nor within
one year after the expiration of his term.
The village manager may be removed by the village board by a majority vote of the members holding office at any time.
A vacancy in the office shall be filled as soon as possible. (Ord. 91-671, 3-18-1991)
Sec. 2-26: BOND.
(Rep. by Ord. 93-756, 3-22-1993)
Sec. 2-27: EMPLOYMENT AGREEMENT AND COMPENSATION.
The president and board of trustees, on behalf of the village, may execute an employment agreement with the village manager subject to the provisions of
this code.
The village manager shall receive such compensation as the board shall from time to time fix in accordance with section 2-8 of this code. (1986 Code)
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=886 20/377
Sec. 2-28: POWERS AND DUTIES.
The village manager shall be the chief administrative officer and head of the administrative branch of the village. He shall be responsible to the corporate
authorities for the proper administration of all affairs of the village. The president and board of trustees shall deal with the administration solely through the
village manager. The village manager shall have sole responsibility for appointment and removal of employees within such administration unless otherwise
provided by law.
The village manager shall have power and be required to:
(1) Appoint and remove all nonelective officers and employees of the village except as provided by law or this code. Such appointments and removals
by the village manager shall be based upon merit and upon the qualifications of such officers or employees without regard to any political belief or
affiliation.
(2) Appoint and remove the Village Attorney and Village Prosecutor with the advice and consent of the Corporate Authorities.
(3) Appoint and remove the Village Engineer with the advice and consent of the Corporate Authorities.
(4) Be responsible for the preparation of the annual budget and submit it to the Corporate Authorities and be responsible for its administration after
adoption.
(5) Prepare and submit to the Corporate Authorities from time to time as they may require reports on the finances and the administrative activities of
the Village.
(6) Keep the Corporate Authorities advised of the financial condition and future needs of the Village and make such recommendations as he may deem
desirable.
(7) Recommend to the Corporate Authorities the salaries to be paid each appointive officer and subordinate employee of the Village.
(8) Recommend to the Corporate Authorities, in writing, from time to time, for adoption, such measures as he may deem necessary and expedient.
(9) Attend all meetings of the Village Board unless otherwise directed by the Board. The Village Manager shall have the privilege of taking part in the
discussion of all matters coming before the Board. He shall be entitled to notice of all meetings, regular and special, of the Board. (1986 Code)
(10) Purchase materials, supplies, equipment and services not exceeding the Illinois compiled statutory allowance for which funds are provided in the
budget, but no such purchase which exceeds any officially budgeted amount may be made until the Village has increased that amount as provided
by law. He may issue such rules and regulations governing requisitions and the transaction of the business of purchasing between himself as
purchasing agent and the heads of departments, officers, and employees of the Village, provided such rules are consistent with the provisions of this
Code and applicable by law. (Ord. 94-810, 8-22-1994)
(11) See that all laws and ordinances are duly enforced.
(12) Conduct reasonable investigations into the affairs of the Village or any department or division thereof.
(13) Investigate all complaints in relation to all matters concerning the administration of the government of the Village and in regard to service
maintained by the public utilities in the Village, and see that all franchises, permits, and privileges granted by the Village are faithfully observed.
(14) Devote his entire time to the discharge of his official duties.
(15) Perform such additional duties as may be required of him by the Village Board or the President, not inconsistent with the Village ordinances or the
law.
(16) Make quarterly reports to the Corporate Authorities of activities of all departments under his jurisdiction.
(17) Enter into mutual assistance agreements with approval of the Corporate Authorities with any other police, fire, or public safety agencies. May
adopt rules governing the assignment of the personnel and equipment of the Police and Fire Departments and emergency medical service outside
the corporate limits of the Village, and may determine the charges to be made for such services. Such agreements, rules and charges, upon
approval of the Corporate Authorities, shall be binding upon the members of the Police and Fire Departments and the emergency medical service.
(1986 Code)
(18) Act in the capacity of Village Clerk or Deputy Village Clerk as appropriate. (Ord. 94-810, 8-22-1994)
(19) Act in the capacity of Assistant Treasurer of the Village and the Police Pension Board. (Ord. 98-928, 2-23-1998)
(20) Sign payroll and disbursement checks as necessary. (Ord. 94-810, 8-22-1994)
(21) Act in the capacity of Assistant Village Treasurer. (Ord. 96-889, 10-28-1996)
(22) a) When purchases are made within the Village Manager's statutory purchasing power pursuant to subsection (10) of this section; the Manager
may offset the cost of a new item by trading surplus Village personal property in on the new item to be purchased; b) when the new item exceeds the
statutory limit of the Village Manager's purchasing power, the Manager may recommend to the Village Board, and the Village Board may approve,
the trade-in of any surplus Village personal property on the new item of personal property being purchased by the Village. (Ord. 17-1692, 10-17-
2017)
Sec. 2-29: ACTING MANAGER.
During the temporary absence or disability of the village manager, the village manager may appoint an acting village manager to act in his stead, unless
the corporate authorities shall provide otherwise. If not already bonded, the acting village manager shall provide a bond as set forth in section 2-5 of this
chapter. (1986 Code)

ARTICLE V. VILLAGE CLERK
Sec. 2-30: APPOINTMENT.
There is hereby created the office of village clerk who shall be appointed by the president and board of trustees. He shall serve for one year and until his
successor shall have been appointed and shall qualify. (1986 Code)
Sec. 2-31: DUTIES.
The village clerk shall keep the corporate seal, to be provided by the corporate authorities, and all papers belonging to the municipality, the custody and
control of which are not given to other officers.
He shall attend all meetings of the corporate authorities and keep a full record of their proceedings.
The clerk shall perform such other duties and functions as may be required by statute or by the provisions of this code or other ordinances of the village.
The clerk shall file and preserve according to date of filing and subject matter, all oaths of office and written reports of officers and committees.
The clerk shall keep and maintain a proper index to all documents and records kept by him so that ready access thereto and use thereof may be had.
(1986 Code)
The village clerk shall be the designated freedom of information officer and her/his designee(s) shall be responsible for complying with requests for access
to public records per the freedom of information act effective July 1, 1984, and amended by PA 96-0542 effective January 1, 2010. See article IX,
"Freedom Of Information Act", of this chapter. (Ord. 09-1440, 12-7-2009)
Sec. 2-32: DEPUTY.
The clerk may appoint a deputy, by and with the consent of the corporate authorities who, in the temporary absence of the clerk, in case of sickness or
otherwise, shall be empowered to perform all, or specifically designated duties of the village clerk. (1986 Code)
Sec. 2-33: VACANCY; CLERK PRO TEM.
In case the office of village clerk shall become vacant for any reason, the vacancy may be filled by the appointment of an acting clerk by the president and
board of trustees voting jointly. Such acting clerk may serve until a permanent village clerk has been appointed. (1986 Code)
Sec. 2-34: BOND.
Before entering upon the duties of his office, the clerk shall execute a bond as provided in section 2-5 of this chapter. (1986 Code)
ARTICLE VI. VILLAGE TREASURER
Sec. 2-35: APPOINTMENT.
There is hereby created the office of village treasurer, who shall be appointed by the president and board of trustees, as is provided by statute. He shall
serve for one year, and until his successor shall have been appointed and shall qualify. (1986 Code)
Sec. 2-36: BOND.
Before entering the duties of his office, the village treasurer shall execute a bond, as provided in section 2-5 of this chapter. (1986 Code)
Sec. 2-37: DUTIES.
The treasurer shall perform such duties as may be prescribed for him by statute or by the provisions of this code or other ordinances of the village. He
shall receive all money paid into the village treasury, either directly from the person paying the money or from the hands of such other officer or employee
who may receive it. (1986 Code)
Sec. 2-38: DEPOSIT OF FUNDS.
The treasurer shall deposit the village funds in such depositories as may be designated from time to time by the corporate authorities. He shall keep the
deposit of the village money separate and distinct from his own money, and shall not make private or personal use of any village money. (1986 Code)
Sec. 2-39: RECORDS.
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=886 22/377
The treasurer shall keep records showing all money received by him, showing the source from which it is received and the purpose for which it is paid, and
he shall keep accurate records at all times showing the financial status of the village. (1986 Code)
Sec. 2-40: ACCOUNTING.
The treasurer shall keep such books and accounts as may be required by statute, by the provisions of this code or other ordinances of the village, and he
shall keep them in the manner required by the corporate authorities. (1986 Code)
Sec. 2-41: SPECIAL ASSESSMENT FUNDS.
All monies received on any special assessment shall be held by the treasurer as a special fund to be applied only to the payment of the improvement or
bonds and vouchers issued therefor, together with interest thereon, for which the assessment was made, and said money shall be used for no other
purpose unless to reimburse the village for money expended for such improvement. Payments on bonds or vouchers shall be made in accordance with the
statutes and the law and the treasurer shall keep his books and accounts in such a manner so that proper prorations in payments of principal and interest
can be made and ascertained. (1986 Code)
Sec. 2-42: WARRANTS; TRANSFER OF FUNDS.
All warrants drawn on the treasurer must be signed by the president, by the clerk, or by some other officer authorized so to do, stating the particular fund
or appropriation to which the same is chargeable, and the person to whom payable; and no money shall be otherwise paid except as may be provided by
statute. Money shall not be transferred by the treasurer from one fund to another, after it has been received by him, nor appropriated to any purpose other
than that for which it has been collected or paid, except as may be ordered by the president and board of trustees in manner and form prescribed by
statute. (1986 Code)
Sec. 2-43: REPORTS.
The treasurer shall make a monthly report to the board of trustees showing the receipts and disbursements during the month previous, and the state and
condition of every account not closed on his books. He shall also make an annual report, during the last month of the fiscal year, showing all the activities
of his office. (1986 Code)
ARTICLE VII. VILLAGE BUDGET OFFICER
Sec. 2-44: ESTABLISHMENT OF OFFICE.
There is hereby created the office of the village budget officer pursuant to chapter 24, section 8-2-9.1 through 8-2-9.10 of the Illinois municipal code (1991
edition). (Ord. 92-735, 8-24-1992)
Sec. 2-45: BOND.
Before entering the duties of office, the village budget officer shall execute a bond, as set forth in section 2-5 of this chapter. (Ord. 92-735, 8-24-1992)
Sec. 2-46: DEPARTMENTAL BUDGET CHANGES.
Upon approval of the village manager and so long as there is not an overall increase in the budget for any fund, the budget officer shall have the following
authority with respect to a departmental budget:
(1) Move monies from one established classification to another within a fund with the exception of specific salaries approved by the board; and
(2) Change the name or subject matter of a classification; and
(3) Create subclassification within an established classification. (Ord. 92-735, 8-24-1992)
ARTICLE VIII. UNIFORM COMPLAINT PROCEDURE
Sec. 2-47: ESTABLISHMENT OF PROCEDURE.
An employee or community member should notify any complaint coordinator (or such alternate person as is specifically designated by the village) if she/he
believes that the village, its employees, officials, or agents have engaged in unlawful discrimination or have violated his or her rights guaranteed by the
state or federal constitution, state or federal statute, or other legal right, including:
(1) Title II of the Americans with disabilities act;
(2) Title VI of the civil rights act or Illinois human rights act;
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=886 23/377
(3) Equal employment opportunities act (title VII of the civil rights act), equal pay act of 1963 or Illinois equal pay act of 2003;
(4) Age discrimination in employment act;
(5) Illinois whistleblower act;
(6) Sexual harassment (Illinois human rights act, title VII of the civil rights act of 1964, and title IX of the education amendments of 1972).
Such complaints should be discussed with the complaint coordinator, who will make efforts to address and resolve the complaint without any further
procedures hereunder. If the problem is not resolved, a written complaint can be filed hereunder and the complaint coordinator will act in good faith to
address the complaint promptly and fairly. This procedure shall not affect, nor be affected by, other remedies such person may have under the law.
Any time lines hereunder may be extended by the complaint coordinator as she/he finds appropriate. As used in this policy, "business days" means those
days when the village hall is open. (Ord. 09-1439, 12-7-2009)
Sec. 2-48: FILING A COMPLAINT.
A written complaint can be filed with the complaint coordinator. The complaint coordinator will assist the person with such filing, as may be needed. If the
person attempting to file a complaint wishes to file with a person of the same gender, the village will designate an appropriate alternate complaint
coordinator of such gender. The complaint coordinator can request at any time that a complaint be put in writing, or arrange a meeting with an employee
as determined necessary by the complaint coordinator. (Ord. 09-1439, 12-7-2009)
Sec. 2-49: PROCESSING A COMPLAINT.
The complaint coordinator will gather such information, or conduct an investigation, as may be appropriate to the complaint. The complaint, and
information gathered pursuant to the complaint, will be kept confidential except as needed to complete the investigation, resolve the complaint, comply
with applicable law or otherwise properly inform and receive feedback from the officials or persons necessary to a resolution of the complaint. The time
lines related to the complaint process are as follows:
(1) Within thirty (30) business days of filing a complaint, the complaint coordinator will complete a written response setting forth his or her findings and
provide such report to the board of trustees. The time will be extended, if necessary, to conduct an accurate and thorough investigation. The
complaint coordinator will keep the board informed of all written complaints.
(2) At its next regular meeting after receiving the complaint coordinator's response, the board shall review the response and make a decision regarding
such response. The board shall affirm, reverse, or amend the response or require the complaint coordinator to take certain further actions or request
additional information.
(3) Within ten (10) business days of the board's decision on the complaint coordinator's response, the board will provide a written copy of its final
decision to the person filing the complaint, by appropriate means, and provide a copy of the decision to the complaint coordinator.
This complaint procedure shall not be construed to create any independent right to any specific remedy or to a board hearing. The complaint coordinator
will make good faith attempts to follow this procedure, in a timely fashion. The nature and extent of each investigation will be dependent upon the specific
facts of each case.
Complaint(s) are to be brought to the attention of the complaint coordinator for the village of Northfield. Contact the complaint coordinator by going to the
village website, www.northfieldil.org and clicking under administration or as follows:
Name: Village of Northfield Complaint Coordinator
Address: 361 Happ Road, Northfield, IL 60093
Telephone: 847-446-9200
If for some reason that is not feasible, the alternate person with whom the complaint can be raised will be:
Name: Village Manager, Village of Northfield
Address: 361 Happ Road, Northfield, IL 60093
Telephone: 847-446-9200
Legal reference: Americans with disabilities act, 42 USC section 12101 et seq.
Equal employment opportunities act (title VII of the civil rights act), 42 USC section 2000e et seq.; equal pay act, 29 USC section 206(d); equal pay act of
2003, 820 Illinois Compiled Statutes 112.
Illinois human rights act, 775 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/1-101; title VI of the civil rights act, 42 USC section 2000d et seq.
Age discrimination in employment act, 29 USC section 621 et seq.
Illinois whistleblower act, 740 Illinois Compiled Statutes 174/1 et seq.
Title IX of the education amendments of 1972, 20 USC section 1681 et seq. (Ord. 09-1439, 12-7-2009)
ARTICLE IX. FREEDOM OF INFORMATION ACT
Sec. 2-50: DESIGNATION OF FOIA OFFICER.
The village clerk is hereby designated as the FOIA officer to whom all initial requests for access to the records of the village are to be referred. Such
requests are to be made in writing and submitted at or mailed to the offices of the Village Clerk at 361 Happ Road, Northfield, IL 60093, between the hours
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=886 24/377
of eight o'clock (8:00) A.M. and four thirty o'clock (4:30) P.M., Monday through Friday, or faxed to 847-446-4670. In the event that the village clerk is not
available during the times described above, the deputy village clerk is designated the deputy FOIA officer to handle such requests. Except in instances
when records are furnished immediately, the FOIA officer, or her/his designees, shall receive requests submitted to the village under the freedom of
information act, ensure that the village responds to requests in accordance with the time designated by the act, and issue responses. The FOIA officer or
her/his designees shall develop a list of documents or categories of records that the village shall immediately disclose upon request. (Ord. 09-1440, 12-7-
2009)
Sec. 2-51: PROCEDURE FOR HANDLING FOIA REQUESTS.
Upon receiving a request for a public record, the FOIA officer shall:
(1) Note the date the village receives the written request;
(2) Compute the day on which the period for response will expire and make a notation of that date on the written request;
(3) Maintain an electronic or paper copy of a written request, including all documents submitted with the request until the request has been complied
with or denied; and
(4) Create a file for the retention of the original request, a copy of the response, a record of written communications with the requester, and a copy of
other communications. (Ord. 09-1440, 12-7-2009)
Sec. 2-52: TRAINING OF FOIA OFFICER AND DESIGNEES.
The FOIA officer, deputy FOIA officer and her or his designees (coordinators) shall, within six (6) months after January 1, 2010, successfully complete an
electronic training curriculum to be developed by the public access counselor of the state of Illinois and, thereafter, successfully complete an annual
training program. Whenever a new freedom of information officer, deputy officer and/or coordinator is designated by the village, that person shall
successfully complete the electronic training curriculum within thirty (30) days after appointment to the position. (Ord. 09-1440, 12-7-2009)
Sec. 2-53: RECORD RETRIEVAL.
Any records which are the subject of a request under the freedom of information act shall be retrieved from such place as they are stored, by the FOIA
officer, or by an employee of the village acting under the direction of the FOIA officer. In no event shall records be retrieved by the party requesting them or
by any person who is not employed by the village. (Ord. 09-1440, 12-7-2009)
Sec. 2-54: FEES.
If copies of records are requested, the fees for such copies, whether certified or not, shall be as determined from time to time by the FOIA officer pursuant
to section 6(b) of the freedom of information act. The village clerk shall maintain a written schedule of current fees in the clerk's and FOIA coordinator's
offices. The fees charged for copying records and the cost of certifying copies, if certification is requested, shall reflect the rates allowable under the FOIA
act and as noted in appendix D of this code. (Ord. 09-1440, 12-7-2009)
Sec. 2-55: DENIAL OF FOIA REQUEST.
In the event that a request to inspect village records is denied by the FOIA officer or her/his designee the denial may be appealed to the public access
counselor of the state of Illinois. (Ord. 09-1440, 12-7-2009)
Sec. 2-56: DOCUMENTS AVAILABLE.
The village clerk or her/his designee shall prepare: 1) a village information directory; 2) a block diagram of the functional subdivisions of the village; 3) a
village records directory; and 4) a records catalogue. This information shall also be posted on the village's website. (Ord. 10-1442, 1-19-2010)
Footnote 1: This will expire one year from the date of its adoption and approval.

ARTICLE I. PUBLIC WORKS DEPARTMENT
Sec. 3-1: ESTABLISHMENT OF PUBLIC WORKS DEPARTMENT; PUBLIC WORKS, WATER AND SEWERAGE DIVISIONS.
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=886 25/377
There is hereby established a public works department for the village. The department shall be made up of three (3) divisions: the public works division
(including parks and forestry), the sewerage division, and the water division. (Ord. 98-928, 2-23-1998)
Sec. 3-2: ADMINISTRATION.
The village manager shall supervise the public works department. The three (3) divisions (public works, sewerage, and water) shall be administered by a
director of public works. The village manager shall have the power to appoint and remove the director of public works. The village manager shall report
any such appointment or removal decisions, and the reasons therefor, to the corporate authorities at their next regular meeting. (Ord. 98-928, 2-23-1998)
Sec. 3-3: COMPENSATION.
The village manager, subject to the approval of the corporate authorities, shall fix the salary of the director of public works. (Ord. 98-928, 2-23-1998)
Sec. 3-4: DIRECTOR OF PUBLIC WORKS.
The director of public works and the department of public works, subject to the direction of the village manager, shall have the following duties and
functions:
(1) Maintain and repair all public streets, lighting, alleys, sidewalks, viaducts, bridges and other structures pertaining thereto in the village.
(2) Have charge of all physical property of the village which is not assigned to the charge or supervision of some other department of the village.
(3) Keep records of all inspections, complaints, repairs and installations as may be attended to by the public works division.
(4) Act as municipal arborist pursuant to chapter 10 of this code.
(5) Manage and operate the village water distribution and sewerage systems.
(6) Be responsible for the enforcement of all ordinances, rules, and regulations relating to the use and operation of the municipal water and sewerage
systems, in particular, but not limited to, those found in chapter 7 of this code.
(7) Keep records of all inspections, complaints, repairs, and installations, as may be attended to by the divisions of water and sewerage.
(8) Perform such other duties as may be assigned by the village manager. (Ord. 98-928, 2-23-1998)

There is hereby established the office of finance director, an administrative office of the village. The finance director shall be appointed by the village
