ARTICLE III. DEPARTMENT OF PUBLIC SAFETY
Division - General
Division I - Police Department
Sec. 3-15: OFFICE OF THE CHIEF OF POLICE.
The department shall be administered by the chief of police who shall be appointed by the village manager. (1986 Code)
Sec. 3-15.1: OFFICE OF THE DEPUTY CHIEF OF POLICE.
(1) The chief of police shall be assisted in the duties of administering the department by a deputy chief of police. The deputy chief of police shall be
appointed by the chief of police from among those officers of the department having at least five (5) years of experience with the department.
(2) If the chief of police is of the opinion that there are no officers within the department who are qualified to hold the office of deputy chief of police, then
the chief shall notify the village manager, in writing, of such circumstances. The chief of police and the village manager shall then seek to otherwise fill
the office as may be permitted by law.
(3) The deputy chief of police shall be subject to removal or suspension by the chief of police, who shall promptly report such removal or suspension and
the reasons therefor to the village manager. If the deputy chief of police held a rank within the police department prior to assuming the office of deputy
chief of police, he or she may not be removed or suspended from said rank except according to the law governing such removal or suspension.
(4) The deputy chief of police shall have such duties as may be assigned to the chief of police. (Ord. 99-992, 9-27-1999)
Sec. 3-16: BOND.
(Rep. by Ord. 93-756, 3-22-1993)
Sec. 3-17: REMOVAL AND SUSPENSION OF THE CHIEF OF POLICE.
The chief of police shall be subject to removal or suspension by the village manager who shall promptly report such removal or suspension and the
reasons therefor to the corporate authorities. If removed, such removal shall not be effective until confirmed by a majority vote of the corporate authorities.
If the chief of police held a rank within the police department prior to assuming the office of chief of police, he may not be removed or suspended from said
rank except according to the law governing such removal or suspension. (Ord. 91-676, 4-22-1991)
Sec. 3-18: DUTIES OF CHIEF OF POLICE.
The chief of police shall have the following duties:
(1) He shall be responsible for the performance by the police department of its functions. All persons who are members of the police department and all
nonsworn personnel within the police department shall serve subject to the orders of the chief of police.
(2) The chief of police shall be keeper of the village detention facility which is established and located in the village hall and shall have charge and
custody of it and of all persons incarcerated therein.
(a) In all cases of arrest in which detention and custody of any person arrested for violations of this code shall be authorized, it shall be the duty of
the keeper of the village detention facility to receive, and he is authorized and empowered to receive from any person legally empowered to make
arrests, any person arrested, and to detain such prisoner until such prisoner shall furnish proper bail or can be safely brought before a court of
competent jurisdiction.
(b) It shall be the duty of the chief of police to keep the village detention facility in such condition and to care for all persons incarcerated therein, in a
manner conforming to the requirements of the department of correction, bureau of detention standards.
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=886 27/377
(3) He shall make and retain such records and reports concerning the activities of his department as may be required by statute, the corporate
authorities or the village manager.
(4) Such other duties as may be assigned by the village manager. (Ord. 91-676, 4-22-1991)
Sec. 3-19: COMPENSATION.
The fixing of compensation for police officers shall comply with statute and section 2-8 of this code.
The salary of the chief of police shall be fixed by the village manager subject to the approval of the corporate authorities. (Ord. 91-676, 4-22-1991)
Sec. 3-20: APPOINTMENT OF MEMBERS; CITIZENSHIP QUALIFICATIONS.
A. No person shall be appointed or considered for appointment as a sworn police officer in the Northfield police department unless, at the time of
application, that person is an elector of the United States Of America.
B. Except as set forth in subsection C of this section, all patrol officers and sergeants of the Northfield police department shall be selected and appointed
by the board of police commissioners as provided in the Illinois municipal code.
C. The board of police commissioners shall have the authority to adopt rules for the appointment of current village employees as sworn patrol officers
provided those rules to contain, at least, the following standards:
(1) The person has served as a village of Northfield public service officer or a part time village of Northfield police officer for a minimum of eighteen (18)
months; and
(2) Has been recommended, in writing, for hiring as a sworn patrol officer by the chief of police.
Such rules may include a waiver of testing and waiver of eligibility list placement similar to the hiring of qualified members from other police departments.
(Ord. 15-1633, 10-20-2015)
Sec. 3-20.1: PART TIME POLICE OFFICERS.
A. "Part time officer" means a member of the Northfield police department who is employed by the village of Northfield for less than one thousand (1,000)
hours in a twelve (12) month period beginning May 1 of any calendar year and who has completed the training requirements for part time police officers
as promulgated by the Illinois law enforcement training and standards board.
B. The chief of police of the village shall have the authority to hire part time police officers subject to the approval of the village manager and to appropriate
funding for such officers by the village board.
C. Part time police officers are not subject to the village of Northfield board of police commissioners, but are at will employees whose employment may be
terminated or their hours diminished at the sole discretion of the chief of police.
D. Part time police officers employed pursuant to the provisions of this section shall not be subject to any of the provisions contained in section 10-2.1-1 et
seq., of the Illinois municipal code for the hiring, discipline and termination of full time police officers.
E. Any person employed as a part time police officer must meet the following standards:
(1) Be of good moral character, of temperate habits, of sound health, and physically and mentally able to perform assigned duties.
(2) Be at least twenty one (21) years of age.
(3) Pass a medical examination.
(4) Possess a high school diploma or GED certificate.
(5) Possess a valid state of Illinois driver's license.
(6) Possess no prior felony convictions.
(7) Any individual who has served in the U.S. military must have been honorably discharged. (Ord. 12-1531, 8-20-2012)
Sec. 3-21: RULES AND REGULATIONS.
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=886 28/377
The chief of police shall make or prescribe such rules and regulations for the conduct and guidance of the members of the department as he or she shall
deem advisable, and all such rules and regulations shall be binding upon all members of the police department. Such rules and regulations may include,
but are not limited to, the chain of command within the department, residency requirements for sworn police personnel, and necessary policies and
procedures. (Ord. 08-1370, 3-18-2008)
Sec. 3-22: STOLEN PROPERTY, CUSTODY OF.
The chief of police shall have the custody of all lost, abandoned or stolen property recovered by the village and may designate a property custodian whose
responsibility it shall be to keep a record of all stolen or abandoned property. (1986 Code)
Sec. 3-23: RECORDS.
All records and reports of the police department shall be preserved within the custody of the chief of police. (1986 Code)
Division II - Fire Rescue Department
Sec. 3-24: CREATION OF THE NORTHFIELD FIRE RESCUE DEPARTMENT.
There is hereby created a fire rescue department for the village as a constituent part of the department of public safety. It shall be known as the Northfield
fire rescue department and shall consist of a fire rescue chief and such assistants and members as the corporate authorities shall from time to time
authorize. The Northfield fire rescue department shall consist of a fire department component and an emergency medical service component. The function
of the emergency medical service shall be to provide emergency medical services to persons in need of such services when called upon or otherwise
ordered to do so. The emergency medical service shall be a part of the fire rescue department, and shall at all times be subject to the rules and regulations
governing the fire rescue department. (Ord. 99-993, 9-27-1999)
Sec. 3-25: OFFICE OF THE FIRE RESCUE CHIEF.
The department shall be administered by the fire rescue chief, who shall be appointed by the village manager. The fire rescue chief may, for both official
and unofficial purposes, be referred to as the fire chief. (Ord. 99-993, 9-27-1999)
Sec. 3-26: REMOVAL OR SUSPENSION OF FIRE RESCUE CHIEF.
The fire rescue chief shall be subject to removal or suspension by the village manager, who shall promptly report any such removal or suspension, and the
reasons therefor, to the corporate authorities. (Ord. 99-993, 9-27-1999)
Sec. 3-27: DUTIES AND POWERS OF THE FIRE RESCUE CHIEF.
(1) The fire rescue chief shall be responsible for the performance by the fire rescue department of all of its functions. All persons employed by or
connected with the department, including emergency medical service personnel, while on duty shall serve subject to the orders of the fire rescue chief.
(2) The fire rescue chief shall have and retain custody of any and all village firefighting apparatus and equipment and emergency medical apparatus and
equipment.
(3) It shall be the duty of the fire rescue chief, if practical, to attend all fires and emergency situations occurring within the village. In the event of his or her
absence from any fire or emergency situation, it shall be the duty of the highest ranking officer present to take charge of the department and exercise
all powers of the fire rescue chief.
(4) The fire rescue chief may prescribe boundaries in the vicinity of any fire or other emergency situation within which no unauthorized person shall be
permitted to go.
(5) The fire rescue chief shall have the power and authority to cause the removal of any property whenever, in his or her judgment, it shall be necessary for
the protection of persons or property from fire or other emergency situations, to prevent the spreading of fire or to protect adjoining property. (Ord. 99-
993, 9-27-1999)
Sec. 3-28: SALARY OF THE FIRE RESCUE CHIEF.
The salary of the fire rescue chief shall be set by the village manager with the approval of the corporate authorities. (Ord. 99-993, 9-27-1999)
Sec. 3-29: RULES AND REGULATIONS.
The fire rescue chief shall prescribe and establish from time to time such rules and regulations for the conduct and guidance of members as he or she may
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=886 29/377
deem advisable, and such rules and regulations shall be binding upon all members of the fire rescue department. Such rules and regulations may include,
but are not limited to, chain of command within the department, residency requirements, response time and necessary policies and procedures. (Ord. 08-
1370, 3-18-2008)
Sec. 3-30: RECORDS.
It shall be the duty of the fire rescue chief to maintain records of the employment and activities of all firefighting and emergency medical personnel. The fire
rescue chief shall also maintain records of any and all fire and emergency medical apparatus and equipment owned and maintained by the fire rescue
department. The fire rescue chief shall record all activities of the Northfield fire rescue department, including, but not limited to, the answering of fire
alarms, calls for emergency medical assistance and firefighting and emergency medical training and exhibitions. These records shall include the extent of
and damage caused by all such fires and emergency situations. (Ord. 99-993, 9-27-1999)
Sec. 3-31: EMERGENCY AUTHORITY.
Every person who shall be present at the scene of a fire shall be subject to the orders of any officer of the fire rescue department. Any person disobeying
such orders shall be subject to a citation and fine in accordance with the general penalty provision of this code. (Ord. 99-993, 9-27-1999)
Sec. 3-32: USE OF FIRE AND EMERGENCY MEDICAL EQUIPMENT.
Neither the fire rescue department nor any of its members shall make use of village firefighting equipment or apparatus, or water from water mains located
within the village, except in cases of fire, fire alarm or training and exhibition purposes. Permission for use of equipment or water for training and exhibition
purposes is required and shall be given only upon the written order of the fire rescue chief or under his immediate supervision and direction. Any member
of the fire rescue department who violates the provisions of this section shall be subject to immediate discharge from the fire rescue department upon the
recommendation of the fire rescue chief. (Ord. 99-993, 9-27-1999)
Sec. 3-33: MEMBERSHIP.
All members of the Northfield fire rescue department except fire rescue chief shall be selected and appointed by the fire rescue chief, subject to the
approval of the village manager. The fire rescue chief may suspend from duty or discharge any of such members, subject to the approval of the village
manager. A written report of any such suspension or discharge shall be made to the village manager within twenty four (24) hours of the action. The village
manager shall in turn report any such suspension or discharge to the corporate authorities at the next scheduled meeting. (Ord. 99-993, 9-27-1999)
Sec. 3-34: COMPENSATION OF MEMBERS.
The members of the Northfield fire rescue department shall be compensated only for services rendered in connection with attending the extinguishing of
fires, answering fire alarms or alerts, answering emergency calls, answering or responding to calls for emergency medical services, performing emergency
medical services, attending training sessions, routine maintenance of equipment, apparatus and buildings, and such other functions as may be authorized
by the fire rescue chief which are reasonably related to fire prevention, fire protection and/or emergency medical services. Such compensation shall be in
accordance with an appropriate wage schedule as approved by the corporate authorities, and shall comply with all requirements of this code and any other
applicable statutory provisions. (Ord. 99-993, 9-27-1999)
Sec. 3-35: ELECTION OF OFFICERS.
The members of the fire rescue department shall have an annual election of officers on the first Monday in October. This election of officers shall not be an
encroachment upon the power and authority granted to the fire rescue chief pursuant to this code. (Ord. 99-993, 9-27-1999)
Sec. 3-36: TAX ON FOREIGN FIRE INSURANCE COMPANIES.
On or before July 15 of each year, every corporation, company, provider and/or association not incorporated under the laws of the state, but engaged in
the provision of fire insurance within the village, shall pay to the finance director for the maintenance, use and benefit of the fire rescue department, an
amount equal to two percent (2%) of the gross receipts collected during the preceding twelve (12) month period ending on July 1 of that year from fire
insurance on properties situated within the village. It shall be unlawful for any foreign fire insurance company to transact any business of fire insurance
within the village while in default of this section. However, such default shall not relieve or otherwise excuse any company from the payment of any risk
that may be undertaken or incurred in violation of this section. (Ord. 99-993, 9-27-1999)
Sec. 3-37: DEPARTMENT FOREIGN FIRE INSURANCE TAX BOARD.
A. The village of Northfield foreign fire insurance tax board (the "board") is hereby created to consist of five (5) members. Five (5) officers shall comprise
the board and shall be elected from all members of the village fire rescue department and shall have full voting privileges on any matter before the
board. Each such officer shall hold one of the following titles:
(1) President
(2) Vice president
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=886 30/377
(3) Treasurer
(4) Secretary
(5) Assistant secretary
The officers of the board shall be filled by election by the members of the village fire rescue department. In addition to the officers as provided above,
the fire rescue chief of the Northfield fire rescue department or his/her designee shall be an ex officio member of the board, unless otherwise elected
to the board at an election held in accordance with the provisions of this section. As an ex officio member, the fire rescue chief shall not have any
voting privileges, but shall have the right to participate in all open or closed session discussions regarding the management of foreign fire insurance
tax funds, preparation of annual budgets, or any other matter within the scope of the powers and duties of the board and notice of any regular or
special meeting in the same manner given to any voting member.
B. The term "member" as used in this section shall mean any nonprobationary member in good standing, including firefighters, paramedics and
emergency medical technicians, paid-on-call firefighter, or officer of the village fire rescue department, including the fire rescue chief and all promoted
positions. No probationary member of the department may hold an office during the period of his/her probation.
C. The initial election of the board shall be held prior to December 31, 1999, and shall be held in odd numbered years thereafter. Officers shall take office
on January 1 and shall serve up to and including December 31 two (2) years thereafter. The terms for all officers shall be two (2) years. The initial
election shall be held in accordance with guidelines and procedures established by the village attorney and, thereafter, the board shall adopt any and
all necessary rules and regulations governing the nomination and election of such officers for subsequent elections.
D. A village fire rescue department foreign fire insurance tax fund (the "fund") is hereby created and all revenue received by the village from the foreign fire
insurance tax shall be deposited in the fund and shall be held and expended in accordance with the following procedures:
(1) The treasurer of the board shall provide to the village finance director an annual accounting of receipts and expenditures of the fund.
(2) By December 31 of each year, the officers of the board shall approve a preliminary budget for the expenditure of funds received pursuant to the
foreign fire insurance tax. The officers of the board shall, no later than April 1, adopt a final budget for the collection and expenditure of the foreign
fire insurance tax, to be approved by ordinance by the president and board of trustees of the village in order to comply with the statutory mandate of
a prior appropriation for all expenditures. The final budget may be amended at any time by a majority vote of the officers of the board with the
concurrence of the president and board of trustees consistent with established practice. Expenditures shall be made only for items specifically
described in the final budget as originally adopted or subsequently amended.
(3) The board shall have the power to approve the expenditure of monies from the fund for the maintenance, use, and benefit of the department. Any
expenditure in excess of five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) shall be subject to the approval of the president and board of trustees; provided, however,
that said expenditure shall be approved if it is for the maintenance, use, and benefit of the department.
(4) Any expenditure made from the fund shall be made in accordance with the village rules and regulations, practices, and ordinances, as may be
amended from time to time, which govern the procurement of goods and services.
(5) No expenditure shall be made from the fund without approval of the board.
(6) The board treasurer shall give a bond in an amount equal to three (3) times the amount of foreign fire insurance tax revenue to the president and
board of trustees of the village to ensure the treasurer's faithful execution and performance of his/her duties as imposed by law and by board rules
and regulations. Any fees for said bond shall be paid from funds collected pursuant to the foreign fire insurance tax.
(7) The board treasurer shall be responsible for paying the service charge levied by the Illinois municipal league for the collection of the foreign fire
insurance tax from the proceeds of the foreign fire insurance tax; provided, however, that such charge is chargeable pursuant to state law, and
further provided that such charge has not already been retained by the Illinois municipal league prior to disbursement of the foreign fire insurance
tax.
E. The board shall, in accordance with the open meetings act, establish a regular time and place for its meetings. The board president shall preside at the
meetings. The board secretary shall keep a record of all resolutions, proceedings, and actions of the board, and these records shall be open to the
public. Three (3) members of the board shall be sufficient to constitute approval of business before the board. Special meetings, with appropriate
notice, may be called by the president or by no less than three (3) members of the board.
F. The board may promulgate written rules and regulations governing board matters so long as such rules and regulations are not inconsistent with any
applicable law. All rules and regulations promulgated by the board must be approved by a majority of the president and board of trustees of the village
in the same manner as for the passage of village ordinances. All rules and regulations shall be available in each fire rescue station. Such rule or
regulation shall be filed with the village clerk and shall be made available for public inspection. Rules or regulations of the board shall become effective
when the ordinance approved by the president and the board of trustees of the village becomes law. The board secretary shall maintain a record of all
board rules and regulations, which shall be available for public inspection.
G. At no time shall the actions of the board or its officers interfere with the rights of the fire rescue chief, or the composition of the village fire rescue
department, or in any way impede the normal and regular operation of the Northfield fire rescue department. (Ord. 99-993, 9-27-1999)
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=886 31/377
Sec. 3-38: CHARGES.
Any fees imposed in relation to the provision of emergency medical services shall be as prescribed in appendix D of this code. (Ord. 99-993, 9-27-1999)
Division III - The Fire Prevention Bureau
Sec. 3-39: CREATION OF THE FIRE PREVENTION BUREAU.
A bureau of fire prevention is hereby established in the Northfield fire rescue department. The fire prevention bureau shall be operated under the
supervision of the fire rescue chief. The fire rescue chief may designate a member of the fire rescue department as official of the fire prevention bureau
("fire official") or he may hold this office himself. The fire rescue chief may designate other members of the fire rescue department as inspectors. The fire
rescue chief may employ technical fire inspectors as may be authorized by the village manager. (1986 Code; amd. Ord. 99-993, 9-27-1999)
Sec. 3-40: ENFORCE LAWS AND ORDINANCES.
It shall be the duty of the bureau of fire prevention to enforce all provisions of the village's fire prevention code, life safety code and building code as
approved by the corporate authorities. (1986 Code)
Sec. 3-41: INVESTIGATE CAUSE OF FIRES.
The bureau of fire prevention shall investigate the cause, origin and circumstances of every fire occurring in the village involving loss of life or injury to
person or damage to property. To the extent possible, the fire prevention bureau shall determine whether the fire is a result of negligence or design. Such
investigation shall be commenced immediately upon the occurrence of such a fire. If it appears that the fire is of suspicious origin, the fire rescue chief
shall be notified immediately; the fire rescue chief shall take charge of the physical evidence, notify the director of public safety of the investigation of such
matters and cooperate with another duly authorized investigation and prosecution of the case. (1986 Code; amd. Ord. 99-993, 9-27-1999)
Sec. 3-42: ISSUE PERMITS, CERTIFICATES, NOTICES, APPROVALS, ORDERS.
The fire prevention bureau may issue permits, certificates, notices, approvals and other orders pertaining to fire control and fire or life hazards as provided
in appendix C of this code. (1986 Code)
Sec. 3-43: REVIEW PLANS AND CONSTRUCTION.
The fire prevention bureau shall assist the building department in reviewing the planning, design and construction of new buildings, building alterations and
building additions to provide appropriate egress facilities, fire protection and built-in fire protection equipment as required by village codes and ordinances.
(1986 Code)
Sec. 3-44: PUBLIC EDUCATION.
The fire prevention bureau may initiate within the fire rescue department the development of informational and instructional programs to village residents
concerning the prevention of fires and fire safety practices. (1986 Code; amd. Ord. 99-993, 9-27-1999)
Sec. 3-45: INSPECTIONS.
The fire prevention bureau shall inspect all structures and premises, except single-family and duplex dwelling units as often as may be necessary for the
purpose of ascertaining and causing to be corrected any conditions liable to cause fire, contribute to the spread of fire, interfere with firefighting operations,
endanger life or any violations of the provisions or intent of village codes and ordinances affecting fire safety. (1986 Code)
Sec. 3-46: RECORDS.
The fire prevention bureau shall keep a record of all inspections, complaints, fire protection systems installed within the village and other information as
required by the fire rescue chief and state and federal law. (1986 Code; amd. Ord. 99-993, 9-27-1999)
Sec. 3-47: FEES.
The corporate authorities may establish such fees as may be necessary for the permits, certificates, approvals, plan reviews and other functions to be
performed under appendix C of this code. Such fees shall be payable to the village and shall accompany each application for such permit, approval,
certificate or other fee-related code provision. Such fees shall be in an amount set forth in appendix D of this code. (1986 Code)
Sec. 3-48: REPORTS.
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=886 32/377
The annual report of the fire rescue department shall be made on or before April 30 and be transmitted to the village manager. It shall report all fires, fire
losses, fire prevention activities, the status and condition of fire equipment and other information and statistics as the fire rescue chief may wish to include
or as may be required by the village manager. (1986 Code; amd. Ord. 99-993, 9-27-1999)
Division IV - The Emergency Medical Service
(Rep. by Ord. 99-993, 9-27-1999)
Division V - Health Department
Sec. 3-58: CREATION.
A health department is hereby established for the village to operate under the direction and supervision of the village health officer. The health department
shall be staffed with such personnel and perform such duties and functions as the village manager may from time to time assign. (1986 Code)
Sec. 3-59: HEALTH OFFICER.
There is hereby created the position of health officer, an administrative officer of the village. The health officer shall be a person suitably trained or
experienced in public health administration, and shall be appointed by the village manager and be subject to removal by him.
At such time or times as this village shall have a health department, he shall be head of the health department, and shall be responsible to the village
manager for the efficient administration of the department's services to said village.
Whenever in this code detailed duties and responsibilities of the department of health are prescribed and the term "health officer" is used, it shall be
understood to include not only that officer but any member of the department's staff assigned to act in his stead.
The health officer shall be an ex officio chief health inspector. The salary of the health officer shall be fixed by the village manager subject to the approval
of the corporate authorities. (1986 Code)
Sec. 3-60: DUTIES AND POWERS.
It shall be the duty of the health officer to execute and enforce all statutes, all ordinances of the village, and all rules and regulations related to the health of
residents of Northfield. He shall take such action as is necessary for the determination of the status of and the promotion and improvement of the public
health, not inconsistent with the state statutes, and ordinances, rules and regulations. The health officer shall accept appointment as a registrar as
provided by state statute and shall execute the duties required by that statute. He shall also collect and keep records pertaining to environmental sanitation
matters related to the public health. (1986 Code)
Sec. 3-61: PROCEDURE IN CASE OF VIOLATIONS.
The health officer shall have the right to issue citations for violations of health ordinances or regulations pursuant to the provisions of this code, state law
and court rule. (1986 Code)
Sec. 3-62: DEPUTY BUILDING COMMISSIONER.
The health officer is hereby made a deputy building commissioner. It shall be and is hereby made his duty to aid the superintendent of public works in
administering and enforcing the provision of this code and other building ordinances pertaining to health, sanitation, and home safety. (1986 Code)
Sec. 3-63: REPORTS AND RECORDS.
The health officer shall at suitable intervals or at the request of the village manager submit a written report detailing pertinent information and
recommendations. He shall maintain records of all services performed by and for the village. (1986 Code)
ARTICLE IV. NORTHFIELD EMERGENCY SERVICES AND DISASTER AGENCY
Sec. 3-64: ESTABLISHMENT.
There is hereby created the Northfield emergency services and disaster agency (ESDA) to prevent, minimize, repair, and alleviate injury or danger
resulting from disaster caused by enemy attack, sabotage, or other hostile action or from natural disaster, in accordance with "the Illinois emergency
services and disaster act of 1975".
The ESDA shall consist of a director and additional members as selected by the director. (1986 Code)
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=886 33/377
Sec. 3-65: DIRECTOR.
The director of the Northfield ESDA shall be the village manager unless some other person is appointed by the corporate authorities and shall serve until
removed by the majority vote of the corporate authorities.
The director shall have direct responsibility for the organization, administration, training, and operation of the ESDA, subject to the direction and control of
the village president as provided by statute.
In the event of the absence, resignation, death, or inability to serve of the director, the village president or any person designated by him shall be and act
as director until a new appointment is made as provided in this article. (1986 Code)
Sec. 3-66: FUNCTIONS.
The Northfield ESDA shall perform such ESDA functions as shall be prescribed by the state ESDA plan, and such orders, rules, and regulations as may be
promulgated by the governor. In addition he shall perform such duties outside the corporate limits as may be required pursuant to any mutual aid
agreement with any other political subdivision, municipality, or quasi-municipalities entered into as provided by the "state ESDA act of 1975".
The Northfield ESDA shall also, when called upon by the village president, take steps to prevent, minimize, repair, and alleviate injury or damage resulting
from any explosion, accident or other disaster occurring in the municipality including rendering such service in a disaster due to natural causes, hostile
action, or explosion of bombs or missiles. (1986 Code)
Sec. 3-67: SERVICE AND COMPENSATION, MOBILE SUPPORT TEAM.
Any or all members of the Northfield ESDA organization may volunteer for and be appointed by the director as members of a mobile support team, created
by the coordinator of the state ESDA, as provided by law. All such appointments of officers or employees of the village of Northfield shall first be approved
by a majority of the corporate authorities. The leader of such mobile support team shall be designated by the director.
Any person thus appointed to a mobile support team may receive from the state of Illinois such reasonable compensation as may be provided by state law,
or as may hereafter be provided by the village of Northfield. (1986 Code)
Sec. 3-68: AGREEMENTS WITH OTHER POLITICAL SUBDIVISIONS.
The director of the Northfield ESDA may negotiate mutual aid agreements with other municipal corporations or political subdivisions of the state, but no
such agreement shall be effective until it has been approved by the corporate authorities and by the state coordinator of ESDA. (1986 Code)
Sec. 3-69: EMERGENCY ACTION.
If the governor declares that a disaster emergency exists in the event of actual enemy attack upon the United States or the occurrence within the state of
Illinois of major disaster resulting from enemy sabotage or other hostile action, or from natural disaster, it shall be the duty of the Northfield ESDA to
cooperate fully with the state ESDA and with the governor in the exercise of emergency powers as provided by law. (1986 Code)
Sec. 3-70: SERVICE AND COMPENSATION FOR STATE TRAINING.
Any and all members of the Northfield ESDA may volunteer for and be appointed by the director as participants in any training program established by the
state coordinator of the ESDA, provided that all such appointments of officers or employees of the village of Northfield shall first be approved by a majority
of the corporate authorities.
Any officer or employee of the village of Northfield who is thus approved for appointment and is appointed to participate in any such state training program
shall continue to receive full compensation incident to his or her usual office or employment.
Any person thus appointed to participate in any such state training program who is not a village officer or employee may receive from the state of Illinois
such reasonable compensation as may be hereafter provided by the village of Northfield. (1986 Code)
Sec. 3-71: REIMBURSEMENT BY STATE.
The treasurer of the state of Illinois may allocate to the village of Northfield any reimbursement by the state of Illinois to the village for expenses incident to
training members of the Northfield ESDA, compensation for services and expenses of members of a mobile support team while serving outside of the
village in response to a call by the governor or state coordinator of ESDA as provided by law and any other reimbursement made by the state of Illinois
incident to ESDA activities. (1986 Code)
Sec. 3-72: PURCHASES AND EXPENDITURES.
The corporate authorities may, on recommendation of the municipal director of NESDA, authorize any purchases or contracts necessary to place the
municipality in a position to meet effectively any disaster arising from war or natural causes.
In the event of enemy caused or natural disaster, the director of NESDA is authorized, on behalf of the municipality, to procure such services, supplies,
equipment, or materials as may be necessary for such purposes, in view of the exigency, without regard to the statutory procedures or formalities normally
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=886 34/377
prescribed by law pertaining to municipal contracts or obligations, as authorized by "the state ESDA act of 1975", provided that if the corporate authorities
meet at such time, the director shall act subject to the directions and restrictions imposed by that body. (1986 Code)
Sec. 3-73: OATH.
Every person appointed to serve in any capacity in the Northfield ESDA shall, before entering upon his duties, subscribe to the following oath, which shall
be filed with the coordinator:
I, , of the ESDA of the Village of Northfield, do solemnly swear (or affirm) that I will support and defend and bear true faith and allegiance to the
Constitution of the United States and the Constitution of the State of Illinois, and the territory, institutions and facilities, thereof, both public and private,
against all enemies, foreign and domestic; that I take this obligation freely, without any mental reservation or purpose of evasion; and that I will well and
faithfully discharge the duties upon which I am about to enter, and I do further swear (or affirm) that I do not advocate, nor am I nor have I been a member
of any political party or organization that advocates the overthrow of the government of the United States nor of this State by force or violence; and that
during such time as I am affiliated with the ESDA of the Village of Northfield, I will not advocate nor become a member of any political party or organization
that advocates the overthrow of the government of the United States or of this State by force or violence.
(1986 Code)
Sec. 3-74: OFFICE.
The village president is authorized to designate space in the village hall or elsewhere, as may be provided for by the village board for the Northfield ESDA
as its office.
In the event that the incumbent of any municipal office shall be rendered incapable of performing the duties of such office as a result of a disaster within
the scope of this article, such office shall be filled until such time as a successor can be selected in the manner prescribed by law as follows: appointment
shall be in the following order of preference: village president, remaining members of the board by seniority, village manager, clerk, director of public
service, chief of police, chief of the fire department, director of the emergency medical service, and director of public works. (1986 Code; amd. Ord. 98-
928, 2-23-1998)
ARTICLE V. DEPARTMENT OF COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT AND BUILDING
Sec. 3-75: COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT DIRECTOR.
The community development director and the department of community development and building shall be responsible for the enforcement of the zoning
ordinance1. In addition, he and the department shall perform the following functions:
(1) Conduct inspections of buildings, structures, and uses of land to determine compliance with the terms of the zoning ordinance of the village; enforce
village ordinances pertaining to signage, subdivision and floodplain regulation.
(2) Maintain permanent and current records pertaining to zoning administration, including, but not limited to, zoning maps, amendments, special uses,
variations, appeals and applications therefor.
(3) Serve as liaison with residents, prospective builders and developers; advise such parties of the building and zoning requirements of the village and
assist them with the application process to and appearances before the architectural commission, plan and zoning commission, and the zoning
board of appeals. Provide staff support, as village staff liaison, for the architectural commission, plan and zoning commission, zoning board of
appeals, and the planning, zoning and community development committee of the board of trustees. This includes attending meetings and supplying
commission and boardmembers with required information pertaining to the issues and petitions before such bodies.
(4) Responsible for the publication of all required notices of public hearings relating to variations or amendments to the zoning ordinance. Review and
revise the village comprehensive land use plan as directed by the corporate authorities.
(5) Receive, file and forward to the board of appeals applications for variations under the zoning ordinance.
(6) Receive, file and forward to the plan and zoning commission, and to the architectural commission, all applications involving matters appropriately
referable to these bodies.
(7) Review all property which has been the subject of legal action invalidating the zoning as applied by the existing zoning ordinance and recommend,
as appropriate, an amendment for reclassification of such property to the plan and zoning commission.
(8) Determine, and disseminate to the public, the use, lot, bulk, and other zoning requirements of buildings.
(9) Initiate, direct, and review, from time to time and at the request of the corporate authorities, a study of the provisions of the zoning ordinance and
make recommendations to the planning, zoning and community development committee of the board of trustees.
(10) Issue building, plumbing and electrical permits with the assistance of the building commissioner for the construction, repair and removal of all
buildings and other structures within the village; issue occupancy permits and enforce all ordinances relating thereto.
(a) Application For Building Permit: Every application for a permit for the erection, construction, alteration or repair of any building or structure
shall be accompanied by three (3) sets of plans, together with a detailed statement written upon blank applications furnished by the building
commissioner, regarding the location of the proposed operation, a full description of said building or structure or part thereof, its proposed use, and
the estimated cost of the work. This statement shall be signed by the owner or his agent. Plans may be retained by the building commissioner for a
reasonable time for inspection before a permit is issued.
1. No permit shall be granted or plans approved unless such plans are signed by the owner or signed and sealed by a licensed architect.
2. No permit shall be granted or plans approved unless all required permits from all tradesmen are received.
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=886 35/377
3. It shall be unlawful for any architect, or other person permitted under state law, to submit for approval any final plans for any building or structure
which do not comply with the structural requirements of this code. All final plans submitted for approval of any building or structure shall be
accompanied by a certificate of such architect or other person preparing plans affirming that the plans and specifications submitted comply with
the structural requirements of this code.
4. The commissioner may require detailed drawings of any part or parts of the building, specifications, and a property survey.
(b) Changes In Plans And Specifications:
1. No changes in plans or specifications shall be made without first filing an amendment to the original application and securing the approval of the
building commissioner.
2. After plans for any proposed work have been approved, one set of such plans shall be filed and kept in the office of the building commissioner,
and another set of such plans, with the approval of the commissioner stamped or written thereon, shall at all times be kept on or about the
building or other structure to be erected.
(c) Supervise the construction, erection, alteration, maintenance, repair, removal and inspection of all buildings, walls, structures or portions thereof
and all appurtenances related thereto, within the village, and enforce all ordinances relating thereto.
(d) Supervise the construction, installation, alteration, repair and inspection of all installations and house connections to sewers within the village,
and enforce all ordinances relating thereto.
(e) Supervise either alone or in conjunction with the fire official, the construction, erection, installation, alteration, repair, removal, and inspection of all
tanks or containers for the storage or use of inflammable liquids within the village as regulated by this code.
(11) Keep records of all requests for permits, reviews, hearings or inspections received by the department of community development and building.
(12) Perform such other duties as may be assigned by the village manager. (Ord. 98-928, 2-23-1998)
Footnote 1: The zoning ordinance is found in appendix A to this code.
Title Chapter 4
BOARDS AND COMMISSIONS
Chapter 4
BOARDS AND COMMISSIONS
ARTICLE I. IN GENERAL
Sec. 4-1: GENERAL PROVISIONS FOR ALL BOARDS AND COMMISSIONS.
Except as otherwise provided in this code, the following shall be applicable to all boards and commissions:
(1) Each member of any board or commission shall be a resident of the village as required by section 2-3 of this code.
(2) All members shall be appointed by the village president with the approval of the board of trustees.
(3) The chairman of each board or commission, unless otherwise stated herein, shall be appointed by the village president with the approval of the
board of trustees.
(4) A vice chairman may be elected by each respective board and commission.
(5) Each member shall hold office until his or her successor has been appointed and has qualified.
(6) If the establishment section for any board or commission provides that certain members must possess certain qualifications, then persons
designated as members fulfilling those requirements shall cease to be members if they should cease to possess such qualifications.
(7) Any member may be removed for cause upon due notice by the village president with the approval of the board of trustees.
(8) Vacancies shall be filled for unexpired terms only.
(9) A majority of the members as designated by the establishment section shall constitute a quorum and a concurring vote of a majority of members
present is necessary in order for the board or commission to take affirmative action or to make a recommendation.
(10) Each board and commission shall keep minutes of each meeting and a secretary may be elected or the village manager or his designate may act
as secretary. Reports of each meeting shall be submitted to the corporate authorities.
(11) All meetings shall be open and public, subject to section 1-12 of this code.
(12) Each commission or board may adopt such administrative rules, not inconsistent with this code, as may be appropriate in the judgment of its
respective membership.
(13) Unless otherwise stated herein, each member of a board or commission shall serve a term of four (4) years or until a successor has been
appointed. Said term shall commence on September 1 of the year in which the appointment is made. Appointments shall be made so that to the
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=886 36/377
extent possible, no more than two (2) terms shall expire in any one year. The village president shall have the authority to adjust the terms of board
and commission members for the purpose of maintaining the required number of members and providing for the efficient transition of members.
(14) In addition to the number of members of each board and commission set forth in this chapter, the president may appoint a member of the board of
trustees to be a member ex officio of a board or commission. Such member ex officio shall be entitled to take part in the discussion of issues, but
shall not be entitled to a vote.
(15) All members of boards and commissions shall serve without compensation.
(16) All boards and commissions are subject to the provisions of the Illinois municipal code, as amended. (1986 Code)
ARTICLE II. BOARD OF POLICE COMMISSIONERS
Sec. 4-2: CREATION.
There is hereby created a board of police commissioners consisting of three (3) members, whose terms of office, except as otherwise provided by statute
of the state of Illinois for the first appointees, shall be three (3) years and until their respective successors are appointed and have qualified. The president
shall make no appointment to the board of police commissioners within thirty (30) days before the expiration of his term of office. (1986 Code; amd. Ord.
96-889, 10-28-1996)
Sec. 4-3: QUALIFICATIONS, BOND, REMOVAL OF BOARD MEMBERS.
The members of the board of police commissioners shall be considered officers of the municipality, and shall file an oath and a fidelity bond in such
amount as may be required by the corporate authorities.
No person holding an office under a municipality shall be a member of the board of police commissioners, or the secretary thereof. The acceptance of any
such office by a member of the board shall be treated as a resignation of his office as a member of the board or secretary thereof. No person shall be
appointed as a member of the board of police commissioners who is related, either by blood or marriage up to the degree of first cousin, to any elected
official of the village. No more than two (2) members of the board shall belong to the same political party existing in the village at the time of such
appointment, as defined in chapter 46, section 10-2 of the state of Illinois election code. If only one or no political party exists in the village at the time of
such appointments, then the state or national political party affiliations shall be considered in making such appointments. Party affiliation shall be
determined by the affidavit of the person appointed as a member of the board.
Members shall not be subject to removal, except for cause, upon written charges, and after an opportunity to be heard within thirty (30) days in his or their
own defense, before the corporate authorities. A majority vote of the corporate authorities shall be required to remove such member from office. (1986
Code; amd. Ord. 96-889, 10-28-1996)
Sec. 4-4: APPOINTMENT AND REMOVAL BY BOARD.
The board of police commissioners shall appoint all full time officers of the police department of the village, except the chief of police and exempt
command positions as otherwise specified in this code. All promotions made by the board of police commissioners shall be from the rank next below that
to which the promotion shall be made. Said board shall have sole power of removal over such officers as they shall appoint. (1986 Code; amd. Ord. 96-
889, 10-28-1996)
Sec. 4-5: RULES AND POWERS.
The board of police commissioners shall make such rules and regulations with respect to appointments, promotions and discipline, as are consistent with
chapter 3, article III, division I, "Police Department", of this code, this article, and the Illinois municipal code, as supplemented or modified by the
ordinances of the village pursuant to its home rule authority. The rulemaking authority of the board shall include, without limitation, the authority to
establish procedures, qualifications and standards for the recruitment, testing and selection to the position of police officer of individuals who have been
full time police officers of a state municipal police department and certified by the Illinois law enforcement training standards board as having successfully
completed the minimum standards basic law enforcement course required by that board. (Ord. 11-1495, 8-16-2011)
Sec. 4-6: ELECTION OF CHAIRMAN.
The board of police commissioners shall elect its own chairman to serve during the village fiscal year. (1986 Code; amd. Ord. 96-889, 10-28-1996)
Sec. 4-7: SECRETARY.
The board of police commissioners may employ a secretary or may designate one of its own members to act as such. The secretary shall keep the
minutes of the board's proceedings, shall be custodian of all papers pertaining to the business of the board, shall keep a record of all examinations held,
and shall perform such other duties as the board shall prescribe. (1986 Code; amd. Ord. 96-889, 10-28-1996)
ARTICLE III. POLICE PENSION BOARD
Sec. 4-8: CREATION.
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=886 37/377
There is hereby created a police pension board as provided by statute. (1986 Code)
Sec. 4-9: MEMBERS.
The board shall consist of five (5) members; two (2) of whom shall be appointed by the village president and two (2) of whom shall be elected from the
regular police force and one from the beneficiaries under the police pension fund act as created by statute; the term of such members shall be two (2)
years as is provided by statute. (1986 Code)
Sec. 4-10: DUTIES.
The police pension board shall have the powers and duties delegated to it by statute. (1986 Code)
Sec. 4-11: TERMS.
All terms, definitions and requirements that are within the scope of this article shall be in accordance with 40 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/3-101 et seq.
(1986 Code)
ARTICLE IV. COMMUNITY LIFE COMMISSION
Sec. 4-12: COMMISSION DISBANDED.
The duties of the community life commission, which was disbanded in September 2005, are being handled by other committees of the village board, by
village administration, or by a special committee/commission that would be formed by the corporate authorities as needed, or combinations of the
foregoing as more specifically set out below:
(1) Public health issues involving traffic or public safety are handled by the traffic and transportation committee which reports to the village board, by
village administration and the police department. Specific studies or issues requiring more extensive work could result in the formation of a special
committee/commission.
(2) Environmental duties and issues related to land, water and air preservation and protection of the environment within the village as well as sources
outside, are handled by various village departments. Specific studies or issues requiring more extensive study might result in the formation of a
special committee/commission.
(3) Human relations issues including investigating complaints or alleged disputes involving discrimination in any category; acts requiring mediation and
conciliation or that require hearings to be conducted; and human relations issues that require studying existing and/or potential problems involving
discrimination, will be handled by the formation of a special committee/commission appointed by the village board.
(4) The functions of the Northfield shade tree commission are handled by the village forester and the community development department and guided
by the tree preservation ordinance in chapter 10 of this code. (Ord. 06-1275, 2-21-2006)

ARTICLE VI. ARCHITECTURAL COMMISSION
Sec. 4-18: MEMBERSHIP OF COMMISSION.
The Village Architectural Commission shall consist of seven (7) members. Two (2) of the members shall be licensed architects, if available. (1986 Code)
Sec. 4-19: SECRETARY.
The Building Commissioner shall serve as Secretary of the commission. (1986 Code)
Sec. 4-20: POWERS AND DUTIES.
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=886 38/377
The Architectural Commission shall review and decide the design for the following matters:
(1) Site Plan Review. All nonresidential uses not subject to special use or planned unit development review. (Ord. 03-1147, 2-18-2003)
(2) Signage Review. Review the design of all signage in accordance with chapter 12 of this Code. This shall include requests for variations. (Ord. 03-
1147, 2-18-2003; amd. Ord. 18-1715, 5-15-2018)
(3) Design Review. On any application before the Plan and Zoning Commission, the Architectural Commission shall review the design of the building,
signage, lighting and landscaping only and shall make their recommendation to the Corporate Authorities on these elements.
(4) Fence Variations. Review of fence variations in accordance with chapter 18 of this Code.
(5) Antennas. Review of antenna installations in accordance with chapter 18 of this Code. (Ord. 03-1147, 2-18-2003)
(6) Tennis And Sport Courts. Review of tennis and sport court installations and consideration of variations in accordance with chapter 18 of this
Code. (Ord. 18-1715, 5-15-2018)
(7) Personal Wireless Service Facilities. Review personal wireless service facility installations in accordance with chapter 18 of this Code.
Approvals shall be made in strict conformity with Village regulations. The Architectural Commission shall have no authority to grant exceptions to Village
regulations, except as may be provided in this Code. (Ord. 03-1147, 2-18-2003)
Sec. 4-21: APPLICATION PROCESS.
A. Requirements For Application. An application to appear before the Architectural Commission may be filed with the Community Development and
Building Department by the legal or equitable owner of the subject property, a bona fide contract purchaser or leaseholder. Applications shall be made
on a form provided by the Community Development and Building Department and must be accompanied by all necessary information and exhibits, as
set forth on the application and as required by Village regulations.
B. Notification. The Architectural Commission shall not hold a meeting on any application unless the following notifications have been paid for by the
applicant:
(1) The Village shall post a sign on the subject property for at least fifteen (15) consecutive days prior to the hearing.
(2) The Village shall publish a notice of the application in at least one newspaper having a general circulation in the Village.
(3) On signage or fence variations, the applicant also must send a notification letter to all property owners of record within two hundred fifty feet (250'),
excluding right of way, of the boundary of the property. This notice shall be given not less than fifteen (15) days nor more than thirty (30) days prior to
the hearing. An affidavit certifying that the above notices have been accomplished must be tendered to the department of community development
and building within fifteen (15) days prior to the meeting.
C. Staff Documentation. The village staff shall provide the architectural commission with a detailed report and recommendation relative to the application.
D. Architectural Commission Meeting. The commission shall review the proposed project relative to the appearance of any structure and site
improvements to ensure the exterior materials and colors maintain the appropriate aesthetic relationships and standards of design within the village. As
part of its report, the architectural commission may recommend specific design conditions and limitations regarding architecture, signage, lighting,
landscaping, screening or other matters relating to the purposes and objectives of the village regulations as it deems appropriate to prevent or minimize
adverse effects upon adjacent properties or improvements in the vicinity of the subject property or upon public facilities and services. Such conditions
shall be expressly set forth in the architectural commission's recommendation.
For any review conducted by the architectural commission as part of a plan and zoning commission application, the architectural commission shall be
advisory only and make their recommendation to the corporate authorities. For all other matters before the architectural commission, its review shall be
final.
E. Appeals. In those cases where the owner or architect is unwilling to make the changes required by the architectural commission, the director of
community development and building shall not issue any permits. The owner shall have the right to appeal the decision to the corporate authorities
within thirty (30) days of the last architectural commission hearing at which the owner's proposal was considered. This section shall not be construed to
give a right of appeal in those matters such as fence or sign variations where the architectural commission's determination is final. Appeals for such
variations shall be taken pursuant to the Illinois administrative review act.
F. Fee Schedule. Fees and escrows required for any action requiring architectural commission review shall be as set forth in appendix D of this code and
shall be paid at the time an application is filed. (Ord. 03-1147, 2-18-2003)
Sec. 4-22: MEETINGS.
Meetings of the commission shall be held at the call of the chair and at such other times as the commission, the director of community development and
building or the corporate authorities may determine. All meetings of the commission shall be open to the public. The commission shall keep minutes of its
proceedings, showing the attendance and vote of each member upon each question and shall keep records of its examinations and other official actions,
all of which shall be filed in the office of the village manager and shall be a public record. (Ord. 03-1147, 2-18-2003)
ARTICLE VII. PLAN AND ZONING COMMISSION
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=886 39/377
Sec. 4-23: MEMBERSHIP OF COMMISSION.
The village plan and zoning commission shall consist of not less than nine (9) nor more than eleven (11) members. The exact number of members shall be
as declared by the chairman in writing to the village president, provided that such declaration shall be made within sixty (60) days of the appointment of a
new chairman; and if the number is reduced, such reduction may be accomplished only by attrition through the expiration of existing terms. (Ord. 89-597,
7-25-1989)
Sec. 4-24: TERM.
The initial terms of members shall be staggered so that an approximate equal number of terms expire after the second, third, and fourth years. Thereafter,
all terms shall be for four (4) years or until a successor has been appointed. (Ord. 89-597, 7-25-1989)
Sec. 4-25: TECHNICAL ADVICE.
Technical advice or other services may be obtained and other expenses incurred only upon authorization of the corporate authorities. (Ord. 89-597, 7-25-
1989)
Sec. 4-26: POWERS AND DUTIES.
A. To prepare and recommend appropriate changes or revisions to the comprehensive official plan and map as enacted on August 13, 1958, and recorded
September 26, 1958, as document no. 17329867 in the recorder's office of Cook County, Illinois, and as subsequently amended from time to time.
Such proposed changes may include: 1) standards of design for subdivisions and for resubdivision of unimproved land and of areas subject to
redevelopment in respect to public improvements; 2) recommended requirements governing the location, width, course, and surfacing of public streets
and highways, alleys, ways for public service facilities, curbs, gutters, sidewalks, streetlights, parks, playgrounds, school grounds, other public grounds,
size of lots to be used for residential purposes, storm sewers and sewage collection and treatment; 3) annexation of suitable land to the village of
Northfield; and 4) jurisdictional boundary lines between the village of Northfield and other municipalities whose limits lie within one and one-half (11/2)
miles at any point from the limits of the village of Northfield.
B. To prepare and recommend to the corporate authorities plans for specific improvements in furtherance of the official plan and map.
C. To give aid as requested to village officials charged with directing projects for improvements embraced within the official plan and map.
D. To generally promote the realization of the official plan.
E. To act as a zoning commission in accordance with section 11-13-2 of the Illinois municipal code1 only upon appointment by the corporate authorities.
F. To act as a plan commission pursuant to section 11-12-4 of the Illinois municipal code2, to hear applications for subdivisions, resubdivisions, zoning map
changes, appendix A text changes, special uses and planned unit developments.
G. To exercise such other jurisdiction germane to the powers granted by this article, as may be conferred by the corporate authorities, including particularly
those powers conferred by any ordinance establishing subdivision regulations, and other ordinances and official records from time to time comprising
and implementing the official plan and map.
H. To prepare and recommend to the corporate authorities schemes for regulating or forbidding structures or activities which may hinder access to solar
energy necessary for the proper functioning of solar energy systems, as defined in section 1.2 of the comprehensive solar energy act of 1977, or to
recommend changes in such schemes.
I. To hold a public hearing and make a recommendation to the corporate authorities on planned unit developments, special uses, and subdivisions and to
attend to any other duties set forth in appendix A or appendix B of this code.
J. To attend to any other duties assigned by the corporate authorities.
As part of any of the above matters the plan and zoning commission may also consider and recommend to the corporate authorities relief from the
strict application of appendix A when considering a petition for resubdivision, special use or planned unit development. (Ord. 03-1146, 2-18-2003)
Sec. 4-27: AMENDMENTS TO OFFICIAL PLAN AND MAP INITIATED BY THE CORPORATE AUTHORITIES.
Upon submission by the corporate authorities of any suggested amendment to the official plan and map to the plan and zoning commission for
consideration and recommendation, the corporate authorities may require a report thereon from the plan and zoning commission with its recommendation
within ninety (90) days. Should the plan and zoning commission fail to make such report within ninety (90) days, then the corporate authorities may
proceed to consider such amendment for adoption, including arranging for and holding of a public hearing thereon in accordance with the provisions
hereinafter contained in the same manner as if the plan and zoning commission had made its recommendation. (Ord. 89-597, 7-25-1989)
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=886 40/377
Sec. 4-28: AMENDMENTS TO OFFICIAL PLAN AND MAP INITIATED BY THE PLAN AND ZONING COMMISSION.
Upon submission by the plan and zoning commission to the corporate authorities of a proposed amendment to the official plan and map, the corporate
authorities shall schedule a public hearing thereon before the plan and zoning commission. Not less than fifteen (15) days' notice of the proposed hearing,
and the time and place thereof, shall be given by publication in a newspaper of general circulation within Cook County or within the area thereof located
within one and one-half (11/2) miles of the limits of the village of Northfield. The hearing shall be informal, but all persons desiring to be heard in support, or
opposition to the amendment shall be afforded a reasonable opportunity to be heard, and may submit their statements orally or in writing, or both. The
hearing may be recessed to another date, if notice of the time and place thereof is publicly announced at the hearing or is given by newspaper publication
not less than five (5) days prior to the new hearing date. Within ninety (90) days after the conclusion of the hearing, the corporate authorities, after
considering the plan and zoning commission's recommendations and the information gathered at the hearing, shall either adopt the amendment in whole
or in part or reject the entire amendment. If adopted, the corporate authorities shall enact an ordinance amending the official plan and map. If at the
expiration of such ninety (90) days, the corporate authorities have taken no formal action, the amendment thereto may thereafter not be acted upon by the
corporate authorities without again complying with the conditions of notice of hearing hereinabove provided. (Ord. 89-597, 7-25-1989)
Sec. 4-29: APPLICATION PROCESS.
A. Requirements For Application. An application to appear before the plan and zoning commission may be filed with the community development and
building department by the legal or equitable owner of the subject property or a bona fide contract purchaser. Applications shall be made on a form
provided by the community development and building department and must be accompanied by all necessary information and exhibits, as set forth on
the application and as required by village regulations.
B. Notification. The plan and zoning commission shall not hold a hearing on any application unless the following notifications have been both
accomplished and paid for the applicant:
(1) The applicant shall provide notice of the application by registered or certified mail, return receipt requested, to the owner or occupant of all
properties located within two hundred fifty feet (250'), excluding rights of way, of the subject property. This notice shall be given not less than fifteen
(15) days nor more than thirty (30) days prior to the hearing. An affidavit certifying that the above notices have been sent must be tendered to the
department of community development and building within fifteen (15) days prior to the meeting. With respect to condominiums and nonresidential
properties, the notice requirements of section 4-36 of this chapter shall apply.
(2) A sign shall be posted by the village on the subject property for at least fifteen (15) consecutive days prior to the hearing.
(3) A notice of the application shall be published, by the village, in at least one newspaper having a general circulation in the village. This notice must
contain the same information as that required in the mailings. This notice must be published within three (3) days of the original mailing. The director
of community development and building shall determine whether to use a common address, intersection designation or legal description in the
newspaper notice.
C. Staff Documentation. The village staff shall provide the plan and zoning commission with a detailed report and staff recommendation relative to the
application.
D. Plan And Zoning Commission Hearing. The commission shall have ninety (90) days in which to make a report regarding the proposed application's
conformance with village regulations, the effect upon the character of the neighborhood, traffic conditions, public utility facilities and other matters
pertaining to the public health, public safety and general welfare. No action shall be taken by the corporate authorities upon any application until the
report of the plan and zoning commission has been filed. However, if no report is received from the commission within the ninety (90) days, the
approval of the commission shall be assumed. Before submitting the report, the plan and zoning commission shall hold at least one public hearing. Due
notice of the time and place of the hearing shall be given as required by law and the above stated standards.
As part of their report to the corporate authorities, the plan and zoning commission may recommend specific conditions and limitations concerning use,
construction, character, location, landscaping, screening and other matters related to the purposes and objectives of this code as it deems necessary
or appropriate to prevent or minimize adverse effects upon other property or improvements in the vicinity of the subject property or upon public facilities
and services. Such conditions shall be expressly set forth in the recommendation to the corporate authorities.
E. Village Board Of Trustees Approval. Final approval of any application shall be reserved to the corporate authorities. The corporate authorities may
also impose such other restrictions and conditions, as are in harmony with the general purpose and intent of village regulations and the village's
adopted comprehensive plan. Violation of any such condition or limitation shall be a violation of this code and shall constitute grounds for revocation of
the approval of the requested action by the corporate authorities.
F. Fee Schedule. Fees and escrows required for any action requiring plan and zoning commission review shall be as set forth in appendix D of this code
and shall be paid at time of application.
G. Appeal. Appeal of any final action of the corporate authorities on a plan and zoning commission recommendation shall be taken pursuant to the Illinois
administrative review act. (Ord. 03-1146, 2-18-2003)
Sec. 4-30: MEETINGS.
Meetings of the plan and zoning commission shall be held at the call of the chair and at such other times as the commission, the director of community
development and building or the corporate authorities may determine. All meetings of the commission shall be open to the public. The commission shall
keep minutes of its proceedings, showing the attendance and vote of each member upon each question and shall keep records of its examinations and
other official actions, all of which shall be filed in the office of the village manager and shall be a public record. (Ord. 03-1146, 2-18-2003)
