granted, the owner, whether the applicant or a successor, shall have six (6) months to connect to the public sanitary sewer. A portion of a lot shall be
deemed to be within five hundred feet (500') if a public or private right of way or easements exist that would permit the connection to be made by the
laying of five hundred feet (500') or less of pipe.
(6) The permit shall become null and void at such time as the system becomes a danger to the health of persons as determined by the health authority
when applying standards established by the federal, state or county government or agency thereof. (Ord. 89-613, 11-28-1989)
Division III - Building Sewers And Connections
Sec. 7-28: SEWER PERMIT REQUIRED.
No person shall uncover, make any connections with, or opening into; use; alter; or disturb any public sewer or appurtenance thereof without first obtaining
a written permit from the village. (Ord. 89-613, 11-28-1989)
Sec. 7-29: SEWER PERMIT REQUIREMENTS.
Application for a sanitary sewer permit shall be made on a special form furnished by the department of community development and building. The permit
application shall be accompanied by three (3) sets of construction plans, specifications and any other information reasonably considered pertinent in the
judgment of the department of community development and building. (Ord. 99-959, 1-25-1999)
Sec. 7-30: SEWER PERMITS, CONNECTIONS AND FEES.
No connection shall be made to the village's sewerage system until application has been made to the department of community development and building
in the name of the licensed plumber who proposes to do the work, a bond for ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) furnished, all fees paid to the village as
required by appendix D of this code and a permit issued.
A sewer pipe connection from a sewer into an applicant's premises shall be made entirely at the applicant's expense. (Ord. 99-959, 1-25-1999)
Sec. 7-31: DOWNSTREAM CAPACITY REQUIRED.
A building sewer permit will only be issued and a sewer connection shall only be allowed if it can be demonstrated that the downstream sewerage facilities,
including sewers, pump stations and wastewater treatment facilities, have sufficient reserve capacity to adequately and efficiently handle the additional
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=886 72/377
anticipated waste load. It shall be the obligation of the applicant to provide to the village reasonable satisfaction that such capacity is available. (Ord. 89-
613, 11-28-1989)
Sec. 7-32: COST AND INDEMNIFICATION FOR INSTALLATION.
All costs and expenses incident to the installation and connection of the building sewer shall be borne by the owner. The owner shall indemnify the village
from any loss or damage that may be directly or indirectly occasioned by the installation of the sewer. (Ord. 89-613, 11-28-1989)
Sec. 7-33: NEED FOR NEW SEWERS, USE OF EXISTING SEWERS.
A separate and independent building sewer shall be provided for every building, except where one building stands at the rear of another on an interior lot,
and no private sewer is available or where a public sewer cannot be constructed to the rear building through an adjoining alley, court, yard, or driveway.
The building sewer from the front building may be extended to the rear building and the whole considered as one building sewer.
Existing building sewers may be used in connection with new buildings only when they are found, on examination and test by the village engineer, to meet
all the requirements of this article. (Ord. 89-613, 11-28-1989)
Sec. 7-33.1: MAINTENANCE OF PRIVATE SANITARY SEWERS.
Every property owner having a sewer service connected to the village's main line public sewer shall, at his or her own expense, keep and repair all pipes,
accessories, and plumbing fixtures including the Tee, Y, break in connection, lateral, or service at the village's main line sewer to any termination point
inside the property. If such a sewer service is in need of repair, the public works department may, after two (2) days' prior notice posted on the main
entrance to the premises, shut off the water to the premises. When the water is shut off, it shall not be permitted to be turned on again until such pipe,
fixture, or accessory shall be placed in proper repair as determined by the director of public works. If no such corrective measures take place and the
situation is deemed an emergency situation or an imminent hazard by the director of public works, the village shall do what is necessary to make the
repair, and directly bill the property owner and/or impose a lien upon the real estate. This bill shall be no less than the contracted price, or in the case of
the village making the repair, the hourly public works rate as well as equipment rate and any administrative costs that would be applicable. The property
owner shall also pay for the cost for public works to turn on and off water. Any liability imposed by this section shall be a joint and several responsibility of
the owner and the occupant of the premises. (Ord. 01-1092, 12-3-2001; amd. Ord. 02-1129, 10-22-2002)
Sec. 7-34: SEWER ABANDONMENT.
When a building is demolished, all existing sanitary sewer service connections shall be abandoned and removed, and the village sewer shall be repaired
at the expense of the property owner to the reasonable satisfaction of the village engineer. (Ord. 89-613, 11-28-1989)
Sec. 7-35: CONNECTION REQUIREMENTS AND PROHIBITIONS.
The connection of the building sewer into the public sewer shall conform to the requirements of all building and plumbing and all other applicable rules and
regulations of the village. Upon approval of the plumbing inspector, the connection shall conform to the procedures set forth in the appropriate
specifications of the American Society of Testing Materials, "Water Pollution Control Federation Manual Of Practice No. 9", and "Standard Specifications
For Water And Sewer Main Construction In Illinois". All such connections shall be made gastight and watertight. In addition, the following regulations shall
apply: (Ord. 99-959, 1-25-1999)
(1) Overhead Plumbing. All new buildings with basements, floors, rooms or occupancy areas below grade level at the building site shall have
overhead plumbing for both storm and sanitary systems.
(2) Footing Drains. Footing drains shall be connected to sump pumps for further discharge via an overhead system into a storm sewer or a drainage
ditch. No footing drain or drainage tile shall be connected to the sanitary sewer system. All sump basins shall be vented. No wastewater from the
building may be connected to a footing drain or footing drain sump basin.
(3) Pipe Bedding. Bedding, other than concrete embedment, shall consist of crushed gravel, or crushed stone, one-fourth inch (1/4") to one inch (1") in
size. As a minimum, the material shall conform to the requirements of article 704.01 of the standard specifications for road and bridge construction,
of the state of Illinois or ASTM C-33. The gradation shall conform to the gradation CA7, CA8, CA11 or CA13 of the Illinois standard specifications or
to ASTM gradation no. 67. The pipe shall be laid so that it will be uniformly supported and the entire length of the pipe barrel will bear on the bedding.
No blocking of any kind shall be used to adjust the pipe to grade except when blocked with embedment concrete and the remainder of the pipe is in
full contact with the bedding. Bedding shall be required for all sewer construction, and shall be of a minimum thickness equal to one-fourth (1/4) of the
outside diameter of the sewer pipe but shall not be less than four inches (4") deep, and shall extend to the spring line and be fully tamped into place.
When PVC, ABS or other flexible or composite sewer pipe or service is utilized, the bedding material shall extend to twelve inches (12") over the top
of the pipe and be fully tamped into place. (Ord. 89-613, 11-28-1989)
(4) Storm Water Discharge. Downspouts and storm water drains shall not be connected to the sanitary sewer but shall be discharged onto splash
blocks, into a dry well or as otherwise approved, in writing, by the village engineer. Under no circumstances shall the point of discharge be located
less than ten feet (10') from the building wall or closer than fifteen feet (15') from any lot line of the property. On properties where the distance
between the foundation and the adjoining property line is less than fifteen feet (15'), the downspout discharge must be hard piped to the front or rear
of the property, no closer than fifteen feet (15') from the property line. In no case shall any downspout termination be installed in a manner that will
cause additional drainage onto a neighboring property. (Ord. 04-1212, 8-17-2004)
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=886 73/377
(5) Floor Drains. Floor drains in basements shall be connected to sump pumps and discharged to the sanitary sewers. (Ord. 89-613, 11-28-1989)
(6) Sump Pumps. A sump pump shall be used for one function only, either the discharge of storm waters or the discharge of sanitary sewage. Subject
to the following exceptions the discharge point from a ground water or other storm water sump pump shall be located no closer than fifteen feet (15')
from the lot line of the property on which the sump pump is located:
(a) Sanitary sump pumps installed to receive and discharge floor drain flow or other sanitary sewage shall be connected to the sanitary sewers.
(b) Storm water or ground water sump pumps installed to receive and discharge ground waters or other storm water shall be connected to the storm
sewer or shall discharge into a drainage ditch. (Ord. 03-1165, 6-17-2003)
Exceptions: 1) The adjacent property owner has approved the location by written instrument acceptable to the village; provided that the approval of
an adjacent owner shall not be binding on a successor owner; or 2) the village engineer makes a written determination that locating the
discharge point closer than fifteen feet (15') from the property will not increase either the volume or rate of runoff on the adjacent property. In no
case shall any sump pump discharge termination be installed in a manner that will cause additional drainage onto a neighboring property. (Ord.
03-1165, 6-17-2003; amd. Ord. 04-1212, 8-17-2004)
(7) Window Well And Areaway Drains. No window or areaway drains carrying surface runoff or ground water shall be connected to the sanitary
sewer.
(8) Construction Standards. In addition to meeting all other applicable requirements, sanitary sewers shall be SDR26 PVC or CL52DIP. Public
sanitary sewers shall have a minimum internal diameter of eight inches (8"). Sanitary sewer services shall have a minimum internal diameter of six
inches (6"). Joints for sanitary sewers and sanitary sewer services shall be of the compression type in conformance with the specifications of the
American Society for Testing Materials, designation D3212 (PVC) of (DIP). Sidewalls and bases of manholes on sanitary sewers shall be of
reinforced precast concrete ring construction which shall have a five inch (5") minimum thickness. Manhole frames and covers shall be Neenah R-
1015 with a concealed pick hole, gasket seal and "SANITARY" cast on top. Precast flexible rubber sleeves shall be provided for all manhole
connections. Manhole covers to be used in the floodplain shall be a bolt down type (R-1077-B or R-1916-F).
(a) Current MDSGC requirements shall apply, including, but not limited to, requirements for pipe slope and manhole spacing. All PVC pipe shall be
deflection tested. All pipe shall be tested for infiltration.
(b) In cases where a connection is within twelve inches (12") of the manhole, sanitary services shall connect directly to the manhole. All other
connections shall be by WYE connection and shall attach to the pipe with a gasket or glue and bonding. Maximum infiltration shall be 100 gal./in
dia.,/mile/day, tested after service connections are installed.
(c) All sanitary sewer lines shall be placed in a prepared (shaped and compacted) bed of crushed stone. The ratio of the thickness of the crushed
stone bed to the outside diameter of the pipe shall be not more than one to four (1:4). Under no circumstances shall the bed be less than four
inches (4"). The pipe shall be covered at least to the springline with the bedding material constructed as outlined in subsection (3) of this section.
(Ord. 89-613, 11-28-1989)
Sec. 7-36: INSPECTION NOTIFICATION.
The applicant for the building sewer permit shall notify the building department when the building sewer is ready for inspection and connection to the public
sewer. The connection shall be made under the supervision of the building commissioner or his representative. (Ord. 89-613, 11-28-1989)
Sec. 7-37: CONSTRUCTION PROTECTION.
All excavations for building sewer installation shall be adequately guarded with barricades and lights so as to protect the public from hazard. Streets,
sidewalks, trees, bushes, parkways, and other public property disturbed in the course of the work shall be restored in a manner satisfactory to the village.
(Ord. 89-613, 11-28-1989)
Division IV - Use Of Public Sewers
Sec. 7-38: DISCHARGE OF STORM WATER AND UNPOLLUTED DRAINAGE.
No person shall discharge, or cause to be discharged, any storm water, surface water, ground water, roof runoff, subsurface drainage, uncontaminated
cooling water, or unpolluted industrial process waters to any sanitary sewer. Storm water and all other unpolluted drainage shall be discharged to such
sewers as are specifically designated as storm sewers or to a natural outlet approved by the village engineer. Industrial cooling water or unpolluted
process waters may be discharged on approval of the village engineer, to a storm sewer or a natural outlet. (Ord. 89-613, 11-28-1989)
Sec. 7-39: PROHIBITED OR RESTRICTED DISCHARGES.
For purposes of determining those materials or substances the discharge of which into the public sewer is prohibited or restricted; article III sections 1 and
2 of sewerage waste control ordinance as amended July 7, 1988, published by the water reclamation district of greater Chicago are hereby adopted by
reference as though fully set forth herein. (Ord. 89-613, 11-28-1989)
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=886 74/377
Sec. 7-40: SPECIAL INTERCEPTORS REQUIRED.
Any restaurant or nonresidential establishment with a kitchen shall be required to have an outside grease trap. Grease, oil and sand interceptors shall be
provided when, in the opinion of the village engineer they are necessary for the proper handling of liquid wastes containing grease in excessive amounts,
or any flammable wastes, sand, or other harmful ingredients; except that such interceptors shall not be required for private living quarters or dwelling units.
All interceptors shall be of a type and capacity approved by the village engineer and easily accessible for cleaning and inspection.
Where preliminary treatment or flow equalizing facilities are provided, they shall be maintained continuously in satisfactory and effective operation by the
owner at his expense. (Ord. 89-613, 11-28-1989)
Sec. 7-41: INDUSTRIAL CONTROL MANHOLE REQUIREMENT.
All commercial, industrial buildings or multi-family buildings, serving more than six (6) units, shall be required to install an inspection manhole together with
such necessary meters and other appurtenances in the building sewer to facilitate observation, sampling, and measurement of the wastes. Such manhole,
shall be accessible and safely located. The manhole shall be installed by the owner at his expense, and shall be maintained by him so as to be safe and
accessible at all times. (Ord. 89-613, 11-28-1989)
Sec. 7-42: INDUSTRIAL LAB TESTS REQUIRED.
The owner of any property serviced by a building sewer carrying industrial wastes shall provide laboratory measurements, tests, and analyses of waters
and wastes to illustrate compliance with this chapter and any special conditions for discharge established by the village or regulatory agencies having
jurisdiction over the discharge.
The number, type, and frequency of laboratory analyses to be performed by the owner shall be as stipulated by the village, but shall be no less than once
per year. The industry must supply a complete chemical and biological analysis of the components of the wastewater discharge to assure that compliance
with the federal, state, local and the other regulatory standards are being met. The owner shall report the results of measurements and laboratory analyses
to the director of public works at such times and in such manner as prescribed by the village. The owner shall bear the expense of all measurements,
analyses, and reporting required by the village. At such times as deemed necessary, the village reserves the right to take measurements and samples for
analysis by an outside laboratory service. (Ord. 89-613, 11-28-1989; amd. Ord. 99-959, 1-25-1999)
Sec. 7-43: TEST STANDARDS.
All measurements, tests, and analyses of the characteristics of waters and wastes to which reference is made in this chapter shall be determined in
accordance with the latest edition of IEPA "Division of Laboratories Manual of Laboratory Methods", and shall be determined at the inspection manhole
provided, or upon suitable samples taken at said inspection manhole. In the event that no special manhole has been provided, the inspection manhole
shall be considered to be the nearest downstream manhole in the public sewer to the point at which the building sewer is connected. Sampling shall be
carried out by scientifically accepted methods to reflect the effect of constituents upon the sewage works and to determine the existence of hazards to life,
health and property. The particular analyses involved will determine whether a twenty four (24) hour composite of all outfalls of a premises is appropriate
or whether a grab sample or samples should be taken. Normally, but not always, BOD and suspended solids analyses are obtained from twenty four (24)
hour composite of all outfalls, whereas pHs are determined from periodic grab samples. (Ord. 89-613, 11-28-1989)
Division V - Powers And Authority Of Inspectors
Sec. 7-44: ACCESS TO PREMISES.
The Village Engineer, Director of Public Works and Community Development Director or any duly authorized employees of the Village, the State or the
United States Environmental Protection Agency bearing proper credentials and identification, shall be permitted to enter all properties for the purposes of
inspection, observation, measurements, sampling, repair, maintenance and testing in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. (Ord. 99-959, 1-25-
1999)
Division VI - Penalties
Sec. 7-45: NOTICE OF VIOLATION AND PENALTY.
Any person found guilty of a violation of any portion of this chapter shall be fined in accordance with appendix D, article III of this Code. (Ord. 97-915, 10-
27-1997)
In addition to any other penalties set forth herein any violation of this chapter is hereby declared to be a nuisance and may be abated in the manner set
forth in chapter 14 of this Code.
The Village may revoke any permit for sewage disposal as a result of any violation of any provision of this chapter. (Ord. 89-613, 11-28-1989)
ARTICLE III. WATER AND SEWERAGE SERVICE CHARGES AND FINANCES
Sec. 7-46: AUDIT AND ADEQUACY OF CHARGES.
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=886 75/377
The adequacy of the water and sewerage service charges shall be reviewed not less often than annually by certified public accountants for the Village in
their annual report. The wastewater service charge shall be revised periodically to reflect a change in local capital or operation, maintenance and
replacement costs. (Ord. 89-613, 11-28-1989)
Sec. 7-47: ACCOUNTS.
The Village Finance Director shall maintain a proper system of accounts and records. Complete and correct entries shall be made of all transactions
relative to the water and sewerage systems. At regular annual intervals an audit by the certified public accountants for the Village will be made of the
books and the receipts and disbursements of the water and sewerage systems. (Ord. 89-613, 11-28-1989)
Sec. 7-48: QUARTERLY BILLING.
The users of the Village water and sewerage systems shall be billed at least quarterly. Each billing will show the current rates and portion of the current bill
attributable to wastewater operation, maintenance and replacement. (Ord. 89-613, 11-28-1989)
Sec. 7-49: CHARGES BASED ON WATER METER READINGS.
All water shall be charged and paid for on the basis of the amount registered by such meter, except in cases where it shall be found that such meter or
meters are registering incorrectly. In such cases, charges and payment shall be made on an estimate by the Division of Water and Sewerage based on the
average of the four (4) preceding readings of such meter, excluding excessive or deficient readings. No deduction shall be made or rebate allowed to any
consumer of water by or on account of any leakage in any service pipe, connecting pipe, meter, tank or plumbing device.
The Divisions of Water and Sewerage shall keep a record of the readings of all meters for each of the separate premises, and shall read said meters at
intervals prescribed by the Village Manager. The rates herein charged shall apply to all water shown by such readings to have been taken from the
waterworks system during the period covered. (Ord. 89-613, 11-28-1989)
Sec. 7-50: RATES FOR WATER AND SEWERAGE SERVICE.
A. Users in the Village of both water and sewer shall be charged and shall pay rates in accordance with the schedule in appendix D of this Code.
B. In the case of any residence in the Village having only one water meter occupied by two (2) families, the minimum rate for water service to such
residence shall be double the rates set forth in appendix D of this Code.
C. All users in the Village of sewerage service only, shall be charged and shall pay at the rate as required by appendix D of this Code. (Ord. 89-613, 11-28-
1989)
D. Water and sewer services may be provided to consumers residing outside of the Village limits at the Village Board's discretion. The rates for water from
the Village's water system to consumers outside the Village limits shall be twice the rates specified for Northfield residents while the rates for sewer
service shall be three (3) times the rates specified for Northfield residents as set forth in appendix D of this Code. (Ord. 03-1139, 1-21-2003)
Sec. 7-51: UNLAWFUL TO TAMPER WITH THE WATER METER; PENALTY.
It shall be unlawful for any person not authorized by the Village to tamper with, alter or damage any water meters or remote reading device. Any person
found guilty of violating this section shall be fined in accordance with appendix D, article III of this Code. (Ord. 97-915, 10-27-1997)
Sec. 7-52: MINIMUM CHARGE.
The entire minimum rate applicable to water users and the entire rate applicable to users of sewer service only shall be charged and paid for if a premises
is connected to the sewerage and/or water system for any portion of any billing period. (Ord. 89-613, 11-28-1989)
Sec. 7-53: PAYMENT FOR VILLAGE USE.
The Village shall be considered a user and shall be subject to the rates and charges provided by appendix D of this Code. Payment for all such services
shall be made from the corporate funds of the Village into the "Waterworks and Sewerage Fund" in the same manner as other revenues are required to be
deposited. (Ord. 89-613, 11-28-1989)
Sec. 7-54: WHEN AND BY WHOM WATER AND SEWERAGE CHARGES ARE PAYABLE.
Charges for water and/or sewerage service shall become payable immediately upon receipt of the appropriate bill. The owner of the premises, the
occupant thereof, and the user of either water or sewerage service, shall jointly and severally be liable to pay for the service to said premises, and the
service is furnished to the premises by the Village only upon the condition that each of said persons shall be jointly and severally liable therefor. (Ord. 89-
613, 11-28-1989)
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=886 76/377
Sec. 7-55: DELINQUENT CHARGES FOR NONPAYMENT.
In the event charges for water and/or sewerage service are not paid within twenty five (25) days after rendition of the bill for such service, such charges
shall be deemed and are hereby declared to be delinquent. Such delinquent charges shall constitute liens upon the real estate for which said services are
supplied, and the appropriate officers of the Village are hereby authorized to file sworn statements showing such delinquencies in the Office of the
Recorder of Deeds of Cook County. The filing of such statements shall be deemed notice for the payment of such charges for such service. (Ord. 89-613,
11-28-1989; amd. Ord. 07-1348, 10-16-2007)
Sec. 7-56: UNPAID WATER AND SEWERAGE BILLS.
(1) If the water and/or sewerage bills are not paid by the due date, the customer will be required to pay an additional ten percent (10%) of the bill.
(2) If the bill remains unpaid for fifty six (56) days, the customer will be notified that if the bill plus the ten percent (10%) penalty is not paid within four
(4) days, the customer's service will be terminated. (Ord. 00-1014, 3-20-2000)
(3) The placing of a notice that the water and/or sewer service is to be terminated within four (4) days at the front entrance to the building shall be
deemed sufficient notice to permit the Village to terminate said service. The owner of the premises, the occupant, thereof, and the user of either
water and/or sewer will be liable for all costs necessary to terminate said service. (Ord. 89-613, 11-28-1989; amd. Ord. 00-1014, 3-20-2000)
(4) A charge for reinstatement of service shall be made in accordance with appendix D of this code. (Ord. 00-1014, 3-20-2000)
Sec. 7-57: BILLING AND COLLECTION OF CHARGES.
The finance director of the village shall render all bills associated with waterworks or sewerage system services, and shall collect all monies due on these
bills. (Ord. 99-959, 1-25-1999)
Sec. 7-58: REVENUES.
All revenues and monies derived from the operation of the sewerage system shall be deposited in the sewer service charge account of the sanitary sewer
fund. All such revenues and monies shall be held by the finance director separate and apart and clearly identifiable from all other monies of the village.
(Ord. 99-959, 1-25-1999)
Sec. 7-59: ACCESS TO RECORDS.
The IEPA, USEPA, or its authorized representatives shall have access to any books, documents, papers and records of the village during normal business
hours. (Ord. 89-613, 11-28-1989; amd. Ord. 00-1014, 3-20-2000)
Sec. 7-60: RESERVED.
(Ord. 00-1014, 3-20-2000)
ARTICLE IV. STORM WATER MANAGEMENT
Sec. 7-61: PURPOSES.
The purposes of this article are as follows:
(1) To provide an improved method of designing and constructing storm water management facilities, using uniform and consistent standards,
throughout the village.
(2) To lessen or avoid hazards to persons or damage to property resulting from the accumulation or flow of storm water runoff by regulating the manner
in which properties within the village are developed or redeveloped.
(3) To minimize the impact of further development or redevelopment of properties within the village by regulating the amount of storm water runoff
discharged into the storm sewer system as a result of rainfall events.
(4) To minimize the expense to property owners and the general public for future improvements and additions to the sewer system by regulating the
development or redevelopment of properties within the village in such a manner as to avoid erosion of existing land surfaces. (1986 Code)
Sec. 7-62: DEFINITIONS.
When used in this article, the following terms shall have the meanings hereinbelow ascribed to them:
ALLOWABLE RELEASE RATE. The maximum permitted rate of storm water discharge from a site during a 100-year design storm.
BYPASS. A physical means or method by which water flow is passed from an upstream watershed through a site, whether through or around a detention
system.
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=886 77/377
CHANGE IN GRADE. Any excavation of land, including the moving, addition or removal of soil or other fill. This shall not include tilling of soil for gardening
purposes that involves only minor disturbance of topsoil.
CHANGE TO DRAINAGE PATTERN. Any disturbance of the surface or subsurface of property that obstructs or changes the quantity, rate or direction of
the flow of surface water.
COMPENSATORY STORAGE. The volume of floodplain space available for the storage of storm water during a 100-year flood, as defined by the federal
emergency management agency maps and profiles. Compensatory storage compensates for a like volume of storage removed from the floodplain during
site grading or development.
DETENTION. The temporary ponding of runoff achieved by restricting its release from a basin to a limited flow rate (but not zero).
DETENTION BASIN. A basin for storm water storage having a horizontal area with limits as defined by a zone designated as the "detention basin" on plats
or plans submitted to the village. On a single zoning lot, the detention basin may be defined on the plat or the final engineering plans, without benefit of an
easement. The detention basin may have either grass/landscaped surface or paved surface that is generally dry when not used for storm water storage.
FREEBOARD. The vertical elevation difference between high-water level or the emergency storm water release level, whichever is higher (overflow), and
the top of an earthen bank.
ILLINOIS BEARING RATIO (IBR). A measure of the maximum structural load-bearing capacity of the soil structure, based upon standard laboratory tests.
IMPERVIOUS. Any surface improvement which reduces the absorption capability of the existing soil to less than fifty percent (50%), as determined by the
village engineer.
100-YEAR FREQUENCY STORM. A design storm having an intensity duration relationship that has a probability of being equaled or exceeded, on the
average, once in a period of one hundred (100) years, as defined by the Illinois state water survey.
PIPE STORAGE. Storm water detention system utilizing underground pipes as part or all of the detention system.
PUMPED STORAGE. Detention, retention, or compensatory storage basins which require pumping to discharge their live storage volume.
RATIONAL METHOD. The empirical method that relates storm water runoff to rainfall intensity by the formula "Q=CiA" where "Q" is the peak runoff rate in
cubic feet per second (cfs), "C" is the runoff coefficient, "i" is the average rainfall intensity in inches per hour (in./hr.) and "A" is the area of the site in acres
(ac.).
RELEASE RATE. The rate of discharge in cubic feet per second from a detention or retention facility.
RESTRICTOR. The physical mechanism or means for controlling the rate of storm water discharge from a detention or retention basin. Most restrictors are
in the form of pipes, although other forms are possible.
RETENTION BASIN. A basin for storm water storage that functions in the same manner as a detention basin except that a retention basin has a water
surface when not actively storing storm water.
RUNOFF COEFFICIENT. The percentage of precipitation that appears as storm water runoff.
SITE DEVELOPMENT. Site development shall include any changes to the topography of property, including construction of buildings, structures,
installation of impermeable surfaces, excavation or other placement or removal of fill.
STORM SEWER. The minor portion of the overall storm water transmission system which carries storm water and surface water, including round or
elliptical pipes, box sections and other enclosed systems.
STORM SEWER CONNECTING STRUCTURE. Precast reinforced concrete manholes, inlets and catch basins connecting a portion of a storm sewer
system.
STORM WATER TRANSMISSION SYSTEM. The physical method of transporting storm water from one location to another, including streams, ditches,
swales and overflow routes (major or overland system), as well as manmade facilities such as storm sewers, tile lines, inlets, catch basins, manholes and
pumped systems (minor or convenience) used to convey storm water and snowmelt to a natural watercourse.
SURCHARGE. A hydraulic condition in a storm sewer which occurs when the height of the water surface in the storm sewer is at an elevation above the
crown (inside top surface) of the sewer pipe.
10-YEAR FREQUENCY STORM. A design storm event having an intensity duration relationship that has a probability of being equaled or exceeded, on
the average, once in a period of ten (10) years, as defined by the Illinois State Water Survey.
TIME OF CONCENTRATION. The time required for the stormwater runoff to flow from the most remote part of a site to the point of its discharge from said
site.
WATERSHED. A physical upstream land area, which contributes stormwater to a single downstream location or area. (1986 Code; amd. Ord. 00-1024, 4-
17-2000)
Sec. 7-63: STORM WATER CONTROL REQUIREMENT.
(1) Subject to this article, no development or series of developments resulting in the cumulative installation of impervious ground coverage having a
surface area of one thousand (1,000) square feet or more, shall be performed within the Village unless stormwater detention is provided to
accommodate stormwater runoff in accordance with the provisions of this article. Any development which would result in less than one thousand
(1,000) square feet of impervious ground coverage shall be required to contribute to the Village a monetary amount as set forth in appendix D, article
I of this Code in lieu of the stormwater detention that would otherwise be required by the application of this article or provide the minimum permitted
detention facility. If the property has an existing detention facility and the amount of impervious ground coverage created by the new development
plus the amount of impervious ground coverage for which the existing detention basin was provided results in one thousand (1,000) square feet or
greater of impervious ground coverage then providing additional detention shall be required. If the current owner caused any site development prior
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=886 78/377
to the adoption hereof and failed to obtain a permit from the Village in circumstances in which a permit was required, then all of the work done
without a permit shall be deemed to be done after the adoption hereof and the impervious surface installed without the permit shall be subject to the
requirements of this article. In no case shall a required stormwater detention facility have a lesser capacity than that required to mitigate one
thousand (1,000) square feet of impervious ground coverage. (Ord. 02-1105, 3-18-2002)
(2) All erosion protection must be installed and functional prior to any building materials being brought on the site and prior to any excavation or grading
of the site.
Unless otherwise approved, all detention required for any work under this ordinance shall be substantially complete before other work on site is
performed. This includes detention capacity in place with outfall requirements complete and any other appurtenant work associated with stormwater
management.
(3) Detention and drainage which is provided pursuant to this article shall not be inconsistent with the Village of Northfield stormwater management
plan, as approved and from time to time amended by the Corporate Authorities. A copy of the plan is on file in the Office of the Village Clerk.
(4) Developers and owners shall be required to apply for a building permit for all new construction. For purposes of this article, construction shall
include, but not be limited to, all buildings and other impervious structures, such as sidewalks, patios and new driveway construction. Construction
shall also include all semiimpervious structures, such as wooden decks if there is to be an impervious barrier such as polyethylene placed beneath
the semiimpervious surface. (Ord. 00-1024, 4-17-2000)
Sec. 7-64: VARIATIONS; EXCEPTIONS FROM SECTION 7-63.
Exceptions to this article may be granted only subject to the following conditions:
A. Without Zoning Board Of Appeals Approval.
(1) A written request for such an exception is filed with the Building Commissioner prior to the start of actual construction.
(2) The amount of detention from which relief is sought is less than five thousand (5,000) cubic feet.
(3) No subdivision of land is involved.
(4) The applicant pays the direct costs of all Village engineering fees.
(5) The decision as to whether to grant any exception shall be based upon the Village Engineer's written report addressing the following matters with
respect to the property of the petitioner:
(a) Lack of or insufficient receiving storm sewer.
(b) Inability to provide sufficient outflow (the surrounding land is too flat or higher than the subject lot); or
(c) Other generally recognized engineering factor(s) that indicate that the required detention would not achieve its purpose.
(d) Adequate proof that the rate of runoff to adjacent properties will not be increased or if it is increased that it will not be unduly harmful to adjacent
property. Certification by the owner or owners of the adjacent property or properties receiving the runoff that the owner has no objection shall be
prima facie proof that the runoff is not unduly harmful.
(e) If the exception is from a detention requirement, whether the lot size is sufficient to accommodate the required detention.
(6) Within forty five (45) days of receiving the request, the Building Commissioner shall notify the applicant, the Village Manager and adjacent property
owners in writing, of the decision, specifying the reasons for either granting or denying the request. If the applicant, Village Manager or any adjacent
property owner does not agree with the ruling, a written appeal may be made to the Zoning Board of Appeals. The appeal shall be filed within
fourteen (14) days of the mailing of notification of the decision.
B. With Zoning Board Of Appeals Approval. Exceptions to any regulation to this article may be granted by the Zoning Board of Appeals consistent with
subsection A of this section. In addition, the Zoning Board of Appeals also may grant exceptions in cases involving more than five thousand (5,000)
cubic feet of detention and in cases involving the subdivision of land. (Ord. 95-838, 3-27-1995)
C. Any Exception To The Detention Requirement. In any case where the exception involves not providing the required detention, for adding
impermeable surface over one thousand (1,000) square feet, the owner or developer shall first attempt to provide an equivalent engineering alternative
to the detention that is acceptable to the Village Engineer. If no acceptable alternative can be achieved, then the owner or developer shall be required
to contribute to the Village an amount of money as set forth in appendix D, article I of this Code. (Ord. 00-1024, 4-17-2000)
D. Provision Of Off Site Detention. A potential equivalent engineering alternative shall be the off site provision of detention. Off site detention may be
provided without Zoning Board of Appeals approval. However, no off site detention shall be approved unless there is strict compliance with the
following conditions:
(1) The petitioner shall demonstrate to the satisfaction of the Village Engineer that its request will not, either individually or unilaterally, unreasonably
increase the potential for flooding of downstream or upstream properties.
(2) The off site detention shall be located within the same watershed as the petitioner's lot.
(3) Unless otherwise authorized by the Corporate Authorities, the stormwater must be detained on a lot which is adjacent to the petitioner's lot. A lot
shall be considered adjacent for these purposes even if there is an intervening public or private roadway.
(4) The obtaining of any easements, licenses or other interests necessary to achieve off site drainage shall be the responsibility of the petitioner. Such
interests shall run with the land and shall be irrevocable.

https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=886 79/377
Nothing contained in this subsection D shall be deemed to create in any person a right to require either the Village or any other public or private entity to
grant any easement, license or other interest in land. (Ord. 96-890, 11-25-1996)
Sec. 7-64.1: CREDIT FOR EXISTING STRUCTURES.
A. Single-Family Residential Zoning Districts. The following credits shall be available for new construction in single-family residential zoning districts
and under the following circumstances:
(1) (a) The structure was in existence prior to January 1, 1992, or
(b) The structure was constructed after January 1, 1992, pursuant to a valid Village building permit, and
(2) The structure being constructed is a single-family residence or accessory to a single-family residence.
If the above criteria are met as to single-family residential zoning districts, the following credits shall be available under the following circumstances:
(1) In cases where existing semi-impervious structures, such as wooden decks, are demolished, the owner or developer shall be allowed to include
fifty percent (50%) of the square footage of ground coverage of the demolished portion of the existing structure as partial credit toward the
stormwater control requirement.
(2) In cases where existing impervious structures, including driveways and patios, are demolished, the owner or developer shall be allowed to
include one hundred percent (100%) of the square feet of impervious coverage of the demolished portion of the existing impervious area of the
structure as a credit toward the stormwater control requirements.
B. Other Zoning Districts. The following credits shall be available in all other zoning districts and under the following circumstances:
(1) The total site area is less than three (3) acres;
(2) There is no existing stormwater detention facility on the site;
(3) There must be a net decrease in the volume and rate of the stormwater runoff from the site;
(4) There must be extenuating circumstances, which limit the ability to provide the required stormwater detention;
(5) There must be some public benefit provided such as enhanced site improvements;
(6) The development must demonstrate the need for the requested level of credit for existing impervious areas; and
(7) The development must be in keeping with the village's comprehensive plan.
If the above criteria are met, the following credits shall be available under the following circumstances:
(1) The stormwater detention volume required shall be adjusted by the following ratio: Vadj = Vr x (Ip/2Ie), where
(a) Vadj is the adjusted detention volume;
(b) Vr is the detention volume required to meet the release rate requirements of section 7-66 of this article;
(c) Ie is the existing impervious area of the site;
(d) Ip is the developed impervious area of the site;
(2) The maximum credit allowed shall be seventy five percent (75%) of the detention volume required to meet the release rate requirements of
section 7-66 of this article.
(3) All impervious areas of the developed site shall discharge to a detention basin irrespective of any detention volume credit applied.
(4) In no case shall the postdevelopment peak release rate exceed the predevelopment peak release rate. (Ord. 16-1659, 6-21-2016)
Sec. 7-65: STORMWATER MANAGEMENT DESIGN CRITERIA.
The design of all stormwater management facilities within the village shall be based upon an event hydrograph method such as HEC = HMS, HEC-1, TR-
20 or similar method approved by the village engineer and shall comply with all other conditions and requirements of this article. (Ord. 00-1024, 4-17-2000)
Sec. 7-66: ALLOWABLE RELEASE RATE.
The maximum allowable release rate of stormwater within the village shall be fifteen-hundredths (0.15) cubic feet per second per acre. In cases where a
restrictor design does not permit the exact allowable release rate, the restrictor shall be designed to provide a more restrictive rate than otherwise would
be permitted. All restrictors shall include traps and cleanouts. (1986 Code)

Sec. 7-67: STORMWATER TRANSMISSION SYSTEMS, MAJOR AND MINOR SYSTEMS.
All stormwater transmission systems shall provide both a major and a minor transmission system as described below: (1986 Code)
(1) Major System, Overland Flow. Emergency overland flow routes shall be provided across every site having an upstream watershed draining
across it, and shall be located in maintenance easements not less than twenty feet (20') in width on terms acceptable to the village, granting the
village the right to undertake maintenance, and lien rights for the cost of such maintenance, in the event the owner fails to maintain said routes.
Bypass routes, as approved by the village engineer, from upstream areas, shall be provided based upon a 100-year frequency rainfall event. (1986
Code; amd. Ord. 00-1024, 4-17-2000)
Bypass from upstream areas which are presently undeveloped shall be provided based upon a 100-year frequency storm with a runoff coefficient of
thirty five hundredths (0.35) or greater.
(2) Minor System, Storm Sewer. The minor system shall consist of storm sewers unless a specific waiver is granted by the village for the use of an
open drainage system.
All storm sewers shall be designed to drain dry during dry weather. The village engineer may waive this requirement and permit a surcharged sewer
in cases where said sewer is installed below frost protection depth.
Storm manholes, inlets, catch basins and lids shall be of a type approved by the village.
All storm sewer connecting structures shall be either type "C" catch basins (2 foot diameter structures with a 2 foot minimum sump) or type "A" catch
basins (4 foot diameter structures with a 2 foot minimum sump). Two foot (2') diameter inlets without sumps shall be permitted only with the prior
written approval of the village. All such connecting structures shall be precast reinforced concrete, except with the prior written approval of the
village.
Upstream times of concentration may be utilized for purposes of storm sewer design in areas where a major watershed flow is bypassed through the
site.
Storm sewer lines which receive surface flow shall be equipped with a catch basin at each alternate structure.
Except in cases of written waiver by the village, all storm lines, except restrictor discharge pipes, shall be a minimum of eight inches (8") in diameter.
Each storm sewer connecting structure shall receive runoff from a maximum of twelve thousand (12,000) square feet of impervious surface.
PVC storm sewer is permitted if the pipe is covered by an amount of material at least one and five-tenths (1.5) pipe diameters from finished surface
to the top of the pipe. (1986 Code)
The following materials are acceptable for use in storm sewers:
Material Pipe Joint
RCP, CLIV C-76 C-361 (O-Ring)
Reinforced concrete pipe
Class IV
PVC, SDR35 3034 D-1869 (Gasket)
Polyvinyl chloride pipe
Standard dimension ratio 35
DIP, CL50-52 A21.51 A21.11
Ductile iron pipe
Class 50-52
(1986 Code; amd. Ord. 00-1024, 4-17-2000)
(3) Pavement Base Drainage. All pavement within the village shall be installed with an adequate drainage system. Such a system may include storm
sewers, roadside ditches, subbase drains, etc., or a combination of them as approved by the village engineer. (Ord. 00-1024, 4-17-2000)
(4) Open Drainage Systems. Roadways and roadside ditches shall be provided with inlets to storm sewers, each inlet to be at a maximum interval of
three hundred feet (300') from each other inlet.
Ditches which function as the minor system shall have a minimum gradient of one percent (1%); provided, however, that emergency overflow swales
may be flatter than one percent (1%) if written analysis, satisfactory to the village engineer, is submitted verifying 100-year storm capacity and
adequate protection of public and private areas. (1986 Code)
(5) Rainfall Frequency Data. The latest rainfall frequency information as published by the Illinois state water survey and as approved for use by the
village engineer shall be utilized in the design of storm water detention facilities, storm sewer systems and any other storm water management or
storm water conveyance system required by this article. (Ord. 00-1024, 4-17-2000)

https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=886 81/377
Sec. 7-68: DETENTION AND RETENTION BASIN DESIGN.
The design criteria for detention and retention basins contained in this section also applies to basins provided for the purpose of compensatory storage
under the village zoning ordinance applicable to special uses.
All detention or retention basins which benefit more than one lot of record in a subdivision shall be located in a "drainage and detention" easement in favor
of the Village shown on the final recorded plat of subdivision. Said easement shall include a zone at least five feet (5') wide above high-water level around
the perimeter of the basin, together with access rights at least ten feet (10') from the public right of way for purposes of inspection and maintenance.
Pipe storage requires permission of the village.
Use of pumped storage requires specific permission of the village.
(1) Restrictors/Release Structures. All restrictors shall be sized at or below the allowable release rate permitted for the subject site. (1986 Code)
When combined with compensatory storage, a restrictor shall be sized for the detention only. (1986 Code; amd. Ord. 00-1024, 4-17-2000)
In calculating restrictor release rates, when combined with compensatory storage volumes, it shall be assumed that the detention occupies the
bottom of the basin.
All basins shall have a defined emergency overflow reasonably protected from erosion. Depressed curbs, riprap, gabions or other structural methods
are preferred.
(2) Detention Basin, Vegetative Cover. Detention basins with vegetative cover shall have a side slope ratio not steeper than four to one (4:1), except
in those areas protected by retaining walls. (1986 Code)
Except as otherwise authorized by the village, in order to maximize the size of the release and minimize the number of restrictors, only one detention
basin and one restrictor shall be provided per watershed within any property under a single ownership. (1986 Code; amd. Ord. 00-1024, 4-17-2000)
Where practical all detention and compensatory storage basins shall have an underdrain system. (Ord. 00-1024, 4-17-2000)
Freeboard is required to be a minimum of twelve inches (12") when earth banks are utilized for a detention basin. If a concrete curb or solid concrete
retaining wall is utilized, freeboard of two inches (2") above the storm water release level (emergency overflow) is required.
(3) Detention Basin, Parking Lot. Pavement in detention zones shall have a structural number of at least 2.50 based upon the current Illinois
department of transportation coefficients. All pavement designs shall incorporate provisions for subbase drainage, have a surface slope between one
percent (1%) and three percent (3%) and be constructed pursuant to Illinois department of transportation standards. If the Illinois bearing ratio for the
existing soil is less than three (3.0), the structural section shall be increased in accordance with the standards of the Illinois department of
transportation. The subbase shall be compacted to ninety five percent (95%) standard proctor. (1986 Code)
All parking lots used for detention shall be surrounded by a six inch (6") barrier vertical curb. (1986 Code; amd. Ord. 00-1024, 4-17-2000)
Provision shall be made for emergency overflow at any point in a parking lot where water attains a depth of twelve inches (12") or more.
(4) Basin Design, Retention. All retention ponds shall be provided with a minimum slope ratio, below water, of three to one (3:1). At a depth of
approximately three feet (3') below normal water level, a safety shelf shall be provided which is approximately four feet (4') in width. Below the safety
shelf, a slope ratio of two to one (2:1) may be used.
Shore stabilization shall be provided, at a minimum slope ratio of three to one (3:1), from a point at least one foot (1') below normal water level to
high-water level. Said stabilization shall take the form of riprap, retaining walls, turf-stone, or other permanent methods of stabilization.
All retention basins shall have at least twelve inches (12") freeboard, except at the location of the emergency overflow.
A minimum of twenty five percent (25%) of the basin shall be at least ten feet (10') deep at normal water level.
Aeration systems shall be provided, which may be either surface aerators or diffused air systems when deemed reasonably necessary by the village
in the interests of public health and safety to maintain proper oxygen levels. (1986 Code)
(5) Detention Basin Capacity. The latest Illinois state water survey rainfall data for a twenty four (24) hour 100-year recurrence interval that is
applicable to a region that includes the village, shall be used, in combination with the allowable release rate to determine minimum basin capacity.
(Ord. 00-1024, 4-17-2000)
Sec. 7-69: BYPASS.
In providing a bypass system for flow from upstream areas across any site, a bypass conduit which is separate from the on site detention system is
preferred; however, bypass may be provided across the site and released through the system restrictor with prior approval by the village engineer. Any
such restrictor shall be sized for the on site allowable release only. (1986 Code)
Sec. 7-70: SITE GRADING AND/OR DRIVEWAY IMPROVEMENTS.
A. Site Grading Permit Required. A site grading permit shall be required for all site development, and all changes in grade or drainage patterns. Each
application for a site grading permit shall require the applicant to furnish, at the applicant's own expense a topographical survey of the areas which will
be topographically altered and a plan illustrating the nature of the construction proposed. The required topographic survey shall be prepared by an
Illinois registered professional engineer or an Illinois registered land surveyor, showing existing ground surface elevations representative of the area,
existing locations and elevations for all structures, sewers, trees over six inches (6") in diameter (or tree masses in dense areas as determined by the
village engineer), drainageways and other structural improvements. The survey shall extend for at least fifty feet (50') off site in every direction or to
such further point or points as determined to be advisable by the village engineer.
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=886 82/377
All surveys shall be based on the village bench mark system and shall show spot elevations and one foot (1') contours.
All applications for subdivision approval or building permits involving modifications to site grading shall include a grading plan containing topographic
data for existing and proposed grades required in this section and shall define final grade, drainage, top of foundation and finished floor elevation.
Tolerances shall be as follows:
(1) Foundations: + or - 0.1 foot, but above flood protection elevations.
(2) Critical grading areas: = or - 0.1 foot, but with positive drainage.
(3) Noncritical grading areas: = or - 0.5 foot, but with positive drainage.
Storm sump pump discharge lines for all sump pumps installed after 1986, or for existing sump pumps altered to serve a building, parking lot or other
improvement covered by this article shall discharge only into an existing or proposed storm sewer within two hundred feet (200') of the property where
the sump pump is located.
If no such storm sewer exists or is proposed, or none is available, the discharge line shall extend to the downstream end of the adjacent street frontage
ditch line, or to a point designated by the village engineer.
Grades shall slope away from or around all buildings.
All yards must slope at one percent (1%) minimum grade.
Emergency overflow shall be directed around all structures and avoid closing emergency access whenever possible.
B. Driveway Permit Required. A driveway permit shall be required for all driveway improvements, except patching repairs, seal coating or regrading of an
existing permeable driveway surface that results in a net gain of one inch (1") or less in height. Each application for a driveway permit shall require the
applicant to furnish, at the applicant's own expense a topographical survey of the areas which will be topographically altered and a plan illustrating the
nature of the construction proposed, and a plat of survey which includes recent improvements. The required topographic survey and plat of survey shall
be prepared by an Illinois registered professional engineer or an Illinois registered land surveyor. The topographical survey must show existing ground
surface elevations representative of the area, existing locations and elevations for all structures, sewers, trees over six inches (6") in diameter (or tree
masses in dense areas as determined by the village engineer), drainageways and other structural improvements. The survey shall extend for at least
fifty feet (50') off site in every direction or to such further point or points as determined to be advisable by the village engineer.
C. Existing Buildings Or Sites. The roof leaders, downspouts and sump pump discharge lines of all existing buildings or structures shall be located and
directed so that the contents thereof will be released into existing drainage routes or into new drainage routes created for the specific purpose of
retaining the water on the subject property or carrying the water to a watercourse or other approved storm water collection system. All such discharge
shall be directed away from existing buildings and except where there is no other reasonable alternative shall not increase the discharge onto adjoining
properties. Under no circumstances shall water be discharged into adjacent properties in such a manner as to damage the adjacent property or cause
pooling on the adjacent property. All existing structures must comply with this subsection within ninety (90) days of the adoption of this section. (Ord.
00-1047, 10-16-2000)
Sec. 7-71: MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS.
(1) In areas where upstream development has the potential to significantly impact existing downstream development in the opinion of the village
engineer, the village may require that owners of the upstream development property participate in the construction of a storm water transmission
system downstream of the site, which participation may be implemented through a recapture ordinance when appropriate.
(2) "As-constructed" reproducible plans on Mylar, or its generic equivalent, shall be submitted to the village engineer upon completion of all
development projects within the village. "As-constructed" plans shall identify utility locations and elevations, high water level, normal water level,
water main fittings, easements, trench backfill, grading, and deviations from the design plans. Said plans shall be signed and sealed by the design
engineer and shall be accepted by the village engineer prior to the issuance of a certificate of occupancy or acceptance or approval of the project by
the village.
(3) On the face of all construction plans, there shall be inscribed a notice to the contractor to request inspections at specified stages. The village
engineer shall advise the design engineer concerning the timing of and procedures for such inspections. (1986 Code)
Sec. 7-72: MAINTENANCE.
The owner of any detention, retention or compensatory storage basin shall maintain that basin in its original design cross section, surface conditions, and
hydraulic system as noted on the original accepted plans.
If, in the reasonable opinion of the village, the owner has failed to maintain the basin properly, including all of such a basin with vegetative cover areas cut
to a maximum height of six inches (6"), in accordance with generally accepted maintenance, erosion control and structural standards, the village may
perform any required maintenance upon said basin and charge the cost thereof to the current owners of the basin, which costs shall be a lien on the entire
property served by said basin, enforceable in the manner provided by law for enforcement and foreclosure of liens. (1986 Code)
Sec. 7-73: OTHER PERMITS.
As a condition of the acceptance of any storm water improvements by the Village, the owner shall obtain all required companion permits from other
agencies having jurisdiction, including but not limited to the metropolitan sanitary district of Greater Chicago, the Illinois environmental protection agency,
the Illinois division of water resources and the U.S. army corps of engineers. (1986 Code)
