Sec. 7-74: DECLARATION OF NUISANCE.
A condition constituting a violation of sections 7-61 through 7-70 shall be deemed a public nuisance and may be abated pursuant to chapter 14 of this
code. (Ord. 497, 4-28-1987)
ARTICLE V. REGULATION OF FLOOD HAZARD AREAS
Sec. 7-75: PURPOSE.
This article is enacted pursuant to the police powers granted to this village by 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/1-2-1, 5/11-12-12, 5/11-30-8, and 5/11-31-2.
This article is adopted in order to accomplish the following specific purposes:
(1) To protect human life and health from the hazards of flooding.
(2) To assure that new development does not increase flood or drainage hazards to others or create unstable conditions susceptible to erosion by new
development.
(3) To protect new buildings and major improvements to buildings from flood damage.
(4) To facilitate the appropriate development of vacant real estate and to protect the continued use and economic value of existing improved property.
(5) To meet the requirements of 615 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/19g, "an act in relation to the regulation of the rivers, lakes and streams of the state of
Illinois", approved June 10, 1911, as amended.
(6) To make federally subsidized flood insurance available for property in the village by fulfilling the requirements of the national flood insurance
program.
(7) To comply with the rules and regulations of the national flood insurance program codified as 44 CFR 59-79, as amended.
(8) To lessen the burden on the taxpayer for flood control projects, repairs to flood damaged public facilities and utilities and flood rescue and relief
operations.
(9) To assist in the protection, conservation and promotion of the orderly development of land and water resources.
(10) To assist in the preservation of the natural hydrologic and hydraulic functions of watercourses and floodplains and the protection of water quality
and aquatic habitats.
(11) To assist in: a) the preservation of the natural characteristics of stream corridors in order to moderate flood and storm water impacts; b)
improvement of water quality; c) reduction of soil erosion; d) protection of aquatic and riparian habitat; e) provision of recreational opportunities and
aesthetic benefit and the enhancement of community and economic development. (Ord. 96-869, 1-22-1996)
Sec. 7-76: DEFINITIONS.
For purposes of this article, the following definitions are adopted:
ACT. An act in relation to the regulation of the rivers, lakes and streams of the state of Illinois, 615 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/5 et seq.
APPLICANT. Any person, firm, corporation or agency which submits an application for development.
APPROPRIATE USE. Uses of the regulatory floodway that are permissible and will be considered for permit issuance. The only uses that will be allowed
are as specified in section 7-81 of this article.
BASE FLOOD. The flood having a one percent (1%) probability of being equaled or exceeded in any given year. The base flood is also known as the 100-
year frequency flood event. Determination of the base flood elevation at any location shall be done pursuant to section 7-79 of this article.
BUILDING. A structure that is principally aboveground and is enclosed by walls and a roof. The term includes, but is not limited to, a gas or liquid storage
tank, a manufactured home and a prefabricated building.
CHANNEL. Any river, stream, creek, brook, branch, natural or artificial depression, ponded area, flowage, slough, ditch, conduit, culvert, gully, ravine,
wash, or natural or manmade drainageway, which has a definite bed and banks or shoreline, in or into which surface or ground water flows, either
constantly or intermittently.
CHANNEL MODIFICATION. Alteration of a channel by changing the physical dimensions or materials of its bed or banks. Channel modification includes
damming, riprapping or other armoring, widening, deepening, straightening, relocating, lining and significant installation or removal of bottom or woody
vegetation. Channel modification does not include the clearing of dead or dying vegetation, debris, or trash from the channel. Channelization is a severe
form of channel modification typically involving relocation of the existing channel (e.g., straightening).
COMPENSATORY STORAGE. An artificially excavated, hydraulically equivalent volume of storage within the special flood hazard area used to balance
the loss of natural flood storage capacity when artificial fill or structures are placed within a special flood hazard area.
DWR. Illinois department of transportation, division of water resources.
DAM. Any obstruction, wall embankment or barrier, together with abutments and appurtenant structures, if any, constructed for the purpose of storing or
diverting water or creating a pool. Underground water storage tanks are not included. The term "dam" may include a weir, restrictive culvert or other control
structure which causes the upstream water surface elevation to be different from the downstream elevation.
DEVELOPMENT. Manmade changes to real estate which shall include:
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=886 84/377
(1) Construction, reconstruction or replacement of a building or any addition to a building.
(2) Drilling, mining, installing utilities, construction of roads, bridges or similar projects.
(3) Demolition of a structure or redevelopment of a site.
(4) Clearing of land as an adjunct of or prefatory to construction.
(5) Construction or erection of leaves, walls, fences, dams, or culverts; channel modification; filling, dreading, grading, excavating, paving or other
nonagricultural alterations of the ground surface; storage of materials; deposit of solid or liquid waste.
(6) Any other activity of man that might change the direction, height or velocity of flood or surface water, including extensive vegetation removal or
planting.
Development does not include:
(1) Gardening, plowing and similar agricultural practices that do not involve filling, grading or construction of levees.
(2) Maintenance of existing buildings and facilities.
(3) Resurfacing of roads or driveways when there is not cumulative increase in elevation.
ELEVATION CERTIFICATE. A form published by the federal emergency management agency that is used to certify the elevation to which a building has
been elevated.
EROSION. The general process whereby soils are moved by flowing water or wave action.
EXEMPT ORGANIZATIONS. Organizations which are exempt from this article per the Illinois Compiled Statutes, including state, federal or local units of
government such as the metropolitan water reclamation district.
FEMA. Federal emergency management agency and its regulations at 44 CFR 59-79 effective as of October 1, 1986. This incorporation does not include
any later editions or amendments.
FLOOD. A general and temporary condition of partial or complete inundation of normally dry land areas from overflow of inland waterways or the unusual
and rapid accumulation or runoff of surface waters from any source.
FLOOD FREQUENCY. This is a statistical likelihood expressed in a period of years that a flood of a stated magnitude may be expected to be equaled or
exceeded.
FLOOD FRINGE. That portion of the special flood hazard area outside of the regulatory floodway.
FLOOD INSURANCE RATE MAP (FIRM). A map prepared by the federal emergency management agency that depicts the special flood hazard area
(SFHA) within a community. This map includes insurance rate zones and floodplains and may or may not depict floodways.
FLOOD PROTECTION ELEVATION (FPE). The elevation of the base flood or 100-year frequency flood plus one foot (1') of freeboard at any given
location in the special flood hazard area.
FLOODPLAIN. Land typically adjacent to a body of water with ground surface elevations at or below the base flood or the 100-year frequency flood
elevation. A floodplain may also include ponding areas that are not adjacent to a watercourse. The floodplain is also known as the special flood hazard
area (SFHA). Stated another way, the floodplains are those lands within the jurisdiction of the village that are subject to inundation of the base flood or
100-year frequency flood. The floodplain of the village is generally identified as a special flood hazard area on map #17031C and panels 0231J, 0232J,
0233J, and 0234J of the countywide flood insurance rate map for Cook County prepared by the federal emergency management agency dated August 19,
2008. The SFHAs of those parts of Cook County that are within the extraterritorial jurisdiction of the village are generally identified as such on the flood
insurance rate map prepared for Cook County by FEMA as dated August 19, 2008, identified on the same map and panels set forth above with the
addition of panel #0253J.
FLOODPROOFING. Any combination of structural and nonstructural additions, changes or adjustments to structures which reduce or eliminate flood
damage to real estate or improved real property, water and sanitary facilities, structures and their contents.
FLOODPROOFING CERTIFICATE. A form published by the federal emergency management agency that is used to certify that a building has been
designed and constructed to be structurally floodproofed to the flood protection elevation.
FREEBOARD. An increment of elevation added to the base flood elevation to provide a factor of safety for uncertainties in calculations, unknown localized
conditions, wave actions and unpredictable effects such as those caused by ice or debris jams.
HISTORIC STRUCTURE. Any structure that is:
(1) Listed individually in the National Register of Historic Places or preliminarily determined by the secretary of the interior as meeting the requirements
for individual listing on the national register;
(2) Certified or preliminarily determined by the secretary of the interior as contributing to the historic district or a district preliminarily determined by the
secretary to qualify as a registered historic district;
(3) Individually listed on the State Inventory of Historic Places by the Illinois historic preservation agency;
(4) Individually listed on a local inventory of historic places that has been certified by the Illinois historic preservation agency.
HYDROLOGIC AND HYDRAULIC CALCULATIONS. Engineering analyses which determine expected flood flows and flood elevations based on land
characteristics and rainfall events.
MITIGATION. Mitigation includes those measures necessary to minimize the negative effects which floodplain development activities might have on the
public health, safety and welfare. Examples of mitigation include compensatory storage, obstruction removal, deflection minimization, soil erosion and
sedimentation control and channel restoration.
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=886 85/377
NGVD. National geodetic vertical datum of 1929. Reference surface set by the national geodetic survey deduced from a continental adjustment of all
existing adjustments in 1929.
NATURAL. When used in reference to channels means those channels formed by the existing surface topography of the earth prior to substantial changes
made by man. A natural stream tends to follow a meandering path; its floodplain is not constrained by levees; the area near the bank has not been
cleared, mowed or cultivated; the stream flows over soil and geologic materials typical of the area with no substantial alteration of the course or cross
section of the stream caused by filling or excavating. A modified channel may regain some natural characteristics over time as the channel meanders and
vegetation is reestablished. Similarly, a modified channel may be restored to more natural conditions by man though regrading and revegetation.
ORDINARY HIGH WATER MARK (OHWM). The point on the bank or shore up to which the presence and action of surface water is so continuous so as to
leave a distinctive mark such as by erosion, destruction or prevention of terrestrial vegetation, predominance of aquatic vegetation or other easily
recognized characteristics.
PUBLIC FLOOD CONTROL PROJECT. A flood control project which will be operated and maintained by a public agency to reduce flood damages to
existing buildings and structures which includes a hydrologic and hydraulic study of the existing and proposed conditions of the watershed. Nothing in this
definition shall preclude the design, engineering, construction or financing, in whole or in part, of a flood control project by persons or parties who are not
public agencies.
PUBLICLY NAVIGABLE WATERS. All streams and lakes capable of being navigated by watercraft.
REGISTERED LAND SURVEYORS. A land surveyor registered in the state of Illinois, under the Illinois land surveyors act1.
REGISTERED PROFESSIONAL ENGINEER. An engineer registered in the state of Illinois, under the Illinois professional engineering act2.
REGULATORY FLOODWAY. The channel, including on-stream lakes, and that portion of the floodplain adjacent to a stream or watercourse designated by
DWR as regulatory floodway. Generally, but not necessarily, the floodway is that portion of the floodplain needed to store and convey the existing and
anticipated future 100-year frequency flood discharge with no more than 0.1 foot increase in stage due to the loss of flood conveyance or storage, and no
more than a ten percent (10%) increase in velocities. The regulatory floodways are designated for the north branch of the Chicago River, Middle Fork and
the Skokie River on map number 17031C and panels 0231F, 0232F, 0233F, and 0234F dated November 6, 2000, of the countywide flood insurance rate
map for Cook County. The regulatory floodways for those parts of unincorporated Cook County that are within the extraterritorial jurisdiction of the village
that may be annexed into the village are designated for the north branch of the Chicago River, Middle Fork and Skokie River on map number 17031C and
panel 0253F dated November 6, 2000, of the countywide flood insurance rate map for Cook County. In the case of conflicting floodway locations, the most
restrictive floodway limit shall be used. To locate the regulatory flooding boundary on any site, the regulatory floodway boundary shall be scaled off the
regulatory floodway map and located on the site plan, using reference marks common to both maps. Where interpretation is needed to determine the
exact location of the regulatory floodway boundary, the division should be contacted for the interpretation.
REPAIR, REMODELING OR MAINTENANCE. Construction activities which do not result in any increases in the outside dimensions of a building or any
changes to the dimensions of a structure.
RETENTION/DETENTION FACILITY. A retention facility is a "wet-bottom" storage facility which retains a normal pool of inactive storage not ordinarily
released by gravity. A detention facility is a normally "dry-bottom" storm water storage facility which also provides for the storage of storm water and runoff
and the controlled release of this runoff during and after a flood or storm.
RIVERINE SFHA. Any SFHA subject to flooding from a river, creek, intermittent stream, ditch, on-stream lake system or any other identified channel. This
term does not include areas subject to flooding from lakes, ponding areas, areas of sheet flow or other areas not subject to overbank flooding.
RUNOFF. The water derived from melting snow or rain falling on the land surface, flowing over the surface of the ground or collected in channels or
conduits.
SEDIMENTATION. The processes that deposit soils, debris, and other materials either on other ground surfaces or in bodies of water or watercourses.
SPECIAL FLOOD HAZARD AREA (SFHA). Any base flood area subject to periodic flooding from a river, creek, intermittent stream, ditch or any other
identified channel or pond and shown on a flood hazard boundary map or flood insurance rate map as zone A, AO, A1-A30, AE, A99, AH, V1-V30, VE, V,
M or E.
SPECIAL FLOOD HAZARD AREA REVISION.
(1) Conditional Letter Of Map Revision (CLOMR). A preconstruction letter which indicates that the federal emergency management agency will revise
base flood elevations, flood insurance rate zones, flood boundaries or floodway as shown on an effective flood hazard boundary map or flood
insurance rate map once as built plans are submitted and approved.
(2) Letter Of Map Revision (LOMR). Letter that revises base flood or 100-year frequency flood elevations, flood insurance rate zones, flood boundaries
or floodways as shown on an effective FHBM or FIRM.
(3) Letter Of Map Amendment (LOMA). Official determination by FEMA that a specific existing structure is not in a 100-year flood zone, thus amending
the effective flood hazard boundary map or FIRM.
STRUCTURE. The results of a manmade change to the land constructed on or below the ground. A structure will result from the construction,
reconstruction or placement of a building or any addition to a building.
SUBSTANTIAL IMPROVEMENT. Any repair, reconstruction, rehabilitation, addition or improvement of a structure, the cost of which equals or exceeds fifty
percent (50%) of the market value of the structure either: 1) before the improvement or repair is started, or 2) if the structure has been damaged from any
source, and is being restored, before the damage occurred. This term includes the restoration of a structure to its predamaged condition when the cost
would equal or exceed fifty percent (50%) of the market value at the time immediately before the damage occurred, regardless of the actual repair work
performed. For the purpose of this definition, "substantial improvement" is considered to occur when the first alteration of any wall, ceiling, floor, or other
structural parts of a building commences, whether or not that alteration affects the external dimensions of the structure. The term does not, however,
include either: 1) any project for improvement of a structure to comply with any existing state or local health, sanitary, or safety code specifications which
are solely necessary to assure safe living conditions, or 2) any alteration of an "historic structure", provided that the alteration will not preclude the
structure's continued designation as an "historic structure".
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=886 86/377
TRANSITION SECTION. Reaches of the stream or floodway where water flows from a narrow cross section to a wide cross section or vice versa. (Ord.
96-869, 1-22-1996; amd. Ord. 00-1043, 9-18-2000; Ord. 00-1045, 10-16-2000; Ord. 08-1386, 7-15-2008)
Sec. 7-77: USE OF THIS ARTICLE.
The village manager shall have the authority set forth in section 7-78 of this article. He may delegate that authority to the building and zoning
commissioner.
The following steps shall be taken by the building and zoning commissioner when an application for development is made:
(1) Determine whether the development site or any portion of it is within a floodplain using the criteria set forth in section 7-79 of this article.
(2) If it is within a floodplain, the requirements of section 7-82 of this article shall apply.
(3) If it is within a floodplain, determine whether the subdivision requirements of section 7-83 of this article shall apply.
(4) If it is within a floodplain, determine whether it is within the flood fringe or a regulatory floodway.
(a) If within the flood fringe, all requirements of section 7-80 of this article shall apply.
(b) If within the regulatory floodway, all requirements of section 7-81 of this article shall apply.
(5) If a variance is being requested, section 7-84 of this article shall apply and all required notifications shall be completed.
(6) In order to assure that property owners obtain the required permits, the village manager or his designee may take any and all actions that are set
forth in section 7-86 of this article. (Ord. 96-869, 1-22-1996)
Sec. 7-78: AUTHORITY OF THE ENFORCEMENT OFFICIAL(S).
The village manager, or his designee, and the building and zoning commissioner shall have the following powers and responsibilities in the administration
and enforcement of this article:
(1) Determining The Floodplain Designation. At such time as permits are requested, check all development sites to determine whether they are in
the floodplain. If they are in the floodplain, determine if they are in the floodway or flood fringe. (Ord. 96-869, 1-22-1996)
(2) Professional Engineering Review. If the development site is within a special flood hazard area to require that the developer provide certification
from a registered professional engineer (PE) that the development meets the requirements of this article. If the development site is located in a
floodway, then the certification of the developer's professional engineer shall be reviewed by a second registered professional engineer (PE),
designated by the village, to ensure that the development meets the requirements of section 7-81 of this article. The costs and expenses associated
with the second engineer's review shall be borne by the petitioner as set forth in appendix D of this code. (Ord. 96-869, 1-22-1996; amd. Ord. 05-
1234, 3-15-2005)
(3) Flow Restrictors Including Any Dams. Require that the developer obtain from DWR either a dam safety permit or a letter indicating no dam
safety permit is required if the proposed development activity includes construction of a "dam" as defined in section 7-76 of this article.
(4) Other Permit Requirements. Assure that all required federal, state or local permits are received prior to the issuance of a permit for development
within a floodplain.
(5) Plan Review And Permit Issuance. Require that all development activities within the floodplain of the jurisdiction of the village meet the
requirements of this article and issue a floodplain development permit in accordance with its provisions and other regulations of this community.
(6) Inspection Review. Inspect all development projects before, during and after construction to assure proper elevation of the structure and to ensure
that a project complies with the provisions of this article.
(7) Elevation And Floodproofing Certificates. Maintain in the permit files an elevation certificate certifying the lowest flood elevation (including
basement) of a residential or nonresidential building or the elevation to which a building has been floodproofed, using a floodproofing certificate, for
all buildings subject to section 7-82 of this article for public inspection and copying.
(8) Records For Public Inspection. Maintain for public inspection and furnish upon request base flood data, special flood hazard area and regulatory
floodway maps, copies of federal or state permit documents, variance documentation, conditional letter of map revision, letter of map revision, letter
of map amendment and "as built" elevation and floodproofing or elevation and floodproofing certificates for all buildings constructed subject to this
article.
(9) State Permits. Require that construction authorization has been granted by the Illinois division of water resources, for all development projects
subject to section 7-81 of this article, unless enforcement responsibility has been delegated to the village. However, the following review approvals
shall not be delegated to the village and shall require review or permits from DWR under any circumstances:
(a) Development by organizations which are exempt by law from this article;
(b) Department of transportation projects, "dams" or impoundment structures as defined in section 7-76 of this article and all other federal, state or
county, village, or unit of local government projects;
(c) An engineer's determination that an existing bridge or culvert crossing is not a source of flood damage and the analysis indicating the proposed
flood profile, pursuant to section 7-81 of this article;
(d) An engineer's analysis of any flood profile or proposed flood profile for new bridge or culvert crossings, pursuant to section 7-81 of this article;
(e) Alternative transition sections and hydraulically equivalent compensatory storage, pursuant to section 7-81 of this article;
(f) Permit issuance for structures within or over publicly navigable rivers, lakes and streams;
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=886 87/377
(g) Any changes in the base flood elevation or floodway locations;
(h) Base flood elevation determinations where none now exist.
(10) Cooperation With Other Agencies. Cooperate with state and federal flood management agencies to improve base flood or 100-year frequency
flood and floodway data and to improve the administration of this article. Submit reports as required for the national flood insurance program. Submit
data to DWR and FEMA for any proposed revisions to the regulatory floodway map. Notify the federal emergency management agency of any
proposed amendments to this article.
(11) Promulgate Regulations. Promulgate rules and regulations as necessary to administer and enforce the provisions of this article, subject however
to the review and approval of DWR and FEMA for any changes to this article. (Ord. 96-869, 1-22-1996)
Sec. 7-79: BASE FLOOD ELEVATION.
This article's protection standard is based on the FEMA flood insurance study for the village. When a party disagrees with this data, that party may finance
a detailed engineering study and submit it to FEMA, DWR and the village manager or his delegate for review. (Ord. 96-869, 1-22-1996)
(1) The base flood or 100-year frequency flood elevation for the north branch of the Chicago River (Middle Fork and Skokie River) shall be as
delineated on the 100-year flood profiles in the flood insurance study of the village prepared by FEMA and dated August 19, 2008, and such
amendments to such studies as may be prepared from time to time. In the case of conflicting base flood elevations between the two (2) profiles, the
higher base flood elevation shall be used.
(2) The base flood or 100-year frequency flood elevation for the SFHAs of those parts of unincorporated Cook County that are within the extraterritorial
jurisdiction of the village or that may be annexed into the village shall be as delineated on the 100-year flood profiles in the flood insurance study of
Cook County prepared by FEMA and dated August 19, 2008, and such amendments or revisions to such study and maps as may be prepared from
time to time. (Ord. 00-1043, 9-18-2000; amd. Ord. 08-1386, 7-15-2008)
(3) The base flood elevation for any special flood hazard areas delineated as an "A zone" on the flood insurance rate map of the village shall be
according to the best existing data available in the Illinois state water survey floodplain information repository. (Ord. 96-869, 1-22-1996; amd. Ord.
08-1386, 7-15-2008)
Sec. 7-80: OCCUPATION AND USE OF FLOOD FRINGE AREAS.
Development in the flood fringe will be permitted if protection is provided against the base flood by proper elevation of the structures and provision of
compensatory storage along with compliance with other provisions of this article. Developments located within the flood fringe shall meet all of the
requirements of this section and section 7-82 of this article.
(1) Development Permit Required. No person, firm, corporation or governmental body not exempted by the Illinois Compiled Statutes shall
commence any development in the special flood hazard area without first obtaining a development permit from the village of Northfield.
(2) Application. Application for a development permit shall be made on a form provided by the building and zoning commissioner. The application shall
be accompanied by scaled drawings of the site showing property line dimensions and a legal description of the property sealed by a licensed
engineer or land surveyor; existing grade elevations in MSL 1929 adjusted datum or NGVD and all changes in grade resulting from excavation or
filling; the location and dimensions of all buildings and additions to buildings. For all proposed buildings, the elevation of the lowest floor (including
basement) and lowest adjacent grade shall be shown on the submitted plans. The development will be subject to the requirements of section 7-82 of
this article. Upon receipt of the permit application the community development director shall compare the elevation of the site to the base flood or
100-year frequency flood elevation. Any development located on land that can be shown to have been higher than the base flood elevation as of the
site's first flood insurance rate map identification is not in the SFHA and, therefore, not subject to the requirements of this article. The community
development director shall maintain the documentation of the existing ground elevations at the development site and certification that the ground
elevation existed prior to the date of the site's first flood insurance rate map identification.
(3) Soil Erosion And Sedimentation Plan. A soil erosion and sedimentation control plan for disturbed areas shall be submitted. This plan shall
include a description of the sequence of grading activities and the temporary sediment and erosion control measures to be implemented to mitigate
their effects. This plan shall also include a description of final stabilization and revegetation measures, and the identification of a responsible party to
ensure postconstruction maintenance. This plan shall be in conformity with the "NIPC Planning Aid No. 11; Suggested Soil Erosion And
Sedimentation Control Ordinance: A Guide For Local Officials, January 1980".
(4) Other Permits. The community development director shall require and the applicant shall provide copies of all other local, state and federal
permits, approvals or permit not required letters that may be required for this type of activity. No village of Northfield permit shall be issued until all
other local, state and federal permits have been obtained.
(5) Preventing Increased Damages. No development in the flood fringe shall be permitted to create a threat to public health and safety. If all other
requirements of this article are met and written certification is provided by a registered engineer that the development does not create a threat to
public health and safety, then the burden of proving such a threat shall shift to the village.
(6) LOMR. If fill is being used to elevate the site above the base flood elevation, the applicant shall obtain a letter of map revision (LOMR) from FEMA
for the purpose of removing the site from the floodplain. Such development must still comply with all other requirements of this article. (Ord. 96-869,
1-22-1996)
(7) Compensatory Storage. Whenever any portion of the flood fringe is permitted to be developed, the volume of space which will be occupied by the
authorized fill or structure below the base flood elevation shall be compensated for and balanced by a hydraulically equivalent volume of excavation
taken from below the base flood or 100-year frequency flood elevation. The excavation volume shall be one hundred twelve percent (112%) of the
volume of storage lost due to the fill or structure. When the property is in the flood fringe of a stream or watercourse, the excavation shall be made
opposite or adjacent to the areas to be filled or occupied. All floodplain storage lost below the existing 10-year flood elevation shall be replaced below
the proposed 10-year flood elevation. All floodplain storage lost above the existing 10-year flood elevation shall be replaced above the 10-year flood
elevation. All such excavations shall be constructed to drain freely and openly to the watercourse. No development permit shall be issued unless the
property owner grants to the village an easement of access for maintenance of the compensatory storage area in a form acceptable to the village
attorney. (Ord. 98-938, 4-27-1998)
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=886 88/377
Sec. 7-81: OCCUPATION AND USE OF IDENTIFIED FLOODWAYS.
This section applies to proposed development, redevelopment, site modification or building modification within a regulatory floodway. No person, firm,
corporation, or governmental body not exempt by state law shall commence any development in a floodway without first obtaining a permit from DWR. All
development shall also meet the requirements of section 7-83 of this article.
No development of any kind or nature shall be permitted within the regulatory floodway except as follows: (Ord. 96-869, 1-22-1996)
(1) Encroachments, including fill, new construction, substantial improvements, and other development within the regulatory floodway are prohibited
unless it has been demonstrated through hydrologic and hydraulic analyses performed in accordance with standard engineering practice that the
proposed encroachment would not result in any increase in flood levels within the community during the occurrence of the base flood discharge. All
new construction and substantial improvements in zones V1-30 and VE, and also zone V if base flood elevation data is available, on the community's
FIRM, must be elevated on pilings and columns so that: a) the bottom of the lowest horizontal structure member of the lowest floor (excluding the
pilings or columns) is elevated to or above the base flood level; and b) the pile or column foundation and structure attached thereto is anchored to
resist flotation, collapse and lateral movement due to the effects of wind and water loads acting simultaneously on all building components. The
elevated portion of the building and supporting foundation system shall not be subject to collapse, displacement, or other structural damage due to
the effects of wind and water loads acting simultaneously on all building components (structural and nonstructural). Water loading values used shall
be those associated with the base flood. Wind loading values used shall be those required by applicable state or village building standards. (Ord. 05-
1234, 3-15-2005)
(2) Rebuilding of existing structures damaged by fire, flood, wind, casualty or acts of God. Such a structure may be repaired only if it was originally built
pursuant to a valid building permit (in cases where a building permit was required) and not originally constructed in violation of any flood control
ordinance. The structure may be repaired only if the perimeter area of the structure is not increased, the total fill brought into the floodway is not
increased, the total amount of impermeable surface is not increased and the repairs are in total conformity to current village regulations and in
compliance in all respects with section 7-80 of this article for development within a flood fringe. If the damage is greater than fifty percent (50%) of
the building's market value before it was damaged, it must also conform to all requirements of subsection 7-82(4)(b)3 of this article. Whether the
damage is greater than fifty percent (50%) of market value shall be determined as follows:
Certified estimate of cost, including labor and materials of restoring the building to its precasualty condition divided by appraised value of building
prior to damage without cost of land as approved by the village equals percent of damage.
If permitted by FEMA regulations in existence at the times that repairs are sought, any reconstruction that requires demolition of all perimeter walls
shall also require that the structure be rebuilt above the base flood elevation while complying with all compensatory storage and detention
requirements. Any reconstruction done pursuant to this subsection must be commenced within one year of the damage.
(3) Construction of the following:
(a) Public flood control projects;
(b) Storm drainage outfalls;
(c) Underground and overhead utilities;
(d) Playing fields and trail systems;
(e) Slope regrading;
(f) Floodproofing of existing structures;
(g) Other structures permitted in 615 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/18g(d)(3) provided that such construction may be accomplished only in absolute
conformity to all federal, state and local regulations with respect to such construction in addition to being in compliance with any regulations
approved by IDOT/DWR in existence at the time application is made. No permit shall be granted unless a registered professional engineer verifies
that there has been compliance with all rules regulating, including, but not limited to, the requirements set forth in the department of natural
resources model floodplain ordinance as it may hereafter be amended.
(4) Whenever any portion of a floodway is authorized for use, the volume of space which will be occupied by the authorized fill or structure below the
base flood or 100-year frequency flood elevation shall be compensated for and balanced by a hydraulically equivalent volume of excavation taken
from below the base flood or 100-year frequency flood elevation. The excavation volume shall be at least equal to one and one-half (1.5) times the
volume of storage lost due to the fill or structure.
(5) If any development within the floodway involves the installation of a flood control structure, the developer shall apply to IDOT/DWR for a conditional
approval of a regulatory floodway map change.
(6) To locate the regulatory floodway boundary on any site, the regulatory floodway boundary should be scaled off the regulatory floodway map and
located on a site plan, using reference marks common to both maps. Where interpretation is needed to determine the exact location of the regulatory
floodway boundary, DWR shall be contacted for the interpretation and its interpretation shall be final. (Ord. 96-869, 1-22-1996; amd. Ord. 05-1234, 3-
15-2005)
Sec. 7-82: PERMITTING REQUIREMENTS APPLICABLE TO ALL SPECIAL FLOODPLAIN AREAS.
In addition to the requirements found in sections 7-80 and 7-81 of this article for development in flood fringes and regulatory floodways, the following
requirements shall be met. (Ord. 96-869, 1-22-1996)
(1) Public Health Standards.
(a) The locating or storing of chemicals, explosives, buoyant materials, animal wastes, fertilizers, flammable liquids, pollutants, or other hazardous or
toxic material below the FPE is prohibited, provided, however, that underground storage tanks (USTs) containing such substances may be installed
provided they meet the requirements of the appropriate state agency. (Ord. 17-1670, 1-17-2017)
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=886 89/377
(b) New and replacement water supply systems, wells, sanitary sewer lines and on site waste disposal systems may be permitted providing all
manholes or other aboveground openings located below the FPE are lockable and watertight.
(2) Carrying Capacity And Notification. For all projects involving channel modification, channel fill or stream maintenance (including levees), the flood
carrying capacity of the watercourse shall be maintained. The developer shall provide written proof to the Building and Zoning Commissioner that
written notification has been given to Northbrook, Glenview, Wilmette, Winnetka and Cook County of the alteration or relocation. Such notification shall
be given at least thirty (30) days prior to the issuance of a building permit by the Village of Northfield.
(3) Protecting Buildings. All buildings located within a 100-year floodplain or a special flood hazard area, shall be protected from flood damage below the
flood protection elevation in the following situations:
(a) Construction or placement of a new building. (Ord. 96-869, 1-22-1996)
(b) A substantial improvement or structural alteration to an existing building that increases the first floor area by more than twenty percent (20%), or the
building market value by more than fifty percent (50%). The value of improvements and alterations shall be calculated cumulatively over the most
recent ten (10) year period. (Ord 17-1682, 7-18-2017)
(4) Methods For Protecting Buildings. This building protection requirement may be met by one of the following methods:
(a) Construction On Permanent Land Fill. A residential or nonresidential building when allowed, may be constructed on permanent land fill in
accordance with the following:
1. The lowest floor (including basement) shall be at or above the flood protection elevation.
2. The fill shall be placed in layers no greater than one foot (1') area before compaction and should extend at least ten feet (10') beyond the
foundation of the building before sloping below the flood protection elevation. The top of the fill shall be above the flood protection elevation.
However, the ten foot (10') minimum may be waived if a structural engineer certifies an alternative method to protect the building from damages
due to hydrostatic pressures. The fill shall be protected against erosion and scour. The fill shall not adversely effect the flow or surface drainage
from or onto neighboring properties.
(b) Floodproofing Of Residential Buildings. A residential building may be floodproofed only in accordance with the following:
1. The building or improvements shall be elevated on crawl space, stilts, piles, walls, or other foundation that is permanently open to floodwaters and
not subject to damage by hydrostatic pressures of the base flood. There shall be a minimum of two (2) permanent openings which shall be no
more than one foot (1') above grade. The openings must have a total net area of not less than one square inch for every one square foot of
enclosed area below the base flood elevation.
2. The foundation and supporting members shall be anchored and aligned in relation to flood flows and adjoining structures so as to minimize
exposure to known hydrodynamic forces such as current, waves, ice and floating debris.
3. All areas below the flood protection elevation shall be constructed of materials resistant to flood damage. The lowest floor (including basement)
and all electrical, heating, ventilating, plumbing, and air conditioning equipment and utility meters shall be located at or above the flood protection
elevation. Water and sewer pipes, electrical and telephone lines, submersible pumps, and other waterproofed service facilities may be located
below the flood protection elevation.
4. The areas below the flood protection elevation may only be used for the parking of vehicles, building access or storage in an area other than a
basement.
(5) Floodproofing On Nonresidential Buildings. Nonresidential buildings may be floodproofed as in subsection (4)(b) of this section, or structurally dry
floodproofed provided that a registered professional engineer shall certify that the building has been structurally dry floodproofed below the flood
protection elevation and the structure and attendant utility facilities are watertight and capable of resisting the effects of the base flood. The building
design shall take into account flood velocities, duration, rate of rise, hydrostatic and hydrodynamic forces, the effects of buoyancy and impacts from
debris or ice. Floodproofing measures shall be operable without human intervention and without an outside source of electricity (levees, berms,
floodwalls and similar works are not considered floodproofing for the purpose of this subsection).
(6) Nonconforming Structures. Nonconforming structures located in a regulatory floodway may remain in use, but may not be enlarged and may be
restored only in accordance with this section and sections 7-81 and 7-83 of this article.
(7) Appropriate Use Standards. Any construction in the regulatory floodway shall meet the more restrictive appropriate use standards as specified by
FEMA or DWR regulations as referred to in section 7-81 of this article. (Ord. 96-869, 1-22-1996)
Sec. 7-83: OTHER DEVELOPMENT REQUIREMENTS.
The corporate authorities shall take into account flood hazards, to the extent that they are known in all official actions related to land management, use and
development.
(1) New subdivisions, annexation agreements, and planned unit developments (PUDs) within the special flood hazard area shall be reviewed to assure
that the proposed developments are consistent with this section and sections 7-80, 7-81, and 7-82 of this article and the need to minimize flood
damage. Plats or plans for new subdivisions and planned unit developments (PUDs) shall include a signed statement by a registered professional
engineer that the plat or plans account for changes in the drainage of surface waters in accordance with the plat act1, this article and article IV of this
chapter.
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=886 90/377
(2) Proposals for new subdivisions, planned unit developments (PUDs), and additions to subdivisions shall include base flood or 100-year flood elevation
data and floodway delineation. Where this information is not available from existing study filed with the Illinois state water survey, the applicant's
engineer shall be responsible for calculating the base flood or 100-year frequency flood elevation per subsection 7-79(3) of this article and the floodway
delineation per the definition in section 7-76 of this article and submitting it to the state water survey and DWR for review and approvals.
(3) Streets, blocks, lots, parks and other public grounds shall be located and laid out in such a manner as to preserve and utilize natural streams and
channels. Wherever possible, the special flood hazard areas shall be included within parks or other public grounds.
(4) The corporate authorities shall not approve any planned unit development (PUD) or plat of subdivision located outside the corporate limits unless such
development or plat is in accordance with the provisions of this article. (Ord. 96-869, 1-22-1996)
Sec. 7-84: VARIANCES.
Any request for a variance to the regulations contained in this article shall be in accordance with the provisions set forth herein:
(1) Variances Prohibited. No variances from this article shall be granted to any development located in a "regulatory floodway", as defined in section 7-76
of this article. Further, no variance may be granted which would reduce compensatory storage requirements for any portion of the floodplain to less
than one hundred percent (100%) as defined in subsection 7-80(7) of this article.
(2) Procedure. Requests for variations from the strict application of this article that are not otherwise prohibited herein shall be made to the plan and
zoning commission in accordance with the procedures set forth in section 4-29 of this code.
(3) Standards For Variance. In making a recommendation for the granting of any variance, the plan and zoning commission shall consider the following:
(a) Whether the requested variance will not be detrimental to public health and safety;
(b) Whether strict application of the provisions of this article would be unduly burdensome on the petitioner;
(c) Whether the requested variance would have a detrimental effect on surrounding properties; and
(d) Whether the requested variance is only a minor deviation of the provisions of this article. (Ord. 17-1670, 1-17-2017)
Sec. 7-85: DISCLAIMER OF LIABILITY.
The degree of flood protection required by this article is considered reasonable for regulatory purposes and is based on available information derived from
engineering and scientific methods of study. Larger floods may occur or flood heights may be increased by manmade or natural causes. This article does
not imply that development, either inside or outside of the special flood hazard area, will be free from flooding or damage. This article does not create
liability on the part of the village or any officer or employee for any flood damage that results from reliance of this article or any administrative decision
made pursuant to it. (Ord. 96-869, 1-22-1996)
Sec. 7-86: PENALTY.
Failure to comply with the requirements of a permit or conditions of a variance resolution shall be deemed to be a violation of this article. Upon due
investigation, the building and zoning commissioner may determine that a violation of the minimum standards of this article exist. The building and zoning
commissioner shall notify the owner in writing of such violation.
(1) If such owner fails after ten (10) days' notice to correct the violation:
(a) The village may make application to the circuit court for an injunction requiring conformance with this article or make such other order as the court
deems necessary to secure compliance with this article.
(b) Any person who violates this article shall, upon conviction thereof, be fined not less than two hundred dollars ($200.00) or more than one thousand
dollars ($1,000.00) for each offense.
(c) A separate offense shall be deemed committed upon each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues.
(d) The village may record a notice of violation on the title to the property.
(2) The building and zoning commissioner shall inform the owner that any such violation is considered a wilful act to increase flood hazards and, therefore,
may cause coverage by a standard flood insurance policy to be suspended.
(3) Nothing herein shall prevent the village from taking such other lawful action to prevent or remedy any violations. All costs connected therewith shall
accrue to the person or persons responsible. (Ord. 96-869, 1-22-1996)
Sec. 7-87: ABROGATION AND GREATER RESTRICTIONS.
This article is not intended to repeal, abrogate or impair any existing easements, covenants, or deed restrictions. Where this article and other ordinances,
easements, covenants, or deed restrictions conflict or overlap, whichever imposes the more stringent restrictions shall prevail. This article is intended to

repeal the original ordinance and subsequent revisions which were adopted to meet the national flood insurance program regulations, but is not intended
to repeal the resolution which the village passed in order to establish initial eligibility for the program. (Ord. 96-869, 1-22-1996)
Sec. 7-88: OTHER PROVISIONS.
(1) It is recognized that property owners may inquire of village officials from time to time with respect to flood elevations, buildability or floodplain
regulations. The village official may respond to such inquiries from property owners only, but shall require a written acknowledgment from the
property owner that the response is informal in nature, nonbinding on the village and subjects the village to no liability for information which may later
prove incorrect. Once a bona fide application for a building permit has been filed, village officials shall perform all appropriate duties pursuant to this
article.
(2) If any questions or ambiguities arise under this article, such questions or ambiguities as to interpretation will be resolved by an opinion letter issued
by the village manager as approved by the corporate authorities of the village. Such opinion letter shall be final and shall be subject to review only
under article III of the Illinois code of civil procedure.
(3) Any engineering or other professional evaluations obtained by an applicant shall be subject to the review and approval of the village.
(4) All data from any source which is adopted by or referred to in this article is hereby recognized to be tentative and subject to error. For this reason,
when any application is made for any development within the floodplain, the village shall be permitted to receive from any party, including the village
itself, any data which tends to indicate that the data sources set forth in this article are in error. Upon submission by the village engineer or any other
engineering consultant, the corporate authorities may, applying appropriate engineering standards and complying with any FEMA or department of
natural resources approval process, substitute the alternative data for data set forth in the sources in this article. The filing of an application for a
building permit pursuant to this article shall not automatically entitle the applicant to the use of the data set forth in this article.
(5) No person who is the owner of property which has already been issued a certificate of occupancy for occupation of a structure in a special flood
hazard area, shall be permitted, on account of this article to remove or reduce the capacity of an already installed flood control structure or measure.
(6) Unless specific action is taken to the contrary by the corporate authorities, any documents incorporated by reference into this article shall include
subsequent amendment to those documents by the respective government agencies. (Ord. 96-869, 1-22-1996)
Sec. 7-89: SEPARABILITY.
The provisions and sections of this article shall be deemed separable and the invalidity of any portion of this article shall not affect the validity of the
remainder. (Ord. 96-869, 1-22-1996)
Sec. 7-90: EFFECTIVE DATE.
This article shall be in full force and effect, from and after its passage and approval and publication as required by law. (Ord. 96-869, 1-22-1996)
