Sec. 11-177: MINORS AND SEXUALLY ORIENTED BUSINESSES.
A person commits a violation of this article if he/she operates or causes to be operated a sexually oriented business, regardless of whether or not a permit
has been issued for said business, and knowingly or with reasonable cause to know permit, suffer or allow:
(1) Admittance of a person under twenty one (21) years of age to the business premises;
(2) A person under twenty one (21) years of age to remain at the business premises;
(3) A person under twenty one (21) years of age to purchase goods or services at the business premises; or
(4) A person who is under twenty one (21) years of age to work at the business premises as an employee. (Ord. 03-1148, 2-18-2003)
Sec. 11-178: ADVERTISING REGULATIONS.
A. It shall be unlawful and a person commits a violation of this article if he/she operates or causes to be operated a sexually oriented business, regardless
of whether or not a permit has been issued for said business, and advertises the presentation of any activity prohibited by any applicable state statute
or local ordinance.
B. It shall be unlawful and a person commits a violation of this article if he/she operates or causes to be operated a sexually oriented business, and
displays or otherwise exhibits any materials and/or performances found at such sexually oriented business in any advertising which is visible outside
the premises. This shall apply regardless of whether or not a permit has been issued for said business. This prohibition shall not extend to the
advertising of the existence or location of such sexually oriented business.
C. The permittee shall not allow any portion of the interior premises to be visible from outside the premises.
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=886 186/377
D. All off street parking areas and premises entries of the sexually oriented business shall be illuminated from dusk to closing hours of operation with a
lighting system which provides an average maintained horizontal illumination of one foot-candle of light on the parking surface and/or walkways. This
required lighting level is established in order to provide sufficient illumination of the parking areas and walkways serving the sexually oriented business
for the personal safety of the sexually oriented business for the personal safety of patrons and employees and to reduce the incidence of vandalism
and criminal conduct. The lighting shall be shown on the required sketch or diagram of the premises. (Ord. 03-1148, 2-18-2003)
Sec. 11-179: HOURS OF OPERATION.
A. It shall be unlawful and a person commits a violation if he/she operates or causes to be operated a sexually oriented business, regardless of whether or
not a permit has been issued for said business, and allows such business to remain open for business, or to permit any employee to engage in a
performance, solicit a performance, make a sale, solicit a sale, provide a service, or solicit a service, before one o'clock (1:00) P.M. of any day or after
eleven o'clock (11:00) P.M. on any day.
B. It shall be unlawful and a person commits a violation if, working as an employee of a sexually oriented business, regardless of whether or not a permit
has been issued for the business, the employee engages in a performance, solicits a performance, makes a sale, solicits a sale, provides a service, or
solicits a service before one o'clock (1:00) P.M. on any day or after eleven o'clock (11:00) P.M. of any day. (Ord. 03-1148, 2-18-2003)
Sec. 11-180: NUDITY AT SEXUALLY ORIENTED BUSINESSES NOT OFFERING FOR SALE ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES.
The United States supreme court in the decision of Barnes v. Glen Theater, Inc., 501 U.S. 560, 111 S. Ct. 2456, (June 21, 1991) and Erie v. Paps, Op. Cit.
has upheld the right of cities to prohibit live public exposure of a persons' private parts, specifically applies to sexually oriented businesses (regardless of
whether or not a permit has been issued to said businesses under this article), including the businesses where no alcoholic beverages are sold, served, or
consumed at the premises.
Live nudity is prohibited in the village of Northfield within any business, including, but not limited to, a sexually oriented business. Any sexually oriented
business which is found in violation of this section shall have its permit revoked pursuant to the provisions of section 11-172 of this article. (Ord. 03-1148,
2-18-2003)
Sec. 11-181: ADDITIONAL PROHIBITIONS FOR THE OPERATION OF A SEXUALLY ORIENTED BUSINESS WITHOUT A VALID
PERMIT.
In addition to the provisions found in other sections of this article, the following additional provisions shall also apply to sexually oriented businesses:
It shall be unlawful and a person commits a violation if he/she operates or causes to be operated a sexually oriented business, regardless of whether or
not a permit has been issued for said business and the person knows or should know that:
(1) The business does not have a sexually oriented business permit under this article for any applicable classification;
(2) The business has a permit which is under suspension;
(3) The business has a permit which has been revoked; or
(4) The business has a permit which has expired. (Ord. 03-1148, 2-18-2003)
Sec. 11-182: EXEMPTIONS.
A. It is a defense to prosecution for any violation of this article that a person appearing in a state of nudity did so in a modeling class operated:
(1) By a college, junior college or university supported entirely or partly by taxation;
(2) By a private college or university which maintains and operates educational programs in which credits are transferable to a college, junior college,
or university supported entirely or partly by taxation; or
(3) In a structure:
(a) Which has no sign visible from the exterior of the structure and no other advertising that indicates a nude person is available for viewing; and
(b) Where, in order to participate in a class a student must enroll at least three (3) days in advance of the class; and
(c) Where no more than one nude model is on the premises at any one time.
B. It is a defense to prosecution for a violation of this article that an employee of a sexually oriented business, regardless of whether or not it is permitted
under this article, exposed any specified anatomical area during the employee's bona fide use of a restroom or during the employee's bona fide use of
a dressing room which is accessible only to employees. (Ord. 03-1148, 2-18-2003)
Sec. 11-183: PENALTIES AND ADDITIONAL LEGAL, EQUITABLE AND INJUNCTIVE RELIEF.
In addition to whatever penalties are applicable under the state of Illinois criminal code, if any person fails or refuses to obey or comply with or violates any
of the provisions of this article, such person upon conviction of such offense, shall be guilty of a violation and shall be punished by a fine as set forth in
appendix D of this code. Each violation or noncompliance shall be considered a separate and distinct offense. Further, each day of continued violation or
noncompliance shall be considered as a separate offense.
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=886 187/377
Nothing shall prevent or restrict the village from taking such other lawful action in any court of competent jurisdiction as is necessary to prevent or remedy
any violation or noncompliance. Such other lawful actions shall include, but shall not be limited to, an equitable action for injunctive relief or an action at
law for damages.
All remedies and penalties provided for in this section shall be cumulative and independently available to the village and the village shall be authorized to
pursue any and all remedies set forth in this section to the full extent allowed by law. (Ord. 03-1148, 2-18-2003)
Sec. 11-184: IMMUNITY FROM PROSECUTION.
The village and its designees, the village of Northfield police department and all other departments and agencies, and all other village officers, agents and
employees charged with enforcement of state and local laws and codes shall be immune from prosecution, civil or criminal, for reasonable, good faith
trespass upon a sexually oriented business while acting within the scope of authority conferred by this article. (Ord. 03-1148, 2-18-2003)
Sec. 11-185: PROHIBITION OF DISTRIBUTION OF SEXUAL DEVICES.
A. It is unlawful for anyone to distribute, for commercial purpose, sell or offer for sale any device, instrument or paraphernalia designed or marketed
primarily for stimulation of human genital organs or for sadomasochistic use or abuse of themselves or others.
B. Such devices, instruments or paraphernalia include, but are not limited to, phallic shaped vibrators, dildos, muzzles, whips, chains, leather restraints,
racks, nonmedical enema kits, body piercing implements (excluding earrings or other decorative jewelry) or other tools of sadomasochistic abuse. (Ord.
03-1148, 2-18-2003)
Sec. 11-186: CONDUCT OF EMPLOYEES AND PATRONS.
A. An employee of a sexually oriented business while within the establishment or on the property, commits a violation if she or he touches a customer or
the clothing of a customer while performing or dancing, or performs, dances or performs any service from a distance in violation of section 11-188 of
this article.
B. A customer or patron of any sexually oriented business commits an offense if he or she touches an employee or the clothing of an employee of any
sexually oriented business. It is the intent of this article that there be no physical contact of any kind or nature (skin to skin, skin to clothing or clothing
to clothing), between an employee and a patron. (Ord. 03-1148, 2-18-2003)
Sec. 11-187: TIPS.
A. Except as set forth in subsection C of this section, no patron shall, in any manner or form, pay for any service or form of entertainment or give any
gratuities directly to any dancer or performer.
B. Except as set forth in subsection C of this section, no dancer shall solicit, in any form or manner, any payment for any service or form of entertainment
or solicit any gratuity from any patron of any sexually oriented businesses.
C. Any payment for any service, entertainment or gratuities for dancers or performers of any sexually orientated businesses must be placed in a
designated box within the facility not located on the dancing or performing stage or in violation of the distance requirements stated in section 11-188 of
this article. (Ord. 03-1148, 2-18-2003)
Sec. 11-188: PERFORMANCE LOCATION.
Any dancing or performance must be on a designated fixed or immovable stage elevated at least four feet (4') from the floor and no patron or audience
member may be seated or otherwise perform or be within ten feet (10') of the edge of a stage or go onto a stage. No dancer, entertainer or employee of
any sexually oriented business may stand, kneel or crouch with any patron or provide any form of entertainment for any patron in violation of the distance
requirements of this section. (Ord. 03-1148, 2-18-2003)
Sec. 11-189: ALL AREAS MUST BE OPEN.
No employee, dancer, performer or other entertainer of any sexually oriented business may provide any service or form of entertainment for any person in
any area which is not open to all other persons within the sexually oriented business. All areas of the sexually oriented business shall be open and
accessible to all customers and patrons and must be visible from the main customer seating area and shall not be closed off from other customer areas.
The interior of the patron washrooms shall not be visible to other customers, but employees may not use the same washrooms as patrons or customers.
(Ord. 03-1148, 2-18-2003)
ARTICLE VII. SALES TAX PREDATION PROHIBITED
Sec. 11-190: SALES TAX SHARING ARRANGEMENT.
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=886 188/377
The Village of Northfield shall not enter into any sales tax sharing arrangement with a retail entity when the sales transaction does not take place in the
Village of Northfield or otherwise have the appropriate nexus to the Village. (Ord. 11-1503, 12-5-2011)
Sec. 11-191: REPORT OF SALES.
It shall be unlawful for any person or entity located in the Village of Northfield, that is required by law to collect the Illinois Retailers' Occupation Tax, to: 1)
report sales that are made from a Village of Northfield location as being made elsewhere; or 2) enter into any agreement with any other unit of local
government to make such reports. (Ord. 11-1503, 12-5-2011)
ARTICLE VIII. CONFLICTS WITH CERTAIN HOME RULE COUNTY ORDINANCES
11-192. PAID SICK LEAVE.
A. Employers located within the Village shall comply with all applicable Federal and/or State laws and regulations as such laws and regulations may exist
from time to time with regard to paid sick leave. Employee eligibility for paid sick leave shall also be in compliance with all applicable Federal and/or
State laws and regulations as such laws and regulations may exist from time to time.
B. No additional obligations with regard to paid sick leave imposed by any ordinance adopted by the County of Cook Board of Commissioners shall apply
to employers located within the Village.
C. For the purposes of this section, the term "employee" means an individual permitted to work by an employer regardless of the number of persons the
employer employs, and the term "employer" means any person employing one or more employees, or seeking to employ one or more employees, if the
person has its principal place of business within the Village or does business within the Village.
D. For the purposes of this section, the term "employer" does not mean:
(1) The government of the United States or a corporation wholly owned by the government of the United States;
(2) An Indian tribe or a corporation wholly owned by an Indian tribe;
(3) The government of the State or any agency or department thereof; or
(4) The government of any municipality. (Ord. 17-1696, 12-5-2017)
ARTICLE IX. PENALTY
Sec. 11-193: PENALTY.
The license of any person, firm or corporation found guilty of violating any section of this chapter shall be subject to revocation. In addition, a person, firm
or corporation found guilty of violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall be subject to a penalty as set forth in appendix D, article III of this Code.
However, in addition to revocation, any person violating a provision of article II, division XI of this chapter shall be penalized according to the penalties
available under a Class C misdemeanor pursuant to the Illinois Criminal Code. (Ord. 97-915, 10-27-1997; amd. Ord. 98-948, 9-28-1998; Ord. 98-952, 10-
26-1998; Ord. 00-1035, 7-17-2000; Ord. 03-1148, 2-18-2003; Ord. 11-1503, 12-5-2011; Ord. 17-1696, 12-5-2017)

Title Chapter 12
SIGN REGULATIONS
Chapter 12
SIGN REGULATIONS
Sec. 12-1: INTENT OF REGULATIONS.
In order that the public locate goods, services and facilities in the village without difficulty or confusion, and to maintain a high quality of development
throughout the village, it is the intent of this chapter to encourage excellence in the design of signs, to promote signs compatible with their surroundings,
appropriate to the type of activity to which they pertain and expressive of the identity of the proprietors of the premises on which such signs are located. In
no case shall permanent signage be used for the sole purpose of advertising. These regulations are further intended to reduce visual confusion, restrict
signs which overload the public's capacity to receive information or which increase the probability of accidents by distracting attention, obstructing vision or
which otherwise adversely affect the public health, safety or welfare. (Ord. 90-655, 11-26-1990)
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=886 189/377
Sec. 12-2: DEFINITIONS.
For the purpose of this chapter, the singular shall include the plural and the masculine shall include the feminine where required by context. ln addition, the
following words and phrases shall have the meaning respectively ascribed to them by this section. Any definition which is regulatory in its terms, shall be
deemed part of the regulations of this chapter.
DEFINITION OF A SIGN.
SIGN. Any permanent or temporary description, display, identification, illuminated device, or illustration which is visible from any public place or is located
on private property and exposed to the public and which its sole purpose is to provide information, identify or offer direction to an activity, building,
business, institution, governmental building, person, place, service or structure; includes any emblem, painting, banner, pennant, placard, poster, symbol
installed or situated merchandise or temporary sign designed to identify or convey information, with the exception of a flag of a unit of government.
OTHER RELEVANT DEFINITIONS.
ADDRESS SIGN. A sign identifying the street and number of the building on which it is placed.
AGGREGATE SIGN USAGE. The total square footage of all the signs on a lot.
ANIMATED SIGNS. Any sign which includes action or motion.
AREA OF A SIGN. The area of a sign shall be computed by the applicable mathematical formula for the shape of the sign face. ln the case of a sign made
up of separate letters or characterizations connected in meaning the area shall be computed as the area lying within straight lines connecting the extreme
projections, corners, or edges of the letters, characters, and other figures composing the sign taken as a whole. See illustration 3 at the end of this chapter.
In the case of a ground sign, the area of the base of the sign shall not be counted towards the total square footage of the sign. The base shall be limited to
four feet (4') in height and landscaped wherever possible. See illustration 3A at the end of this chapter.
In the case of a multifaced sign, the area shall be computed as follows:
(1) If the outermost projection of one face is less than twelve inches (12") from the outermost projection of the other face and the message on each
face is the same; the sign area shall be the area of one face. Said sign shall be considered a single sign for purposes of this chapter. See illustration
4 at the end of this chapter.
(2) If the outermost projection of any face of a two (2) faced sign is more than twelve inches (12") removed from the outermost projection of any other
face, or if the message of one face differs in any respect from the message on the other face, the area shall be determined by multiplying the
distance between the outermost projections of the two (2) faces times the height of the sign face and adding that product to the sum of the area of
the two (2) sign faces. See illustration 4 at the end of this chapter.
(3) If a sign has more than two (2) faces with messages, the area shall be the combined area of all faces.
AREA OF STREET EXPOSURE. The square foot area of the building wall (width x height) which faces or is primarily oriented towards the principal street.
The height of the wall shall not include any portion of the roof. If a wall has an irregular form, or is rounded, the area of street exposure shall be calculated
as the area of a projection of an elevation of such wall upon a plane which is parallel to the principal street. See illustration 2 at the end of this chapter.
This calculation shall be used to determine the aggregate sign usage permitted on a lot.
ASYMMETRICAL MULTIFACED SIGN. Multifaced signs with faces which are of different dimensions or whose faces have sides that are not parallel.
AWNING. An overhead cover, often of fabric or metal designed and intended for protection from the weather or as a decorative embellishment, and which
projects from a wall or roof of a structure over a window, walk, door or the like. See section 12-18, illustration 1 of this chapter.
BANNER. A sign made of lightweight material, such as vinyl, fabric or a similar flexible material that is either ground mounted between two (2) poles,
mounted to an exterior building wall or designed as part of a permanent sign structure which promotes grand openings, special promotions, holidays,
special events, charitable events, educational events and is displayed for a limited amount of time.
BENCH SIGN. A sign located on any part of the surface of a bench or seat placed on or adjacent to a public right of way.
BILL. A poster or similar public notice.
BILLBOARD. See definition of Off Premises Sign.
BUILDING. Any structure permanently affixed to the ground with a permanent roof, separated on all sides from adjacent open space by exterior or party
walls; built for the support, shelter, or enclosure of persons, animals, chattel, or movable property of any kind.
CANOPY SIGN. A sign which is located in a hood, awning, or roof like structure which projects from a building wall for the purpose of providing shelter or
protection from the weather. See section 12-18, illustration 1 of this chapter.
CHANGEABLE COPY SIGN. A permanent sign that is designed or used so that characters, letters, or symbols can be manually changed or rearranged
without altering the surface of the sign for purposes of conveying store hours or help wanted.
COMMERCIAL ADVERTISING SIGN. A temporary sign advertising retail and nonretail uses as defined herein.
DIRECTORY SIGN. A sign stating the names and locations of occupants and uses within the building in letters not exceeding one-half inch (1/2") in height
and width and which sign shall not exceed six (6) square feet in area. A directory sign must be attached to the building which it serves.
ELECTRIC SIGN. See definition of Illuminated Sign (Internal).
EMBELLISHMENT. Letters, numbers, objects, figures, characters or representations projecting more than six inches (6") from the surface to which they
are attached.
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=886 190/377
EMBLEM. An object or representation that functions as a symbol.
FLASHING SIGN. Any sign which contains an intermittent or flashing light source, or which includes the illusion of intermittent of flashing light by means of
animation, or an externally mounted intermittent light source.
GARAGE SALE SIGN. Any sign advertising a sale open to the public, conducted from or on a residential premises in any residential zone as defined by
the zoning ordinance, for the purpose of disposing of personal property owned and maintained by an individual or members of the immediate family
residing on the property and acquired in the normal course of living in or maintaining a residence.
GROUND SIGN. Any sign located on the ground or supported by structural members placed in the ground and which is structurally independent of any
other structure on the lot. See section 12-18, illustration 1 of this chapter.
HEIGHT OF SIGN. The vertical distance from the upper surface of the nearest adjacent street curb to the highest point of the sign; or if no curb is present,
then from the adjacent street grade.
IDENTIFICATION SIGN. A sign containing only the name and address of the occupant or business establishment.
ILLUMINATED SIGN (EXTERNAL). A sign characterized as having its source of artificial light located on or outside the perimeter of such sign.
ILLUMINATED SIGN (INTERNAL). A sign characterized as having its source of artificial light located within the perimeter of such sign.
ILLUSTRATIONS. Various signs are depicted in the addendum of this chapter. These illustrations are an integral part of this chapter.
INDEXING SIGN. A sign designed to change from one message to another by use of multifaced sections with moving and stopping actions.
LOT. A zoning lot unless the context of the chapter clearly indicates otherwise.
LOT LINE. A recorded property boundary line of any single lot which divides one lot from another lot or from a right of way.
MARQUEE SIGN. See definition of Canopy Sign.
MULTIFACED SIGN. A sign with a message or surface intended for a message on more than one side.
NONCOMMERCIAL SIGN. Signs, espousing charitable, political, social, civic, religious, philanthropic or other nonprofit ideological causes. This is
intended to include the promulgation of all information protected by the first amendment to the United States constitution which does not promote retail or
nonretail commercial establishments as defined herein.
NONCONFORMING SIGN. Any sign existing before the adoption hereof which does not conform to the regulations of this chapter.
NONRETAIL COMMERCIAL ESTABLISHMENT. An establishment which produces or distributes goods for use by industry, a particular trade or retail
establishments.
OFF PREMISES SIGN. Any sign including a billboard which directs attention to any promotion, business, commodity, service, or activity which is not
conducted, sold, or offered on the lot upon which the sign is located.
OPAQUE. A surface or material completely impervious to the passage of light.
OPEN HOUSE SIGN. Any sign which may accompany a real estate sign and be used to indicate the premises is open for viewing by the general public.
OPEN WALL SIGN. A wall sign that consists of formed or shaped letters, numerals, trademarks or other insignia that are attached to a wall and between
which the wall is exposed. See illustration 3 at the end of this chapter.
OWNER. Shall include either the owner of the sign or the owner of the premises on which the sign is located.
PAINTING. A picture, design or display in paint.
PENNANT. See definition of Banner.
PERMANENT SIGN. Any fixed sign whose structure and location is not intended to be subject to temporary or routine alteration.
PHYSICAL INTERFERENCE. Any obstruction or distraction caused by a sign that adversely affects highway safety.
PLACARD. A printed or written announcement or display in a public place.
POLE SIGN. See definition of Ground Sign.
PORTABLE SIGN. Any sign designed to be moved from place to place or not permanently attached to the ground or to any structure.
POSTER. A large printed placard, bill, or announcement, often illustrated, posted to advertise or publicize something.
PREMISES. A zoning lot including any structure thereon.
PRINCIPAL STREET. The principal street shall be only one of the following at the option of the owner:
(1) The street from which the building takes its address.
(2) The street on which the building has its main entrance.
PROJECTED IMAGE SIGN. Any sign which has a prephotographed light image projected onto it.
PROJECTING SIGN. Any sign that is fastened directly to an outside wall of any building and projects outward more than twelve inches (12") from such
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=886 191/377
wall.
PUBLIC RIGHT OF WAY. Land under the control of a public agency that is dedicated for public use to accommodate a transportation system and/or public
infrastructure.
PUBLIC SERVICE INFORMATION SIGN. Any sign intended primarily to promote items of general interest to the community rather than to espouse a
particular idea, product or service.
PUBLIC STREET. The area lying within the described limits of a dedicated right of way or thoroughfare for vehicular traffic (excluding an alley) which is
open to public use as a matter of right.
PYLON SIGN. See definition of Ground Sign.
REAL ESTATE SIGN. Any sign which is used to offer for sale, lease or rent the property upon which the sign is placed. Both residential, commercial and
office real estate signs are included.
RESIDENTIAL NAMEPLATE SIGNS. A nonilluminated sign identifying only the name, address, profession or degree of the occupant of premises on which
the sign is located.
RETAIL COMMERCIAL ESTABLISHMENT. An establishment which sells products or services to the general public.
RIGHT OF WAY. A strip of land acquired by the public or by a utility and occupied or intended to be occupied by a street, walkway, railroad, utility or other
similar use.
ROOF SIGN. Signs on, above, mounted on, attached to or overhanging the roof of any building.
SEASONAL OR HOLIDAY SIGNS. Signs used for generally recognized holidays which are installed for a limited period of time, e.g., Christmas
decorations.
SIGN STRUCTURE. Any structure which supports, has supported or is capable of and intended to support a sign.
SINGLE FACED SIGN. A sign with a message on only one side.
SNIPE SIGN. Any sign of any material that is attached in any way to a utility pole, tree, traffic sign pole or fence located on public or private property.
Banners displayed for the purpose of publicizing civic events shall not be included in this definition.
SOLD SIGN. Signs with a message indicating that real estate has been sold.
STRUCTURE. Anything constructed or erected, the use of which requires permanent location on the ground or attachment to something having a
permanent location on the ground, including advertising signs.
SYMBOL. See definition of Emblem.
TEMPORARY SIGN. Any sign, or advertising description or display, which has a designated display period in conjunction with a special event (e.g., sale,
construction, for sale or lease), usually constructed of cloth, canvas, fabric, paper or other light material and designed or intended to be displayed for a
short period of time not to exceed three (3) months. See section 12-18, illustration 1 of this chapter.
TRANSLUCENT. A surface or material that allows light to be transmitted but causes sufficient diffusion to eliminate view of the light source.
UNIMPROVED LOT. A lot or tract of land which is unoccupied by any building or structure.
VILLAGE. The village of Northfield, Illinois.
WINDOW SIGN. Any sign which is applied to, placed in or attached to a window or is located within a building such that the sign may be viewed from the
exterior of the building. See section 12-18, illustration 1 of this chapter. (Ord. 90-655, 11-26-1990; amd. Ord. 95-845, 5-22-1995; Ord. 03-1149, 2-18-2003;
Ord. 03-1156, 3-18-2003; Ord. 11-1481, 3-15-2011; Ord. 11-1489, 7-19-2011)
Sec. 12-3: STANDARDS AND CRITERIA.
All signs erected or posted in the village of Northfield, except those listed in section 12-5 of this chapter shall be submitted with detailed designs to the
building commissioner for referral to the architectural commission. The following standards shall be utilized in the architectural commission's evaluation of
submittals:
(1) Signs may only be displayed on a principal street exposure except as follows:
(a) If the building has more than one tenant and the main entrances of those tenants are on different sides of the building, then each tenant may
have signs on his side of the building. This exception will not increase the aggregate sign usage permitted on the lot.
(b) If it is demonstrated to the architectural commission that strict enforcement of this provision: 1) is clearly impractical; or 2) that no public detriment
will result from waiver of this restriction.
(2) An overall sign plan shall be submitted where a building, lot, or group of continuous buildings are under common ownership or control and
contemplate more than one sign.
(3) The information contained in a sign shall be:
(a) Appropriate to the activity to which it pertains.
(b) Legible in the circumstances in which it is seen.
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=886 192/377
(c) Limited in quantity so as not to be confusing or misleading.
(4) No advertising sign shall be permitted on any railroad right of way or siding regardless of the zoning district in which it is located.
(5) No sign may be erected or maintained in any zoning district if the sign emits or reflects more than thirty (30) foot-candles of light at a distance of one
foot (1') based upon an average of three (3) readings taken at any three (3) points on the sign as long as the distance between each of those points
is at least one-third (1/3) of the longest side of the sign or if the sign is round, one-third (1/3) its diameter. No single point of light emission or reflection
shall exceed seventy five (75) foot-candles at a distance of one foot (1'). Any sign violating this standard shall be deemed to cause excessive glare.
In addition, the sign contractor must certify in writing that the lighting source meets village code.
(6) A sign shall have a harmonious relationship with nearby signs, buildings and neighborhood. The sign shall be designed so as not to adversely
impact upon adjacent structures. The size, shape, material, color, texture, lettering, numbers, location, arrangement, and lighting of a sign shall be
consistent in character with its building and its surrounding neighborhood.
(7) Colors shall be used with restraint. Sign surfaces shall not be treated with any reflective or glitter type material.
(8) External lighting shall be arranged so that light sources are not visible.
(9) An internally illuminated sign may have no transparent surfaces and may display only letters, trademarks or logos.
(10) Any illuminated sign shall be extinguished between the hours of eleven o'clock (11:00) P.M. and seven o'clock (7:00) A.M., except that such sign
may remain illuminated during such times as the activity to which the sign pertains is open for business during eleven o'clock (11:00) P.M. and seven
o'clock (7:00) A.M.
(11) The sign must be constructed and used so as to maintain the architectural integrity of the building to which it relates. For internally illuminated
signs, only the copy, display and logo shall be of translucent materials, the background of such signs shall be of opaque materials.
(12) Additional restrictions and requirements included elsewhere in this chapter shall be part of the criteria of the design review process. (1986 Code)
Sec. 12-4: PROHIBITED SIGNS.
The following signs are specifically prohibited throughout the village of Northfield.
(1) A-frame, sandwich board, and other signs which are placed on a sidewalk or curb or between a sidewalk and curb or other parkway except as
otherwise provided herein. This prohibition shall not include duly authorized governmental signs.
(2) Permanent advertising signs. (Ord. 90-655, 11-26-1990)
(3) All off premises commercial advertising signs, except those permitted by section 12-5 of this chapter. (Ord. 11-1489, 7-19-2011)
(4) Animated signs.
(5) Asymmetrical multifaced signs.
(6) Bench signs.
(7) Flashing signs.
(8) Ground signs greater than twenty four (24) square feet in area or twelve feet (12') in height from the average grade of the lot.
(9) No wall sign shall be placed higher than the second floor windowsill of a structure; provided, however, that if the wall area to be covered has no
windows or openings, the sign may extend to sixteen feet (16') to top of sign.
(10) Ground signs which overhang any part of another structure, parking or loading area, driveway or walkway.
(11) Signs greater than fifty (50) square feet in area for each face.
(12) Indexing signs. (Ord. 90-655, 11-26-1990)
(13) Neon or similar gaseous tube illuminated signs, except where the neon is used as a backlight and the lamp/bulb is not visible. (Ord. 95-845, 5-22-
1995)
(14) Portable signs.
(15) Projected image signs.
(16) "Projecting signs", as defined herein, except awning and canopy signs.
(17) Roof signs.
(18) Signs consisting of a string, cluster or series of lights, with the exception of "seasonal or holiday decorations" as defined in this chapter.
(19) Signs painted or pasted directly on the wall of a building or on a fence. (Ord. 90-655, 11-26-1990)
(20) Signs or lighting for signs located on or projecting into a public right of way. This shall not include signs or lighting otherwise permitted and which
are eight feet (8') above an adjoining sidewalk and project no more than twelve inches (12") into the right of way. This likewise shall not include
directional or traffic signs authorized by the state, county, or village; or village approved streetlight banners that promote civic events or seasonal
messages/graphics. (Ord. 90-655, 11-26-1990; amd. Ord. 07-1338, 7-17-2007)
(21) Signs posted on any commercial or retail building entrance or exit door with the exception of: a) operating instructions for the door itself, b) signs
required by any government department or organization, c) signs depicting hours of operation. Such signs may not exceed one square foot in area.
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=886 193/377
(22) Signs which move, expand, rotate or in any way change size to attract attention.
(23) Snipe signs.
(24) Permanent signs in any residential district with the exception of street signs and subdivision names.
(25) Sold signs displayed on any lot or premises.
(26) For sale signs displayed in vehicles on any lot or premises. (Ord. 90-655, 11-26-1990)
(27) All other signs of whatever kind or nature which are not specified in section 12-5 or 12-6 of this chapter. (Ord. 11-1489, 7-19-2011)
Sec. 12-5: SIGNS EXEMPT FROM PERMIT REQUIREMENTS.
Each of the following signs is exempt from the application and review process so long as the sign conforms to all other requirements of this chapter and
other regulations of the village of Northfield:
(1) Indoor signs which are not visible from outside the building.
(2) A residential nameplate sign not exceeding eighty (80) square inches in area. Such a sign may also contain a street and house number.
(3) In the case of apartment houses for three (3) or more families, one identification sign not exceeding five (5) square feet in area indicating the name
of the building and its ownership. This may be in addition to such other signs as may be permitted by reason of any commercial use of the first floor.
(Ord. 90-655, 11-26-1990)
(4) Nonilluminated signs, not exceeding two (2) square feet in area, for a garage, estate or demolition sale may be placed on the lot or premises on
which such sale/event is conducted. There may not be more than two (2) such signs on the lot or premises and one off premises. Such signs may be
displayed only on the day of the event. No residential address shall display such a sign more than two (2) times in a calendar year for garage sales
and one time in a calendar year for estate or demolition sales. A permit for such sales shall be obtained after the appropriate application permit/fee
for the sales event has been secured from the village and placed in the front window of the event. No other type of signs shall be permitted for these
events. (Ord. 13-1567, 9-17-2013)
(5) A sign placed on a vehicle. However such vehicle may not be parked for more than two (2) consecutive hours in any location where visible from any
public right of way. This two (2) hour limitation shall not include business vehicles which are parked at a residence or business premises other than
that of the owner of the vehicle while conducting business at that premises. This shall not prohibit an election sign provided such sign conforms to
subsection (16) of this section. (Ord. 90-655, 11-26-1990)
(6) Directional or instructional signs, not exceeding three (3) square feet in area, which provide direction or instruction to guide persons to
noncommercial facilities intended to serve the public. (Ord. 90-655, 11-26-1990; amd. Ord. 02-1106, 3-18-2002)
(7) Temporary nonilluminated window signs in retail establishments only advertising special sales or merchandise or special occasions. The total area
covered by such signs shall not exceed fifteen percent (15%) of the total window area of the street exposure side of the building. Such signs may not
be displayed more than fourteen (14) days prior to the special sale or event to which they pertain, and they shall be removed within twenty four (24)
hours after said sale or event. Temporary nonilluminated window signs shall be used only insofar as they do not produce an aggregate percentage of
sign usage greater than seven percent (7%) of the area of principal street exposure for the lot when added to the permanent signage under
subsection 12-6(2)(b) of this chapter.
(8) Memorial plaques, cornerstones, historical plaques and similar designations not exceeding three (3) square feet displayed for noncommercial
purposes.
(9) Temporary nonilluminated residential real estate signs, advertising the sale or lease of the lot or premises on which it is placed. Information on such
sign shall pertain to said property only. Such signs shall be ten (10) square feet or less in area and limited to one sign per lot and no higher than four
feet (4') in height to the highest part of such sign. Such signs shall be removed within twenty four (24) hours after the sale or lease of the premises.
(10) Temporary nonilluminated commercial and office real estate signs, advertising the sale or lease of the lot or premises on which it is placed.
Information on such sign shall pertain to said property only. Such signs shall be twenty four (24) square feet or less in area and limited to one sign
per lot and no higher than eight feet (8') in height to the highest part of such sign. Such signs shall be removed within twenty four (24) hours after the
sale of the premises or seventy five percent (75%) of the premises is leased.
(11) Open house signs shall be displayed with real estate signs only on Wednesdays and Sundays. Each premises or lot is allowed a maximum of two
(2) signs. One of the two (2) open house signs may be displayed adjacent to the real estate sign on the lot itself and the other may be displayed off
premises at the closest dedicated intersection. (Ord. 90-655, 11-26-1990)
(12) Seasonal or holiday signs or decorations customarily displayed in conjunction with a national holiday or a village sponsored event, for a period not
to exceed sixty (60) days. Lights with globes of more than one inch (1") diameter at any point are not included within this exemption. (Ord. 90-655,
11-26-1990; amd. Ord. 02-1106, 3-18-2002)

(13) Temporary banners. Nonilluminated temporary special event sign/banners to celebrate a special event, such as a grand opening or other special
events, may be displayed outdoors under these conditions:
(a) Banners are to be professionally made and adhere to the following:
1. Banners are to be clear and legible. Letter height is to be at least four inches (4") if all uppercase and at least five inches (5") if upper and lower
case mixed.
2. Banners may not be illuminated unless the banner is part of a permanent ground sign structure.
3. Banners may not exceed thirty two (32) square feet on properties with one hundred (100) linear feet or more of frontage and twenty four (24)
square feet if the frontage is less than one hundred (100) linear feet and/or six feet (6') above ground level unless wall mounted.
4. Wall mounted banners may not be placed higher than the second floor windowsill of the structure.
(b) Banners may be displayed for a maximum period of fourteen (14) days and must be removed within one day following the event, no more than six
(6) times a year.
(c) One banner is allowed per lot. In case of multiple tenants, no more than two (2) banners from different tenants shall be permitted at one time and
no closer than one hundred feet (100').
(d) Banners shall be affixed in such a manner so the banner sign does not allow wind activation and wall banners must remain flush with the wall.
(e) Off site banners are prohibited.
(f) Banners may not be located in the local, county or state right of way or within the sight distance triangle at any street or drive intersection. (Ord.
11-1481, 3-15-2011)
(14) Flags and emblems of any unit of government. The structure to which any such flag or emblem is attached shall conform to the height
requirements for heights of buildings or structures of the zoning district in which it exists.
(15) Address signs not exceeding two (2) square feet in area. (Ord. 90-655, 11-26-1990; amd. Ord. 02-1106, 3-18-2002)
(16) Nonilluminated signs, expressing a political message, that are thirty two (32) square feet or less in area on any single lot or premises. No single
such sign may exceed ten (10) square feet in area. (Ord. 10-1463, 7-20-2010)
(17) Signs required of property owners or occupants by the police, fire or other government departments for the convenience or safety of the public.
(18) Scoreboards for athletic fields. Such scoreboards shall not exceed twenty four (24) square feet.
(19) Directory signs, as defined herein.
(20) "No Trespassing" signs posted on the property to which the signs relate, subject to the following restrictions:
(a) Such signs shall be no more than two (2) square feet in area, and
(b) Such signs may be placed no closer than one hundred (100) yards apart on the same lot, and, in no event, shall exceed four (4) in number per
lot.
(21) Signs warning of danger or prohibiting certain activities with respect to public utility property, not to exceed four (4) square feet in area and limited
in number to such as are necessary to adequately inform the public. (Ord. 90-655, 11-26-1990; amd. Ord. 02-1106, 3-18-2002)
(22) Residential construction signs are limited to one per lot. Such a sign shall be no greater than five (5) square feet in area and may be displayed on
any lot or premises in any R-1, R-2, R-3, R-4, R-5 or R-6 residential dwelling district as established by the Northfield zoning ordinance.
(23) Any municipal or community related signs as approved by the village manager or designee. (Ord. 90-655, 11-26-1990; amd. Ord. 02-1106, 3-18-
2002; Ord. 11-1481, 3-15-2011)
(24) Construction hour signs in accordance with appendix C, section C-8.3, "Construction Signage", of this code. (Ord. 05-1244, 6-21-2005; amd. Ord.
11-1481, 3-15-2011)
(25) Banners displayed for the purpose of publicizing civic events located on village approved ornamental streetlight poles located within the Central
Avenue right of way and in the village center district. The banners may not exceed twelve (12) square feet. A maximum of one banner per streetlight
pole may be displayed. The artwork, copy and colors of all banners are subject to the review and approval of the architectural commission. The
banners may display the name or logo of a community based organization, seasonal messages or graphics, and information announcing villagewide
events. The banners may not contain advertisement of any individual business entity. The banners shall be constructed of fade resistant materials
and incorporate wind flaps to reduce strain. Torn, damaged and faded banners may not be displayed. Banners shall not be displayed under this
subsection until a governmental entity or quasi-governmental entity enters into a written agreement with the village to consider requests for banners
by governmental entities; determines the term of display of banners; determines if proposed public service announcements, seasonal messages, and
civic events are appropriate for publicizing on banners, and provides for the installation, maintenance and removal of banners, subject to the village's
hold harmless, indemnification and insurance requirements. "Civic event" for purpose of this subsection shall include any event sponsored in whole

or in part by the village or any governmental entity. A "quasi-governmental agency" for purposes of this subsection shall be determined by the village.
(Ord. 07-1341, 8-21-2007; amd. Ord. 11-1481, 3-15-2011)
Sec. 12-6: SIGNS REQUIRING A PERMIT.
The following signs are allowed in the village of Northfield subject to the securing of a permit pursuant to section 12-8 of this chapter:
(1) Construction Site Signs. Such signs shall be temporary, nonilluminated and identify only the parties engaged in design, construction, or financing
on the lot or premises on which they are displayed and then only where new construction or remodeling work is in progress and shall be subject to
the following additional restrictions: (Ord. 90-655, 11-26-1990)
(a) Only one sign no greater than twenty four (24) square feet in area may be located on a lot or premises in any R-6, O/R, NC, village center, B-1, B-
2, or M-1 district, as established by the Northfield zoning ordinance. Information with respect to design, construction and financing shall be
removed within seven (7) days after completion of work. (Ord. 90-655, 11-26-1990; amd. Ord. 03-1156, 3-18-2003; Ord. 11-1481, 3-15-2011; Ord.
16-1661, 9-20-2016)
(2) Permanent Signs. Permanent signs calling attention to establishments located on the premises within O/R, village center, B-1, B-2, and M-1 zoning
districts of the village and permitted nonresidential uses in residential districts, with the following restrictions: (Ord. 03-1172, 9-16-2003; amd. Ord.
16-1661, 9-20-2016)
(a) Such signs must be placed only on the principal street exposure side or face of the building, except as stated in subsection 12-3(1) of this
chapter.
(b) The aggregate sign usage for any lot shall not exceed a total of seven percent (7%) of the area of principal street exposure, subject to the
following restrictions:
1. Permanent sign usage shall not exceed five percent (5%) of the area of principal street exposure or one hundred (100) square feet, whichever is
less.
2. Temporary window sign usage for retail establishments under subsection 12-5(7) of this chapter shall not exceed fifteen percent (15%) of the
total window area of the principal street exposure side of the building, subject to the seven percent (7%) limitation for all sign usage on the
building. (Ord. 90-655, 11-26-1990)
(3) Off Premises Directional Signs. No more than two (2) off premises directional signs for educational institutions and governmental buildings. No
single sign shall be more than six (6) square feet in size. The location, placement, design, and color shall be subject to the approval of the
architectural commission. (Ord. 02-1106, 3-18-2002)
Sec. 12-7: OFF PREMISES SIGNS.
Off premises signs, as defined in this chapter, shall not be permitted in the village of Northfield except as noted in subsection 12-5(4) of this chapter
regarding nonilluminated signs for a garage sale, and subsection 12-6(3), "Off Premises Directional Signs", of this chapter. (Ord. 11-1489, 7-19-2011)
Sec. 12-8: OBTAINING SIGN PERMITS.
Any person desiring to erect, construct or maintain a sign, for which a permit is required pursuant to section 12-6 of this chapter, shall submit an
application to the building commissioner on forms provided by the village. (Ord. 11-1489, 7-19-2011)
(1) Whenever the building commissioner receives an application for a sign permit, he shall examine the plans, specifications, and other data submitted
to him. If the proposed sign is in compliance with the rules and regulations of this chapter and other laws and ordinances of the village, he shall refer
the application and other submitted data to the architectural commission which shall have final authority to approve or deny issuance of the permit. If
the proposed sign would not conform to the rules and regulations of the village, the building commissioner shall notify the applicant of the items of
nonconformance and deny the application. The applicant shall then have sixty (60) days to amend the application to conform to the regulations of the
village.
(2) All applications shall contain the following information and material:
(a) Name, address and telephone number of the owner of the property on which the sign is to be located.
(b) Name, address and telephone number of the applicant (owner of the sign).
(c) Name, address and telephone number of the sign contractor, if applicable.
(d) Location of the building, structure or lot on which the sign is to be attached or erected.
(e) One set of color photographs taken within seven (7) days of the application showing from various angles existing signs on the premises and
adjacent property. (Ord. 90-655, 11-26-1990)
(f) Seventeen (17) copies of drawings and other appropriate materials showing: (Ord. 99-961, 1-25-1999)
1. The position of the proposed sign in relation to adjacent signs, buildings, and structures.
2. The design, size, structural details, materials, colors, and placement of the proposed sign and sign structure on the lot or building.
(g) A statement specifying the aggregate size of all signs existing on the lot and building at the time of making such application.
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=886 196/377
(h) The information submitted by the applicant shall be in sufficient detail to illustrate clearly the design for which approval is being sought and its
relationship to the structure it serves. (Ord. 90-655, 11-26-1990)
(i) All applications must be made in writing and shall be accompanied by the applicable fee required in appendix D of this code. (Ord. 99-961, 1-25-
1999)
(3) Upon receipt by the building commissioner of a properly completed application for a sign permit, the architectural commission shall, at its next
meeting occurring not less than thirty (30) days after the receipt of the application, review and render a decision on the application. The applicant or a
qualified representative is required to be in attendance at such meeting. The architectural commission shall apply the standards and criteria set forth
in section 12-3 of this chapter. Additionally:
(a) The architectural commission may, prior to rendering its decision, continue the hearing and make recommendations to the applicant as to
changes in the sign plans which, in the commission judgment, would effect compliance with the standards and criteria set forth in section 12-3 of
this chapter.
(b) Should the architectural commission make recommendations for changes in the sign plans, the applicant shall then have twenty one (21) days
from the date of the initial hearing to notify the architectural commission in writing as to whether the applicant intends to incorporate the
recommendations into the applications. If the applicant decides not to incorporate the recommendations into the application he shall state the
reasons for this decision.
(c) If the applicant accepts in writing the recommended changes, the application shall be deemed to have been amended to conform to the
recommendations.
(d) If the applicant rejects the recommendations, the architectural commission shall decide on the application as originally submitted. If the
commission receives no notice of either acceptance or rejection, the recommendations shall be deemed to have been rejected.
(e) At the next meeting after making its recommendations the architectural commission shall vote on whether to approve or disapprove the
application unless the commission and the applicant agree to further continue the hearing.
(f) The architectural commission may approve a permit application only upon a majority vote of all members. Decisions of the architectural
commission shall be a final order for purposes of administrative review. Therefore, any rejection of an application by the commission shall include,
in writing, the reasons for said rejection. (Ord. 90-655, 11-26-1990)
(4) The community development and building department shall approve or deny the construction site sign application. Two (2) copies of construction
site sign information including: property owner's signature, contact name, address and phone number, site plan including address, rendering of
construction site sign including size, text, colors and dimensions and date to be installed are required. (Ord. 11-1481, 3-15-2011)
(5) All signs for which a permit has been approved under the provisions of this chapter are subject to a final inspection by the building commissioner to
assure compliance with this chapter and the terms of the permit granted hereunder. (Ord. 90-655, 11-26-1990; amd. Ord. 11-1481, 3-15-2011)
Sec. 12-9: INDEMNIFICATION; LIABILITY FOR DAMAGES.
A. Every applicant for a permit for a sign which will extend over or be located within a public right of way shall file with the village a copy of a liability
insurance policy or a certificate of insurance covering all damage or injury that might be caused by the sign, issued by an insurance company
authorized to do business in the state. The limits of liability shall be not less than one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) for property damage and ten
million dollars ($10,000,000.00) for personal injuries. The village, its officers, agents, and employees shall be named as additional parties insured.
Such policy shall be renewed and maintained in force throughout the life of the permit. If at any time the policy shall not be in full force, the permit shall
become null and void.
B. Persons, other than the owner of a premises on which an advertised business is located, who are engaged in the business of erecting, repairing, or
maintaining signs in the village, shall file with the building commissioner a bond in the penal sum of fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) with a
responsible surety company as surety thereon. Said bond shall be subject to the reasonable approval as to form by the village attorney. Said bond shall
indemnify the village, its officers, agents, and employees for any and all loss, cost, expense or liability of any kind or nature whatsoever including
attorney fees which said village or its officers, agents, or employees may sustain by reason of the issuance of a sign permit. This bonding requirement
shall not apply to window signs.
C. Neither the provisions of this section nor the issuance of any sign permit shall be construed as relieving any person erecting, owning or maintaining any
sign from liability arising by reason of personal injury or property damage resulting from work related to the sign; nor shall such permit limit the liability
of any such person for personal injury or property damage resulting therefrom. The provisions of this chapter shall not be construed as imposing upon
the village or its officials or employees any liability by reason of the approval of any sign or sign permit under any of the provisions of this chapter. (Ord.
90-655, 11-26-1990)
Sec. 12-10: REVOCATION OF SIGN PERMIT.
A. In the event that the person to whom a sign permit has been granted fails to complete the work required in accordance with the provisions of said permit
during the time said permit is in effect, the building commissioner shall so notify such person in writing. If such failure is not corrected within ten (10)
days after said notification, the sign permit shall be revoked by order of the building commissioner.
B. Any sign permit issued under this chapter shall be revoked by the building commissioner when it is shown that:
(1) The permit was issued without or in excess of the authority of the commissioner or architectural commission; or
(2) The application for the sign permit contained a material misrepresentation of fact; or
(3) The sign or its structure was erected, constructed, reconstructed, altered, or used in a manner not in compliance with this chapter or the permit and
the submittals which served as the basis for issuance of the permit. (Ord. 90-655, 11-26-1990)
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=886 197/377
Sec. 12-11: SAFETY AND MAINTENANCE.
All safety and maintenance requirements shall be the joint and several obligation of the owner of the sign and the owner of the premises on which it is
located.
(1) All signs shall be designed and constructed to safely support their weight, and to withstand wind and other stresses to which they may be subjected.
(2) All signs in which electrical wiring and connections are to be used shall have a plate showing the voltage of the apparatus attached to it. No
overhead services shall be allowed.
(3) No sign shall be erected, relocated, maintained or otherwise permitted to obstruct or prevent free ingress and egress from any window, door, or
stairway of any building or structure. No sign shall be attached to a fire escape.
(4) No sign shall be erected, constructed or maintained where by reason of its position, shape, color or wording, it may interfere with, obstruct the view
of or be confused with any authorized traffic sign, signal or device; nor shall it otherwise cause a safety hazard. All signs shall be maintained in a
safe, and orderly condition and appearance, and shall be repainted or otherwise maintained periodically to prevent corrosion or deterioration caused
by weather, age or other condition. The owner shall be responsible for providing such maintenance, including any necessary repairs, which shall be
completed within thirty (30) days after notification by the building commissioner of maintenance required hereunder. With respect to freestanding
signs, such maintenance shall also require that the ground area be kept free and clear of weeds, trash and other debris.
(5) Whenever any business, service or other party moves from or vacates the premises previously occupied by it, or for any reason renders a sign not
applicable to the premises, all signs relating to such business, service or use shall be removed from such premises within ten (10) days from the date
of such move, vacation or rendering inapplicable. (Ord. 90-655, 11-26-1990)
Sec. 12-12: NONCONFORMING SIGNS.
A. If a lot or premises is improved or remodeled to the extent of fifty percent (50%) or more, of its existing area or fair market value, all permanent signage
upon the lot and premises shall be made to conform to the provisions of this chapter.
B. If a nonconforming sign is damaged by fire or other casualty, the entire sign shall be made to conform to the provisions of this chapter. (Ord. 90-655, 11-
26-1990)
Sec. 12-13: VIOLATIONS, NUISANCE DECLARATIONS AND ENFORCEMENT.
A. Any person, firm, or corporation which displays a sign or is the legal or beneficial owner of the premises on which a sign is located shall comply with the
provisions of this chapter; and any time this chapter refers to the ownership of a sign, it shall refer with equal effect to legal and beneficial owners of the
lot on which the sign is located. (Ord. 90-655, 11-26-1990)
B. Any sign not authorized under section 12-5 or 12-6 of this chapter is prohibited. (Ord. 11-1489, 7-19-2011)
C. The building commissioner or his representative is hereby authorized and empowered to enforce this chapter. He is hereby authorized to make
inspections and tests of all signs within the village to obtain compliance with the provisions of this chapter. He shall have the right to enter upon any
premises for inspections whenever the premises are open to the general public. If the building commissioner is unable to conduct an inspection which
he deems appropriate, he may apply to the appropriate court for a warrant authorizing entry.
D. Subject to the provisions of section 12-12 of this chapter, all signs violating the provisions of this chapter are hereby declared to be a nuisance and are
subject to abatement pursuant to the State law and the nuisance provisions of this Code.
Additionally, in the event that any sign is deemed by the Northfield Chief of Police to present an immediate peril to persons or property, such sign may
be removed by the Village summarily and without notice. The Village shall be entitled to recover the costs of removal from the owner of the sign or the
owner of the premises on which the sign is located and to place a lien on the property for its costs. (Ord. 90-655, 11-26-1990)
E. Unless otherwise stated in this chapter, any person displaying a sign in violation of this chapter, shall be subject to a fine as outlined in appendix D,
article III of this Code. Additionally, each day of continued violation shall constitute a separate offense with respect to the computation of fines. (Ord.
97-915, 10-27-1997)
F. In addition to other remedies as specified in this chapter, the Village may institute any appropriate action or proceeding to prevent, restrain, correct, or
abate any violation of this chapter, including any action to recover costs incurred in removing or altering signs. (Ord. 90-655, 11-26-1990)
Sec. 12-14: APPEALS.
A. Appeals may be taken to the Architectural Commission as follows:
(1) If the Building Commissioner denies a permit application pursuant to subsection 12-8(1) of this chapter or revokes a permit pursuant to section 12-
10 of this chapter.
(2) If the Building Commissioner determines that a sign is nonconforming pursuant to section 12-12 of this chapter.
B. All appeals pursuant to section 12-7 of this chapter shall be brought before the President and Board of Trustees of the Village.
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=886 198/377
C. All appeals from a determination by the Building Commissioner must be brought within sixty (60) days. (Ord. 90-655, 11-26-1990)
Sec. 12-15: VARIATIONS.
A. Requests for variations from any provisions of this chapter may be filed with the Building Commissioner who shall refer the request to the Architectural
Commission within thirty (30) days. A variation may be permitted only if the variation requested will not alter the essential character of the locality; and
(1) It is in harmony with the general purpose and intent of this chapter; or
(2) The plight of the petitioner is due to unusual circumstances; or
(3) There are practical difficulties or particular hardships in carrying out the strict requirements of this chapter which difficulties and hardships have not
been created by the petitioner. (Ord. 90-655, 11-26-1990)
B. When by reason of nonavailability of materials or any other valid circumstance, it becomes appropriate to vary the provisions under which a permit was
issued, the applicant shall submit the requested changes, along with a written report stating the circumstances necessitating such changes, to the
Architectural Commission for its review, along with the applicable fees as required in appendix D of this Code. (Ord. 99-961, 1-25-1999)
C. Every decision with respect to a variation by the Architectural Commission shall be accompanied by findings of fact specifying the reasons for granting
or denying the requested variation and shall constitute final administrative action. (Ord. 90-655, 11-26-1990)
Sec. 12-16: SEVERABILITY.
The several provisions of this chapter are hereby declared to be separable in accordance with the following rules:
(1) If any court of competent jurisdiction declares any provision or provisions of this chapter to be invalid, such declaration shall not affect the validity of
any other provisions of this chapter not specifically included in the court's decision.
(2) If any court of competent jurisdiction declares any provision or provisions of this chapter to be invalid as applied to any particular sign, such
declaration shall not affect the application of such provision to any other sign not specifically included in the court's decision. (Ord. 90-655, 11-26-
1990)
Sec. 12-17: ADMINISTRATIVE REVIEW.
Any decision made under this chapter shall be subject to the provisions of article 3-101 et seq., of the Illinois code of civil procedure providing for review of
administrative decisions. (Ord. 90-655, 11-26-1990)
Sec. 12-18: ILLUSTRATIONS.

(1986 Code)
Title Chapter 13
MOTOR VEHICLES, TRAILERS AND TRAFFIC CONTROL
Chapter 13
MOTOR VEHICLES, TRAILERS AND TRAFFIC CONTROL
ARTICLE I. IN GENERAL
Sec. 13-1: ADOPTION OF THE ILLINOIS VEHICLE CODE.
The provisions of the Illinois vehicle code, 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/1-100 through 5/20-402, inclusive, except where applicable to matters not within
the jurisdiction of the village, are hereby adopted by reference pursuant to the authority granted in 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/20-204. This adoption
by reference shall contain such amendments as are from time to time adopted by the general assembly. (1986 Code)
Sec. 13-2: DEFINITIONS.
All terms used in this chapter shall have the meanings ascribed to them in the Illinois vehicle code, unless otherwise provided. (1986 Code)
ARTICLE II. LICENSING
Sec. 13-3: DEFINITIONS.
For purposes of this article, the various classes of vehicles shall be defined as set forth in 5/1-101 through 5/1-224 of the Illinois vehicle code, unless
otherwise specified in this code, in which case the definition of this code shall govern. (1986 Code)
Sec. 13-4: VILLAGE LICENSE REQUIRED.
Any person or any business, association, firm or corporation residing within the village, or any other person owning a motor vehicle which is registered in
the village of Northfield shall pay to the director of finance each year a tax or license fee for the use of each motor vehicle owned or leased by such person
and used on any public street or highway in the village, or principally garaged or stored in the village, or registered with the office of the secretary of state
of the state of Illinois to an address within the village. Such garaging, storing or state registration shall be deemed prima facie evidence that such vehicle
shall require a village vehicle license. For purposes of this code, a license year for motor vehicles shall be July 1 through June 30 of the following year.
(1986 Code; amd. Ord. 92-721, 5-26-1992)
Sec. 13-4.1: SENIOR DISCOUNT ON VEHICLE STICKERS.
Seniors sixty five (65) years of age and older who participate in the state of Illinois circuit breaker program may receive a discount of fifty percent (50%) of
the cost of one passenger vehicle sticker per household. (Ord. 03-1183, 12-2-2003)
Sec. 13-5: SCHEDULE OF LICENSE FEES.
The respective fees (exclusive of any penalties) for licenses issued hereunder for a full license year shall be as prescribed in appendix D of this code.
(1986 Code)
Sec. 13-6: LICENSE FEES, PART YEAR.
The respective fees for licenses hereunder, when sought for a period after January 1 of any license year for all motor vehicles shall be one-half (1/2) the
yearly license fee prescribed by section 13-5 of this article. (1986 Code)
Sec. 13-7: LICENSE APPLICATIONS.
Any person desiring a license for such motor vehicle shall file an application with the director of finance upon a form to be provided by the director of
finance; signed by the applicant and setting forth the applicant's name and address, a description of the motor vehicles to be licensed, and the class to
which it belongs, and such other information as may be required in order to identify said motor vehicle and to enforce the provisions of this article. (1986
Code; amd. Ord. 92-721, 5-26-1992)
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=886 202/377
Sec. 13-8: PROPER STATE LICENSES, REGISTRATIONS AND DISPLAY OF VEHICLE STICKERS REQUIRED.
The State license plates, display title, State vehicle emission inspection sticker and Village vehicle sticker, where required, shall be current and properly
displayed. All of the required vehicle equipment, as defined in 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/12, shall be operational on all vehicles used, operated,
stored or parked within the Village of Northfield. The property owner shall have and display upon request to authorized Village officials, proof of ownership
of any vehicle or recreational equipment. See appendix D, article III of this Code for the appropriate fine. (Ord. 10-1455, 6-15-2010)
Sec. 13-9: VILLAGE VEHICLE STICKER ISSUANCE AND DISPLAY.
Upon receipt of such application and payment of the vehicle sticker fee herein specified, the Director of Finance shall issue a Village vehicle sticker to the
applicant for the operation of such motor vehicle and shall provide the applicant with a suitable vehicle sticker with an adhesive substance on one or both
sides thereof, bearing the word "Northfield", the vehicle sticker number, the designation of the class to which the vehicle belongs and the year for which the
vehicle sticker is issued. Such sticker shall be affixed to the lower left hand corner (driver's side) of the front windshield of the motor vehicle to be
registered, if such vehicle has such windshield and, otherwise, shall be affixed to such vehicle in such manner that it can be plainly seen from the front or
left side of such vehicle. No out of date vehicle sticker(s) from any jurisdiction may be displayed at any time. In the case of motorcycles or motor driven
cycles, said sticker/tag may be attached to the rear of the vehicle. (Ord. 10-1455, 6-15-2010)
Sec. 13-9.1: FAILURE TO OBTAIN VILLAGE STICKER ON TIME.
Every person required to obtain a Village vehicle sticker/tag by section 13-4 of this article, and who has not obtained his or her motor vehicle sticker(s) or
tag(s) prior to July 1, shall pay a penalty as noted in appendix D, article III of this Code. This penalty shall not be applicable to vehicles purchased or
leased after June 30 of that year. This penalty shall be in addition to any other penalties assessed for a violation under this Code. (Ord. 10-1455, 6-15-
2010)
Sec. 13-9.2: CITATION FOR FAILURE TO OBTAIN AND DISPLAY VILLAGE STICKER.
Any person ticketed for failing to obtain and display a Village vehicle sticker shall be fined, upon a finding of guilty, at the rate indicated in appendix D,
article III of this Code. (Ord. 10-1455, 6-15-2010)
Sec. 13-10: LICENSE EXPIRATION.
Each license issued hereunder shall expire on June 30 following its issuance. (1986 Code)
Sec. 13-11: REPLACEMENT OF VILLAGE LICENSE AND STICKER.
In the event of destruction of any license sticker, the Director of Finance, upon application by the person to whom such sticker was issued and upon
receipt of an affidavit by such person or other satisfactory proof of such destruction, shall issue to the applicant a new license and license sticker for the
same year as the license sticker destroyed, for the same vehicle if such vehicle has not been sold or assigned, or for another vehicle acquired by the same
owner during such year, upon payment of the fee as noted in appendix D, article I of this Code, for the following reasons: (1986 Code; amd. Ord. 92-721,
5-26-1992; Ord. 07-1352, 12-3-2007; Ord. 08-1385, 7-15-2008)
(1) If the new license and license sticker is to the same owner for use on the same vehicle previously licensed, a replacement fee will be charged as
outlined in appendix D, article I of this Code; (Ord. 07-1352, 12-3-2007)
(2) If the vehicle originally licensed has been sold or assigned and the owner since said sale or assignment has acquired another vehicle for which
license is desired, the fee noted in appendix D, plus the excess, if any, is required in the amount per appendix D, article I of this Code for the vehicle
so acquired for the remainder of the year after the date of its acquisition, over the fee required for the same period for the vehicle so sold or
assigned. (Ord. 07-1352, 12-3-2007; amd. Ord. 08-1385, 7-15-2008)
Sec. 13-12: DESTRUCTION OF VILLAGE STICKER ON SALE OF VEHICLE.
If any person owning a motor vehicle licensed hereunder shall sell or assign such motor vehicle, he shall destroy such license sticker before the delivery of
such motor vehicle to the purchaser or assignee thereof. Notice of such sale or assignment shall be given to the director of finance within ten (10) days
after the delivery of such vehicle to the purchaser or assignee. (1986 Code; amd. Ord. 92-721, 5-26-1992)
ARTICLE III. OPERATION OF VEHICLES
Sec. 13-13: AUTHORITY TO CONTROL TRAFFIC WITHIN THE VILLAGE.
(1) The corporate authorities or their lawful delegate shall place and maintain official traffic control devices including, but not limited to, electronic signals,
signs, roadway markings, lane designations and manual or oral signals from law enforcement officers when and as required under the village traffic
ordinances or the Illinois vehicle code for the purpose of making such ordinances or statutes effective. This authority includes, but is not limited to, the
designation of one-way streets, arterial streets, through streets, parking and no parking areas, play streets, crosswalks, safety zones and traffic lanes.
(2) All rules and regulations concerning the placement and maintenance of the traffic control devices included in subsection (1) of this section, heretofore
authorized by the corporate authorities or their lawful delegate prior to the passage of this chapter, shall remain in force and effect to the extent that
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=886 203/377
they do not contradict or conflict with the rules and regulations passed pursuant to this chapter. (1986 Code)
(3) In cases of emergency, or when public health, safety or convenience require, the village manager may establish temporary traffic controls, including the
designation of one-way streets, through streets and the regulation or restriction of parking on any street or alley; provided that such controls shall not
become effective until the posting of proper signs, which must remain conspicuously displayed while said regulation is in effect. (Ord. 13-1557, 6-11-
2013)
Sec. 13-14: OBEDIENCE TO TRAFFIC SIGNS AND SIGNALS.
It shall be unlawful for the driver of any vehicle to disobey the instructions of any traffic sign or signal placed in view by the corporate authorities in
accordance with the laws of the state. (1986 Code)
