Sec. 13-15: NEGLIGENT DRIVING.
(1) It shall be unlawful for any person to operate any motor vehicle in an unreasonable manner, which endangers or is likely to endanger any person or
property.
(2) It is unlawful for any person to operate any motor vehicle in excess of the posted speed limit, pursuant to this section. (1986 Code)
Sec. 13-16: SPEED RESTRICTIONS.
(1) The provisions of the Illinois vehicle code of the Illinois Compiled Statutes, shall be applicable to all streets under the jurisdiction of the village,
subject, however, to whatever lower speed limits may be posted by the corporate authorities in accordance with the laws of the state.
(2) It is unlawful for any person to operate any motor vehicle in excess of the posted speed limit, pursuant to this section. (1986 Code)
Sec. 13-17: MUD OR REFUSE ON WHEELS.
No vehicle shall be driven from any unpaved area or parcel of land onto any improved public street or alley in the village without first having the wheels of
such vehicle free from any mud, dirt, clay or other refuse which may be deposited on the public streets or alleys by the operation of the vehicle. (1986
Code)
Sec. 13-17.1: WEIGHT RESTRICTIONS.
(1) The maximum weight provisions of the Illinois vehicle code of the Illinois Compiled Statutes, shall be applicable to all streets under the jurisdiction of
the village, subject, however, to whatever lower weight limits may be posted by the corporate authorities in accordance with the laws of the state.
(2) It is unlawful for any person to operate any motor vehicle in excess of the maximum weight limit, pursuant to this section. (Ord. 92-715, 4-27-1992)
ARTICLE IV. PARKING REGULATIONS
Sec. 13-18: NO PARKING REGULATIONS.
It shall be unlawful to permit any vehicle at any time except when necessary to avoid conflict with other vehicles or in compliance with the direction of
traffic policemen or traffic signals, to stand in any of the following places:
(1) In any intersection.
(2) In a crosswalk or on a sidewalk.
(3) Upon any bridge or viaduct, or in any subway of the approach thereto.
(4) Between a safety zone and the adjacent curb or within thirty feet (30') of a point on the curb immediately opposite the end of the safety zone.
(5) Within thirty feet (30') of a traffic signal or of a through street sign on the approach side.
(6) Within twenty feet (20') of any intersection.
(7) At any place where the standing of a vehicle reduces the usable width of the roadway for moving traffic to less than eighteen feet (18').
(8) At any curb within fifteen feet (15') of a fire hydrant.
(9) In such a place as to block safe ingress and egress from any driveway.
(10) Within fifty feet (50') of the nearest rail of a railroad crossing.
(11) Within twenty feet (20') of the driveway entrance to any fire department station and on the side of the street opposite the entrance to such station
within seventy five feet (75') of the entrance.
(12) Within twenty feet (20') of the entrance to a driveway on which police department vehicles are customarily parked at the village hall when not on
the road. (1986 Code)
(13) At any place where official signs prohibit parking, including, but not limited to, fire lanes (on public or private property) as properly designated by
the village. (Ord. 91-666, 2-25-1991)
(14) With the vehicle facing in a direction which is against the flow of traffic on the side of the street where the vehicle is parked.
(15) Between a curb line and the adjacent sidewalk line unless this has been designated as a parking area by the corporate authorities.
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=886 207/377
(16) On any private portion of any curbed street other than in a driveway.
(17) Upon the parkway portion of any curbed street other than in a driveway.
(18) Upon a parkway at a distance of more than fifteen feet (15') from the pavement, or upon the planted portion of a parkway so as to damage any
grass, plants, trees, bushes, or other foliage.
(19) On either side of the New Willow Road, Wagner Road, Waukegan Road or Sunset Ridge Road at any point in the village. (1986 Code)
(20) On North Happ Road, except on the section north of Old Willow Road, parking shall be allowed on the east side and only with the permission of
the village of Northfield police department. This allowance for parking shall be subject to the remaining provisions of this article. (Ord. 94-820, 11-28-
1994)
Sec. 13-19: PARKING BETWEEN TWO O'CLOCK A.M. AND SIX O'CLOCK A.M.
It shall be unlawful to park any vehicle on any village street or in any village parking lot during the hours of two o'clock (2:00) A.M. to six o'clock (6:00) A.M.
(1986 Code)
Sec. 13-20: PARKING AT CURB.
No vehicle shall be parked with the left side of such vehicle next to the curb, except on one-way streets, and it shall be unlawful to stand or park any
vehicle in a street other than parallel with the curb line and with the two (2) right wheels of the vehicle within twelve inches (12") of the regularly
established curb line, except upon those streets which have been marked for angle parking, in which case vehicles shall be parked at the angle and in a
space indicated by such marks. (1986 Code)
Sec. 13-21: PARKING IN RESIDENTIAL AREAS.
It shall be unlawful for any person to park any vehicle except a private passenger vehicle with a seating capacity of not more than ten (10) passengers in
any block in any street in which more than one-half (1/2) of the buildings in such block are used exclusively for residential purposes, for a longer period
than is necessary for the reasonably expeditious unloading and loading of such vehicles. Loading and unloading as used herein shall not include loading
or unloading for the purpose of displaying or demonstrating a product for sale, gift or premium, but shall be limited to the delivery of a product for which an
actual sale has already been made. (Ord. 91-690, 8-26-1991)
Sec. 13-22: PARKING OF COMMERCIAL VEHICLES.
It shall be unlawful for any person to park any commercial vehicle, taxicab, truck or trailer within any residential area in the village or upon the traveled
portion of the dedicated right of way of any street or highway in the village or nearer than fifty feet (50') to any building in said village except during the
loading or unloading of said vehicle, truck or trailer in the regular course of business. (1986 Code)
Sec. 13-22A: UNAUTHORIZED USE OF PARKING PLACES RESERVED FOR HANDICAPPED PERSONS.
It shall be prohibited to park any motor vehicle which is not bearing registration plates or decals issued to a physically handicapped person pursuant to 625
Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/3-616 or 5/11-1301.2 or to a disabled veteran pursuant to 5/3-609 of the Illinois vehicle code, as evidence that the vehicle is
operated by or for a handicapped person or disabled veteran, in any parking place, including any private or public off street parking facility specifically
reserved by the posting of an official sign for motor vehicles bearing such registration plates. (1986 Code)
Sec. 13-22B: UNATTENDED MOTOR VEHICLES.
No person driving or in charge of a motor vehicle shall permit it to stand unattended without first stopping the engine, locking the ignition, removing the key,
and effectively setting the brake thereon. (1986 Code)
Sec. 13-22C: ACCESSIBLE PARKING REQUIRED1.
Parking spaces provided in accordance with this code shall be constructed and maintained in compliance with the Illinois accessibility code, 71 Illinois
administrative code chapter I, section 400.310, as it may be amended from time to time and which is hereby incorporated into this code by reference. The
village community development and building department shall provide copies of the pertinent regulations and diagrams to residents, businesses and
property owners on request and shall require compliance with this provision in all other respects, where applicable. (Ord. 06-1301, 10-17-2006)
Sec. 13-23: TRAFFIC NOT TO BE OBSTRUCTED.
No vehicle shall be operated or allowed to remain upon any street in such manner as to form an unreasonable obstruction to the traffic thereon. (1986
Code)
Sec. 13-24: RESPONSIBILITY OF REGISTERED OWNER FOR VIOLATIONS.
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=886 208/377
Whenever any vehicle shall have been parked in violation of any of the provisions of this chapter prohibiting or restricting parking, the person in whose
name such vehicle is registered and the actual operator shall be prima facie responsible for such violation and subject to the penalty therefor. This
responsibility shall be joint and several.
For the purpose of this section, it is the intent of the corporate authorities of the village of Northfield that vicarious liability shall be imposed upon the
registered owner of the vehicle and it shall not be a defense that someone other than the registered owner was in control of the vehicle when the violation
occurred. (1986 Code)
Sec. 13-25: LOADING ZONES.
During the time specified in this section it shall be unlawful for the driver of a vehicle to stop a passenger vehicle for longer than is necessary to load or
unload passengers, not to exceed three (3) minutes, and for the driver to stop any freight carrying vehicle for a period of time longer than is necessary to
load, unload and deliver materials, not to exceed thirty (30) minutes at any of the following places:
(1) In a public alley, during any hour of the day or night.
(2) At any place not to exceed seventy five feet (75') along the curb before the entrance to a public building between eight o'clock (8:00) A.M. and six
o'clock (6:00) P.M. except on a Sunday. (1986 Code)
Sec. 13-26: SNOW REMOVAL.
(1) Whenever a snowfall of three inches (3") or more has occurred in the Village, the owner or operator of any motor vehicle parked in any roadway or
Village parking lot shall promptly remove it therefrom to permit snow removal. In addition to other penalties, any such vehicle not so moved may be
moved or impounded by the police in accordance with the provisions of this chapter.
(2) It shall be unlawful for any person to plow or remove snow from any property and deposit such plowed or removed snow on any public road or
sidewalk. (1986 Code)
ARTICLE V. ACCIDENT REPORTS
Sec. 13-27: ACCIDENT REPORTS.
It shall be unlawful for the driver of a vehicle which has collided with any vehicle, person or property within the Village of Northfield, in such a manner as to
cause injury or damage, to fail or refuse to report each such accident in writing to the Northfield Police Department within twenty four (24) hours after the
accident. (1986 Code)
ARTICLE VI. MISCELLANEOUS TRAFFIC REQUIREMENTS
Sec. 13-28: REMOVAL OF VEHICLES BECAUSE OF EMERGENCY.
When any emergency arises necessitating the removal of any vehicle from any public way, members of the Police Department are hereby authorized to
remove or have removed any such vehicle from one location to any other location. (1986 Code)
Sec. 13-29: PARKING TRAILERS, PROHIBITED.
No person shall park on any street in the Village any vehicle to which is attached a trailer for hauling except as may be allowed for loading and unloading,
which loading or unloading shall be done as expeditiously as possible. This provision shall not apply to any recreational vehicle as defined by the Illinois
Vehicle Code. (1986 Code)
Sec. 13-30: PARKING VEHICLES FOR SALE.
It shall be unlawful to park any vehicle upon any street for the purpose of displaying it for sale, or to park upon any street, any vehicle from which
merchandise is offered for sale. (1986 Code)
Sec. 13-31: RIDING ON VEHICLE EXTERIOR.
It shall be unlawful for any person to ride upon the roof, hood, fender, running board, outside step or any part of a vehicle not designed to carry goods or
passengers. (1986 Code)
Sec. 13-32: TOY OR OTHER NON-ROAD WORTHY VEHICLES.
It shall be unlawful for any person to use or ride skates, skate board, coaster sled, hover board, motorized skate board, electric scooter or Segway type
vehicle or other toy vehicle upon any roadway other than at a crosswalk. (Ord. 18-1728, 9-17-2018)
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=886 209/377
Sec. 13-33: UNATTENDED ANIMALS.
It shall be unlawful to leave any horse or other animal unattended in any street. (1986 Code)
Sec. 13-34: PERMIT REQUIRED TO DRIVE OVER CURB.
It shall be unlawful for the driver or operator of any vehicle, truck, tractor or wagon to drive over any curb, parkway or sidewalk in the Village without first
having obtained a permit from the Village. (1986 Code)
ARTICLE VII. BICYCLE REGULATIONS
Sec. 13-35: LICENSE REQUIRED.
No bicycle owned by a resident shall be operated upon the streets or alleys of the Village unless the owner of such bicycle procures and displays a license
therefor as provided in this article. (1986 Code)
Sec. 13-36: LICENSE APPLICATION.
Any person desiring a license for such bicycle shall file an application with the Village Collector upon a form to be provided by him, signed by the applicant,
and setting forth the applicant's name and address, a description of the bicycle to be licensed, and such other information as may be required in order to
identify said bicycle and to enforce the provisions of this article. A copy of this application shall be filed with the Chief of Police. (1986 Code)
Sec. 13-37: LICENSE TAG, ATTACHMENT.
Upon receipt of such application and payment of the license fee herein specified, the Village Collector shall issue a license to the applicant for the
operation of such bicycle and shall provide the applicant with a suitable license tag bearing the word "Northfield" and the license number. Such license tag
shall be affixed to such bicycle in such manner that it can be plainly seen. (1986 Code)
Sec. 13-38: LICENSE FEE.
The fee for licenses issued hereunder shall be as prescribed in appendix D of this Code. (1986 Code)
Sec. 13-39: DESTROY TAG UPON SALE OF BICYCLE.
If any person owning a bicycle licensed hereunder shall sell or assign such bicycle, he shall destroy such license tag before delivery of said bicycle to the
purchaser or assignee thereof. Notice of such sale or assignment shall be given to the Village Collector within ten (10) days after the delivery of such
bicycle to the purchaser or assignee. (1986 Code)
Sec. 13-40: REPLACEMENT OF LICENSE AND TAG.
In the event of destruction of any license tag, the Village Collector, upon application by the person to whom such tag was issued and upon receipt of an
affidavit by such person or other satisfactory proof of such destruction, shall, upon payment of the fee set forth in appendix D of this Code, issue to the
applicant a new license and license tag for the same bicycle if it has not been sold or assigned, or for another bicycle acquired by the same owner. (1986
Code)
Sec. 13-41: TRAFFIC CONTROLS.
(1) Any person operating a bicycle shall comply with official traffic control signals, signs and other control devices applicable to vehicles, unless otherwise
directed by a police officer.
(2) Whenever authorized signs are erected indicating that no right or left turn or a turn in the opposite direction is permitted, no person operating a bicycle
shall disobey the direction of any such sign, except where such person dismounts from the bicycle to make any such turn, in which event such person
shall then obey the regulations applicable to pedestrians and have the rights of pedestrians. (1986 Code)
Sec. 13-42: OPERATION OF BICYCLES.
Whenever any person is riding a bicycle upon a sidewalk, such person shall yield the right-of-way to any pedestrian and shall give an audible signal before
overtaking and passing such pedestrian. (1986 Code; amd. Ord. 18-1728, 9-17-2018)
Sec. 13-43: SPEED OF BICYCLES.
No person shall operate a bicycle in any manner or at a speed greater than is reasonable and prudent under the conditions then existing, which shall in no
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=886 210/377
case exceed the speed limits posted for motor vehicles. (1986 Code)
Sec. 13-44: RIGHT OF WAY.
The operator of a bicycle emerging from an alley or driveway or building upon approaching a sidewalk or the sidewalk area extending across any alley,
driveway or approach shall yield the right of way to all pedestrians approaching on said sidewalk or sidewalk area. (1986 Code)
Sec. 13-45: LEAVING OR PARKING BICYCLES.
No person shall park or leave a bicycle upon a street or other public way for use of motor vehicles, and no person shall park or leave a bicycle upon any
other public way, including sidewalks, except in a rack to support a bicycle, or in such other manner as to afford the least obstruction to pedestrian traffic.
(1986 Code)
Sec. 13-46: MECHANICAL CONDITIONS, EQUIPMENT.
(1) Every bicycle when in use shall be in a safe mechanical operating condition.
(2) In addition to complying with the requirements set forth in 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-1507 and 5/11-1507.1, no person shall operate a
bicycle unless it is equipped with a bell or other device capable of giving a signal audible for a distance of at least one hundred feet (100'), except
that a bicycle shall not be equipped with nor shall any person use upon a bicycle any siren or whistle.
(3) Every bicycle shall be equipped with a brake which shall enable the operator to make the braked wheel skid on dry, level, clean pavement. (1986
Code)
ARTICLE VIII. ENFORCEMENT OF TRAFFIC REGULATIONS
Sec. 13-47: POLICE TO ENFORCE TRAFFIC ORDINANCE AND LAW.
Officers of the police department, or such other authorized officers as are assigned by the chief of police shall have the authority to enforce all street traffic
ordinances of the village and all of the state vehicle laws applicable to street traffic in the village. (1986 Code)
Sec. 13-48: DIRECTING TRAFFIC.
Officers of the police department, or such other authorized officers or crossing guards as are assigned or authorized by the chief of police, are hereby
authorized to direct all traffic by voice, hand or signal in conformance with traffic laws or ordinances; provided that, in the event of a fire or other
emergency, or to expedite traffic, or to safeguard pedestrians, officers of the police department may direct traffic as conditions may require notwithstanding
the provisions of the traffic laws or ordinances. It shall be unlawful for any person not authorized by the chief of police to direct traffic except in case of an
emergency. (1986 Code)
Sec. 13-49: ATTACHING NOTICE ON ILLEGALLY PARKED VEHICLES.
Whenever any vehicle is parked in violation of the provisions of any ordinance prohibiting or restricting parking, a notice to appear in court may attach to
the vehicle. It shall be unlawful for any person, other than the driver of the vehicle to which said complaint is attached, to remove the same from said
vehicle. (1986 Code)
Sec. 13-50: AUTHORIZATION FOR REMOVAL AND IMPOUNDMENT OF VEHICLES.
Members of the police department are hereby authorized to cause the removal of abandoned, lost, stolen or unclaimed motor vehicles in the manner
provided by the statutes of the state of Illinois. (1986 Code)
Sec. 13-51: AUTHORIZED TOWING SERVICE AND GARAGE.
The Chief of Police shall designate authorized towing service or services, garage or garages or other vehicle pound or pounds for the purpose of
removing, towing away and receiving abandoned, lost, stolen or unclaimed motor vehicles pursuant to this article or the Statutes of the State of Illinois.
(1986 Code)
Sec. 13-52: RECORD AND DESCRIPTION OF VEHICLES IMPOUNDED.
The Chief of Police shall cause an accurate record of all information required by the Statutes of the State of Illinois to be kept with respect to each vehicle
towed away or impounded pursuant to this article. Said record shall include the names of the police officers from whom such vehicle was received, the
person employed to tow or deliver the same to the pound or authorized garage, the date and time when received, the place where found, seized or taken
possession of, the make and color of the car, the style of the body, the motor number, serial number, where built, state license number, if any, equipment
and general description of condition, the name and address of the person redeeming said vehicle in case the same shall not have been redeemed
together with the towing and storage charges. Said record shall be in a form prescribed by the Chief of Police. (1986 Code)
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=886 211/377
Sec. 13-53: NOTICE TO OWNER OF IMPOUNDED VEHICLE.
Whenever the Police Department has impounded any vehicle, as aforesaid, said Police Department shall ascertain, if possible, from the registration
records of the State, or of this Village, or of any other city, village or municipality, the name and address of the owner thereof, and shall immediately give or
cause to be given notice in writing to such owner, if known, of the fact of such removal and impounding and reason therefor and of the place to which such
vehicle has been removed. (1986 Code)
Sec. 13-54: DISPOSITION OF ABANDONED, LOST, STOLEN OR UNCLAIMED VEHICLES.
Whenever the Police Department has caused to be towed away or impounded any vehicle pursuant to this article, such vehicle shall be held, released,
sold or disposed of in accordance with the applicable Statutes of the State of Illinois. (1986 Code)
Sec. 13-55: OBEDIENCE TO POLICE AND FIRE DEPARTMENT ORDERS.
It shall be unlawful for any person to fail or refuse to comply with any lawful order, signal or direction of a police officer, Fire Department official, or any
other authorized official. (1986 Code)
Sec. 13-56: PENALTY.
Any person violating any provision contained in the foregoing articles of these traffic regulations shall be fined, upon a finding of guilty, as indicated in
appendix D, article III of this Code. (Ord. 97-915, 10-27-1997; amd. Ord. 03-1144, 2-18-2003)
Sec. 13-57: ARRESTS FOR TRAFFIC VIOLATIONS.
Any person arrested for a violation of the foregoing traffic regulations shall be issued an appropriate traffic violation complaint and released upon proper
bail being furnished as required by statute or rule of court. (1986 Code)
ARTICLE IX. PARADES AND MOTORCADES
Sec. 13-58: DEFINITIONS.
MOTORCADE. An organized procession containing fifteen (15) or more vehicles, except funeral processions, upon any public street, sidewalk or alley.
PARADE. Any march or procession consisting of people, animals or vehicles or a combination thereof, except funeral processions, upon any public street,
sidewalk or alley, which does not comply with normal and usual traffic regulations or controls. (1986 Code)
Sec. 13-59: PERMIT REQUIRED.
It shall be unlawful for any person to conduct a parade or motorcade in or upon any public street, sidewalk or alley in the village, or knowingly participate in
any such parade unless and until a permit to conduct such a parade or motorcade has been obtained from the village manager. (1986 Code)
Sec. 13-60: PARADE OR MOTORCADE FOR COMMERCIAL PURPOSES PROHIBITED.
No permit shall be issued authorizing the conduct of a parade or motorcade which is to be held for the sole purpose of advertising any produce, goods,
wares, merchandise and is designed to be held purely for private profit. (1986 Code)
Sec. 13-61: INTERFERENCE WITH PARADE OR MOTORCADE.
No person shall knowingly join or participate in any parade or motorcade conducted under permit from the village in violation of any of the terms of said
permit or knowingly join or participate in any permitted parade or motorcade without the consent and over the objection of the permittee, nor in any manner
interfere with its progress or orderly conduct. (1986 Code)
Sec. 13-62: APPLICATION FOR PERMIT.
Any person who desires to conduct a parade or motorcade shall apply to the village manager for a permit at least fifteen (15) days in advance of the date
of the proposed parade or motorcade. The application for such permit shall be in writing on a form approved by the president and board of trustees of the
village or in a form acceptable to the village manager. The village manager may waive the fifteen (15) day requirement as provided herein. In order that
adequate arrangements may be made for the proper policing of the parade or motorcade, the application shall contain the following information:
(1) The name of the applicant, the sponsoring organization, the parade or motorcade chairman, and the addresses and telephone numbers of each.
(2) The nature of the parade or motorcade, the date when it is proposed to be conducted, the location of the assembly area, the location of the
disbanded area, route to be traveled and the approximate time when the parade or motorcade will assemble, start and terminate.
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=886 212/377
(3) A general description of the units to be used.
The village manager shall immediately forward a copy of the application to the chief of police and the fire chief. (1986 Code)
Sec. 13-63: ISSUANCE OR DENIAL OF PERMIT.
(1) Standards Of Issuance. The village manager shall issue a parade or motorcade permit conditioned upon the applicant's written agreement to
comply with the contents of such a permit as hereinafter specified, unless it is found that:
(a) The time, route and size of the parade or motorcade will disrupt to an unreasonable extent the movement of other traffic or emergency vehicles
and equipment of the village of Northfield.
(b) The parade or motorcade is of a size or nature that requires the diversion of so great a number of police officers of the village to properly police
the line of movement and the areas contiguous thereto that allowing the parade or motorcade would deny reasonable police protection to the
village.
(c) Such parade or motorcade will interfere with another parade or motorcade for which a permit has been issued.
(2) Standards For Denial. The village manager shall deny an application for a parade or motorcade permit and notify the applicant of such denial
where:
(a) The village manager makes any finding contrary to the findings required to be made for the issuance of a permit as above specified.
(b) The information contained in the application is found to be false or nonexistent in any material detail.
(c) The applicant refuses to agree to abide by or comply with all the contents of the permit and all ordinances of the village of Northfield and statutes
of the state of Illinois.
(3) Time For Issuance Or Denial. The applicant shall be informed of the issuance or denial of the permit within seven (7) days of the filing of the
application for same. (1986 Code)
Sec. 13-64: CONTENTS OF PERMIT.
In each permit, the following shall be specified:
(1) The assembly area and time therefor.
(2) The starting time.
(3) The minimum and maximum speeds of any motor vehicle.
(4) The route of the parade or motorcade.
(5) What portions of streets to be traversed may be occupied by such parade or motorcade.
(6) The maximum length of such parade or motorcade in miles or fractions thereof.
(7) The disbanding area and disbanding time.
(8) The permittee shall advise all participants in the parade or motorcade, either orally or by written notice, of the terms and conditions of the permit
prior to the commencement of such parade or motorcade.
(9) That the parade or motorcade continue to move at a fixed rate of speed and that any wilful delay or wilful stopping of said parade or motorcade
except that which is reasonably required for the safe and orderly conduct of the parade or motorcade shall constitute a violation of the permit; all
conditions of the permit shall be complied with so far as reasonably practical. (1986 Code)
Sec. 13-65: APPEAL PROCEDURE.
Upon a denial by the village manager of an application made pursuant to section 13-62 of this article, the applicant may appeal from the determination of
the village manager within five (5) days thereafter to the village president and board of trustees by filing a written notice of the appeal with the village clerk
and such appeal will be placed upon the agenda for the next regularly scheduled board meeting. The president of the village may, in his discretion, call a
special meeting to consider such appeal. Upon such appeal, the president and board of trustees may reverse, affirm or modify in any regard the
determination of the village manager, and shall submit their decision to the applicant within five (5) days of the hearing. In the event the application is not
filed within the required time as specified in section 13-62 of this article and the village manager refuses to waive said request, the applicant may request
such a waiver of the president and board of trustees at its next regular meeting, or at a special meeting which may be called prior thereto by said president
and board of trustees to consider such a matter. The president and board of trustees, if they find unusual circumstances and in the exercise of their sound
discretion, may waive such requirement. (1986 Code)
Sec. 13-66: OFFICIALS TO BE NOTIFIED.
Immediately upon the granting of a permit for a parade or motorcade, the village manager shall notify the following persons:
(1) The president of the village of Northfield.
(2) The chief of police.
(3) The fire chief. (1986 Code)
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=886 213/377
Sec. 13-67: REVOCATION OF PERMIT.
The village manager or president and board of trustees shall have the authority to revoke a parade or motorcade permit issued hereunder if, at any time,
facts are brought to the attention of the village manager or president and board of trustees which show that the parade, motorcade or similar activity does
not, or will not, comply with the requirements of the permit as therein set forth. (1986 Code)
Sec. 13-68: WAIVER OF PROVISIONS.
The corporate authorities may, with the consent of all members of the board present at any meeting thereof, waive any provisions of this article. (1986
Code)
ARTICLE X. ADMINISTRATIVE ADJUDICATION OF CERTAIN VEHICULAR OFFENSES
(Rep. by Ord. 12-1509, 2-21-2102) See chapter 6 of this code.
ARTICLE XI. SOLICITATION ON HIGHWAYS
Sec. 13-72: PROHIBITION FOR SOLICITATION ON HIGHWAYS WITHOUT A LICENSE.
No person shall stand on any street or highway within the village for purposes of soliciting employment, business or contributions of any kind from the
occupant of any vehicle unless that person has received a permit from the village to do so. (Ord. 91-670, 2-25-1991)
Sec. 13-73: CONDITIONS OF PERMIT.
Such permit may be issued only on the following conditions:
(1) Such agency shall be registered with the attorney general as a charitable organization in the manner provided by law. (Ord. 91-670, 2-25-1991)
(2) Solicitation by such agency shall be part of a statewide fundraising activity as indicated by written resolution of the state organization or other
satisfactory evidence:
(a) For purposes of this article, "statewide fundraising activity" shall mean a fundraising activity established at the state organization level authorizing
a certain type of activity at times certain. (Ord. 91-678, 5-29-1991)
(3) Solicitation may occur only at the following intersections and no other:
(a) Winnetka Avenue and Happ Road.
(b) Winnetka Avenue and Wagner Road.
(c) Winnetka Avenue and Sunset Ridge Road.
(d) Frontage Road and Tower Road.
(e) Frontage Road and Central Road.
(f) Old Willow Road and Happ Road.
and only at said intersections so long as all traffic is required to come to a full stop.
(4) The soliciting agency shall be liable for any injuries to any person or property occurring during any solicitation activity which are causally related to
an act of ordinary negligence of the soliciting agency and shall sign a hold harmless and indemnification commitment as prepared by the village
attorney so indicating. Additionally, the soliciting agency shall provide the village with proof of public liability insurance in an amount of not less than
one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) per loss, naming the village as an additional insured.
(5) Persons engaging in the act of solicitation for such agency shall be at least sixteen (16) years of age and shall wear a high visibility vest.
(6) No more than six (6) such solicitations may be permitted within the village in any calendar year and no organization shall be permitted to hold more
than one such activity in any calendar year. (Ord. 91-670, 2-25-1991)
(7) No permit may be issued for more than one calendar day. (Ord. 99-961, 1-25-1999)
Sec. 13-74: CONDITIONS OF PERMIT; PROCEDURE FOR ISSUANCE PERMIT; APPLICATION; INSURANCE.
Application for the permit required by section 13-72 of this article shall be made in writing to the chief of police on a form as provided. No application for a
permit may be made prior to November 1 of the calendar year preceding the calendar year for which the permit is required. Such form shall provide for a
statement of the following facts, together with such other information as may be required:
(1) The name, address and telephone number of the soliciting agency.
(2) The name, address and telephone number of the person signing the application or of another local representative of the soliciting agency. The
permit applicant must appear in person to request the permit at the times specified in the application form.
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=886 214/377
(3) Proof that the soliciting agency is registered with the attorney general as a charitable organization.
(4) A statement by the applicant of the nature of the statewide fundraising activity of which the local solicitation is a part.
(5) A statement that the soliciting agency will accept liability for any injuries to any person or damage to any property occurring during any solicitation
activity which may be causally related to an act by the soliciting agency or by any soliciting agent on behalf of such agency. Additionally, the agency
shall execute the hold harmless and indemnification commitment set forth in subsection 13-73(4) of this article.
(6) The location or locations at which solicitation activities are proposed to take place.
(7) The days and times at which solicitation activities are proposed to take place.
The chief of police may cause the investigation of any applicant for a permit to conduct solicitation activities on the streets and highways of the village to
determine that said applicant has complied with all of the provisions of Illinois law and of this code regarding solicitation on highways. Upon a
determination that the applicant has fully complied therewith, the chief of police shall issue a permit stating the exact dates, times and locations for which
such permit shall be valid. Priority for permit issuance to qualified applicants shall be on the basis of date and time of receipt of application. (Ord. 91-670,
2-25-1991)
ARTICLE XII. OUTDOOR STORAGE OF VEHICLES AND RECREATIONAL EQUIPMENT
Sec. 13-75: DEFINITIONS.
INOPERABLE VEHICLE. Any motorized vehicle which for any reason, including but not limited to mechanical or equipment problems or lack of
registration, title or other regulatory deficiencies, has been rendered incapable of being legally operated on Illinois roadways for at least seven (7) days.
This shall include but not be limited to a vehicle for which the motor, wheels or other parts have been removed or damaged making it incapable of being
driven under its own motor power.
RECREATIONAL EQUIPMENT. Every vehicle or other transportation equipment designed to be used primarily for recreational purposes, including, but not
limited to the following:
(1) Boat. Any vessel used for water travel.
(2) Camping Trailer. A trailer constructed with partial side walls which fold for towing and unfold to provide temporary living quarters for recreational
camping or travel use and of a size or weight not requiring an over size permit when towed on a highway.
(3) Motor Home, Mini Motor Home Or Van Camper. A self-contained motor vehicle designed or permanently converted to provide living quarters for
recreational, camping or travel use, with direct walk through access to the living quarters from the driver's seat. Such vehicles must include at least
four (4) of the following:
(a) A cooking facility with an on board fuel source;
(b) A gas or electric refrigerator;
(c) A toilet with exterior evacuation;
(d) A heating or air conditioning system with an on board power or fuel source separate from the vehicle engine;
(e) A potable water supply system that includes at least a sink, faucet, and a water tank with an exterior service supply connection.
(4) Off The Road Vehicle. A vehicle intended principally for recreational off road use, such as a dune buggy, go-cart, ATV or snowmobile.
(5) Racing Car Or Cycle. A vehicle intended to be used in racing competition, such as a race car, stock car or racing cycle.
(6) Travel Trailer. A trailer designed to provide living quarters for recreational, camping or travel use, and of a size or weight not requiring an oversize
permit when towed on a highway.
(7) Truck Camper. A truck, not used commercially, when equipped with a portable unit designed to be loaded onto the bed which is constructed to
provide temporary living quarters for recreational, travel or camping use.
(8) Vehicle Trailer. A vehicle without its own motor power that is designed to transport another vehicle, such as a boat, motorcycle or snowmobile for
recreational or vacation use and that is eligible to be licensed or registered and insured for highway use.
(9) Other Recreational Equipment. Other wheeled items which are designed for recreational use but do not meet the exact definitions of items defined
in (1) through (8).
VEHICLE. Any motorized device for carrying passengers, goods or equipment including but not limited to, passenger automobiles, motorcycles, vans,
trucks, buses, recreational vehicles and vehicles used for commercial, business, or governmental purposes. (Ord. 92-736, 8-24-1992)
Sec. 13-76: APPLICATION OF THIS ARTICLE XII.
This article XII shall apply to the owner of any vehicle or any person in charge of or in control of premises, whether as owner, lessee, tenant, occupant or
otherwise. (Ord. 92-736, 8-24-1992)
Sec. 13-77: SURFACE.
No vehicle or recreational equipment shall be parked or stored in the front yard except on a dustless stone, gravel, asphalt or concrete pavement surface.
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=886 215/377
Vehicles or recreational equipment may be parked or stored on a grass or dirt surface in the side or rear yard. The ground under or surrounding the
location where a vehicle or recreational equipment is stored shall be free of weeds, debris and combustible material. (Ord. 92-736, 8-24-1992)
Sec. 13-78: RECREATIONAL EQUIPMENT.
A. Residential Use Prohibited. No recreational equipment shall be used for living, sleeping or housekeeping purposes while in the village of Northfield
nor connected to any public utility except for required servicing.
B. Permanent Location Prohibited. Unless under repair pursuant to subsection D of this section, no recreational equipment, designed to have wheels,
shall have its wheels removed or be affixed to the ground so as to prevent its ready removal.
C. Unsafe Conditions. No recreational equipment shall be parked or stored in a manner that creates an unreasonable danger to persons or property.
D. Repairs Prohibited. No repairs shall be performed on any recreational equipment except within a completely enclosed building. However, the owner of
a residential lot may wash, change tires or perform minor routine maintenance on the owner's own recreational equipment while parked outside for an
aggregate of time not exceeding twenty one (21) days in any calendar year. In order to perform such functions all other regulations of this article must
be observed.
E. Must Be Moved. Recreational equipment parked or stored outdoors must be moved outside the village of Northfield boundaries for at least ten (10)
days during each calendar year. This requirement shall be deemed satisfied if the equipment is moved for portions of ten (10) different days provided
the moving was for bona fide maintenance or recreational purposes. (Ord. 92-736, 8-24-1992)
F. Screening. Recreational equipment parked or stored outdoors shall be surrounded by a solid fence and/or evergreen vegetation. It is recognized that
plantings may not be effective in totally blocking such equipment from view. However, it is the purpose of this subsection to require, to the extent
practicable, that the equipment be screened from the street and adjacent residences. To accomplish this any vegetative screen must be evergreen and
at least five feet (5') in height at the time planted and shall be capable of growing to the height of the equipment within a reasonable time. This
subsection shall not be interpreted as requiring plantings to be done between October 1 and April 15 of any year. All regulations regarding fences
pursuant to chapter 18, article II of this code shall apply. (Ord. 92-747, 11-23-1992)
Sec. 13-79: INOPERABLE VEHICLES.
A. Parking Or Storage Prohibited. No person shall keep an inoperable vehicle on any premises within the village of Northfield except in an enclosed
building.
B. Gasoline Service Stations. Vehicles lawfully stored on the premises of a licensed automobile repair shop may remain for a period not to exceed thirty
(30) days as set forth in chapter 11, article II, division IX of this code. (Ord. 92-736, 8-24-1992)
Sec. 13-80: PROPER LICENSES AND REGISTRATIONS REQUIRED.
(Rep. by Ord. 09-1437, 12-7-2009)
Sec. 13-81: TARPAULINS.
The covering of a vehicle or recreational equipment by or with any type of tarpaulin or covering of any nature shall not be a valid reason for noncompliance
with any provisions of this article. (Ord. 92-736, 8-24-1992)
Sec. 13-82: DECLARATION OF NUISANCE.
A condition constituting a violation of sections 13-75 through 13-81 of this article shall be deemed a public nuisance and may be abated pursuant to
chapter 14 of this code. (Ord. 92-736, 8-24-1992)
ARTICLE XIII. AUTOMATED TRAFFIC LAW ENFORCEMENT SYSTEMS AND
ADMINISTRATIVE ADJUDICATION OF AUTOMATED TRAFFIC LAW VIOLATIONS
Sec. 13-83: ADOPTION OF THE AMENDED ILLINOIS VEHICLE CODE.
Pursuant to the Illinois vehicle code, as recently amended by public act 94-0795, municipalities in the counties of Cook, DuPage, Kane, Lake, Madison,
McHenry, St. Clair and Will are authorized to provide by ordinance for "automated traffic law enforcement systems", as that term is defined in section 11-
208.6 of the vehicle code. (Ord. 08-1368, 2-19-2008)
Sec. 13-84: PURPOSE.
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=886 216/377
It has been determined to be in the best interests of the village of Northfield to establish automated traffic law enforcement systems and to provide for
administrative adjudication of automated traffic law violations as specified in this article. Establishing automated traffic law enforcement systems at
specified intersections in the village at which traffic is controlled by signals exhibiting different colored lights or color lighted arrows will benefit the public
health, safety and welfare by deterring drivers from entering those intersections in violation of red light signals, thereby decreasing the potential for
personal injury and property damage due to vehicle collisions caused by red light violations. (Ord. 08-1368, 2-19-2008)
Sec. 13-85: DEFINITIONS.
As used in this article, words or terms shall have the following meanings unless the context or usage clearly indicates that another meaning is intended:
ADMINISTRATOR. The village's traffic control administrator.
AUTOMATED TRAFFIC LAW ENFORCEMENT SYSTEM. A device with one or more motor vehicle sensors working in conjunction with a red light signal
to produce recorded images of motor vehicles entering an intersection against a red light signal in violation of section 11-306 of the Illinois vehicle code or
a similar provision of this article.
AUTOMATED TRAFFIC LAW VIOLATION. A violation described in section 11-208.6 of the Illinois vehicle code.
CERTIFIED REPORT. A report concerning five (5) or more unpaid fines or penalties for automated traffic law violations made by the village to the
secretary in accordance with section 6-306.5 of the Illinois vehicle code.
CODE OR ILLINOIS VEHICLE CODE: 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/1-100 et seq.
DETERMINATION NOTICE. A notice of determination of automated traffic law violation liability issued pursuant to the provisions of this article.
FINAL DETERMINATION NOTICE. A notice of final determination of automated traffic law violation liability issued pursuant to section 11-208.3 of the
vehicle code and pursuant to the provisions of this article. This notice shall be issued after the period for judicial review has expired if judicial review has
not been sought or after the judicial review is completed.
RECORDED IMAGES. Images showing the time, date and location of an automated traffic law violation recorded by an automated traffic law enforcement
system on: 1) two (2) or more photographs, 2) two (2) or more microphotographs, 3) two (2) or more electronic images or 4) a video recording showing the
motor vehicle and, on at least one image or portion of the recording, clearly identifying the registration plate number of the motor vehicle.
SECRETARY. The Illinois secretary of state.
SUSPENSION NOTICE. A notice of impending driver's license suspension issued pursuant to section 11-208.3 of the vehicle code and pursuant to the
provisions of this article.
SYSTEM. Individually, an automated traffic law enforcement system or, collectively, automated traffic law enforcement systems established in the village
pursuant to this article.
VILLAGE. The village of Northfield, Cook County, Illinois.
VIOLATION NOTICE. An automated traffic law violation notice issued pursuant to sections 11-208.3 and 11-208.6 of the Illinois vehicle code and pursuant
to the provisions of this article. (Ord. 08-1368, 2-19-2008; amd. Ord. 09-1405, 2-17-2009)
Sec. 13-86: LOCATIONS OF AUTOMATED SYSTEMS.
The village hereby establishes systems at all of the following intersections to be implemented on the schedule devised by village staff located within the
corporate limits of the village:
Frontage Road and Tower Road
Willow Road and Happ/Central
Willow Road and Lagoon
Willow Road and Northfield Road
Willow Road and Sunset Ridge Road
Willow Road and Wagner Road
Willow Road and Waukegan Road
Winnetka Road and Hibbard Road
Winnetka Road and Waukegan Road (Ord. 08-1368, 2-19-2008)
Sec. 13-87: ESTABLISHING OFFICE OF ADMINISTRATOR.
There is hereby established the office of administrator, which shall be filled by appointment of the village president. The administrator or his designee shall
be authorized to adopt, distribute and process violation notices and other notices required by section 11-208.3 of the Illinois vehicle code, collect money
paid as fines and penalties for automated traffic law violations and operate an administrative adjudication system for automated traffic law violations. The
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=886 217/377
administrator is also authorized to make a certified report to the secretary pursuant to section 6-306.5 of the vehicle code, and any such certified report
shall contain the information required under section 6-306.5(c) of the vehicle code. (Ord. 08-1368, 2-19-2008)
Sec. 13-88: VIOLATION NOTICE.
A violation notice shall be served by mail to the address of the registered owner of a vehicle cited for an automated traffic law violation as recorded with
the secretary within thirty (30) days after the secretary notifies the village of the identity of the owner of the vehicle, but in no event later than ninety (90)
days after the violation. Service of a violation notice shall be deemed complete as of the date of deposit in the United States mail. The original or a
facsimile of a violation notice or, in the case of a violation notice produced by a computerized device, a printed record generated by the device showing the
facts entered on the violation notice, shall be retained by the administrator, and a record kept in the ordinary course of business. A violation notice issued,
signed and served in accordance with this article and section 11-208.3 of the Illinois vehicle code, a copy of the violation notice or the computer generated
record shall be prima facie correct and shall be prima facie evidence of the correctness of the facts shown on the violation notice. The violation notice,
copy or computer generated record shall be admissible in any subsequent administrative or legal proceedings. (Ord. 08-1368, 2-19-2008)
Sec. 13-89: DETERMINATION PRIOR TO CITATION.
Before a citation may be issued for any automated traffic law violation, a determination must be made by a law enforcement officer or retired law
enforcement officer employed or contracted by the village that based on inspection of recorded images generated by the system, the motor vehicle was
being operated in violation of section 11-208.6 of the vehicle code or a village ordinance or this code. If the law enforcement officer or retired law
enforcement officer determines that the vehicle entered the intersection as part of a funeral procession or in order to yield the right of way to an emergency
vehicle, a citation shall not be issued. (Ord. 08-1368, 2-19-2008; amd. Ord. 11-1474, 1-18-2011)
Sec. 13-90: HEARINGS ON CITATIONS.
The registered owner of the vehicle cited in a violation notice shall have the opportunity for a hearing in which said owner may contest the merits of the
alleged violation. The lessee of a vehicle cited in a violation notice likewise shall be afforded the opportunity for a hearing of the same kind afforded the
registered owner. The formal or technical rules of evidence shall not apply at any such hearing. Such hearings shall be recorded, and the person
conducting the hearing on behalf of the administrator shall be empowered to administer oaths and to secure by subpoena both the attendance and
testimony of witnesses and the production of relevant books and papers. Persons appearing at such a hearing may be represented by counsel at their own
expense. (Ord. 08-1368, 2-19-2008)
Sec. 13-91: DETERMINATIONS OF LIABILITY.
A determination of automated traffic law violation liability shall occur following failure to pay the fine or penalty or failure to appear to contest the alleged
violation after requesting a hearing. Where a person fails to appear at a hearing to contest the alleged violation in the time and manner specified in a prior
mailed notice, the hearing officer's determination of violation liability shall become final: 1) upon denial of a timely petition to set aside that determination,
or 2) upon expiration of the period for filing such a petition without a filing having been made. If a person appears at a hearing and is found liable or
contests the violation by mail and is found liable, the hearing officer will enter findings, decision and order, which is a final, appealable order. (Ord. 08-
1368, 2-19-2008; amd. Ord. 09-1405, 2-17-2009)
Sec. 13-92: DETERMINATION NOTICE.
A determination notice shall be sent following a determination of automated traffic law violation liability. A determination notice shall be sent by first class
United States mail, postage prepaid, to the address of the registered owner of the cited vehicle as recorded with the secretary of state, if any notice to that
address is returned as undeliverable, to the last known address recorded in a United States post office approved database or, under section 11-1306 of
the vehicle code, to the lessee of the cited vehicle at the last address known to the lessor of the cited vehicle at the time of the lease or, if any notice to that
address is returned as undeliverable, to the last known address recorded in a United States post office database. Service of the determination notice shall
be deemed complete as of the date of deposit in the United States mail. (Ord. 09-1405, 2-17-2009)
Sec. 13-93: APPEALING DETERMINATION NOTICE.
A person owing an unpaid fine or penalty for an automated traffic law violation penalty may file a petition to set aside a determination of such liability within
ten (10) days after service by the village of a determination notice. Such a petition shall be filed by sending the same, together with any documentation in
support thereof, to the administrator by certified mail, return receipt requested, or by personal delivery to the administrator. The grounds for such a petition
shall be limited to: 1) the person not having been the owner or lessee of the cited vehicle on the date the violation notice was issued, 2) the person having
already paid the fine or penalty for the violation in question, 3) the vehicle being in the possession and control of a person other than the person named in
the violation notice at the time of the violation, and 4) excusable failure to appear at or request a new date for a hearing. A hearing on such a petition shall
be held within thirty (30) days after the filing of same. In the event that such a petition is granted upon a showing of just cause, and the subject
determination of automated traffic law violation liability is thereby set aside, the registered owner shall be provided with a hearing on the merits for that
violation. (Ord. 08-1368, 2-19-2008; amd. Ord. 09-1405, 2-17-2009)
If more than ten (10) days has expired, a person owing an unpaid fine or penalty must file for judicial review pursuant to the administrative review law in
order to appeal a determination notice. (Ord. 09-1405, 2-17-2009)
Sec. 13-94: FINAL DETERMINATION NOTICE.
A final determination notice will be sent following the conclusion of judicial review procedures or, if judicial review was not sought, following the expiration
of the time period to seek judicial review in accordance with section 11-208.3 of the Illinois vehicle code. The notice shall contain the following information:
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=886 218/377
(1) A statement that the unpaid fine and any penalty assessed is a debt due and owing to the village;
(2) A warning that a failure to pay the fine and penalty due and owing the village within fourteen (14) days may result in the village's filing a complaint in
the circuit court to have the unpaid fine or penalty rendered a judgment in accordance with section 11-208.3(f) of the Illinois vehicle code; and
(3) A warning that a failure to pay the fine and penalty may result in the suspension of the person's driver's license for failure to pay the fine or penalties
for five (5) or more violations. (Ord. 09-1405, 2-17-2009)
Sec. 13-95: SUSPENSION NOTICE.
A suspension notice shall be sent to the person liable for any fine or penalty that remains due and owing on five (5) or more unpaid automated traffic law
violations. The suspension notice shall be sent by first class United States mail, postage prepaid, to the address recorded with the secretary or, if any
notice to that address is returned as undeliverable, to the last known address recorded in a United States post office approved database. Service of a
suspension notice shall be deemed complete as of the date of deposit in the United States mail. (Ord. 08-1368, 2-19-2008; amd. Ord. 09-1405, 2-17-2009)
Sec. 13-96: CHALLENGING CERTIFIED REPORTS.
If the administrator provides a suspension notice to a vehicle owner and subsequently makes a certified report to the secretary, the subject vehicle owner
may challenge the accuracy of the certified report in writing. To do so, the vehicle owner must submit to the administrator a written statement under oath,
together with any supporting documentation, establishing one of the following grounds for challenging the accuracy of the certified report: 1) that the
person was not the owner or lessee of the subject vehicle or vehicles receiving five (5) or more automated traffic law violations on the date or dates such
violation notices were issued, or 2) that the person already paid the fines or penalties for the five (5) or more automated traffic law violations indicated on
the certified report. Such statement and supporting documentation must be sent to the administrator by certified mail, return receipt requested, or hand
delivered to the administrator within five (5) days after the person receives notice from the secretary that that person's driver's license will be suspended at
the end of a specified period of time unless the secretary is presented with a notice from the village certifying that the fines or penalties due and owing
have been paid or that the inclusion of the person's name on the certified report was in error. (Ord. 08-1368, 2-19-2008; amd. Ord. 09-1405, 2-17-2009)
Sec. 13-97: CONTESTING VIOLATION NOTICES BY NONRESIDENTS.
Nonresidents of the Village who receive violation notices may contest the merits of the alleged automated traffic law violation without attending a hearing
by sending a signed statement, under oath, together with any supporting documentation, to the Administrator via certified mail, return receipt requested,
within ten (10) days after service of the violation notice. Such a statement shall set forth the reasons why a finding of liability should not be entered. The
Administrator shall rule on such a statement within ten (10) days after receipt of same, and shall inform the nonresident of his decision within ten (10) days
thereafter. (Ord. 08-1368, 2-19-2008; amd. Ord. 09-1405, 2-17-2009)
Sec. 13-98: PENALTIES.
The penalties to be assessed pursuant to this article shall be as set forth in appendix D, article III, "Penalties", of this Code. (Ord. 08-1368, 2-19-2008;
amd. Ord. 09-1405, 2-17-2009)

Title Chapter 14
NUISANCES
Chapter 14
NUISANCES
ARTICLE I. IN GENERAL
Sec. 14-1: ENUMERATION.
In addition to those actions which are elsewhere in this Code declared to be and constitute a nuisance, each of the following enumerated acts or omissions
is hereby declared to be a nuisance for any person within the territorial jurisdiction of the Village and within one-half (1/2) mile of the corporate limits
thereof. In addition, it shall be a nuisance and shall constitute a violation of this Code to commit any offense or permit a condition or use of property which
is in fact a nuisance according to the common law, other ordinances of the Village, or the Statutes of the State of Illinois, or which deleteriously affects
public health, safety or welfare or greatly offends the public morals or decency. (Ord. 13-1564, 9-17-2013)
(1) To use any premises to create an offensive smell which taints the air and renders it unwholesome or disagreeable to other persons.
(2) To deposit, cause or allow the carcass of any animal or any offal, filth or noxious substance to be collected, deposited or remain in any place to the
prejudice of other persons.
(3) To render unwholesome or impure the water of any spring, stream, pond or well to the injury or prejudice of others.
(4) To obstruct or impede, without legal authority, the passage of any gutter, conduit, sewer, or the natural drainage of any public or private property.
(5) To construct or encroach upon public highways, private ways, streets, alleys or commons. (1986 Code)
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=886 219/377
(6) To keep or suffer to be kept in a foul, offensive, nauseous or filthy condition any building, yard, cellar, barn, stable, ground or premises. (1986 Code;
amd. Ord. 03-1183, 12-2-2003)
(7) To own, keep or use any yard, pen, place or premises, in or upon which animals shall be confined or kept, so as to be offensive to those residing in
the vicinity, or cause annoyance to others.
(8) To bring in or transport through the Village the body or carcass of any unslaughtered dead animal, offal, blood, bones or any putrid or otherwise
offensive animal matter.
(9) To operate any vehicle which emits dense smoke or such an amount of smoke or fumes as to be dangerous to the health of persons or as to

private grounds, streets, yards, woods, fields, parks, parkways or elsewhere.
(11) To suffer to collect, to stand or remain on any premises, water which is or which may become stagnant, foul or offensive, or detrimental to the

Sec. 14-2: DANGEROUS OR UNSAFE BUILDINGS.
Whenever a building of any construction within the fire limits established in appendix C of this code has been damaged by any means to the extent of fifty
percent (50%) of its value, or when in the judgment of the building commissioner, it constitutes a dangerous or unsafe building, and the building
commissioner shall so report in writing, any such building shall be deemed a nuisance, and the president and the board of trustees shall direct that such
building be repaired or demolished, whichever they deem proper, and shall pursue appropriate statutory remedies to cause such repairs or demolition if
the owners or owner thereof, after at least fifteen (15) days' written notice so to do, shall have failed to commence actual work on such building to put it in
a safe condition or to demolish it. (Ord. 497, 4-28-1987)
Sec. 14-2.1: UNWARRANTED EMERGENCY ALARMS.
A. Purpose. The purpose of this section is to provide for the imposition of fees to be charged to that portion of the village resident and business population
that maintains mechanically or electronically activated alarm systems, and to reduce the number of unnecessary responses by the department of public
safety to these alarms.
The inherent difficulties and malfunctions associated with such mechanically or electronically activated alarm systems result in unnecessary or nonbona
fide alarm activation and consequently require unnecessary responses by the department of public safety. Such unnecessary responses severely
endanger the safety and welfare of the residents of the village. In addition to the significant cost involved in responding to such alarms and the
concurrent loss of manpower and ineffective utilization of equipment, such alarms require emergency responses which may contribute to an increased
frequency in motor vehicle accidents.
A system of graduated fees for public safety department responses to alarms serves the dual purpose of encouraging the cessation of non-bona fide
alarms and of charging the cost of such alarms to that portion of the population wishing to use them.
B. Definitions.
ALARM OCCURRENCE. The activation of an alarm system for, or as a result of, any reason whatsoever which notifies or causes to be notified the
department of public safety to respond to the premises at which the alarm system is maintained.
ALARM OFFICER. The member of the police department designated by the chief of police to perform the functions specified in this section.
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=886 220/377
ALARM SYSTEM. Any assemblage of mechanical or electrical equipment devices (or a single device such as a solid state unit which plugs directly into
a 110-volt AC line) arranged to signal the presence of a fire, hazard, occurrence of an unauthorized intrusion or other activity normally requiring urgent
and immediate attention. The term "alarm system" shall include, but shall not be limited to, "automatic holdup alarm systems", "burglar alarm systems",
"holdup alarm systems", "direct dial systems", "fire alarm systems", "medical emergency alarm systems", "on premises alarm systems", "oscillator
systems", and "outside ringers". The following alarm systems are specifically excluded from the provisions of this section: motor vehicle alarm systems
and alarm systems which monitor temperature, humidity or any other condition not directly related to the detection of an unauthorized intrusion into a
premises, an attempted robbery or burglary at a premises, a fire or a medical emergency at a premises.
ALARM USER. The person, family, household, firm, entity, partnership, association, corporation, company or organization in possession or control of
any building, structure, facility or property in the village where an alarm system is maintained.
ALARM USER PERMIT. A permit issued by the village for the privilege and ability to operate an alarm system within the village. No person, entity or
alarm user shall be issued an alarm user permit unless: 1) an application is completed and submitted in a form satisfactory to the village manager, 2)
the applicable alarm user permit fee referred to below is paid, and 3) the alarm system complies with the alarm system requirements set forth below.
An alarm user permit shall be valid for a one year time period, and may be consecutively renewed upon the payment of the renewal fee referred to
below.
DELAY MECHANISM. An electrical or mechanical feature of an alarm system that: 1) provides a time delay between activation of the alarm system and
the annunciation of an audible alarm or the transmitting of a message or signal to the department of public safety.
DIRECT DIALER. A feature of an alarm system that utilizes a telephone device or attachment to automatically select a telephone trunk line at the
department of public safety and then reproduces a prerecorded message to report an alarm occurrence. (Not permitted.)
OSCILLATOR SYSTEM. A feature of an alarm system that utilizes one telephone line for the connection of both a burglar alarm and a fire alarm to the
department of public safety. (Not permitted.)
OUTSIDE RINGER. A feature of an alarm system that, when activated, causes an audible and/or visual device to activate in, on or near the premises
within which the alarm system is maintained.
SERVICE CHARGE. The amount of money determined by the corporate authorities to be reasonable compensation for the services and liabilities
assumed by the village in responding to alarm occurrences.
C. Requirement Of A Valid Alarm User Permit.
(1) No person, entity or alarm user shall maintain or operate an alarm system in the village without a valid and effective alarm user permit.
(2) The maintenance or operation of an alarm system: a) without first applying for and securing an alarm user permit, or b) after the expiration or
revocation of an alarm user permit shall constitute an offense punishable in accordance with this code. Each day that such violation continues shall
constitute a separate offense.
(3) In addition to any other remedy provided by law, the village manager or his designate may take all necessary steps, including an action at law or in
equity, or an action to abate a nuisance in accordance with this code, to prevent the operation or effect the removal of such alarm system.
(4) Any alarm system maintained or operated in violation of this section is a nuisance.
D. Alarm System Requirements.
(1) No alarm user permit shall be issued for any alarm system that:
(a) Consists, in whole or in part, of an oscillator system;
(b) Is not equipped with a delay mechanism on ingress and egress doorways that allows at least thirty (30) second delay before the annunciation of
an audible alarm or, the transmitting of a message or signal to the department of public safety; provided, however, that no delay mechanism shall
be required for any fire or medical emergency alarm component of an alarm system;
(c) Consists, in whole or in part, of a direct dialer;
(d) Includes an outside ringer unless: 1) any audible sound emitted by the outside ringer is completely distinguishable from emergency vehicles of
the village or any other audible village alert system; and 2) is equipped with an automatic cut off mechanism that permits deactivation within fifteen
(15) minutes of the initial alarm. (Ord. 92-714, 3-23-1992)
E. Permit And Connection Fees.
(1) There shall be a one time nonrefundable connection fee and an alarm user fee as set forth in appendix D of this code. The fees shall be payable
with submission of the alarm user permit application.
(2) There shall be a biennial (every other year) alarm user permit renewal fee as set forth in appendix D of this code. However, when the calendar year
of the initial permit falls on an even year, a permit will be issued for that year or part of year at a fee as set forth in appendix D of this code. A two (2)
year renewal permit will be issued the following January at a fee as set forth in appendix D of this code. (Ord. 02-1132, 12-3-2002)
F. Connection Agreement Required. No alarm system shall be connected to the village's alarm panel unless and until the alarm user executes an
agreement with the person, firm or entity under contract with the village to provide and maintain the alarm panel.
G. Service Charges.
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=886 221/377
(1) More than four (4) alarm occurrences in a calendar year from any alarm system in the village of Northfield shall result in the imposition of service
charges according to the schedule set forth in appendix D of this code. (Ord. 92-714, 3-23-1992)
(2) After the department of public safety has recorded four (4) alarm occurrences within a calendar year from any alarm system, it shall invoice the
alarm user on a quarterly basis for the service charge which has been imposed. (Ord. 01-1055, 2-20-2001)
(3) All service charges must be paid within thirty (30) days of receipt of the invoice tendered pursuant to subsection G(2) of this section.
H. Waiver Of Service Charge/Nullification Of Alarm Occurrence.
(1) The alarm officer shall have the authority, but not the obligation, to waive any service charge and/or nullify the existence of any alarm occurrence
only after finding, based on evidence presented by the alarm user, that one or more of the following circumstances exist:
(a) Evidence of an actual intrusion, obvious intrusion attempt, fire, medical or other actual emergency;
(b) Evidence of utility outage conditions lasting four (4) hours or longer and affecting a general neighborhood area;
(c) Evidence of a tornado, earthquake or other violent or extreme conditions of nature or acts of God, excluding thunder, snow, ice and storms;
(d) Alarm occurrences during the thirty (30) day period following installation of an alarm system;
(e) Evidence, in a form satisfactory to the alarm officer that the alarm system in question has been satisfactorily serviced or repaired at some time
after the alarm occurrence in question. This circumstance shall not, however, constitute grounds for waiver or nullification unless the alarm officer
is completely satisfied that the service or repair will reduce or eliminate alarm occurrences similar to the one in question.
(f) Evidence that the alarm user of the alarm system in question has implemented a training program, satisfactory to the alarm officer, to instruct
involved persons (family members, employees and/or contractual personnel) in the proper use of the alarm system. This circumstance shall not,
however, constitute grounds for waiver or nullification unless the program will reduce or eliminate alarm occurrences similar to the one in question.
(Ord. 92-714, 3-23-1992)
(2) Requests for a waiver or nullification may be made by any alarm user to the alarm officer. Such requests shall be in writing and must be made
within seven (7) days of the receipt of invoice set forth in subsection G(2) of this section. Within fourteen (14) days of receipt of such written request,
the alarm officer shall review the alarm user's request in accordance with this subsection and shall issue a decision. The decision of the alarm officer
shall be final. (Ord. 92-714, 3-23-1992; amd. Ord. 01-1055, 2-20-2001)
I. Revocation Of Alarm User Permit.
(1) Authority Of Chief Of Police. The chief of police shall have the authority to revoke an alarm user permit on either of the following grounds:
(a) Failure To Pay Service Charge. The failure to pay any service charge imposed pursuant to subsection G of this section.
(b) Multiple Alarm Occurrences. Eleven (11) or more alarm occurrences for one alarm system in one calendar year (none of which having been
nullified pursuant to subsection H of this section) regardless of whether the service charge for any of said alarm occurrences has been paid.
(2) Notice And Hearing Prior To Revocation.
(a) The chief of police shall, at least fifteen (15) days prior to the revocation of an alarm user permit, notify the alarm user in writing, by certified mail,
return receipt requested, or by direct police service, on the grounds for revocation and of the village's intent to revoke the alarm user permit.
(b) Within ten (10) days of receipt of the notice, the alarm user may submit a written request to the village manager for a hearing before the chief of
police, setting forth the reasons the alarm user permit should not be revoked. The submission of the request shall suspend the revocation of the
alarm user permit.
(c) If the alarm user fails to submit a request for hearing within the stated time period, the chief of police shall issue a written statement of revocation.
The written statement shall include an explanation of the consequences of revocation. The written statement shall be sent to the alarm user by
certified mail, return receipt requested, or by direct police service. Revocation shall be effective immediately upon receipt by the alarm user of said
written statement.
(d) If a request for a hearing is submitted within the stated time period, a written notice of the time and place of the hearing shall be served on the
alarm user by the chief of police by first class mail at least ten (10) days prior to the date set for the hearing.
(e) At the hearing, the alarm user, or his authorized representative, shall have the right to confront and examine witnesses and to present evidence in
his own behalf. After the hearing, the chief of police may either order revocation or cancel the notice of revocation. In the event that the chief of
police orders revocation, he shall notify the alarm user, in writing, by certified mail, return receipt requested, or by direct police service explaining
the consequences of revocation. Revocation shall be effective immediately upon receipt by the alarm user of the written notice. (Ord. 92-714, 3-23-
1992)

Sec. 14-4: BRINGING NUISANCES INTO THE VILLAGE.
It shall be unlawful for any person to bring into the village, or keep therein for sale or otherwise, either for food or for any other purposes whatsoever, any
animal, dead or alive, matter, substance or thing which shall be or which shall occasion a nuisance in the village, or which may or shall be dangerous or
detrimental to health. (1986 Code)
