4-5 acres 174,240 - 217,799 4
5-6 acres 217,800 - 261,359 5
6 or more acres 261,360 or more 6
(9) No Commercial Or Agricultural Use. No private stable, or horses or ponies sheltered in the stable, or any paddock, shall be used for commercial
or agricultural purposes.
(10) Sanitation. A horse or pony shall be adequately sheltered and proper sanitation shall be maintained at all times. All grain used for feeding shall be
stored in metal or other rodentproof receptacles. (Ord. 03-1155, 3-18-2003)
Sec. 19-8: SEASONAL AND TEMPORARY USES.
A. Approval. Temporary uses may be allowed in any zoning district. Such uses shall be subject to the restrictions and standards established in this
appendix A, and shall meet the bulk regulations and parking requirements established in this article. All temporary and seasonal uses are subject to
approval as set forth in this section. No temporary use shall continue for such a length of time that it constitutes a permanent use. Any temporary use
lasting for more than thirty (30) days shall be deemed prima facie a permanent use. Recurring temporary uses where the same temporary use or
structure is established on the property on an annual or other periodic basis shall be treated as a special use and shall be subject to the regulations
established in article XVI of this appendix A. Conditions for approval of any temporary use may include special traffic provisions and/or other measures
deemed appropriate to protect public safety.
B. Compliance With Building, Electrical And Fire Prevention Codes. Notwithstanding any other provisions of this appendix A, any tent, trailer, building
or structure and intended or used for human occupancy, however briefly, shall comply with the applicable building, electrical and fire prevention codes
of the village and shall not be used or occupied until a temporary use permit has been issued.
C. Temporary Uses And Structures Subject To Approval By The Building Commissioner. The following temporary uses and structures meeting
requirements of this appendix A, are permitted in any zoning district upon receipt of a temporary use permit:
(1) Construction trailers, equipment storage sheds and portable lavatories, provided that:
(a) The trailer, shed or portable lavatory is an integral part of construction of an active, properly permitted building project; and
(b) The trailer, shed or portable lavatory is located on the same parcel as the building development; and
(c) The trailer, shed or portable lavatory remains on the property only during the time of active construction; and
(d) The trailer, shed or portable lavatory is located no closer than ten feet (10') to any property line or sidewalk.
(2) Portable lavatory for public uses, provided that:
(a) The portable lavatory is for public use incidental to a specific event; and
(b) The portable lavatory is located on the same lot as the public use; and
(c) For events having a duration of forty eight (48) hours or less, the portable lavatory is located no closer than twenty five feet (25') to any property
line located within or adjacent to a residential district.
(d) For events having a duration in excess of forty eight (48) hours, the portable lavatory must be located no closer than one hundred feet (100') to
any other property line located within or adjacent to a residential district.
(e) In no case shall the portable lavatory remain on the property longer than ninety (90) days and no longer than forty eight (48) hours after the event
is over.
(f) Upon request of the Northfield park district or the Winnetka park district or a local school district, the village shall have the authority to permit
portable lavatories to be placed in the parks or school athletic fields from April 1 to October 31 of each year. The village may require such
screening as may be reasonably necessary to minimize the visual impact of the portable lavatories. The number of such lavatories shall be
determined by the village after consultation with park district or school officials. The location of such lavatories shall be consistent with the
restrictions on locations as set forth in subsection C(2)(d) of this section.
(3) Garage, estate and demolition sales in accordance with chapter 11 of this code. (Ord. 03-1155, 3-18-2003)
(4) Temporary portable storage containers provided that:
(a) Only one container shall be permitted on a zoning lot; and
(b) A container may not remain on any property for more than fifteen (15) days; and
(c) A container may not exceed sixteen feet (16') in length, eight feet (8') in width, and eight feet (8') in height; and
(d) The container is placed on a paved surface; and
(e) A container may not be located closer than five feet (5') from any property line or street, as defined in this article. (Ord. 10-1458, 6-15-2010)
D. Temporary Uses And Structures Subject To Approval By The Village Manager. The following temporary uses and structures are permitted only
upon approval by the village manager based upon the standards set forth below:
(1) Carnivals, provided that:
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=886 327/377
(a) Trailers and other equipment do not block driveways or other points of emergency vehicular access to any property;
(b) Trailers and other equipment do not block a public street, alley or sidewalk; and
(c) The operation, including parking, will be located entirely within the private or public property designated for the event.
(2) Produce and farmers' markets.
(3) Retail sales associated with a wholesale or warehouse establishment, provided that such sales are:
(a) Not to be held more than twice in a twelve (12) month period; and
(b) Associated with the warehoused, manufactured, or wholesale products and incidental to the main use; and
(c) Application for a warehouse sale shall be made not less than thirty (30) days prior to the date of the sale to the village manager; and
(d) The village manager may make reasonable regulations for such sales in order to protect the public safety and the orderly flow of traffic.
(4) Showcase display homes in accordance with chapter 11 of this code.
(5) Christmas tree sales lots, provided that:
(a) The use is located on a lot that fronts on a collector or arterial street;
(b) The use is located on a vacant lot or parking area;
(c) The trees are located at least fifty feet (50') from any structure on another lot;
(d) All trees shall be removed from the premises no later than December 31 of the same year;
(e) A refundable cash deposit, in the amount of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) is posted with the village in order to assure that the site is properly
cleaned after the sale is completed; and
(f) The use is located in a commercial district or a site developed as nonresidential in a residential zoning district.
(6) Art, craft and book sales.
(7) Sidewalk sales.
(8) Other temporary events not exceeding ten (10) days in duration and/or occurring more than two (2) times per year.
E. Temporary Uses And Structures Subject To Approval By The Corporate Authorities. The following temporary uses and structures are permitted
only upon approval by the corporate authorities based upon the standards set forth below:
(1) Uses or activities in relation to which a person has filed a petition under this appendix A for an exemption, based on the free exercise of religion,
from any appendix A regulation or any village policy or practice.
The corporate authorities may issue a temporary use permit if it makes a preliminary finding, based on the information contained in the person's
exemption petition and the written recommendation of the village attorney that the issuance of a temporary use permit is necessary to avoid or
resolve any potential violation of the religious based rights afforded to any person under federal or state law which would otherwise be cause by the
enforcement of such village regulation, policy or practice. However, no temporary use permit shall be granted if the corporate authorities determine
with respect to the regulation, policy or practice in question:
(a) The regulation, policy or practice constitutes or furthers a compelling governmental interest in need of protection; and
(b) The regulation, policy or practice is the least restrictive alternative for achieving the compelling governmental interest.
The temporary use permit shall be limited to the land use or activity that is the subject of the exemption petition and shall expire at the time the board
issues its final decision in relation to the exemption petition.
(2) Any other temporary use or structure not specified in this article. (Ord. 03-1155, 3-18-2003)
Sec. 19-9. FITNESS CLASS STUDIO STANDARDS.
A. The classes must be conducted in an enclosed building or tenant space.
B. The space must not exceed three thousand (3,000) square feet in floor area.
C. The class instruction may include fitness workouts, dance, yoga, martial arts or similar activities.
D. Attendance must be for specifically scheduled classes supervised by an employee of the studio who has specialized training in the class being
conducted.
E. The aggregate total floor area occupied by fitness class studios may not exceed twenty percent (20%) of the total floor area of a building located in the
village center zoning district.
F. Must have a retail component for the sale of merchandise unique to the fitness industry.
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=886 328/377
G. If the studio provides childcare or babysitting services, that service shall be limited to the children in the care of those attending a class. A child may not
be left in the care of the studio unless the adult bringing the child is on the premises attending a studio class. (Ord. 13-1546, 3-19-2013)
19-10: SHORT TERM DWELLING RENTALS.
Short term dwelling rentals are prohibited in all zoning districts. (Ord. 19-1737, 1-15-2019)
Article XX. Off Street Parking, Loading, Traffic And Access Regulations
Sec. 20-1: PURPOSE AND SCOPE.
A primary objective of the village's planning mission is to relieve traffic congestion in the streets, minimize vehicular conflicts, minimize any detrimental
effects of any off street parking areas on adjacent properties and to ensure the proper and uniform development of parking areas throughout the village.
The village also strives to successfully and safely integrate automobile and pedestrian traffic within common rights of way. Therefore, all off street parking
and loading spaces shall be provided in strict accordance with the standards established in this article. Nothing in this article shall prevent the voluntary
establishment of off street parking and loading facilities in excess of the number or standards, provided that such facilities meet all other minimum
requirements of the village. (Ord. 08-1377, 4-15-2008)
Sec. 20-2: OFF STREET PARKING REQUIREMENTS.
A. Each principal and accessory use of land shall provide the number of off street parking spaces indicated for that use in the table provided in subsection
F of this section for all zoning districts, unless adjusted in accordance with section 20-10 of this article. When the square footage of the building or
tenant area is stated, the gross square footage shall be used unless specifically stated otherwise.
B. When the use of any lot or structure is changed to a use requiring more off street parking than the previous use or there has been an addition of
dwelling units, gross floor area or seating capacity, the additional parking and loading facilities shall be provided as required for the entire use.
However, if the structure involved was erected prior to the effective date of this appendix A, additional parking or loading facilities are required only in
the amount by which the requirements for the new or added use exceed those for the existing use.
C. In the case of mixed uses, or when there are two (2) or more buildings on a single lot, the total requirements for off street parking spaces shall be the
sum of the requirements of the various uses computed separately.
D. When calculations of the required number of spaces result in fractional numbers, results less than 0.5 shall be rounded down to the nearest whole
number, and results 0.5 or greater shall be rounded up to the nearest whole number.
E. Designated parking for bicycles shall be provided at a ratio of one to twenty (1:20) of required parking spaces for passenger vehicles for the following
uses: multi-family residential, public and quasi-public uses, recreational, commercial and employment uses. Whenever bicycle spaces are required a
minimum of two (2) shall be provided. However, no individual use shall be required to provide more than fifteen (15) spaces.
F. The following number of off street parking spaces shall be provided for the associated use listed below in all zoning districts. When the square footage
of building area is stated, the gross square footage shall be used unless specifically stated otherwise. (Ord. 08-1377, 4-15-2008)

Sec. 20-2A: ACCESSIBLE PARKING REQUIRED2.
Parking spaces provided in accordance with this code shall be constructed and maintained in compliance with the Illinois accessibility code, 71 Illinois
administrative code chapter I, section 400.310, as it may be amended from time to time and which is hereby incorporated into this code by reference. The
village building department shall provide copies of the pertinent regulations and diagrams to residents, businesses and property owners on request and
shall require compliance with this provision in all other respects, where applicable. (Ord. 06-1311, 12-5-2006)
Sec. 20-3: LOADING SPACE REQUIREMENTS.
A. Off street loading berths of the number and size set forth in the following table shall be provided in conjunction with any multi-family development or the
erection of, addition to, or expansion of any use within any nonresidential district. The number and size requirements shall be calculated based on the
aggregate gross floor areas of the various uses and occupancies within any given building. To the extent that it is practical, the locations of loading
spaces shall be placed so as to be equally accessible to the several occupancies of a building.

B. All required off street loading spaces shall be located on the same lot as the use to be served and designed to ensure that no portion of a vehicle shall
extend into a street or alley or block a sidewalk. No loading space shall be located in a front yard. Every loading space shall be located at the rear or
side of the building and shall have direct access to a service entry through the rear or side of the building.
C. All loading spaces shall be designed with appropriate means of vehicular access to a street or alley in a manner which will least interfere with traffic
movements.
D. No storage of materials and no motor vehicle repair or service work shall occur within any required loading space.
E. The space allotted to any loading space shall not be used to satisfy the space requirements for any off street parking facilities.
F. All loading spaces shall be screened from view of abutting lots to a minimum height of six feet (6') by a solid fence, evergreen vegetation or a
combination of these elements. (Ord. 08-1377, 4-15-2008)
Sec. 20-4: LOCATION OF PARKING SPACES.
A. No parking space shall be located within the required front yard or within five feet (5') of any lot line, except in residential districts where such space is
located in a driveway serving a single-family dwelling.
B. No parking space serving a nonresidential use shall be located within five feet (5') of any lot line.
C. All off street parking spaces required to serve a structure or use in a residential zoning district shall be located on the same lot as the structure to be
served.
D. Off street parking spaces required to serve any structure or use established in a nonresidential zoning district may be served by an off street parking
facility located on land other than the lot on which the structure or use to be served is located, provided that:
(1) Such facility is within one thousand feet (1,000') of the structure or use to be served; and
(2) Such facility is located in a zoning district where such facilities are allowed as a permitted use or special use; and
(3) Such facility is located on a lot owned or leased by the same party as the lot on which the structure or use to be served is located or is a publicly
owned facility with parking spaces dedicated to the structure to be served; and
(4) A letter executed by the owner of the use and the owner of the property is provided acknowledging that at such time as the additional parking is no
longer available the use will terminate or the use will be reduced in intensity so that on site parking is sufficient to meet these requirements;
(5) A recordable covenant is provided that runs with the land on which the parking facility is located, and prohibits any other use of the lot. The village
shall be the beneficiary of the covenant;
(6) Where the parking facility is located on leased land, a copy of the lease shall be provided to the village and a letter confirming that the lease
remains in effect shall be provided to the village on an annual basis. Failure to maintain the lease or to submit the annual lease shall result in the
termination of use described in subsection C of this section.
E. The covenant required in subsection D(5) of this section shall not be released until such time as one of the following conditions occurs:
(1) The use served by the required off street parking is terminated; or
(2) The required off street parking is provided on the same lot as that on which the structure or use being served is located; or
(3) Another lot meeting all of the requirements set forth in subsection D of this section is used to provide the required parking. (Ord. 08-1377, 4-15-
2008)
Sec. 20-5: SIZE OF REQUIRED PARKING SPACES AND AISLES.
A. A required off street parking space shall be a rectangle having a minimum size at least nine feet (9') wide and eighteen feet (18') long, with the following
exceptions:
(1) Those spaces designated and marked for handicapped parking shall comply with the Illinois accessibility code.
(2) In parking lots where the predominant use is "low turnover parking" (defined as at least 65 percent of the daily users are parking for more than 4
hours) the stall width may be reduced to eight feet zero inches (8'0"), with all other dimensions and clearance remaining equal to the standard space
size.
(3) Up to ten percent (10%) of spaces in any facility may be designated for compact car parking (a minimum size of at least 8 feet wide and 16 feet
long) if appropriately identified with signage reviewed and approved by the architectural commission.
(4) The calculation for the required number of handicapped accessible spaces shall be based on the total number of spaces provided, including
compact car spaces.
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=886 332/377
B. Any aisle providing access to a required parking space shall be at least the width designated in this figure, based on the angle and number of rows of
parking provided. (Ord. 08-1377, 4-15-2008)
(Ord. 03-1155, 3-18-2003)
C. Enclosed parking spaces shall have a minimum vertical clearance of seven feet (7'). (Ord. 08-1377, 4-15-2008)
Sec. 20-6: DESIGN AND MAINTENANCE.
A. Off street parking spaces may be open to the sky or enclosed in a building.
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=886 333/377
B. All off street parking areas shall provide continuous curb and gutter around the perimeter of the parking area and a surface area of asphalt, concrete or
other approved surface.
C. All off street parking spaces shall open directly upon an aisle or driveway.
D. All off street parking facilities shall provide an appropriate means of vehicular access to a public street or alley.
E. No motor vehicle repair work of any kind, other than noncommercial emergency repairs to one's own vehicle, shall be permitted in an off street parking
area.
F. All nonpaved areas in a parking lot shall be covered with grass, shrubs or other vegetative ground cover and shall not be utilized for the parking or
storage of vehicles or any other items.
G. A landscaped island, equal in size to one parking stall, shall be placed at the end of each row of parking in all off street parking lots. (Ord. 08-1377, 4-
15-2008)
Sec. 20-7: PARKING LOT LANDSCAPING.
All parking lots must be landscaped consistent with the standards established in chapter 10 of this code. (Ord. 08-1377, 4-15-2008)
Sec. 20-8: RESERVED. (Ord. 08-1377, 4-15-2008)
Sec. 20-9: DRIVEWAYS AND ACCESS.
A. No driveway that is located or extends into or across any public sidewalk or street right of way shall be constructed or maintained unless a permit for
such driveway has been issued in accordance with the procedures and standards set forth in this code.
B. One driveway is permitted per lot unless a traffic impact analysis is provided and approved by the village engineer indicating a safety or traffic flow need
for a greater number of driveways. Shared driveways and those which limit left turn movements are encouraged.
C. Any driveway or curb cut which serves a nonresidential use and provides direct vehicular access into a lot from a major street or collector shall be
located:
(1) At least twenty five feet (25') from any other driveway or curb cut located on the same side of the street; and
(2) At least sixty five feet (65') from any street intersection, as measured from the intersecting street right of way along the edge of the pavement.
D. No driveway or driveway apron shall exceed a width of twenty five feet (25').
E. In the R-1, R-2, R-3, R-4, R-5 and R-6 zoning districts, no more than thirty five percent (35%) of the required front yard shall be covered with
impermeable surface. Driveway access shall be located so as to avoid conflicts within the public right of way (i.e., trees, hydrants, manholes), and no
new driveway shall be located within twenty feet (20') of any intersection. In addition, the following driveway standards must be met:
(1) Width at property line: Ten feet (10') minimum.
(2) Flair: Six feet (6') on collector and arterial roadways, three feet (3') on side or local roadways.
(3) Radius: Twelve feet (12') minimum radii on all arcs for curvilinear driveways. (Ord. 03-1155, 3-18-2003)
Sec. 20-10: ADJUSTMENTS TO OFF STREET PARKING, BICYCLE PARKING AND LOADING REQUIREMENTS.
A. Adjustments. The parking requirements of this article may be adjusted in accordance with the following:
(1) Any adjustment to required parking or loading shall require a public hearing before the plan and zoning commission and shall be subject to the
approval of the president and the board of trustees.
(2) Any percentage adjustment to the required number of spaces shall be considered as a percentage of the requirements of this article and not a
percentage of existing parking.
(3) The zoning administrator may require a parking demand analysis by a qualified parking or traffic consultant in order to support a request for reduced
parking. Such a report shall be submitted with the application for plan and zoning commission review.
(4) The zoning administrator will review the submitted application and provide a recommendation to the plan and zoning commission.
(5) The village may attach such conditions to the adjustment as it may deem appropriate.
(6) The village may require a fee in lieu of parking spaces in accordance with a schedule approved from time to time by the village board.
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=886 334/377
(7) An adjustment to parking, loading or bicycle parking requirements to less than seventy percent (70%) of the requirements of this article may be
made only if the adjustment is subject to the following additional restrictions:
(a) The petitioner must be an existing owner of the subject property; and
(b) Such relief may not be granted if the petitioner is seeking a variation from the gross floor area, building height or yard requirements.
(c) The owner has not created the problem by having previously subdivided the parcel from a larger tract.
(d) Such an adjustment shall require the affirmative vote of four (4) trustees.
B. Other Adjustments. The village board, without a public hearing, and not in addition to subsection A of this section, may approve a reduction in the
required parking in the following situations:
(1) Captive Market Credit. Retail and restaurant uses may be eligible for a captive market credit where it is determined that some portion of the
patronage of these businesses derives from other uses located within a maximum walking distance of one thousand feet (1,000'). In addition to or in
lieu of a parking design analysis the following factors for captive market adjustments may be utilized for uses as noted in the VC and O/ROD
districts:
ALLOWABLE PARKING REDUCTION BY USE
Retail/service 15 percent
Food and beverage 15 percent
General offices 5 percent
Financial institution 5 percent
(2) Public Transportation Proximity Credits.
(a) A reduction of up to five percent (5%) of the required parking, based on substantiated projections of reduction in parking demand, may be granted
for any use, building or complex located within three hundred feet (300') of any regularly scheduled bus route or other transportation system.
(b) A reduction of up to fifteen percent (15%) of the required parking, based on substantiated projections of reduction in parking demand, may be
granted for any use, building or complex that institutes and maintains a continuous, personalized shuttle service, or contracts with an outside
agency for such service.
(3) Complementary Uses. Up to ten percent (10%) of the gross floor area in the same building or building complex may be occupied by other
complementary uses without providing parking in addition to that imposed by the application of the ratio for the principal use. Occupancy by
complementary tenancies shall not exceed ten percent (10%) of the gross floor area of the building or building complex.
(a) Examples.
1. Pharmacy in a hospital or doctor's office building.
2. Food court, bar or restaurant in an office building.
(4) Alternative Transport Provision Credit.
(a) A reduction of up to five percent (5%) of the required number of parking spaces may be granted for any use, building or complex of buildings at a
credit of two (2) spaces for each space provided with no fee access electric car charging stations.
(b) A reduction of up to five percent (5%) of the required number of parking spaces may be granted for any use, building or complex of buildings at a
credit of four (4) spaces for each space provided with no fee access solar powered electric car charging stations.
(c) A reduction of up to five percent (5%) of the required number of parking spaces may be granted for any use, building or complex of buildings at a
credit of one space for each ten (10) bicycle parking spaces provided beyond the minimum calculated requirement. Said spaces shall be provided
with adequate rack parking as determined by the zoning administrator, sheltered from precipitation, and shall meet the minimum standards for
parking spaces as set forth in this code. (Ord. 08-1377, 4-15-2008)
Sec. 20-11: DRIVE-IN AND DRIVE-THROUGH FACILITIES IN NC, B-1, AND O/R DISTRICTS.
A. Banking Facility. Stacking lanes sufficient to accommodate the number of automobiles that is equal to five (5) times the number of drive-through teller
windows. Stacking lanes shall not interfere with or include any portion of an access or service drive, aisle or designated parking space. Stacking lanes
shall not be located within any street setback.
B. Restaurants. Drive-through facilities shall provide for a vehicle stacking lane sufficient to ensure all stacking activity is provided on site. A stacking lane
for each order box or window shall be provided at a minimum length of one hundred feet (100'). The actual length of the stacking lane shall be
determined based on the queuing expectations of peak hour projections, transaction time and number of windows. Stacking lanes shall not interfere
with or include any portion of an access or service drive, aisles or designated parking space. No order box or window shall be located closer than one
hundred feet (100') to any residentially zoned property. This requirement shall not be deemed to confer any right to a drive-through facility for food
service.
C. Other Facilities. Stacking lanes sufficient to accommodate a number of automobiles equal to at least three (3) times the number of drive-through
service windows. Stacking lanes shall not interfere with or include any portion of an access or service drive, aisles, or designated parking space. The
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=886 335/377
actual length of the stacking lane shall be determined based on the queuing expectations of peak hour projections, transaction time and number of
windows. (Ord. 08-1377, 4-15-2008)
Sec. 20-11A: DRIVE-IN AND DRIVE-THROUGH FACILITIES IN THE VC ZONING DISTRICT.
The following shall apply to drive-in and drive-through facilities in the VC zoning district:
(1) A site within the village center district may not have more than one drive-in/drive-through lane.
(2) No lane may have more than two (2) service/transaction positions, subject to the following:
(a) Automatic teller machines shall be deemed to be a transaction position.
(b) A stacking lane must be provided sufficient to accommodate a minimum of three (3) and a maximum of five (5) automobiles, not including the
transaction/service position(s).
(c) Stacking lanes shall not interfere with or include any portion of an access or service drive, aisles or designated parking space.
(d) Electronic telecommunication devices, menu signage or order boxes shall not be counted toward the maximum number of teller/service positions.
However, none of these devices may be located closer than one hundred feet (100') to any residential district.
(e) This requirement shall not be deemed to confer any right to a drive-through facility for food service.
(f) No portion of any stacking lane or area shall be located within any required setback or yard. (Ord. 08-1377, 4-15-2008)
Sec. 20-12: ADDITIONAL PARKING REGULATIONS.
A. Village Review. In addition to the parking standards set forth in this section, the village reserves the right to review planned unit development, special
use or any seasonal or temporary use to determine if additional parking, loading or stacking is needed based on the actual application and the
proposed location.
B. User Parking. Every use for which any requirement for parking is listed in subsection 20-2F of this article must provide an absolute minimum of one
user off street parking space.
C. Commercial Vehicles. In addition to the requirements of subsection 20-2F of this article, one off street parking space shall be required for each
commercial vehicle directly associated with a permitted use, whether or not the vehicle is anticipated to be stored only overnight on the premises. (Ord.
08-1377, 4-15-2008)
Article XXI. Nonconforming Situations
Sec. 21-1: PURPOSE.
Some uses and structures currently existing in the village may not conform to the requirements of this appendix A. This may be due to: 1) their
establishment prior to the adoption of this appendix A; or 2) a subsequent modification made to a zoning regulation. Generally accepted planning
standards require that such nonconforming uses or structures should be changed over time to conform to the regulations of this appendix A. This article
addresses the conditions under which uses and structures that do not conform to this appendix A may continue to exist. Under no circumstances shall a
structure or use that was illegal at the time of the adoption of this appendix A be deemed to become a legal nonconforming use because of such adoption.
(Ord. 03-1155, 3-18-2003)
Sec. 21-2: NONCONFORMING USES.
A. Uses In Existence At The Time Of Adoption Of Appendix A. Except as otherwise provided in this section, the lawful use of a building existing at the
time of the adoption of this appendix A may be continued as a nonconforming use, although such use does not conform to the provisions of appendix
A. Such a use may be extended throughout a building, provided that parking is provided on site that is in compliance with this appendix A. Further, no
structural alterations or additions may be made to the structure in which the use is located other than those ordered by an authorized public official or
without first obtaining a special use permit to do so. Further, such extension of the use may not displace any residential use in a residential district.
B. Unimproved Land. A nonconforming use existing at the time of the adoption of this appendix A, of unimproved land may continue for three (3) years
from the effective date of this appendix A. However, no improvements may be made to the land other than normal maintenance or those ordered by an
authorized public official. If such nonconforming use is discontinued at any time or if ownership or possession is transferred, all future uses of the land
shall then conform to the provisions of this appendix A.
C. Modifications To The Law. A zoning district may be changed or the text of this appendix A may be amended so that a use becomes nonconforming as
a result of the action. In those instances, the use may be continued and may be extended throughout the structure in which it is located, provided that
parking that is in conformance with this appendix A is provided on site. Further, no structural alterations may be made other than those ordered by an
authorized public official.
D. Discontinuance Of Nonconforming Uses. Whenever a nonconforming use has been discontinued for a period of six (6) months, such nonconforming
use shall become illegal and shall not thereafter be reestablished and all future use shall be in conformity with the provisions of this appendix A. (Ord.
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=886 336/377
03-1155, 3-18-2003)
Sec. 21-3: NONCONFORMING LOTS OF RECORD.
A. Nonconforming Lots For Detached Single-Family Dwellings. Notwithstanding the regulations imposed by any other provisions of this article, in any
zoning district in which detached single-family dwellings are a permitted use, a single-family dwelling may be erected and thereafter maintained,
repaired, restored, replaced, altered and enlarged on a legal nonconforming lot of record provided that such lot has both width and area which are
equal to at least eighty percent (80%) of the lot width and area regulations required in the district in which the lot is located. Such construction shall
comply with all other regulations (except lot area, shape, width and depth) applicable to single-family dwellings in the zoning district.
B. Nonconforming Lots For Multi-Family And Commercial Use. In any district in which detached single-family dwellings are not permitted, a legal
nonconforming lot of record may be used for any use permitted in the district in which it is located, but only if, the lot of record has a width and area
equal to at least eighty percent (80%) of the lot width and area regulations of the district in which it is located. However, the development of such lot
shall comply with all other regulations (except lot area, shape, width and depth) applicable to the use and district in which it is located.
C. Adjacent Nonconforming Lots. In certain instances at the time of the adoption of this appendix A, there may be in existence two (2) or more lots of
record, combinations of lots or portions of lots with contiguous frontage in single ownership. If all or part of such lots do not meet the requirements
established for lot width and area, the parcels or portions involved shall be considered an undivided parcel for the purpose of this code. No portion of
the parcel or parcels shall be used or sold in a manner which diminishes compliance with lot width and area requirements established by this code.
Further, no division of any parcel may be made which creates a lot of a width or area below the requirements stated in this appendix A. (Ord. 03-1155,
3-18-2003)
Sec. 21-4: NONCONFORMING STRUCTURES.
A. Use Of Nonconforming Structures.
(1) Any structure that cannot be adopted to a conforming use without modifications that will cost in excess of fifty percent (50%) of the structure's fair
market value, and that has not been used for twelve (12) consecutive months, shall not be placed back into use and shall be deemed a nuisance that
may be abated in accord with the provisions of this code.
(2) Use of any nonconforming accessory structure shall be terminated and the structure brought into compliance when the principal use on the lot is
terminated or ownership or possession of the principal use is changed or transferred.
B. Improvements To Nonconforming Structures. Except as otherwise provided in this section, no nonconforming structure may be enlarged, extended,
expanded or structurally altered. Repairs, however, may be made to buildings or structures even if the building is nonconforming as to height and/or
area regulations.
Additionally, structural alterations and enlargements may be made to residential buildings or structures provided that all alterations are in compliance
with village regulations and that:
(1) The building or structure was legally constructed and/or modified with proper permits; and
(2) Upon completion, the structural alteration or enlargement will conform in all respects to the regulations of the district in which it is located.
C. Dwellings Constructed Prior To 1957. Single-family dwellings which were constructed prior to January 1, 1957, are not to be considered as
nonconforming. However, such dwellings may not be enlarged or modified if any of the following result from the change:
(1) Decreased required yard areas because of additional encroachment into setback;
(2) Increased height above the maximum permitted by this appendix A;
(3) Increased portions of the structure that are above such maximum height;
(4) Increased lot coverage above the maximum permitted by this appendix A; and
(5) Increased FAR above the maximum permitted by this appendix A.
D. Relocation Of Nonconforming Structures. A nonconforming building or structure shall not be moved in whole or in part to any other location on its lot
unless every portion of such building or structure is made to conform to all the regulations of the district in which it is located.
E. Damage To Nonconforming Structures. A building or structure which is nonconforming at the effective date of this appendix A and is damaged or
partially destroyed by fire, flood, wind, or other calamity or act of God to the extent of less than fifty percent (50%) of its fair market value may be
restored and its previous occupancy or use resumed, provided such restoration is started within six (6) months of the occurrence of the damage and
diligently prosecuted to completion. If, however, such damage amounts to fifty percent (50%) or more of the fair market value of the building or
structure, no restoration shall be made unless every portion of the building or structure is made to conform to all the regulations of the district in which it
is located. For purposes of this subsection, the dollar amount of damage shall be the amount that it takes to restore the structure to substantially the
same condition that existed prior to the calamity. This shall be based on a certified contractor's estimate obtained by the owner, subject to the approval
of the director of community development and building. (Ord. 03-1155, 3-18-2003)
Sec. 21-5: APPEAL.
Appeals with respect to nonconforming structures are subject to the zoning board of appeals review process as set forth in chapter 4 of this code. (Ord.
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=886 337/377
03-1155, 3-18-2003)
Article XXII. Variations And Amendments
Sec. 22-1: VARIATIONS.
Requests for variations from the strict application of this appendix A shall be made to the zoning board of appeals in accordance with the standards,
reviews and submittal process set forth in chapter 4 of this code. Variations may only be applied to structures and not to uses. The only regulations which
may be varied are those with numerical standards. (Ord. 03-1155, 3-18-2003)
Sec. 22-2: AMENDMENTS.
The corporate authorities may from time to time on their own motion or on petition, after public notice and hearing before the plan and zoning commission,
amend the regulations of this appendix A. In case a written protest against any proposed amendment of the regulations or districts is signed and
acknowledged by: 1) the owners of twenty percent (20%) of the frontage of the property or properties proposed to be altered; or 2) by the owners of twenty
percent (20%) of the frontage immediately adjoining or across an alley from the property or properties; or 3) by the owners of twenty percent (20%) of
frontage directly opposite the frontage of the property or properties proposed to be altered, is filed with the village clerk and such protest has been served
by the protestor on the zoning amendment applicant or his or her attorney by regular mail, such amendment shall not be passed except by a favorable
vote of two-thirds (2/3) of the trustees then holding office. (Ord. 03-1155, 3-18-2003)
Sec. 22-3: FEES AND ESCROW.
Any fees or escrows associated with any variation or rezoning of any property shall be as set forth in appendix D of this code. (Ord. 03-1155, 3-18-2003)
Article XXIII. Violation And Penalty
Sec. 23-1: GENERAL PENALTY.
Any person, firm or corporation who violates, disobeys, omits or refuses to comply with, or who resists the enforcement of any of the provisions of this
appendix A shall upon a finding of guilty be fined in accordance with the general penalty provision as set forth in appendix D of this code unless otherwise
set forth in this code. (Ord. 03-1155, 3-18-2003)
Article XXIV. Repeal
Sec. 24-1: REPEALER.
All ordinances or parts of ordinances in conflict with this appendix A, be, and the same are hereby repealed. (Ord. 03-1155, 3-18-2003)
Article XXV. Effective Date
Sec. 25-1: DATE OF EFFECTIVENESS.
This appendix A shall be in full force and effect from and after its passage, approval and publication according to law.
Title Appendix B
SUBDIVISIONS
Chapter
SUBDIVISIONS
DIVISION I. GENERAL
1.1: Title.
This ordinance shall be known, cited and referred to as the Northfield subdivision regulations (hereinafter "appendix B"). This article shall be considered as
an implementation of the official comprehensive land use plan of the village. (Ord. 88-536, 3-22-1988)
1.2: Intent.
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=886 338/377
The intent of the Northfield subdivision regulations are to protect the interests of the land owner or subdivider, the investor in land, the homeowner, and the
village with respect to any map, plat, or subdivision of any block, lot, sublot, or any part thereof, or any portion or parcel of land within the village's
jurisdictional area. This appendix B will: a) provide reasonable rules and regulations in conformity with accepted engineering and public health standards
and practices; b) govern the location, width, and course of streets; c) control floodwater runoff; d) provide rules and regulations with respect to water
supply, sewerage collection, street drainage, and other public improvements. (Ord. 88-536, 3-22-1988)
1.3: Illinois Department Of Transportation Specifications.
For any improvement or structure for which the Illinois Department of Transportation has issued specifications, those specifications shall apply to this
appendix B unless otherwise stated herein. (Ord. 88-536, 3-22-1988)
1.4: Standard Specifications For Sewer And Water Main Construction In Illinois.
All underground utility improvements shall comply with the most recent edition of the "Standard Specifications For Sewer And Water Main Construction In
Illinois". (Ord. 88-536, 3-22-1988)
1.5: Time Limitations.
All time limitations placed upon the village by this appendix B shall be considered directory and not mandatory and unless otherwise specified, shall in no
way affect the obligation of the applicant to abide by the regulations herein or otherwise deprive the village or any agency thereof of jurisdiction. Further,
unless otherwise stated, any time limitation herein may be extended by mutual consent of the parties. (Ord. 88-536, 3-22-1988)
1.6: Forms.
Any applications, bonds, certificates, or other documents required in this appendix B shall be in a form provided or approved by the building commissioner.
(Ord. 88-536, 3-22-1988)
1.7: Definitions.
For the purposes of this appendix B, the following words and terms shall have the meaning indicated below. If there is an affirmative requirement in any
definition herein, that requirement shall have the same force and effect as if set forth in any other section of this appendix B.
ALLEY: A public right of way, other than a street, which affords a secondary means of access to abutting property.
BLOCK: A tract of land bounded by streets or by combinations of streets and public parks, forest preserves, cemeteries, railroad rights of way, bulkhead
lines or shore lines, waterways, or boundary lines of the county of Cook, or municipalities adjacent to the village of Northfield.
BUILDING: Any covered structure built for the support, shelter, or enclosure of persons, animals, or movable property of any kind and which is affixed to
the land. When a building is separated by division walls from the ground up and without openings, each portion of such building shall be deemed a
separate building.
BUILDING COMMISSIONER: The village of Northfield building commissioner or his designate.
BUILDING SETBACK LINE: A line on the final plat of subdivision which a building or structure may not be erected beyond or encroached upon in any
manner. The line may designate a setback from the street or it may designate a setback from a lot line.
COMPREHENSIVE LAND USE PLAN: A plan for the present and future development and/or redevelopment of the village of Northfield and the
jurisdictional area adjacent to Northfield.
CONCEPT APPLICATION: The completed initial form furnished by the building commissioner as set forth in section 2.5 of this appendix B.
CONSOLIDATION: The combination of two (2) or more tracts or lots into one "lot" as defined in this appendix B.
CORPORATE AUTHORITIES: The president and board of trustees of the village of Northfield.
CUL-DE-SAC: A local street with only one outlet and having an appropriate terminal for the safe and convenient reversal of traffic movement.
DEDICATION: The designation of land for some public use that is made by the owner and accepted for such use by a municipality.
DETENTION BASIN: A basin for storm water storage having a horizontal area with limits as defined by a zone designated as the "detention basin" on plats
or plans submitted to the village. On a single zoning lot, the detention basin may be defined on the plat on the final engineering plans, without benefit of an
easement. The detention basin may have either grass/landscaped surface or paved surface that is generally dry when not used for storm water storage.
DWELLING UNIT: One or more rooms designed, occupied or intended for occupancy as separate living quarters with cooking, sleeping, and sanitary
facilities provided within the unit for the exclusive use of one family maintaining a household or a community residence.
(a) Single-Family Dwelling: A residential building unattached to any other and containing, or designed to contain, only one dwelling unit.
(b) Multiple-Family Dwelling: A building containing, or designed to contain, two (2) or more dwelling units.
EASEMENT: A recorded agreement whereby a grant is made by a property owner for the use of land for a specific purpose.
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=886 339/377
FINAL PLAT: A map or plan of a subdivision and any accompanying material as described in section 2.9 of this appendix B.
FLOODPLAIN REGULATIONS: See chapter 7, article V of this code.
JURISDICTIONAL AREA: The area described in section 1.8 of this appendix B.
LOT: A parcel of land legally described and subdivided as a single lot which is occupied or intended for occupancy by one principal building together with
its accessory structures and uses. A "lot" shall have its principal frontage on a street, or other place officially approved by the corporate authorities, and
shall include open spaces required by this ordinance.
(a) Corner Lot: A lot having frontage on two (2) intersecting streets.
(b) Double Frontage Lot: A lot which abuts on two (2) streets but is not a corner lot.
(c) Interior Lot: A lot other than a corner or double frontage lot.
LOT DEPTH: The average distance between the front and rear lot lines, measured at five (5) equidistant points along the respective front and rear lot
lines.
LOT OF RECORD: Land designated as a lot on a plat of subdivision or described by metes and bounds, and which is recorded in the office of the recorder
of deeds or registered in the office of the registrar of titles of Cook County, Illinois.
LOT WIDTH: The average distance measured between side lot lines, measured at five (5) equidistant points along the respective side lot lines.
OFFICIAL MAP: A graphic portion of the comprehensive land use plan implemented by regulatory ordinance, made up of, but not necessarily limited to,
the Northfield zoning ordinance, subdivision regulations, and major street, sewer, and water maps.
OWNER: Any person who owns jointly or severally with others, legal or equitable title to any property or improvement thereon.
PARKWAY: Any nonpaved area within the right of way.
PAVEMENT WIDTH: Measurement perpendicular to a pavement centerline extending from the face of a curb to the face of the opposing curb or from edge
of pavement to the edge of the opposing pavement if there are no curbs.
PEDESTRIANWAY: A public thoroughfare across a block or providing access within a block, which is designated for the use of pedestrians and for the
installation of utility lines.
PLANNED UNIT DEVELOPMENT: A unified development pursuant to article XVII of the village of Northfield zoning ordinance of one or more tracts of
contiguous land containing not less than that specified in appendix A of this code, except as otherwise provided by ordinance, and involving a single or
combination of land uses where one or more of the uses proposed may not otherwise be permitted in the zoning district or districts in which the land is
located. A single entity must be responsible to the village for the development. All access to a planned unit development, public or private, must be within
the control of said legal entity or village. Private access to each principal building must be granted by easements to the public or to specific classes of
individuals as permitted by law. The width of easement must be adequate for its purpose. The area reserved for the easement shall not be included when
determining land area for purposes of meeting provisions of the zoning ordinance.
PLAT OF SUBDIVISION OR RESUBDIVISION: A plat involving a "subdivision" as defined in this section.
PRELIMINARY PLAT: A tentative map or plan of a proposed subdivision as described in section 2.7 of this appendix B, including supporting documents
required for preliminary approval of the proposed plat of subdivision.
PUBLIC IMPROVEMENTS: Those land improvements including any sanitary sewer, storm sewer, drainage ditch, public or private street, detention facility,
environmental protection facility, water main, street planting strips, sidewalks, pedestrianway, off street parking area, or other facility for which the village of
Northfield may assume control and responsibility for maintenance and operation.
PUBLIC WAY: Any sidewalk, roadway, alley, or other public thoroughfare open to the use of the public as a matter of right for the purpose of travel.
RESTRICTIVE COVENANTS: Contracts or regulations restricting the manner in which the land may be used.
RETENTION BASIN: A basin for storm water storage that functions in the same manner as a detention basin except that a retention basin has a water
surface when not actively storing storm water.
RIGHT OF WAY: Land owned, dedicated, or used as a roadway, accessway, or easement.
SCREENING: Structures or evergreen vegetation maintained for the purpose of concealing from view designated areas or objects behind such structures
or vegetation.
STANDARDS: Specifications for the preparation of plans indicating, among other things, the optimum, minimum, or maximum dimensions of such features
as rights of way and blocks.
STREET: A public or private right of way which affords primary access by pedestrians and vehicles to abutting properties. Street shall not include
driveways leading to buildings.
STREET WIDTH: Pavement width plus any additional right of way retained by the agency owning the street.
SUBDIVIDER: A person, corporation, or duly authorized agent who undertakes the subdivision of land as defined herein.
SUBDIVISION: A subdivision is: a) any change or rearrangement (including resubdivision) in the boundary or division lines of any parcel or parcels of real
estate or of any public thoroughfare and shall include, but not be limited to, the resubdivision of multiple parcels into a single parcel; or b) the platting of a
parcel or tract of land into a single numbered lot without alteration of its boundaries; or c) a "planned unit development" as defined herein or in the zoning
ordinance of the county of Cook. This definition shall apply regardless of the purpose of the subdivision. Only tax division shall not be subject to this
appendix B.
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=886 340/377
SUBDIVISION DESIGN STANDARDS: The basic land planning principles established as guides for the preparation of plans, plats, or plan for public
improvement.
SURVEYOR: Any person licensed as a land surveyor in the state of Illinois.
THOROUGHFARE: A street with a high degree of continuity and serving as an arterial traffic way.
WORKING DRAWINGS: Engineer's and architect's plans, details, sections, and profiles prepared for the building or constructing of a public improvement.
YARD, CORNER SIDE: The portion of a lot lying between the corner side lot line and the building and extending from the front yard to the rear lot line.
YARD, FRONT: A yard extending across the full width of the front of a lot, the depth of which is the minimum permissible horizontal distance between
either the public right of way line, the street line or a private access easement and the front of the main building as specified by appendix A of this code for
that zoning district.
YARD, REAR: A yard extending across the full width of the rear of a lot, the depth of which is the minimum horizontal distance between the rear lot line
and the rear of the main building as specified by appendix A of this code for that zoning district. On corner lots the rear yard shall be considered as parallel
to the street upon which the lot has its least dimension. On both corner lots and interior lots the rear yard shall in all cases be at the opposite end of the lot
from the front yard.
YARD, SIDE: A yard extending across the side of a lot, from the front lot line to the rear lot line, which is the minimum horizontal distance between the side
lot line and the side of the main building excluding steps, unenclosed balconies or unenclosed porches as specified by appendix A of this code for that
zoning district.
ZONING MAP: The official zoning map of the village of Northfield delineating the various zoning districts within the village of Northfield and outside the
village of Northfield to the extent permitted by law. (Ord. 88-536, 3-22-1988; amd. Ord. 03-1156, 3-18-2003)
1.8: Jurisdiction.
The provisions of this appendix B shall apply to land situated within the corporate limits and, except where specifically excluded, to contiguous territory
within one and one-half (11/2) miles beyond the corporate limits of the village as now or hereafter existing which is not included in any other city or village,
except as such jurisdiction is limited by the provisions of statutes of the state of Illinois or amended by agreement between the village and any other
municipality pursuant to statute. (Ord. 88-536, 3-22-1988)
1.9: Organization.
A. Northfield Corporate Authorities. The corporate authorities shall have the authority granted by statute in regard to subdivision control, including, but
not limited to, the following:
(1) Approval or disapproval of final plats and working drawings or any documents preliminary thereto.
(2) Approval or disapproval of all variations and exceptions recommended by the plan commission.
(3) Amendment of this appendix B when found necessary and desirable as hereinafter provided.
(4) Enforcement of the provisions of this appendix B, including spending and the revocation of building and occupancy permits.
(5) Approval or disapproval of intended dedication of land for public use.
(6) The vacation of streets, alleys, or other public places and the fixing of compensation to the village therefor.
B. Northfield Plan Commission. With respect to subdivisions, the Northfield plan commission's duties and responsibilities shall include:
(1) Subject to the approval of the corporate authorities, to prepare and adopt such procedural rules and regulations as are required for the orderly and
efficient conduct of its business as provided by chapter 4, section 25 of this code, provided the same shall not be in conflict with any provision of this
appendix B; and
(2) Review all preliminary and final subdivision plans and plats in order to make determinations and recommendations in the areas of design standards
and engineering specifications, as specified and referred to herein and to hold public hearings pertaining thereto; and
(3) Make determinations and recommendations to the corporate authorities regarding approval or disapproval of plats, working drawings, code
amendments, variations and exceptions, land dedications, and vacations. (Ord. 88-536, 3-22-1988)
1.10: Variations And Exceptions.
The plan commission may recommend to the corporate authorities that a variation or exception be granted to this appendix B when it is found that
extraordinary hardships may result from strict compliance with this appendix B because of unique physical surroundings, shape, or topographical
characteristics of the property, or such other reasons not caused by the property owner or anyone under his direction, as distinguished from mere
inconvenience or a desire to derive greater economic gain. The granting of the variation shall not be detrimental to the public health, safety, and welfare or
injurious to other property or improvements or to the neighborhood in which the property is located. (Ord. 88-536, 3-22-1988)
1.11: Violations Penalties And Enforcement.
Whosoever, without having complied with all the requirements of this appendix B, shall sell, offer for sale, or lease any lot, block, or parcel of real estate in
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=886 341/377
the village of Northfield or within its jurisdictional area, or shall subdivide or resubdivide any lot or block therein shall be subject to fines of not less than two
hundred dollars ($200.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each lot, block, parcel, or part thereof and shall be subject to suspension or
revocation of any building and occupancy permit(s) issued for each such lot. Each day of the violation may be considered a separate offense. (Ord. 88-
536, 3-22-1988)
1.12: Construing These Subdivision Regulations.
A. Minimum Requirements. The provisions of this appendix B are intended to be the minimum requirements for the promotion of the public health,
safety, morals, and welfare.
Where the conditions imposed by any provision of this appendix B upon the use of land or buildings are either more restrictive or less restrictive than
comparable conditions imposed by any other provision of this appendix B, or of any other law, ordinance, resolution, rule, or regulations of any kind, the
regulations which are more restrictive shall govern.
B. Private Agreements. This appendix B is not intended to abrogate, annul, or otherwise interfere with any easement, covenant, or other private
agreement or legal relationship; provided, however, that where the regulations of this appendix B are more restrictive or impose higher standards or
requirements than such easements, covenants or other private agreements or legal relationships, the regulations of this appendix B shall govern.
C. Covenants. The corporate authorities may require or approve, consistent with this appendix B, certain subdivision restrictions that are to be private
covenants that run with the land. However, the village of Northfield shall be under no obligation to enforce such private covenants.
D. Recapture Agreements. The village in its sole discretion, may enter into an agreement with the developer to recapture on behalf of the developer or
the village reasonable costs, or any portion thereof, for off site and on site improvements. This subsection shall not be deemed to require the village to
enter into such an agreement.
E. Off Site Improvements. The village may require contributions for off site improvements which are necessary to effect compliance with this appendix B
or which are of benefit to the proposed subdivision. (Ord. 88-536, 3-22-1988)
DIVISION II. PROCEDURE
2.1: Subdivision Prohibited Without Approval.
It shall be unlawful to subdivide property within the jurisdiction of this appendix B without first receiving approval therefor by the corporate authorities of the
village of Northfield. Such approval of the corporate authorities shall only be by official adoption of a resolution pursuant to section 2.8(3). (Ord. 88-536, 3-
22-1988)
2.2: Fees.
All subdivision fees shall be as set forth in appendix D of this code. (Ord. 88-536, 3-22-1988)
2.3: Forms.
Unless otherwise specified, all forms referred to in this appendix B shall be as provided by the village of Northfield building commissioner. (Ord. 88-536, 3-
22-1988)
2.4: Time For Filing Documents.
All information shall be submitted complete at least twenty (20) days prior to the initial hearing or meeting. Subsequent information shall be submitted at
least ten (10) days prior to a hearing or meeting. (Ord. 88-536, 3-22-1988)
2.5: Concept Application Procedure.
(1) A concept application shall be made to the building commissioner which shall include:
(a) Location of the proposed subdivision.
(b) Current and proposed zoning for the subdivision.
(c) Nature of the improvements.
(d) Name of the applicant. If the applicant is a contract purchaser, that applicant shall include with the application a letter signed by the record owner
granting express consent to make said application.
(e) If the applicant is a corporation, the application must be accompanied by a resolution of the corporation authorizing the execution and submittal of
the instant application. In addition, the application shall indicate on its face the names of all directors and corporate officers of the corporation and
also the names of all shareholders who own individually or beneficially five percent (5%) or more of the outstanding stock of the corporation.
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=886 342/377
(f) If the applicant is a general partnership, the application shall contain a list of all general partners who have a five percent (5%) or greater individual
or beneficial interest in the partnership.
(g) If the applicant is a limited partnership, the application shall contain the following information:
A list of all the names of general partners and the names of all limited partners having a five percent (5%) or greater individual or beneficial interest
in the partnership.
(h) If the applicant is a land trust or any other trust, the application shall contain the names and addresses of all beneficiaries of the trust together
with their respective interests in the trusts. The application shall be further verified by the applicant in his capacity of trustee or by the beneficiary
as a beneficial owner of an interest in the trust and the application shall be signed individually by as many beneficiaries as are necessary to
constitute greater than fifty percent (50%) ownership of the beneficial interest of the trust.
(2) Within fourteen (14) days of receipt of the concept application, the building commissioner shall arrange with the applicant a prehearing meeting
which shall take place within sixty (60) days of the receipt of the concept application. (Ord. 88-536, 3-22-1988)
(3) Consolidations or lot line adjustments do not require this procedure. (Ord. 99-966, 1-25-1999)
2.6: General Procedure; Preliminary Plat.
(1) Within thirty (30) days of the final prehearing meeting, the applicant shall file a preliminary plat of subdivision with the building commissioner. The
filing of the preliminary plat shall be deemed to be the filing of the preliminary application. (Ord. 88-536, 3-22-1988)
(2) The petitioner shall send notice by registered or certified mail, return receipt requested, of the first meeting at which the plan and zoning
commission will consider the said preliminary plat, to all owners of record of each lot or parcel of property located within two hundred fifty feet (250')
of any portion of the land proposed to be subdivided. This notice shall be based upon the most recent Cook County tax records and Sidwell maps.
This notice shall be given not less than fifteen (15) days nor more than thirty (30) days prior to the hearing. The notice shall contain a general
description of the land proposed to be subdivided and a general description of the proposed subdivision. The date for the first meeting shall be set
within twenty eight (28) days of the filing of the preliminary plat. (Ord. 99-966, 1-25-1999)
(3) The plan commission shall approve or disapprove the application for preliminary approval within ninety (90) days from the date of the application or
the filing by the applicant of the last item of required supporting data, whichever date is later. If such plat is disapproved, then within said ninety (90)
days the plan commission shall furnish to the applicant a written statement setting forth the reason for disapproval and specifying with particularity
the aspects in which the proposed plat fails to conform to village regulations. The corporate authorities shall accept or reject said plat within thirty
(30) days after its next regular stated meeting following any action of the plan commission. Preliminary approval shall not qualify a plat for recording.
(4) Upon approval of the corporate authorities, the applicant shall be responsible for submitting a copy of the preliminary plat to such authorities as are
required for the approval of final plats under 765 Illinois Compiled Statutes 205/2.
(5) The plan commission shall have the right to continue a hearing for the purpose of permitting the applicant to comply with the requirements of this
appendix or other regulations of the village. However, the plan commission shall not be required to grant such continuances.
(6) The plan commission may recommend or the corporate authorities may require such changes or revisions in the preliminary plat as are deemed
necessary in the interests and needs of the community and as are consistent with this appendix. (Ord. 88-536, 3-22-1988)
(7) Consolidations or lot line adjustments do not require this procedure. (Ord. 99-966, 1-25-1999)
2.7: Preliminary Plat; Requirements.
A. Preliminary Plat. Each preliminary plat shall show and contain the following:
(1) Identification And Description.
(a) Proposed name of subdivision (not duplicating name of any plat heretofore recorded in Cook County).
(b) Location by township, section, town, and range, or by other legal description.
(c) Graphics (engineering scale not smaller than 1 inch to 100 feet).
(d) Names and addresses of all property owners adjacent to the subject property shall be shown on the plat along with all adjacent property lines and
easements or rights of way.
(e) North point (designated as true north).
(f) Date of preparation.
(g) A signed statement by the land planner or developer that the plat meets the requirement of this appendix B and the Illinois plat act.
(h) Names and addresses of planners, engineers, surveyors, legal and beneficial title holders, and persons responsible for the subject plat.
(i) Total acreage of the subdivision to within one-tenth (1/10) of an acre.
(2) Existing Conditions.
All of the following occurring within two hundred feet (200') of the boundaries of the proposed subdivision shall be shown:
(a) Clear indication of the boundary lines of the proposed subdivision.
(b) Location, widths, and names of all existing or previously platted streets or other public ways indicating types of improvements and location of
railroad and utility rights of way, parks and other public open spaces, permanent buildings and structures, easements, and section and corporate
boundary lines.
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=886 343/377
(c) Location and size of existing sewers, water mains, culverts, or other underground facilities, including such data as grades, invert elevations, and
locations of catchbasins, manholes, and hydrants.
(d) Boundary lines of adjoining unsubdivided or subdivided land identified by name and ownership.
(e) Topographical data including contours at vertical intervals of not more than one foot (1'); watercourses, marshes, rock outcrops, and high water
elevation. Sources of information and other significant features shall be included. When contour lines are more than one hundred feet (100') apart
intermediate spot elevation lines shall be provided.
(3) Subdivision Design Features. The application for preliminary approval shall show or contain the following:
(a) The location and width of proposed streets, alleys, and public ways.
(b) The proposed location of sewers and storm drains.
(c) The proposed dedication of public grounds, if any.
(d) The layout, number, area, and typical dimensions of lots to the nearest foot.
(e) Proposed easements for public utilities.
(f) An engineering plan and narrative statement of the proposed method of sewage and waste disposal, storm water disposal, and water supply.
(g) The quantity of storm water detention required and provided, the actual and allowable release rate, the upstream bypass area, and the route and
capacity of the downstream system.
(h) Soils information including USDA type, water table, bearing capacity, and boring location. (1 boring shall be provided for every 300 feet of road.)
(i) Preliminary landscape and lighting plan for roads or other areas intended for use by the public.
(j) Lot area for each lot with designations of the largest lot, smallest lot, and average lot area.
(4) Restrictive Covenants.
(a) An outline of the restrictive covenants shall accompany the preliminary plat.
(b) In cases of annexation, the applicant shall, within ninety (90) days after the final plat is recorded, initiate proceedings to disconnect from the
Northbrook rural fire protection district and the special police district such portion or portions of land contained in said subdivision that lies within
the village limits. The applicant shall further petition to annex such portions of land to the Northfield or the Winnetka park district and to the
Winnetka library district. (Ord. 88-536, 3-22-1988)
2.8: General Procedure; Final Plat.
(1) Application for approval of the final plat shall be filed with the building commissioner not later than one year after preliminary approval has been
granted. Such application shall be accompanied by:
(a) The original tracing of the proposed final plat, suitable for recording, and six (6) copies thereof.
(b) All fees as required by appendix D of this code.
(c) Four (4) complete sets of engineering plans and specifications of required land improvements as regulated by section 3.2 of this appendix B. Said
plans and specifications shall bear the seal of an Illinois registered professional engineer, along with his signed statement that such plans and
specifications have been prepared in compliance with this appendix B and with good engineering practice.
(d) A statement signed by the subdivider, builder, or land developer setting forth an agreement executed by such subdivider, builder, or land
developer wherein he, or they, agree to make and install the improvements provided in section 3.3, division III of this appendix in accordance with
the plans and specifications approved by the village.
(e) All bonds required under section 2.11 of this division.
(2) The applicant may elect to have final approval made on a geographic part or parts of the plat which have received preliminary approval, and may
delay application for approval of other parts until a later date or dates beyond one year with the approval of the corporate authorities, provided that all
public improvements required to serve the part or parts for which final approval is sought have been provided. In such case only the part or parts of
the plat that have received final approval shall be recorded1.
(3) The plan commission shall approve or disapprove the final plat of subdivision within forty five (45) days from the date of the application for final
approval of the plat or the filing by the applicant of the last item of required supporting data, whichever date is later. If such plat is disapproved, then
within said forty five (45) days the plan commission shall furnish to the applicant in writing a statement setting forth the reason for disapproval and
specifying with particularity the aspects in which the proposed plat fails to conform to the village of Northfield regulations. The corporate authorities
shall by resolution accept or reject said plat within thirty (30) days after its next regular meeting following any action of the plan commission.
(4) After approval by the corporate authorities, the secretary of the plan commission shall cause the final plat to be recorded in the recorder's office of
Cook County. However, in the case of subdivision in the jurisdictional area outside the village limits, the final plat will be transmitted to the plat officer
of Cook County. (Ord. 88-536, 3-22-1988)
2.9: Final Plat; Requirements.
Each final plat shall contain and show the following:
(a) Proposed name of subdivision and legal description of subdivision.
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=886 344/377
(b) An identification system for all lots and blocks.
(c) Accurate angular and lineal dimensions for all lines, angles, and curvatures used to describe boundaries, streets, alleys, easements, building
setback lines, areas to be reserved for public use, and other important features. Lot lines shall show dimensions in feet and hundredths. All
dimensions shown on curved lines shall be arc distances. The minimum scale of final plats shall be one inch equals fifty feet (1" = 50').
(d) True angles and distances to at least two (2) of the nearest established street lines or official monuments accurately described in the plat.
(e) North point (designated as true north).
(f) Township, county or section lines accurately tied to the lines of the subdivision by distance and angles.
(g) Radii, internal angles, points of tangency and curvature, tangent bearings, and lengths of all arcs.
(h) Accurate location of all subdivision boundary monuments of three inches by three inches by thirty inches (3" x 3" x 30") precast concrete with iron
pipe cast in the center. Concrete monuments shall be placed at all changes in direction of a subdivision exterior boundary and at all points where a
proposed dedicated right of way crosses the boundary. Pipes or steel rods shall be placed at the corners of each lot and at each point of tangency
and curvature.
(i) Accurate outlines and legal descriptions of any areas to be dedicated or reserved for public use or for the exclusive use of the property owners within
the subdivision, with purposes indicated thereon.
(j) Where a floodwater retention or detention basin or storm sewer system is to be constructed, the date of completion of such basin or system or a
phasing schedule for the completion thereof. Such schedule shall assure the completion of all storm sewers and floodwater retention basins
necessary to accommodate all storm water associated with the particular phasing of the development prior to the issuance of any building permits.
(k) Restrictive covenants shall be lettered on the final plat or appropriately referenced thereon.
(l) Certification by a licensed surveyor, to the effect that the plat represents a survey made by him and that monuments and markers shown thereon
exist as located and that all dimensional details are correct.
(m) Mylar topographical overlay for entire subdivision.
(n) The flood base elevation for the site shall be shown at each corner of each subdivision plat. Said plat shall also indicate for each lot in a subdivision
in the floodplain the minimum elevations of ground floors, basement floors, or the bottom of openings in basement walls. (Zoning Ordinance)
(o) Signed approval of the Illinois department of transportation indicating that the plat complies in all respects with all local, county, state and federal
regulations, including, but not limited to, 765 Illinois Compiled Statutes 205/2, with respect to the approval for roadway access. (Ord. 01-1073, 8-20-
2001)
(p) Notarized certification by owner and by any mortgage holder of record of the adoption of the plat and the dedication of streets and other public
areas.
(q) Forms for certification showing that all special assessments due on the property to be subdivided have been paid in full.
(r) Forms for approval by signature of village, county, metropolitan sanitary district, and state officials concerned with the specifications of utility
installations.
(s) Form for approval by the plan commission.
(t) Form for approval by the village board.
(u) Forms for approval by Cook County authorities as required. (Ord. 88-536, 3-22-1988)
2.10: Compliance With Floodplain Regulations.
