All subdivision plats shall comply in all respects with article XIIIA, "Floodplain Regulations" of the Northfield zoning ordinance. (Ord. 88-536, 3-22-1988)
2.11: Bonds Required For Subdivisions Both Within And Without Corporate Limits.
A. Completion Bond. Before issuance of any building permits for improvements of lots in a subdivision within the borders of the village or outside the
village border (but within the village's zoning jurisdiction) the subdivider, builder, or developer shall deposit with the village an amount sufficient to cover
one hundred fifteen percent (115%) of the estimate made by the village engineer to complete all public improvements, both on and off site, (except
trees) required under this appendix, including all reasonable inspection fees. This bond may be accomplished in one of the following ways: 1) a cash
bond in said amount, 2) an irrevocable commercial letter of credit in said amount issued by a national or state banking association, or 3) an irrevocable
letter of commitment in said amount issued by a federal or state savings and loan association. The bond shall contain a statement that it shall not
expire prior to completion and acceptance of the public improvements as set forth in section 2.13 and a further statement that failure to complete the
public improvements prior to the scheduled completion date shall constitute default. The bond may be reduced from time to time upon the approval of
the village Manager concurrently with preliminary approval of corresponding portions of the improvements. Said reduction shall be on the basis of one
dollar ($1.00) reduced for each one dollar ($1.00) paid by the owner or developer. If cash is posted, as in item 1 of this subsection, that cash deposit
may be used to pay dollar for dollar for invoiced labor and materials subject to reasonable procedures for lien waivers and verification of invoices as
established by the village.
B. Defects Bond. Prior to any reduction in bond pursuant to subsection A of this section by the village, owner, subdivider, or developer shall deposit with
the village cash in an amount equal to fifteen percent (15%) of the total deposit required under subsection A of this section. Such cash along with any
remaining principal deposit described in subsection A of this section, shall be retained by the village for a period of one year following the final
acceptance of all improvements to be constructed in order to insure and protect against defects or faults discovered during said one year period. The
village may use all or any portion of such amount retained to cure and correct any faults or defects discovered during said one year period, including
legal and engineering fees necessarily incurred by the village as a result of those faults or defects. Upon the expiration of said one year period, the
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=886 345/377
entire amount remaining shall be refunded to the developer. Nothing herein shall prevent the village from further charging the subdivider for repair or
replacement of defective items or from maintaining legal action to enforce payment for repair of defects2.
C. Tree Bond. The owner, subdivider, or developer shall deposit with the village one hundred twenty five percent (125%) of the amount of the village
engineer's estimate of the cost of all parkway trees within the subdivision. This amount shall be retained by the village for a period of forty eight (48)
months after the last tree is planted. The trees shall be replaced as often as necessary during that time period. Funds remaining after forty eight (48)
months shall be released upon approval of the building commissioner. Nothing herein shall prevent the village from further charging the subdivider for
repair or replacement of defective items or from maintaining legal action to enforce payment for repair of defects3. (Ord. 88-536, 3-22-1988)
2.12: Portional Development Of Subdivision.
It shall be presumed to be in the best interests of the village that all subdivisions be developed and completed as a unit. No builder, developer, or
subdivider may install public improvements on a phased or sectional basis as a matter or right. The corporate authorities may approve such sectional
development only upon a finding that it will not adversely affect the rest of the subdivision or the village as a whole. Such sectional development shall be
subject to modification of bonding requirements, public improvement and private road acceptance requirements, and scheduling of issuance of building
permits as the corporate authorities shall deem appropriate. (Ord. 88-536, 3-22-1988)
2.13: Acceptance Of Required Land Improvements.
When all public improvements required by this appendix B have been installed in conformance with the approved engineering plans and specifications and
when "as built" plans have been submitted to the building commissioner, the subdivider shall then present to the building commissioner a certificate by an
engineer licensed to practice in the state of Illinois stating that all public improvements have been completed in accordance with the specifications. "As
built" plans shall include a survey of all public improvements and private streets noting "as constructed" elevations, locations, materials, and fittings. All
structures shall be located by means of two measurements to surrounding permanent objects. The corporate authorities may then enact a resolution
accepting said improvements as having been completed, provided that roads and sidewalks may not be accepted by the corporate authorities until fifty
percent (50%) of the lots have buildings on them. Private roads shall require approval by the village in the same manner. In the sole discretion of the
village, roads and streets may be accepted subject to the installation of the asphalt surface not later than fifteen (15) months after installation of the binder
and base. The village shall require appropriate security for such delayed installation of the surface course. (Ord. 88-536, 3-22-1988)
2.14: Building Permit.
No building permit shall be issued by any village official for the construction of any building, structure or improvement to the land or any lot within a
subdivision until the plat of subdivision or portion of the plat affected by the building permit has been recorded. (Ord. 88-536, 3-22-1988)
2.15: Occupancy Permit.
No occupancy permit shall be granted for the use of any structure within a subdivision approved for platting until the required public improvements and
private roads have been accepted pursuant to section 2.14 of this division. (Ord. 88-536, 3-22-1988)
2.16: Failure To Complete.
In the event that the subdivider fails to complete the construction in accordance with the requirements of this appendix B within two (2) years of the date of
the bond agreement, the bond shall be forfeited and the village of Northfield may use all or part of such bond as may be required to complete the project in
accordance with the approved working drawings. The above time limit may be extended by the village when it deems that to do so is in the public interest.
(Ord. 88-536, 3-22-1988)
DIVISION III. SUBDIVISION STANDARDS AND REQUIREMENTS
3.1: Public And Private Streets.
It is the intention of this appendix B that new streets shall be dedicated public roads with sidewalks which must specifically conform to the standards set
forth herein. However, a single-family residential subdivider may request, and the corporate authorities may approve, a subdivision which does not comply
with the construction standards of section 3.3 of this division which contains private, undedicated streets or which contains no sidewalks. The corporate
authorities may authorize the construction of streets that do not comply with the construction standards of section 3.3 of this division, approve such private
streets, and authorize the elimination of sidewalks. They may do so upon written notice from the village engineer, police chief, and fire chief that the street,
as designed, provides adequate and safe access for the public and for appropriate emergency vehicles; that doing so will result in the development of a
subdivision that is consistent with the character of the neighborhood in which the subdivision is to be located; and that the health, safety, and welfare of all
Northfield residents will not be adversely affected. Unless the corporate authorities have granted relief from the requirements of section 3.3 of this division
pursuant to the terms of this section, private, undedicated streets shall conform in all respects to the construction requirements of this appendix B. If the
subdivider petitions for relief under this section, the subdivider agrees to be bound by the requirements of the corporate authorities. If the subdivider is
unwilling to abide by the terms set out by the corporate authorities, he will then be required to abide by all of the standards set forth in this division. (Ord.
06-1277, 2-21-2006)
3.2: Design Standards.
(1) Street Plan. The arrangement, character, extent, width, grade, and location of all streets shall conform to the official comprehensive plan and to the
provisions of this section; and shall be considered in their relation to existing and planned streets, to reasonable circulation of traffic, to topographical
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=886 346/377
conditions, to runoff of storm water, to public convenience and safety, and in their appropriate relations to the proposed uses of the area to be
served.
(2) Streets.
(a) All streets shall have a minimum pavement width of twenty four feet (24') and a minimum street width of sixty six feet (66'), subject to the
provisions of section 3.1 of this division.
(b) Where a street centerline within a single block deflects more than ten degrees (10°), a curve with a minimum centerline radius of one hundred fifty
feet (150') shall be required. Street centerlines within a single block may deflect at less than ten degrees (10°) without curves, provided that such
deflections are at least three hundred feet (300') apart.
(c) Proposed subdivisions containing more than ten (10) acres shall have street layouts on curvilinear patterns. However, in such subdivisions an
interconnecting grid system of thoroughfares shall be required at approximately one-half (1/2) mile intervals unless specifically waived by the
corporate authorities upon advice of the village engineer. Subdivisions containing ten (10) acres or less may be curvilinear or rectangular.
(d) The maximum length of a straight street centerline or extension of a tangent to a curve shall be three hundred feet (300'). This shall not apply to
straight streets on the boundary of a subdivision.
(e) All centerline gradients shall be at least one percent (1.00%) and shall not exceed six percent (6.00%).
(f) Vertical curves shall be used whenever a change in the centerline gradient occurs except where the algebraic difference in gradients is one
percent (1%) or less. The length of vertical curve on minor streets shall be forty feet (40') for each one percent (1%) of algebraic difference of
grade but in no case shall such length be less than one hundred feet (100').
(g) Local streets shall be so aligned that their use by traffic other than local will be discouraged.
(h) Street jogs with centerline offsets of less than one hundred twenty five feet (125') are prohibited.
(i) All street intersections and confluences shall be designed so as to encourage safe and efficient traffic flow. Visual or "sightline" easements will be
provided at intersections where directed by the village engineer.
(j) The maximum length of cul-de-sacs shall be five hundred feet (500') measured along the centerline from the intersection at origin to end of right of
way, unless there are fewer than sixteen (16) lots abutting the cul-de-sac. Each cul-de-sac shall have a terminus of nearly circular shape with a
minimum right of way diameter of one hundred twenty feet (120'). Cul-de-sac pavements shall have a minimum diameter of ninety feet (90').
Curbed planting islands with a maximum diameter of forty feet (40') shall be included.
(k) Reserved strips of land designed to block the extension of platted or existing streets or direct street access are prohibited.
(l) Where a lot abuts two (2) or more streets, access shall be restricted to the more local cross street.
(3) Alleys And Sidewalks.
(a) Alleys are not permitted in residential areas.
(b) Alleys, at least twenty four feet (24') wide, shall be provided in commercial or industrial subdivisions unless all lots therein are otherwise provided
with access to off street loading space.
(c) Sidewalks shall be at least five feet (5') wide and shall be required along all streets. (Ord. 88-536, 3-22-1988)
(4) Street Lighting. There shall be at least one standard luminaire at each intersection in residential zoning districts. In the village center,
office/research, M-1 and NC zoning districts, spacing and location of standards shall be as approved by the corporate authorities. (Ord. 88-536, 3-22-
1988; amd. Ord. 03-1156, 3-18-2003)
(5) Public Utility Easements. Easements for utilities, sewer and/or drainage shall be provided by clearly indicating on the face of the plat the following
language:
Easement Provisions
Whenever the words "public utilities" or "public utilities easement" shall appear on this plat, the Village of Northfield, a municipal corporation,
Cook County, Illinois, and its successors and assigns, jointly and severally, shall hold a perpetual easement under, over, and across the surface of
the property marked as such on the plat. The words "public utilities" or "public utilities easement" shall designate land to be used for the
installation, construction, use, repair, and maintenance of all public utility equipment, including, but not limited to, facilities used in connection with
underground transmission and/or distribution of electricity, sounds, signals, water, sewage, and overland swales. Rights to enter the subdivided
property shall be granted for all such purposes, including the right to enter to cut, trim, or remove vegetation as may be reasonably required for
such public utilities. Obstructions shall not be placed over grantee's facilities or in, upon, or over the property within the lines marked "easement"
without the prior written consent of the grantee. Such consent of the grantee shall not relieve the grantor(s) or their successors or assigns from the
duty and obligation to remove, at their sole expense, such obstructions whenever the grantee, in its sole judgment, deems such removal
necessary, in its sole judgment, to enable the grantee to repair or maintain any facilities within the easement rights granted hereunder. After
installation of any such facilities, the grade of the subdivided property shall not be altered in a manner so as to unreasonably interfere with the
proper operation and maintenance thereof.
The submission of the final plat to the corporate authorities for final approval shall constitute consent by the property owner(s) to the terms of the
declaration or easement set forth in this section. (Ord. 88-536, 3-22-1988)
(6) Drainage Easement. Where subdivisions abut the Middlefork or the Skokie branch of the north branch of the Chicago River or its tributaries, an
easement shall be granted to the village for drainage and future access to such watercourse. The easement shall be the greater of either of the
following: a) fifty feet (50') on each side of the waterway as measured from the centerline; b) the entire width of the floodway as designated by the
Illinois department of transportation. The width of an easement along tributaries may be reduced from the aforementioned width with the consent of
the corporate authorities. The village may also require a reasonable easement for drainage and future access from the street to the watercourse.
(Ord. 05-1247, 6-21-2005)
All subdivision plans shall include provisions (and easements, if required) for emergency overload flow.
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=886 347/377
(7) Block Standards.
(a) The maximum lengths of blocks shall be one thousand eight hundred feet (1,800'). Blocks over nine hundred feet (900') long shall have
pedestrianways at their approximate centers. The use of additional accessways to schools, parks, or other destinations may be specified by the
plan commission.
(b) No specific rule concerning the shape of blocks is made, but blocks must fit readily into the overall plan of subdivision and their design must
evidence consideration of lot planning, traffic flow, and public open space areas.
(c) Blocks intended for commercial, industrial, and institutional use must be designed to accommodate such traffic and development.
(d) It shall be an objective of the village to limit intersections of subdivision roadways with existing roadways to not less than one-half (1/2) mile
intervals. To this end, any new subdivision with more than one-half (1/2) mile of frontage along an existing roadway shall have access points at not
less than one-half (1/2) mile intervals. The village may also require all subdivisions whether having more or less than one-half (1/2) mile frontage, to
have access from existing subdivision roadways or the village may require the construction of an access street parallel to the existing roadway
within a single subdivision or to connect new subdivisions to existing subdivisions.
(e) The above standards may be modified for planned unit developments upon approval of the corporate authorities.
(8) Lot Standards.
(a) Minimum lot dimensions in subdivisions designed for single-family detached dwelling developments shall be:
1. Seventy five feet (75') wide (85 feet for corner lots), measured at the established building setback line and fifty feet (50') wide measured at the
front lot line along outside street curvatures.
2. Not less than one hundred ten feet (110') in average depth.
3. Rear lot lines shall be a minimum of thirty feet (30'). (Ord. 88-536, 3-22-1988)
4. All lots shall be in full compliance with the zoning ordinance of the village of Northfield, except those outlots established for compensatory
storage or detention. (Ord. 05-1247, 6-21-2005)
5. Any portion of a lot dedicated to detention, retention, or compensatory storage shall not be included when determining minimum lot square
footage for a particular zoning district pursuant to the zoning ordinance of the village of Northfield.
(b) Acute angled lot corners are prohibited. In general, lots should be as nearly rectangular as practicable.
(c) Side lines of a lot shall be substantially at right angles or radial to the street line.
(d) All lots, except those in planned developments, shall abut on a publicly dedicated street or a private road as approved by the corporate
authorities.
(e) Double frontage lots are not permitted except:
1. Where lots back upon a major thoroughfare.
2. Where topographic or other conditions (such as commercial usage) render subdividing otherwise unreasonable.
Such excepted double frontage lots shall have an additional depth of at least twenty feet (20') in order to allow space for a protective screen along
the back lot line.
No excepted double frontage lot shall have access to more than one street.
(f) A minimum of four inches (4") of topsoil must be provided on all lots and parkways. (Ord. 88-536, 3-22-1988)
(9) Floodplain Regulations. (Rep. by Ord. 05-1247, 6-21-2005)
(10) Drainage Grading Plan. Prior to the approval by the village authorities of the final plat of subdivision, the applicant shall have prepared an overall
drainage grading plan of the area covered by the subdivision plan on which is indicated the proposed method of disposing of storm water from the
lots and blocks in the area. When possible, the plan shall indicate the approximate size and location of each home to be constructed on each lot, the
foundation or first floor elevation, the elevation of the proposed pavement and sidewalk, the route and elevation of the emergency overflow route, the
location grading and release rate from each detention or retention basin, and the elevation of the finished grade at each corner of each lot. The plan
shall also indicate the manner in which storm water runoff is to discharge from back lot line locations to the proposed pavement or storm sewer
system. All drainage plans shall comply with chapter 7 of this code.
(11) Compensatory Storage And Detention. All compensatory storage basins and detention areas in subdivisions of three (3) or more lots shall be
located in a separate outlot. The village, in its sole discretion, may also require that compensatory storage basins and detention areas in subdivisions
of less than three (3) lots be located in a separate outlot. An easement of not less than twenty feet (20') in width and running from a street to the
outlot shall be required to give access to the village for the purpose of maintaining the outlot. All new subdivisions in the village of Northfield or any
portion thereof which is located within the floodplain and which requires compensatory storage, shall provide the compensatory storage according to
a ratio of one to twenty five (1:25) units of storage for any unit of fill brought into the floodplain. This requirement shall be enforced notwithstanding
any less stringent compensatory storage requirements found in any other ordinances of the village of Northfield.
The building commissioner shall maintain a complete listing of all compensatory storage basins and detention basins for the storage and retention of
storm water in the village, whether required under this appendix B or otherwise, and shall cause each basin to be inspected periodically, but not less
than every five (5) years. Such inspection shall be performed at the owner's expense and by an engineer registered in the state of Illinois. A report
shall be submitted to the building commissioner, including supporting calculations stipulating the existing capacity of the storage basin. The building
commissioner shall cause notice to be served upon the record owner thereof to restore, repair, or properly maintain any such basin which does not
retain its original storage capacity. This paragraph shall apply to all compensatory storage basins or detention areas existing on the date of the
adoption of this appendix B as well as all future compensatory storage basins or detention areas. In the event such notice has not been complied
with on or before ninety (90) days after service thereof (unless such time period shall be extended by the corporate authorities), the village may
perform such restoration, repair, or maintenance work as may be necessary to return such compensatory storage basin or detention area to its
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=886 348/377
original storage capacity. The cost thereof shall be a lien in favor of the village upon the lot, tract, or parcel of land upon which compensatory storage
basin or detention area is located or against each property for which it was created to benefit. Such lien shall be enforceable at law or in equity upon
the village's filing with the recorder of deeds of Cook County, Illinois, a notice of lien citing this paragraph and describing the necessary work
performed and the reasonable cost thereof to the village. A recordable covenant satisfactory to the village attorney shall be required for the perpetual
maintenance of the compensatory storage basin or detention area.
(12) Preservation Of Landscape. The landscape shall be preserved in its natural state, insofar as practicable, by minimizing tree and soil removal so
that the resulting development will be in keeping with the general appearance of neighboring developed areas and will not adversely affect the
ecology of the area. (Ord. 88-536, 3-22-1988)
3.3: Construction Standards.
The owner or subdivider shall install storm and sanitary sewers, water supply system, street grading and pavement, alleys, pedestrianways, public utilities
and street lighting in accordance with applicable ordinances of the village of Northfield and with the most current "Report And Master Plan For Sanitary
Sewer Extensions", "Report And Master Plan For Storm Drainage", and "Report And Master Plan For Water Supply And Distribution". All utilities and
services shall be placed underground and trenched in. If such utilities are placed within a 1.1 slope of an existing or proposed pavement or sidewalk, they
shall be backfilled with crushed stone, the grade shall be as specified by the village engineer.
(1) Sewers.
(a) Sanitary sewers and sanitary sewer services shall be installed to serve all properties in the subdivision and shall meet all requirements of chapter
7 of this code. Sanitary sewers shall be constructed of SDR 26 PVC or class 52 DIP. Sanitary and storm services shall be SDR 35 PVC or CL52
DIP. Public sanitary sewers shall have a minimum internal diameter of eight inches (8"). Sanitary sewer services shall have a minimum internal
diameter of six inches (6"). Joints for sanitary sewers and sanitary sewer services shall be of the compression type in conformance with the
specifications of the American Society for Testing Materials, designation D3212 (PVC) or (DIP). Sidewalls and bases of manholes on sanitary
sewers shall be of reinforced precast concrete ring construction which shall have a five inch (5") minimum thickness. Manhole frames and covers
shall be Neenah R-1015 with a concealed pickhole, gasket seal and "SANITARY" cast on top. Precast flexible rubber sleeves shall be provided for
all manhole connections. Manhole covers to be used in the floodplain shall be a bolt down type (R-1077-B or R-1916-F).
(b) Current MDSGC requirements shall apply, including, but not limited to, requirements for pipe slope and manhole spacing. All PVC pipe shall be
defection tested. All pipe shall be tested for infiltration.
(c) In cases where a connection is within twelve inches (12") of the invert, sanitary services shall connect directly to the manhole. All other
connections shall be by WYE connection and shall attach to the pipe with a gasket or glue and bonding. Maximum infiltration shall be 100 gal./in
dia./mile/day, tested after service connections are installed.
(d) Storm sewers throughout the entire subdivision shall be designed to carry water off from all inlets and catch basins and connect to an adequate
outfall. The storm water drainage system shall comply with all requirements of chapter 7 of this code. Storm sewers shall be constructed of
reinforced concrete pipe (class IV). SDR 35 PVC may be used off road or where cover materials at least 1.5 x diameter of the pipe is available.
Other materials of storm sewer construction may be used in special cases only upon the approval of the corporate authorities. Existing drain tiles
shall be connected to the storm sewers and shall be restored to operating condition. Sidewalls and bases of manholes on storm sewers shall be of
reinforced precast concrete ring construction which shall have five inch (5") minimum thickness. Storm sewer capacities shall be determined with
the use of the SCS TR 55 method, or in accordance with the village's storm water management code, whichever is more restrictive. All
transmission lines shall be designed for a return frequency of not less than ten (10) years. Street grades and drainage swale grades shall be
constructed to transport storm overflow for a 100-year storm without damage to adjoining property and shall be subject to approval by the village
engineer.
(2) Fire Hydrants. All fire hydrants shall be Traverse City TVC-5 (Traffic). All eight inch (8") water valves shall be installed in four feet (4') diameter
precast concrete vaults with minimum five and one-fourth inch (51/4") valve openings rated at 150 psi working pressure and 300 psi total pressure
and shall have Neenah R-1015 frame and grate with "water" cast on top. Valves shall be waterproof resilient wedge gate valves, AWWA C509. All
tapping valves and valves larger than ten inches (10") shall be in a vault at least sixty inches (60") in diameter.
(3) Water Supply. Water distribution facilities, including pipe fittings, hydrants, valves, valve basins, water services, and all other necessary
appurtenances required for fire and domestic needs shall be in compliance with all requirements of chapter 7 of this code and shall be installed to
serve all properties within the subdivision. Water mains shall have a minimum eight inch (8") internal diameter, be constructed of ductile iron class
52, and shall conform to the specifications of the federal government designation WWP421, class 250. Pipes shall have approved double sealing,
single gasket type joints. Fittings shall have mechanical joints. All water services shall be constructed of type K copper pipe, having a minimum
internal diameter of one inch (1"). Such services shall be equipped with corporation cock, curb stops, and other necessary fittings in accordance with
current village standards. Fire hydrants shall be located with a maximum of three hundred feet (300') between hydrants. Each building site shall be
located not more than three hundred feet (300') from a hydrant, any other code notwithstanding.
(4) Bedding And Backfill. All utility lines shall be placed in a prepared (shaped and compacted) bed of crushed stone, one-fourth inch (1/4") to threefourths
inch (3/4") in diameter. The bedding shall be one-fourth (1/4) the ID of the pipe. but at least four inches (4") thick. The pipe shall be covered at
least to the springline with the bedding material. Crushed limestone is required. Crushed gravel may be used with prior written approval of the village
engineer in special circumstances. In situations where storm sewers function as french drains, washed crushed gravel without fines shall be used for
bedding and trench backfill. Plastic pipe must be covered with the same material to twelve inches (12") above the crown of the pipe. All areas below
existing or proposed pavement must be filled to the surface with granular trench backfill of the same material.
(5) Street And Sidewalk Improvements.
(a) Street Grading. The full width of the right of way shall be graded to the required section and major trees shall be protected as specified in the
approved plans. All unsuitable subbase material shall be removed and replaced with stable, compacted material in conformance with generally
accepted engineering practices.
(b) Pavement And Sidewalk Widths. Pavement and sidewalk widths shall conform to the design standards specified in sections 3.1, 3.2(2) and
3.2(3) of this appendix B.
(c) Service Drives. Service drives shall be provided along thoroughfares. Pavement width of these service drives shall meet with the requirements
for streets.
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=886 349/377
(d) Street Pavements.
1. No public pavement or sidewalk within the village shall be constructed on soil which is unstable or which, in the opinion of the village engineer, is
otherwise unsuitable for pavement or sidewalk construction. Wherever unstable ground is encountered, either before preparation of detailed
plans or during the construction phase of the proposed improvements, said unstable materials shall be removed in their entirety and shall be
adequately compacted to the satisfaction of the village engineer. Combined thickness of base and surface course or base only shall be
determined from the Illinois department of transportation criteria for pavement design as dictated by soil testing. In no case shall the thickness
be less than the minimums stated below.
2. Pavements in residential areas shall consist of either of the following listed materials:
a. Portland cement concrete pavement having a minimum uniform thickness of eight inches (8"). Concrete for such pavement shall have a
minimum twenty eight (28) day compressive strength of three thousand five hundred (3,500) pounds and shall contain not less than six (6)
bags of cement per cubic yard of concrete. Entrained air content shall not be less than three percent (3%) nor more than six percent (6%).
Slump shall be not less than two inches (2") nor more than four inches (4").
b. Flexible pavement shall consist of a BAM base (minimum 6 inches thick) and class I modified surface (minimum 2 inches) course or a CA6
crushed limestone base (minimum 12 inches thick), a bituminous binder course (minimum 2.0 inches thick), and a class I modified surface
course (minimum 11/2 inches thick). Other flexible materials or designs may be permitted upon approval of the village engineer if the design is
in accordance with standard IDOT procedures. Minimum structural number shall be as follows:
Subdivision streets Minimum 3.00
Thoroughfare Minimum 4.00
Parking areas Minimum 2.75
Fire lanes Minimum 2.50
Minimum structural number designations shall be increased and geotextile utilized where the soil IBRs are less than three (3.0). Soil borings
are required, as per IDOT specifications, every three hundred feet (300') on all streets. IBR tests shall be required.
3. Pavements in or bordering industrial and/or commercial areas shall consist of either of the following listed materials:
a. Portland cement concrete pavement having a uniform thickness of nine inches (9"). Concrete for such pavement shall have a minimum twenty
eight (28) day compressive strength of three thousand five hundred (3,500) pounds per square inch, shall contain not less than six (6) bags of
cement per cubic yard of concrete, and shall contain not less than three percent (3%) nor more than six percent (6%) entrained air. Slump
shall not be less than two inches (2") nor more than four inches (4").
b. See subsection (5)(d)2b of this section for flexible design requirements. A structural number of four (4.00) minimum is required.
4. All curbs shall be of the M-6.12 type. Curbs and gutters on all streets shall be Portland cement concrete of the integral type not less than
eighteen inches (18") in overall width and having a thickness at the gutter flag of not less than the thickness of the proposed street pavement.
Two (2) #4 rebars in the flags are required. Curbs may be constructed integrally with the Portland cement concrete pavement. Concrete for curb
and gutter shall conform to that hereinbefore required for concrete pavement.
5. All curb corners shall have a radii of not less than fifteen feet (15').
(e) Improvements Outside Corporate Area. Street improvements in subdivisions within one and one-half (11/2) miles outside of the corporate area
shall conform to the same standards of improvements as required of subdivisions within the corporate area.
(f) Sidewalks. Sidewalks shall be constructed of Portland cement concrete to a thickness of five inches (5") on a four inch (4") crushed stone bed
and offset one foot (1') from the abutting lot line. The sidewalks may meander to avoid large trees but shall at all times be at least six feet (6') from
the adjacent roadway pavement. Concrete for such sidewalks shall have a minimum twenty eight (28) day compressive strength of three thousand
five hundred (3,500) pounds, shall contain not less than six (6) bags of cement per cubic yard of concrete, and shall contain not less than three
percent (3%) nor more than six percent (6%) entrained air. Slump shall not be less than two inches (2") nor more than four inches (4"). Sidewalks
shall be continuous between adjoining streets and shall be constructed through driveways.
(g) Handicapped Ramps. Handicapped ramps shall be required on all sidewalks at street crossings.
(h) Street Signs. Street name signs shall be erected at each intersection so as to identify every street within the subdivision. The design of public
street name signs shall be as designated by the village of Northfield.
All signs designating street names for all public streets in any subdivision or planned development shall be obtained and installed by the developer,
at developer's expense, pursuant to village specifications and at locations approved by the village. Private street name signs shall also obtain
approval by the village prior to installation. All public and private street names shall obtain village approval in order to avoid duplication or
confusion with existing street names.
(i) Storm Water Inlets. Storm water inlets shall be provided within the roadway improvements at points specified by the village engineer, but at least
once every three hundred feet (300') on both sides of the street. All curb inlets must include two foot (2') sumps and be at least forty eight inches
(48") in diameter. Frames shall be recessed approximately one-tenth foot (0.1') below the gutter line.
(j) Parkways. All parkways within a dedicated street area shall be covered with a minimum of four inches (4") of topsoil and fine graded. (Ord. 88-
536, 3-22-1988)
(k) Trees. Trees shall be planted along both sides of all streets at a maximum interval of thirty feet (30') unless suitable trees are in existence. All
new trees shall be balled and bagged and have a trunk diameter of not less than three inches (3") measured twelve inches (12") above grade. This
requirement may be waived in the sole discretion of the village if an equivalent number of trees of the same size or larger are planted in a natural
manner in the front yards of the adjoining lots. The plantings shall be approved by the village. (Ord. 03-1152, 2-18-2003)
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=886 350/377
(6) Pedestrianways. Pedestrianways shall be constructed of Portland cement concrete conforming to the requirements set forth under subsection (5)
(f) of this section.
(7) Public Utilities. Electrical and telephone service lines shall be installed underground in back and side yard easements unless permission for
overhead service is specifically given by the corporate authorities. Underground telephone, electrical, and gas service shall be placed within
easements or dedicated public ways in a manner which will not conflict with other underground services. All transformer boxes shall be located so as
not to be unsightly or hazardous to the public.
(8) Street Lighting Improvements. Street lighting improvements shall be installed to serve all properties within the subdivision. Such improvements
shall be of the individual service or of the multiple circuit type and shall consist of standards, luminaries, cable conduit under driveways and/or
streets, controllers, handholes, and all other miscellaneous work and equipment necessary for an integrated system of streetlights.
(a) Specifications. Lighting structures shall be consistent with other developments within the village and shall conform to neighborhood design
standards.
(b) Luminaries. Luminaries shall be of the mercury vapor or metal halide type. Size and life shall be as follows:
1. Residential area: One hundred seventy five (175) watts with average life of three thousand (3,000) hours.
2. Commercial, industrial and manufacturing areas: Two hundred fifty (250) watts or four hundred (400) watts with average life of three thousand
(3,000) hours as approved by the corporate authorities.
3. Ballasts shall be of the constant wattage type.
(c) Cable On Multiple Circuit Systems. Cable on multiple circuit systems shall be not less than no. 8 wire and shall be buried at least thirty inches
(30") below finished grade. Cable shall be installed in a two inch (2") galvanized rigid steel conduit with two inch (2") fiber bushings where such
cable crosses beneath existing or proposed pavements, driveways or sidewalks. No underground cable splices will be permitted.
(d) Cable In Individual Service Systems. Cable in individual service systems shall be not less than no. 12 wire with six hundred (600) volt
insulation, type USE, style RR, installed in direct burial not less than thirty inches (30") below grade. Underground splices will be permitted at
points of connection to the Public Service Company lines.
(9) Soils Investigations And Physical Tests.
(a) Soil borings, at least six feet (6') deep, shall be required at three hundred feet (300') on center in all proposed roadways, including IBR tests. If the
subsoil IBR is less than three (3.0), either structural geotextile shall be placed below the stone base or the subsoil shall be removed and replaced
at the village engineer's discretion. If used, the geotextile with structural compacted fill shall extend one hundred feet (100') beyond the poor soil
zone.
(b) If, in the opinion of the village engineer, soil of the buildable lots in the proposed subdivision is questionable and will require soil investigators'
borings or other soil tests to determine the nature and extent of such questionable material, the subdivider, builder or land developer shall retain
the services of a competent testing laboratory to perform the needed investigations. Such testing laboratory shall be subject to the approval of the
village.
(c) Copies of the completed reports compiled by the testing laboratory shall be filed with the village manager and the village engineer.
(d) Prior to installation of the base course, density tests must be made by the nuclear density method and approved by the village engineer. Density
of ninety five percent (95%) standard Proctor shall be required. Also, a proof-roll with a loaded six (6) wheeler track must be performed in the
presence of the village engineer.
(e) Nuclear density tests shall be performed on all asphalt courses to establish a proper rolling pattern. Weight tickets, cores, and test results must
be submitted and approved by the village engineer.
(10) Supervision. The design engineer engaged by the subdivider, builder, or land developer shall be represented by his agent at the site of
construction at all times when construction of required land improvements is in progress. Failure to comply with this requirement shall constitute
grounds for immediate stoppage of said construction by the village inspector. (Ord. 88-536, 3-22-1988)
3.4: Inspections.
Inspection of public improvements or required land improvements to be installed under the provisions of this article shall be performed during the course of
construction by an inspector appointed by the corporate authorities. Salaries and other costs pursuant thereto shall be paid by the subdivider, builder, or
land developer. (Ord. 88-536, 3-22-1988)
3.5: Conveyance Of Improvements.
Title to all public improvements required in this section shall, at the time the same are accepted by the corporate authorities, be conveyed and transferred
to the village of Northfield by sufficient documents of transfer. Partial acceptance of improvements by the village is permitted. (Ord. 88-536, 3-22-1988)
3.6: Dedication Of School And Park Lands.
If a new subdivision or planned development: a) creates a need that is uniquely and specifically attributable to the subdivision or development; and b) the
subdivision is wholly or partially residential; and c) is more than five (5) acres, then as a condition of approval of a final plat the subdivider or developer will
be required to dedicate land to serve immediate and future park, recreational and school needs. In certain instances as set forth below, the subdivider or
developer, at the sole discretion of the village, may be required to make a cash contribution in place of or in combination with actual land dedication. All
dedications or contributions shall be made in accordance with the following criteria and formulae. If because of the small number of persons added by a
new development, any required dedication is less than the minimum requirement set forth below, the dedication or contribution shall be prorated. This
dedication requirement shall apply to the park district and elementary or middle school district in which the development is located.
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=886 351/377

B. Criteria For Requiring Land Dedication.
(1) Parks.
(a) Requirement And Population Ratio. The land dedication requirement shall be 0.55 acres of land for each one hundred (100) persons
estimated to be added in accordance with the table set forth in subsection 3.6A of this section. (If the estimated population increase is less than
100 persons, a cash contribution shall be required based on a figure of 0.0055 acres of land for each person.)
The type and location of the recreational site shall be determined by the village, in its sole discretion, using accepted recreational planning
standards and examining the community needs that are on account of and are uniquely and specifically attributable to the proposed development.
(b) Credit For Private Open Spaces Or Private Recreation Areas. Depending on the size of the development, a portion of the park and recreation
area requirement for subdivisions or planned developments may, at the option of the corporate authorities, be provided in the form of "private"
open space or recreational facilities instead of dedicated "public" open space. This shall be determined by the corporate authorities, based upon
the needs of the village residents, the needs of the new residents of the development and total park and recreation land available in the general
area.
Substitution of "private" open space for "public" open space will require that the developer pay for and complete all of the private recreational
facilities. Detailed plans for these private recreational areas, including specifications of facilities to be installed, shall be subject to the review and
approval of the corporate authorities. Before any credit is given for "private" open space, the subdivider or developer must guarantee that the
grounds and facilities of such "private" open space areas will be permanently maintained for such use. Such guarantee, supported by a
performance bond where deemed necessary, shall be in a form satisfactory to the village attorney. If the developer desires to qualify a private
swimming club as "private" open space, then the "suggested criteria for swimming pool development", as adopted by the park district, shall be
used to determine the suitability of the swimming pool for this purpose.
(2) Schools.
(a) Amount Of Land. The amount of land dedication required for a primary school shall be 3.5 acres for each one hundred (100) students estimated
to be added in accordance with the table as set forth in subsection 3.6A of this section and seven (7) acres for each one hundred (100) middle
school students to be added. (If the estimated student increase is less than 100 persons in either category, a cash contribution shall be required
based on a figure of 0.035 acres for each primary school student and 0.07 acres for each middle school student.)
C. Criteria For Requiring A Contribution In Place Of Park And/Or School Sites. Where, in the judgment of the corporate authorities, a development
will add too few persons for a land dedication to be practical, or if the available land is inappropriate for park and/or school purposes, or if land for park
and/or school site purposes has already been obtained, the village shall require the subdivider or developer to make a cash contribution instead of or in
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=886 352/377
combination with land dedication. This contribution shall be used for park and/or school purposes for the direct and material benefit of those persons in
the particular subdivision or development. The cash contribution instead of park and/or school land dedication shall be paid to the village. The village
shall pay over such contribution to the appropriate park or school district only upon proper certification from the district that the funds will be used for
park and/or school purposes for the direct and material benefit of those persons in the particular subdivision or development in reasonable proportions
to the need for park or school facilities or services attributable to the subdivision or development.
D. Determining Fair Market Value For Either School Or Park Cash Contribution Purposes. The cash contribution instead of land shall be based on
the fair market value of undeveloped land in the area that might be appropriate as a park or school site. Fair market value shall be determined by the
certified appraisal of an independent MAI appraiser employed and selected by the village. Such appraisal shall be furnished to the corporate authorities
prior to the final approval of the subdivision plat. The developer shall reimburse the village for all fees and expenses associated with the appraisal.
E. Objections To Formula. A subdivider or developer may file, prior to the submission of a final plat, a written objection to the table of estimated persons
per dwelling unit in this section. In this event, the objection shall include a demographic study showing the developer's estimate of additional population
to be generated from the subdivision or planned development. In the event of an objection, the final determination of the density formula to be used in
such calculations shall be made by the corporate authorities based upon such demographic information submitted by the subdivider or developer and
from other sources collected by the village. It is recognized that population density, age distribution and local conditions change from time to time.
Therefore, the specific formula for the dedication of land or the payment of fees is subject to periodic review.
F. Reservation Of Additional Land. Where the village comprehensive plan, the standards of the village, or standards of the park district or school district
call for a larger amount of park and recreation or school land than the developer is required to dedicate pursuant to this appendix, the land needed
beyond the developer's contribution shall be reserved for subsequent purchase by the appropriate public body, provided that such acquisition is made
within one year from the date of approval of the final subdivision plat or planned development.
G. Topography And Grading. The slope, topography and geology of the dedicated site, must be suitable for the purposes designated by the
governmental unit which will ultimately be responsible for the site. Grading on sites dedicated for park and school uses shall not differ greatly from
surrounding land.
H. Improved Sites. All sites shall be dedicated in a condition ready for full service of electrical, water, sewer, and streets (including enclosed drainage and
curb and gutter) as applicable to the location of the site, unless otherwise approved by the village.
I. Nonresidential Development. In the case of a nonresidential development that involves more than fifty thousand (50,000) square feet of new space
under roof, the corporate authorities may require that a study (to be paid for by the school district and/or park district) be conducted to determine
whether there will be additional land needed for schools or parks that is uniquely and specifically attributable to the development. If such a need is
predicted, the corporate authorities may, in its sole discretion, seek such land or donation on behalf of the school or park district.
J. Indemnification. Under no circumstances shall this section be construed to create a cause of action on behalf of the school or park district or its
constituents against the village or its officials for any failure to require land or donations. Further, the village shall not seek any donation of land or
money from any subdivider or developer pursuant to this appendix, unless it has received from the school district and/or park district a waiver, release,
hold harmless and indemnity agreement that gives complete liability coverage by the affected district to the village as may be satisfactory to the village
attorney.
K. Waiver Of Dedication Or Donation. Instead of indemnifying and holding the village harmless, the school district and/or the park district may in its sole
discretion, request that the village waive the dedication or contributions. (Ord. 00-1040, 8-21-2000)
Footnote 1: See also section 2.12, "Portional Development Of Subdivision", of this division.
Footnote 2: See also section 2.16, "Failure To Complete", of this division.
Footnote 3: See also section 2.16, "Failure To Complete", of this division.
Title Appendix C
SAFETY CODES
Chapter
SAFETY CODES
ARTICLE I. GENERAL AUTHORITY, INTERPRETATION, LIMITATIONS
Sec. C-1: ADOPTION OF MODEL CODES.
The model codes adopted in this appendix C are adopted pursuant to the authority granted by 50 Illinois Compiled Statutes 220/1 et seq.1 In the event that
any provision of any model code is in conflict with any federal, state or county regulation or any other ordinance or regulation of the village of Northfield,
then the provision which establishes the higher standard for the promotion and protection of the safety and welfare of the public shall prevail. Further, no
provision of any code adopted in this appendix C shall be deemed by implication to permit any use or structure in the village which is otherwise prohibited.
(1986 Code; amd. Ord. 98-929, 2-23-1998)

ARTICLE II. FIRE PREVENTION CODE
Sec. C-3: ADOPTION OF THE INTERNATIONAL FIRE CODE.
The international fire code 2009 is hereby adopted by reference as the fire prevention code for the village and is hereby made a part of this article with the
same force and effect as if it was specifically and particularly set forth herein. (Ord. 06-1293, 9-19-2006; amd. Ord. 08-1363, 2-19-2008; Ord. 14-1588, 5-
20-2014)
Sec. C-4: AMENDMENTS.
Section 108 is hereby deleted and in its place shall read the following:
Appeals To The Fire Chief.
Whenever the fire prevention bureau shall deny a permit applied for or shall issue an order requiring any fire prevention measures to be taken, or when it
is claimed that the provisions of the fire prevention code do not apply or that the true intent and meaning of the code have been misconstrued or wrongly
interpreted, the applicant or such person to whom such order has been issued may appeal the decision or order of the fire prevention bureau to the fire
chief within five (5) days. The fire chief shall, within five (5) days, review such order and file his decision thereon with the applicant and the village
manager. Pending decision of the fire chief, the order of the fire prevention bureau shall be stayed unless the fire chief believes there is a distinct fire
hazard to life or the property of others.
Appeals to the Corporate Authorities.
Whenever the fire chief shall deny or revoke or modify an order on appeal, the applicant or such person to whom such order has been issued may appeal
from the decision or order of the fire chief to the corporate authorities within five (5) days.
Within thirty (30) days of the filing of the appeal, the corporate authorities shall meet as a board of appeals to uphold, reverse or modify the decision of the
fire chief. The meeting of this board of appeals shall be public. Pending final decision of the board of appeals, such order of the fire chief shall be stayed
unless in the opinion of the board of appeals there is a distinct fire hazard to life or the property of others. The decision of the board of appeals shall be
final.
Unlawful Continuance.
Any person who shall refuse to obey a summary abatement order, refuse to leave, interfere with the evacuation of other occupants or continue any
operation after having been given an evacuation order, or who shall not comply with a written violation notice within the specified time, or who violates a
condition attached to a permit, approval or certificate, shall be subject to penalties as hereinafter described.
Penalties.
Any person who fails to comply with any of the provisions of this code, or fails to comply with any order issued pursuant to any section thereof, or violates
any condition attached to a permit, approval or certificate, shall be fined not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for
each offense. Each day that a violation continues after a service of notice as provided for in this code shall be deemed a separate offense. The imposition
of one penalty for any violation shall not excuse the violation or permit it to continue, and all such persons shall be required to correct or remedy such
violations or defects.
(1986 Code; amd. Ord. 88-571, 10-18-1988; Ord. 98-929, 2-23-1998; Ord. 06-1293, 9-19-2006)
Section 506 is hereby deleted and in its place shall read the following:
Section 506 Rapid Entry Key Box. The following structures within the village of Northfield shall be equipped with a fire department rapid entry key box of a
design and location approved by the village of Northfield fire official:
(Ord. 98-929, 2-23-1998; amd. Ord. 06-1293, 9-19-2006)
1.All existing buildings equipped with a fire alarm or fire suppression system,
2.Office or commercial buildings for which a certificate of occupancy has been issued after the effective date of this ordinance,
3.Office or commercial buildings where remodeling, the cost of which exceeds $10,000, takes place after the effective date of this ordinance,
4.Any building which the fire official determines, based upon accepted fire safety standards, has a condition where a delay in waiting for a key holder to
arrive may create a hazard to the public, the structure, or its contents.
The key box shall contain the keys necessary to gain entry into the building when the building owner or occupants are not present.
(Ord. 92-705, 12-16-1991)
Section 3404.2.13.1.4 is hereby deleted.
(Ord. 14-1588, 5-20-2014)
Sec. C-5: LOCAL RESTRICTIONS.
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=886 354/377
(1) Expansion Of Facilities For Oil Storage And Flammable Liquids. It shall be unlawful to increase the facilities for storage of oil or other flammable
liquids of any business operating within the fire limits as set forth in the BOCA national fire prevention code unless such facilities are connected with a
business use permitted in the zoning districts in which the business is located.
(2) Dumping Of Refuse. It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to dump any refuse upon any property within the established fire limits.
(Ord. 98-929, 2-23-1998)
(3) Open Burning Prohibited. The open burning of leaves, branches, trunks, trimmings and roots of trees, bushes and shrubs, rubbish, waste, garbage,
paper, carbonaceous materials or any other combustible materials on any public or private property within the village is hereby declared to be unlawful
and is hereby prohibited; provided, however, that this section shall not apply to the following: a) noncommercial cooking of food in outdoor fireplaces or
grills; b) the burning of diseased trees by employees of the village; c) the Northfield fire department for training sessions; d) the industrial fire brigades
under the fire department's supervision; e) the incineration of refuse in a device approved by the air pollution control board of the state of Illinois,
provided there is compliance with all other applicable laws and regulations; f) noncommercial use of outdoor fireplaces such as Weber or Chimenea,
limited to thirty six inches (36") in diameter or smaller in compliance with subsection (17) of this section; and g) prescribed burn for maintenance of
prairie landscape, subject to village and Illinois environmental protection agency permits and all applicable state and federal laws. (Ord. 00-1023, 4-17-
2000; amd. Ord. 05-1233, 3-15-2005; Ord. 14-1588, 5-20-2014)
(4) License Required For Persons Engaging In The Business Of Woodworking And Wood Finishing. An annual license shall be required of any
person engaging in the business of woodworking in which woodworking power machinery is used, or in the business of finishing or refinishing furniture
or other articles. The license shall be granted only after the fire chief has determined that the premises is safe for such operation, and upon payment of
the fee established in appendix D of this code. (1986 Code)
(5) Regulations For New Materials, Processes Or Occupancies. The fire chief and director of public works shall act as a committee to determine and
specify, after giving affected persons an opportunity to be heard, the regulations applicable to any new materials, processes or occupancies, which may
involve fire or other hazards to the public safety in addition to those covered by this article. The fire chief shall post such regulations in a conspicuous
place in his office, and distribute copies thereof to interested persons. (1986 Code; amd. Ord. 98-928, 2-23-1998)
(6) Storage And Display Of Christmas Trees. Christmas trees, other than artificial, stored or displayed for sale shall be outside of buildings and at a
distance of at least ten feet (10') from any building or structure, except that such trees may be stored closer to a blank masonry wall with the
permission of the owner of such wall. No Christmas trees may be stored or displayed within thirty five feet (35') of any flammable liquid. Trees
remaining on hand after December 25 of any year shall be removed from the premises not later than December 31 of the same year.
(7) Ashes. Ashes from the combustion of solid fuel shall be placed in noncombustible containers. No such ashes shall be stored inside of any building. No
ashes shall be placed on any combustible floor nor in any combustible container.
(8) Interference With Fire Department Operations. It shall be unlawful to interfere with, attempt to interfere with, conspire to interfere with, obstruct or
restrict the mobility of, or block the path of travel of any fire department emergency vehicle in any way, or to interfere with, attempt to interfere, conspire
to interfere with, obstruct or hamper any fire department operation.
(9) Blocking Fire Hydrants And Fire Department Connections. It shall be unlawful to obscure from view, damage, obstruct or restrict the access to any
fire hydrant or any fire department connection for the pressurization of fire suppression systems, including fire hydrants and fire department
connections that are located on public or private streets and access lanes, or on private property.
If upon the expiration of a time stated for compliance in a notice of violation, the violation is not remedied, the fire official may proceed to remedy the
same. Any cost incurred in the performance of necessary work shall be paid from the municipal treasury on certification by the fire chief with the
approval of the chief of police; the legal authority of the municipality shall institute appropriate action for the recovery of such costs.
(10) Maintenance Of Fire Suppression Equipment. A person shall not obstruct, remove, tamper with or otherwise disturb any fire hydrant or fire
appliance required to be installed or maintained under the provisions of the fire prevention code except for the purpose of extinguishing fire, training or
testing purposes, recharging, or making necessary repairs, or when permitted by the fire official. Whenever a fire appliance is removed as herein
permitted, it shall be replaced or reinstalled as soon as the purpose for which it was removed has been accomplished. Defective and nonapproved fire
appliances or equipment shall be replaced or repaired as directed by the fire official.
(11) Fire Hydrant Placement. The fire chief may also require the installation of approved yard hydrants when a fire or life hazard occupancy is located
more than one hundred fifty feet (150') from a public street. No public or private fire hydrant may be placed into or removed from service until approved
by the fire chief.
(12) Prohibited Occupancies And Activities. The following occupancies or activities are prohibited within the village:
(a) Storage of unstable (reactive) chemicals such as organic peroxides, nitromethane, and ammonium nitrate.
(b) Storage of magnesium in excess of fifty (50) cubic feet. (1986 Code)
(13) Automatic Sprinkler Systems. Automatic sprinkler systems in accordance with NFPA #13 or an alternate fire protection system providing
comparable protection as approved by the fire chief shall be installed in:
(a) All new construction with the exception of one- and two-family dwellings.
(b) All existing structures, except one- and two-family dwellings: 1) where there is a change to a more intense occupancy or use, or 2) there is
remodeling or reconstruction in excess of fifty percent (50%) of the fair market value of the property prior to the remodeling or reconstruction.
(14) Two Hour Construction/Walls.
(a) All walls of elevator and stair shafts shall be two (2) hour masonry construction.
(b) The fire separation between office/warehouse, office/plant, or other mixed uses shall be two (2) hour masonry or concrete construction.
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=886 355/377
(c) The tenant fire separation walls in multiple tenant retail, covered malls and office occupancies may utilize a two (2) hour rated gypsum wall
assembly with noncombustible materials in lieu of masonry. Such walls shall extend from the floor to the underside of the roof deck.
(d) The party walls of each townhouse or row house unit shall have a two (2) hour masonry vertical fire separation wall continuous at each side of each
unit. (Ord. 98-929, 2-23-1998)
(15) Passenger Elevators. Passenger elevators other than those for one- and two-family dwellings shall be of such size to accommodate an ambulance
cot that is twenty four inches by eighty inches (24" x 80") in the horizontal open position, plus two (2) attendants. (Ord. 14-1588, 5-20-2014)
(16) Standpipe Systems. Standpipe systems shall be required in all buildings of three (3) or more stories in height. (Ord. 08-1363, 2-19-2008)
(17) Outdoor Fires; Outdoor Fireplaces, Grills And Firepits.
(a) Outdoor Fires In General. All outdoor fires, recreational or otherwise, shall be subject to the following requirements:
1. All outdoor fires shall be under continuous competent supervision.
2. No outdoor fire, including, but not limited to, fires in outdoor fireplaces, grills, firepits and similar devices, shall be used in such a manner or
location that it causes any building fire alarm to activate or that it otherwise creates a hazardous or objectionable condition.
(b) Outdoor Fireplaces, Grills And Firepits. All portable outdoor fireplaces, grills, firepits and similar devices and all such devices that are
permanently installed, shall be located and operated at least fifteen feet (15') from any building, fence or property line. Notwithstanding the foregoing,
the operation of a permanent outdoor fireplace, grill, firepit or similar device that was lawfully installed before May 20, 2014, shall be permitted,
provided that such operation complies with section 307.4.2a of the international fire code.
(c) Authority To Extinguish. The code official is authorized to order the extinguishment of any outdoor fire that is not in compliance with this code or
that otherwise creates a hazardous or objectionable condition.
(18) Premises Identification - Rear And Side Access. In addition to the premises identification in section C-30 of this appendix C, all buildings except for
one- and two-family dwellings shall have their address posted on any rear and/or side door. The signage shall include the address, the name of the
street and business name or building name. The sign shall be installed at a height of approximately five feet (5') above the standing surface. The sign
shall be installed immediately to the side of the door so it is visible with the door in the open or closed position. All other installation locations shall be
approved by the fire chief or his designee. (Ord. 14-1588, 5-20-2014)

ARTICLE IV. BUILDING CODE
Sec. C-8: ADOPTION OF THE INTERNATIONAL BUILDING CODE AND THE INTERNATIONAL RESIDENTIAL CODE.
(1) Residential Construction. The international residential code 2006 is hereby adopted by reference as the building code applicable to all residential
construction for the village and is hereby made a part of this article with the same force and effect as if it was specifically and particularly set forth
herein and as now or hereafter amended. If there is a discrepancy between the Council Of American Building Officials, the Illinois plumbing code,
international mechanical code and national electrical code, the specific trade code shall apply.
(2) Commercial And Nonresidential Construction. The international building code 2006 is hereby adopted by reference as the building code applicable
to all commercial and nonresidential construction for the village and is hereby made a part of this article with the same force and effect as if it was
specifically and particularly set forth herein and as now or hereafter amended. If there is a discrepancy between the Council Of American Building
Officials, the Illinois plumbing code, international mechanical code and national electrical code, the specific trade code shall apply. (Ord. 01-1074, 8-20-
2001; amd. Ord. 08-1363, 2-19-2008)
Sec. C-8.1: PERMITS; TIME LIMITATIONS.
(1) All permits issued shall require that construction begin within six (6) months of the date on which the permit is issued, and be completed within
eighteen (18) months after the date on which the permit is issued, or such other time as the corporate authorities may have established by ordinance
for a particular project. (1986 Code; amd. Ord. 88-562, 8-23-1988)
(2) A onetime extension of the time limits set forth in subsection (1) of this section may be granted by the Northfield building commissioner for good
cause shown and upon such conditions as the building commissioner may specify. "Good cause" shall require a showing that construction has
proceeded in the normal course without undue lapses but nevertheless has not been completed prior to expiration of the permit or that the permittee
has been prevented from completing construction in a timely fashion for reasons beyond their control, including, but not limited to, adverse weather
12/18/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=886 356/377
conditions, fire, flood, windstorms, strikes, or scarcity of building materials. Any denial of a request for an extension must be made in writing and
delivered in person or by certified mail to the applicant. Any appeal of a denial of an extension by the building commissioner and any request for a
further extension after one extension has been granted by the building commissioner must be made to the zoning board of appeals (ZBA) of the
village by serving written notice of such an appeal or request on the village manager within five (5) days of the denial of the extension or the
expiration of the permit or prior extension. The ZBA shall apply the criteria set forth above in determining whether a building permit extension should
be granted and the decision of the ZBA shall be final. (Ord. 03-1162, 5-20-2003)
Sec. C-8.2: FEES.
Fees for permits - time limitations shall be as set forth in appendix D of this code. (Ord. 03-1162, 5-20-2003)
Sec. C-8.3: CONSTRUCTION SIGNAGE.
A sign eighteen inches by twenty four inches (18" x 24") must be placed in the front yard of all properties undertaking any demolition, alteration or repair,
requiring a permit, of any structure within the village. The sign shall state: "No construction related activity except between the hours of 7:00 A.M. _ 7:00
P.M. Monday _ Friday, 9:00 A.M. _ 5:00 P.M. Saturday, and 12:00 P.M. _ 5:00 P.M. Sundays and national holidays". This sign must remain prominently
posted on site throughout the construction activity period. Signs may be purchased from the village in accordance with the fees set forth in appendix D of
this code. A paper sign may be posted for projects with a duration of ten (10) days or less, metal signs must be posted for all other projects. (Ord. 04-1214,
8-17-2004)
Sec. C-9: AMENDMENTS.
The international building code hereinabove referred to is hereby amended as follows: (Ord. 98-929, 2-23-1998; amd. Ord. 08-1363, 2-19-2008)
Section 102.2 Existing Structures.
Section 102.2 is hereby deleted and replaced with the following:
Except as provided in this section, existing buildings, when altered or repaired as herein specified, shall conform to the full requirements of the building
code for new buildings.
102.2.1 Alterations Exceeding 50 Percent: If alterations or repairs are made within any period of twelve (12) months, costing in excess of fifty percent
(50%) of the physical value of the building; or
102.2.2 Damages Exceeding 50 Percent: If the building is damaged by fire or any other cause to an extent in excess of fifty percent (50%) of the physical
value of the building before the damage was incurred.
102.2.3 Alterations Under 50 Percent: If the cost of alterations or repairs described herein is between twenty five percent (25%) and fifty percent (50%) of
the physical value of the building, the building official shall determine to what degree the portions so altered or repaired shall be made to conform to the
requirements for new buildings.
102.2.4 Alterations Under 25 Percent: If the cost of alterations or repairs described herein is twenty five percent (25%) or less of the physical value of the
building, the building official shall permit the restoration of the building to its condition previous to damage or deterioration with the same kind of materials
as those of which the building was constructed; provided, that such construction does not endanger the general safety and public welfare and complies
with the provisions of section 928.1 with respect to existing roofs.
102.2.5 Increase In Size: If the building is increased in floor area or number of stories, the entire building shall be made to conform with the requirements
of the building code in respect to means of egress, fire safety, and light ventilation.
102.2.6 Part Change In Use: If a portion of the building is changed in occupancy or to a new use, that portion is separated from the remainder of the
building with the required vertical and horizontal fire divisions complying with the fire grading in table 16, then the construction involved in the change shall
be made to conform to the requirements for the new use and occupancy and the existing portion shall be made to comply with the exit way requirements
of the building code.
102.2.7 Physical Value: In applying the provisions of this section, the physical value of the building shall be determined by the building official and be
based on current replacement costs.
(Ord. 98-929, 2-23-1998)
102.2.8 Wood Roof Shingles: Wood roof shingles shall not be used under any circumstances unless proof is provided that said shingles have been treated
for fire resistance.
(Ord. 01-1074, 8-20-2001)
102.2.9. In addition to international one and two family dwelling code 1998, section 502.10 draft stopping required.
(Ord. 01-1054, 2-20-2001)
Engineered Wood Products. Where engineered wood products such as trusses and joists, etc. are used for floor and ceiling assemblies in finished or
unfinished spaces or areas in one or two family dwellings, these assemblies shall be separated from adjacent spaces or areas by fire-resistant material
equal to 5/8 inch type X gypsum board or better. Such separation shall not be required for areas fully equipped with an automatic sprinkler system
designed and installed in accordance with N.F.P.A. 13 or areas where the floor to ceiling dimension is less than thirty-six inches (36").

the necessity for said permit shall be fined not less than five hundred dollars ($500.00) per day for each day the work is in progress without a permit. A like
penalty of five hundred dollars ($500.00) per day shall be assessed against any person who contracts to work in violation of a stop work order.

and the zoning ordinance shall take precedence.
